Text: rangements of liquefied petroleum gas, and

Text: general, and by the traditional users in New South

Text: Wales, the local government gas industry, in par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticular, of a policy designed to promote greater

Text: Notice of Motion

Speaker: Mr SHIPTON
Text: Higgins)-l give notice that,

Speaker: NA
Text: on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House-

Speaker: NA
Text: (I) notes that-

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) the Government's new air fares for inbound

Speaker: NA
Text: travellers from Japan have had the effect of

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing the price of most package deal hol-

Speaker: NA
Text: idays to Australia from Japan;

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: about the increases; and

Text: gain Japanese travellers and tourist trade at

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's expense; and

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: mediately by providing a cheap, effective and com-

Speaker: NA
Text: petitive inbound tourist fare to encourage

Speaker: NA
Text: Japanese tourists to visit Australia.

Text: OLYMPIC GAMES

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Asian Games and the 1988 Olympic Games in

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Text: ments of the Republic of Korea and the Demo-

Speaker: NA

Text: in this way to ease the tension between themselves;

Text: and

Text: storing to the Olympic Games some of the ideals of

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: ARMY RESERVE

Speaker: NA
Text: Motion of Motion

Speaker: Mr NEWMAN
Text: Bass)-I give notice that, on

Speaker: NA
Text: the next day of sitting, I shall move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House-

Speaker: NA
Text: (I) notes that, despite a public commitment to main-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain a strong Army Reserve, Government policy

Speaker: NA
Text: implemented over the 12 month period to April

Speaker: NA
Text: 1984 will lead to a run-down, second-rate Reserve

Speaker: NA
Text: Force;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) notes that the detrimental Government policies

Speaker: NA
Text: include-

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) wholesale reductions in training time;

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) attacks on conditions of service;

Speaker: NA
Text: AIR FARES (c) prohibitions on voluntary, unpaid para-es;

Speaker: NA
Text: (d) reductions in allocations of petrol, rations

Speaker: NA
Text: and ammunition which are essential for

Speaker: NA
Text: efficient training, and

Speaker: NA
Text: (e) incapacity to define what the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: wants the Reserve to do, and

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) urges the Government to reverse its destructive

Speaker: NA
Text: policies and put in place a program to encourage

Speaker: NA
Text: and support a strong and vigorous Army Reserve.

Text: FOREIGN WARSHIPS

Speaker: NA
Text: Notice of Motion

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Text: Mitchell)-I give notice that,

Speaker: NA
Text: on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House-

Speaker: NA
Text: (I) requests the Minister for Defence to-

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) clarify the Government's unintelligible policy

Speaker: NA
Text: on foreign war

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) apologise to Australia's allies for creating un-

Speaker: NA
Text: certainty and waning confidence in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's capacity as a nation, and

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Chief of Defence Force Staff before making

Speaker: NA
Text: incoherent pronouncements, and

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) demands that the policy give priority to principles

Speaker: NA
Text: which relate to Australia's allies rather than to the

Speaker: NA
Text: phobia of the LeFt Wing of the Australian Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: and

Speaker: NA
Text: completion of the proposed international covenant

Speaker: NA
Text: against torture.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: wish it, we would be prepared to facilitate debate

Text: on that notice of motion now.

Speaker: NA
Text: MEDICARE: BULK BILLING

Speaker: NA
Text: Notice of Motion

Speaker: Mr WELLS
Text: Petrie)-I give notice that, on

Speaker: NA
Text: the next day of sitting, I shall move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House-

Speaker: NA
Text: (I) notes that-

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) the rate of bulk billing in Queensland has now

Speaker: NA
Text: Notice of Motion risen to 49 per cent, close to the highest level

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia; and

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: engaged in any of the irresponsible industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: action which has blighted certain other States;

Speaker: NA
Text: and

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) congratulates the rank and file of the medical pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: fession in that State on its responsible approach to

Speaker: NA
Text: the introduction of Medicare, its concern for

Speaker: NA
Text: patients, and its commitment to the spirit of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Hippocratic Oath.

Speaker: NA
Text: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

Speaker: NA
Text: HONOURABLE MEMBER FOR

Speaker: NA
Text: MELBOURNE: LETTER

Speaker: Mr MACKELLAR
Text: I refer the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Foreign Affairs to a newspaper report last week

Speaker: NA
Text: concerning a letter said to have been sent by a

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Leading Victorian Left-winger, Mr Gerry Hand'

Speaker: NA
Text: to all his Caucus colleagues. I quote from the

Speaker: NA
Text: newspaper report of that letter which states:

Speaker: NA
Text: 'The US . . . is practising its normal policy of

Speaker: NA
Text: isolating and undermining a country whose policies

Speaker: NA
Text: attitudes it finds unacceptable. The ASEAN nations

Speaker: NA
Text: supporting their own reactionary positions which keep

Speaker: NA
Text: workers in oppression, poverty and fear.'

Speaker: NA
Text: Will the Foreign Minister now publicly dissociate

Speaker: NA
Text: himself and his Government from those

Speaker: NA
Text: sentiments?

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Text: My administration does not

Speaker: NA
Text: include the administration of the affairs or behav-

Speaker: NA
Text: iour of the honourable member for Gerry Hand,

Speaker: NA
Text: for want of a better description. I might say I am

Speaker: NA
Text: somewhat grateful about that. Nor do therespon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sibilities of the honourable member for Warrin-

Speaker: NA
Text: gah, as Opposition spokesman for foreign affairs,

Speaker: NA
Text: include responsibility for the behaviour of the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Denison. The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Warringah is even more pleased

Speaker: NA
Text: about that. The great attributes that the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Denison brings to bear in this

Speaker: NA
Text: House are a mouth in perpetual motion and a

Speaker: NA
Text: mind with a permanent vacancy sign outside. I

Speaker: NA
Text: suggest to the honourable member for Warringah

Speaker: NA
Text: that if he wants further details on the intent, pur-

Speaker: NA
Text: pose or inclinations of my good friend and

Speaker: NA
Text: colleague-what is his seat?

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Text: Melbourne.

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Text: Really, I am preoccupied in

Speaker: NA
Text: running the affairs of the world and I cannot keep

Speaker: NA
Text: up with these mundane matters. I suggest the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Warringah discuss it with

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Melbourne.

Speaker: Mr HOLLIS
Text: Is the Minister for Foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs aware of reports that violence has once

Speaker: NA
Text: more erupted in Sri Lanka and that in the last

Speaker: NA
Text: week of March a number of people were killed

Speaker: NA
Text: outside Jaffna? What is the Government's atti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tude towards the continuing violence in Sri Lanka

Speaker: NA
Text: and towards the overall human rights situation in

Speaker: NA
Text: that country?

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Text: The Government is concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: about reports of continuing inter-communal viol-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence in Sri Lanka. On 20 March two air force per-

Speaker: NA
Text: sonnel were killed by terrorists. On 25 March

Speaker: NA
Text: three unarmed policemen were shot dead by ter-

Speaker: NA
Text: rorists. On 27 March another policeman was

Speaker: NA
Text: killed by terrorists. On 28 March, in Jaffna, at

Speaker: NA
Text: least seven people-terrorists and bystanders-

Speaker: NA
Text: were killed when a gunfight occurred between air

Speaker: NA
Text: force personnel and terrorists. The Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Government and, I believe, the Australian Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment condemn the use of violence to further the

Speaker: NA
Text: political aims of any group in Sri Lanka or else-

Speaker: NA
Text: where. At least some of the recent terrorist activi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties seem designed to provoke reprisals and a new

Speaker: NA
Text: and round of anti-Tamil violence. I accordingly call on

Speaker: NA
Text: are all groups in Sri Lanka to eschew violence and to

Speaker: NA
Text: work together through the All Party Conference

Speaker: NA
Text: which is discussing communal problems in a

Speaker: NA
Text: search for a lasting solution to Sri Lanka's

Speaker: NA
Text: communal differences.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government's concern about these matters

Speaker: NA
Text: has been conveyed to the Government of Sri

Speaker: NA
Text: Lanka on a number of occasions. Last year when

Speaker: NA
Text: the Sri Lankan Deputy Foreign Minister visited

Speaker: NA
Text: here I conveyed to him personally that deep feel-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing of concern.

Speaker: NA
Text: URANIUM MINING

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.

Speaker: NA
Text: In view of his return to Cabinet can the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: say whether he fully supports the Government de-

Speaker: NA
Text: cision to allow mining at the Roxby Downs

Speaker: NA
Text: uranium project in South Australia? Is it the Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister's intention to participate fully in all Cabinet

Speaker: NA
Text: discussions concerning the uranium industry?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order! I remind the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition that questions to a Minister must

Speaker: NA
Text: deal with those matters that are within his admin-

Speaker: NA
Text: istrative responsibility.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Cabinet will he, in the execution of his

Speaker: NA
Text: duties as Minister for Immigration and Ethnic

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs in sitting in the Cabinet, fully endorse all

Speaker: NA
Text: decisions of that Cabinet?

Speaker: Mr WEST
Text: The answer, of course, to the

Speaker: NA
Text: SRI LANKA honourable member's question is yes. In answer-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing his question I take the opportunity to place on

Speaker: NA
Text: the record my appreciation of the actions of my

Speaker: NA
Text: Caucus .colleagues, the Cabinet and the leader-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship. I think that the very nature of the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member's question implies that it is import-

Speaker: NA
Text: ant that the portfolio of Immigration and Ethnic

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs be represented within the Cabinet. I also

Speaker: NA
Text: add that I consider that it is important that the

Speaker: NA
Text: representation of our Party within the Cabinet be

Speaker: NA
Text: as wide as possible.

Speaker: NA
Text: DEPARTMENT OF ABORIGINAL

Speaker: NA
Text: AFFAIRS: DEPARTMENTAL HEAD

Speaker: Mr BLANCHARD
Text: My question is addressed

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. In view of

Speaker: NA
Text: the recent comments made by the shadow Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter for Aboriginal Affairs concerning the appoint-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of Mr Charles Perkins as the departmental

Speaker: NA
Text: head of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, can

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister inform the House of the response to

Speaker: NA
Text: that appointment by Aboriginal community

Speaker: NA
Text: leaders?

Speaker: Mr HOLDING
Text: Aboriginal organisations-I

Speaker: NA
Text: include the Federation of Land Councils and the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Aboriginal Conference-gave very

Speaker: NA
Text: strong support to this appointment. It has also

Speaker: NA
Text: been a matter of favourable editorial comment in

Speaker: NA
Text: journals such as the Courier-Mail in Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Northern Territory Times, which is good.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would also like to place on record my thanks to

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Peter Baume, the previous Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Peter Rae, Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: Macklin, Senator Kilgariff and Senator Chaney,

Speaker: NA
Text: also a former Minister for Aboriginal Affairs,

Speaker: NA
Text: who, I think, spoke in the Senate with both genu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ineness and generosity in respect of this appoint-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment and who, I think, showed a generosity of

Speaker: NA
Text: spirit appropriate to the occasion. My only regret

Speaker: NA
Text: is that the same generosity of spirit did not prevail

Speaker: NA
Text: in this House.

Speaker: NA
Text: COCOS (KEELING) ISLANDS

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: tories and Local Government explain why, at this

Speaker: NA
Text: time of alleged government financial stringency,

Speaker: NA
Text: up to 48 officials are now on their way to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Cocos (Keeling) Islands for the Islands' act of

Speaker: NA
Text: self-determination under United Nations super-

Speaker: NA
Text: vision? That is, as I understand it, approximately

Speaker: NA
Text: one official for every six of the Islands'

Speaker: NA
Text: inhabitants.

Speaker: Mr UREN
Text: I cannot verify the number but a

Speaker: NA
Text: Boeing 707 aircraft is going there. It will have on

Speaker: NA
Text: board a United Nations mission and a United

Speaker: NA
Text: Nations secretariat as well as members of the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian bureaucracy and nine Press people. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Cocos (Keeling) Islands decision is an important

Speaker: NA
Text: historical decision, not only for the indigenous

Speaker: NA
Text: people of Cocos but also for the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: people. It is strange that it took so long for a

Speaker: NA
Text: government to get the agreement of the Cocos

Speaker: NA
Text: Malay people to give effect to that decision of

Speaker: NA
Text: self-determination.

Speaker: NA
Text: The record of the former Government, for in-

Speaker: NA
Text: stance, in allowing Clunies-Ross to dominate the

Speaker: NA
Text: economy and the peopie of the Cocos Islands for

Speaker: NA
Text: so long is an utter disgrace. It was only in later

Speaker: NA
Text: years that the former Minister for Home Affairs

Speaker: NA
Text: bit the bullet-I give him credit for that-and was

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared to recommend to the Government that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Clunies-Ross land be purchased. But the Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister could not get the support of the Cabinet of

Speaker: NA
Text: the day. It was only when our Government took

Speaker: NA
Text: over the administration that we got the agreement

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Cocos Malay people to make a decision on

Speaker: NA
Text: self-determination. It was only then that we were

Speaker: NA
Text: able to get this decision from the Cocos people. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think that all my colleagues believe that this is an

Speaker: NA
Text: historic decision. There is always a tendency for

Speaker: NA
Text: bureaucracies to take over.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Ruddock-Yes, Minister.

Speaker: Mr UREN
Text: I know there are some jackals.

Speaker: NA
Text: The shadow Minister for Territories and Local

Speaker: NA
Text: Government said: 'Yes, Minister'. The facts are

Speaker: NA
Text: that I have been a Minister on two occasions and I

Speaker: NA
Text: have been able at least to control my

Speaker: NA
Text: administration.

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members-Ha, hal

Speaker: Mr UREN
Text: Honourable members opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: can laugh their heads off if they like. I know that

Speaker: NA
Text: some people consider this a joke, but the sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: retariat and the delegation of the United Nations

Speaker: NA
Text: Visiting Mission had to go to the Cocos (Keeling)

Speaker: NA
Text: Islands and any aircraft other than a Boeing 707

Speaker: NA
Text: would be inadequate because on the return trip

Speaker: NA
Text: several members of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands

Speaker: NA
Text: Council will return with the United Nations

Speaker: NA
Text: Mission. I would agree that where there are

Speaker: NA
Text: vacant seats it is logical that some bureaucrats go

Speaker: NA
Text: in those places. I support the decision that was

Speaker: NA
Text: made. That the Press was under-represented was

Speaker: NA
Text: a fair criticism on the part of the Press and there-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore the Press delegation was lifted from six to

Speaker: NA
Text: nine. I fully support that decision. But I am saying

Speaker: NA
Text: quite clearly that a 707 aircraft was necessary,

Speaker: NA
Text: that other aircraft were not adequate and that

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands Council

Speaker: NA
Text: will return on that plane with the United Nations

Speaker: NA
Text: Mission. I believe this is an important decision.

Speaker: NA
Text: BROADCASTING: LOCALISM POLICY

Speaker: Mr CUNNINGHAM
Text: Can the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Communications provide the House with details

Speaker: NA
Text: of the review of the localism policy in Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: broadcasting?

Speaker: Mr DUFFY
Text: I thank the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for his question. The policy of localism was de-

Speaker: NA
Text: signed to encourage development of local pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gramming, local ownership or control of local

Speaker: NA
Text: stations, and local advertising. But the concept of

Speaker: NA
Text: localism has not been formally reviewed at any

Speaker: NA
Text: stage of its development. Having regard to the de-

Speaker: NA
Text: cisions which have been taken on broadcasting,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly decisions related to Aussat Pty Ltd

Speaker: NA
Text: and the satellite, it was decided that there should

Speaker: NA
Text: be a review of the concept of localism. On 23

Speaker: NA
Text: December last year I announced that the Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment would conduct a review of the policy of

Speaker: NA
Text: localism in Australian radio and television.

Speaker: NA
Text: The review is examining the extent to which

Speaker: NA
Text: localism should be maintained, and in what form,

Speaker: NA
Text: in the continuing development of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: broadcasting system. While localism is of most sig-

Speaker: NA
Text: nificance to commercial stations, the review is

Speaker: NA
Text: also examining' its relevance in respect of other

Speaker: NA
Text: broadcasters such as public radio stations. The

Speaker: NA
Text: view has been undertaken by Mr James Oswin,

Speaker: NA
Text: who is a senior officer in the Department of Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munications, and is expected to be completed by

Speaker: NA
Text: the middle of this year.

Speaker: NA
Text: PRIME MINISTER: VISIT TO ASIA

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Text: Will the Prime Minister make a

Speaker: NA
Text: detailed statement to the Parliament this week on

Speaker: NA
Text: any achievements he believes he may have made

Speaker: NA
Text: during his Asian trip? In such a statement will he

Speaker: NA
Text: advise Parliament what action, if any, has been

Speaker: NA
Text: taken to implement the sound principles of his

Speaker: NA
Text: Osaka statement on industry restructuring? Will

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister explain why Mr Nakasone

Speaker: NA
Text: appears to have broken undertakings given to him

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Australian beef industry would not be

Speaker: NA
Text: disadvantaged by the United States-Japan trade

Speaker: NA
Text: negotiations? Will he outline what progress has

Speaker: NA
Text: been made to implement his integrated steel deal

Speaker: NA
Text: with China and provide the details of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia-China steel plan?

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Text: I cannot make a promise about

Speaker: NA
Text: making a statement to the Parliament later this

Speaker: NA
Text: week, although I will give consideration to it. The

Speaker: NA
Text: achievements of the visit, as has been universally

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledged in the Press, were considerable. I

Speaker: NA
Text: will certainly give consideration to discussing with

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the House whether, in our very busy

Speaker: NA
Text: schedule, there is time to include such an import-

Speaker: NA
Text: ant statement. In the meantime, I can give some

Speaker: NA
Text: brief references to some of the particular matters

Speaker: NA
Text: raised in the question asked by the Deputy Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the National Party of Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: In respect of industry restructuring, I can in-

Speaker: NA
Text: form the Deputy Leader of the National Party

Speaker: NA
Text: that at my suggestion the Cabinet has established

Speaker: NA
Text: a Cabinet sub-committee under the chairmanship

Speaker: NA
Text: of Senator Button, the Minister for Industry and

Speaker: NA
Text: Commerce. That sub-committee will consist of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Ministers having responsibility for the port-

Speaker: NA
Text: folios of Trade, Education and Youth Affairs,

Speaker: NA
Text: Employment and Industrial Relations, and De-

Speaker: NA
Text: fence Support, to consider together--

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Barry Jones-Science and Technology.

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Text: I knew that I had overlooked

Speaker: NA
Text: one, but that it would come to me. If I were to

Speaker: NA
Text: overlook one, there is no doubt who would remind

Speaker: NA
Text: me of it, and that is the Minister for Science and

Speaker: NA
Text: Technology. I assure the Minister that no slight

Speaker: NA
Text: was intended.

Speaker: Mr HODGMAN
Text: This is a hatchet gang.

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Text: No, not a hatchet gang. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: a collection of Ministers who have relevant port-

Speaker: NA
Text: folio responsibility, to address themselves to that

Speaker: NA
Text: re- wide range of interrelated considerations necess-

Speaker: NA
Text: ary for this country to bring about the restructur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing of industry, which will lead to significant econ-

Speaker: NA
Text: omic growth and the type of economy which will

Speaker: NA
Text: give the greatest opportunity for employment in

Speaker: NA
Text: the years to come. That has been done, and this

Speaker: NA
Text: approach of the Government in regard to industry

Speaker: NA
Text: restructuring has received the unanimous support

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Economic Planning Advisory Council and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Council of Trade Unions.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Deputy Leader of the National Party

Speaker: NA
Text: asked also about what progress had been made in

Speaker: NA
Text: regard to the integrated steel developments in

Speaker: NA
Text: China and Australia. Very considerable advances

Speaker: NA
Text: have been made in that regard. An Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: working party will go to China in the near future.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister for Metallurgical Industry in China,

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Li, will visit Australia in May.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Newman- Mr Speaker, I take a point of

Speaker: NA
Text: order. The Prime Minister has been going for five

Speaker: NA
Text: minutes. Would you ask him to say something?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order! There is no point of

Speaker: NA
Text: order.

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Text: It is scintillating, is it not? It is

Speaker: NA
Text: devastating. The other particular matter addres-

Speaker: NA
Text: sed by the Deputy Leader of the National Party

Speaker: NA
Text: was the question of exports of beef to Japan. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: surprised at this coming from that source. I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: think that the question of relations between

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia and Japan in general and of our trading

Speaker: NA
Text: relationship in particular is assisted by a respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sible member of this Parliament making accu-

Speaker: NA
Text: sations against the Prime Minister of Japan. It

Speaker: NA
Text: may be that those on that side of the House be-

Speaker: NA
Text: lieve that negotiations between our two countries

Speaker: NA
Text: on an important issue like this are assisted by ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: cusations of that kind being made in this place. If

Speaker: NA
Text: that is the sort of approach that the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: wishes to follow and it receives the endorsement

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Leader of the Opposition, so be it. It will

Speaker: NA
Text: not be the approach of this Government. What

Speaker: NA
Text: we are constructively doing is holding discussions

Speaker: NA
Text: at the level of the Ambassador of Japan in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country and at the official level and all those dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: cussions are directed to trying to ensure that the

Speaker: NA
Text: beef producers of this country get the best poss-

Speaker: NA
Text: ible deal that can be achieved. That will not be

Speaker: NA
Text: helped by accusations made in this Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: against the Prime Minister of Japan.

Speaker: NA
Text: CANBERRA AND THE AUSTRALIAN

Speaker: NA
Text: CAPITAL TERRITORY: HOUSING

Speaker: Mr FRY
Text: Is the Minister for Territories and

Speaker: NA
Text: Local Government aware that the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: spokesperson on the Australian Capital Territory

Speaker: NA
Text: has stated that the Minister is responsible for

Speaker: NA
Text: ating the severe housing crisis in Canberra?

Speaker: Mr UREN
Text: I heard the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: on an Australian Broadcasting Corporation

Speaker: NA
Text: program this morning, and I might say that his

Speaker: NA
Text: torted views of the housing situation in Canberra

Speaker: NA
Text: are very sad. First of all, we inherited a very

Speaker: NA
Text: serious social problem here in Canberra. The pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: vious Government, between 1976 and the time

Speaker: NA
Text: when we took over the administration, failed to

Speaker: NA
Text: develop any serviced land, failed to develop any

Speaker: NA
Text: public housing and failed to construct any office

Speaker: NA
Text: accommodation. When the Labor Government

Speaker: NA
Text: was struck down in 1975 those opposite inherited

Speaker: NA
Text: 7,500 serviced blocks of land as a land bank in

Speaker: NA
Text: Canberra. Because Labor in the preceding three

Speaker: NA
Text: years had developed over 3,000 public dwellings,

Speaker: NA
Text: 18 per cent of all housing in Canberra at that time

Speaker: NA
Text: was public housing. The figure now is only 13 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent. We inherited only a few hundred serviced

Speaker: NA
Text: blocks of land in Canberra. What we have had to

Speaker: NA
Text: do is stimulate the supply of serviced housing land

Speaker: NA
Text: by 3,000 blocks-500 blocks in the first year-and

Speaker: NA
Text: to develop the construction industry to get the

Speaker: NA
Text: building of office accommodation under way, be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause all those things are interrelated. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: aware in respect of office accommodation, par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticularly in the case of Havelock House, that de-

Speaker: NA
Text: partments are taking over areas in which low cost

Speaker: NA
Text: housing is normally involved. This is the serious

Speaker: NA
Text: social problem we inherited but we have set down

Speaker: NA
Text: priorities for land servicing, for public housing

Speaker: NA
Text: and for office accommodation to help to rebuild

Speaker: NA
Text: not only the Australian economy but also and par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticularly the Canberra economy. Because of the

Speaker: NA
Text: policies that this Government has carried out the

Speaker: NA
Text: Canberra economy is coming out of the economic

Speaker: NA
Text: decline faster than any other region in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: CABINET DOCUMENTS

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: I refet the Prime Minister to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Cabinet meeting his Government held in

Speaker: NA
Text: Perth on 27 September at which decisions were

Speaker: NA
Text: made on the now leaked defence document and

Speaker: NA
Text: which also coincided with the victory of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: II in the America's Cup. I also remind the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister of his leaving his hotel room in the early

Speaker: NA
Text: hours of that morning to join the televised cham-

Speaker: NA
Text: pagne celebrations at the Royal Perth Yacht

Speaker: NA
Text: Club. In the interests of national security, I ask:

Speaker: NA
Text: Was the Prime Minister as careless on that

Speaker: NA
Text: occasion with the sensitive documents in his care

Speaker: NA
Text: as he was on a previous occasion at the Boulevard

Speaker: NA
Text: Hotel in Sydney when he reportedly had stolen

Speaker: NA
Text: from his room a sum of $4,000 in mixed Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian and international currencies?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order! I think that question is

Speaker: NA
Text: crescarcely within the Prime Minister's administra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. Does the Prime Minister wish to respond?

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Text: I assume that that question has

Speaker: NA
Text: the endorsement of the Leader of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: dis- and of the Opposition. The country will, there-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore, make its judgment, not merely about the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for O'Connor but about the

Speaker: NA
Text: whole of the Opposition unless he is disowned.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: Tell us the answer.

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Text: The answer is that I was care-

Speaker: NA
Text: less on neither occasion.

Speaker: NA
Text: UNIVERSITY ENTRANCE

Speaker: NA
Text: EXAMINATIONS

Speaker: Mr MILTON
Text: Is the Minister representing

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs

Speaker: NA
Text: aware of the report in yesterday's Melbourne Age

Speaker: NA
Text: that Melbourne University may ask the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Council for Educational Research to pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: pare entrance examinations that could be used in

Speaker: NA
Text: the selection of prospective students? Is the Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister also aware that the discussion in Melbourne

Speaker: NA
Text: University on new selection procedures is causing

Speaker: NA
Text: widespread concern amongst both academics and

Speaker: NA
Text: the public? Will the Minister explain how the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: troduction of new university entrance examin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ations might affect the Government's policy of en-

Speaker: NA
Text: couraging more young Australians to gain tertiary

Speaker: NA
Text: education qualifications?

Speaker: Mr DAWKINS
Text: I thank the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for his question. I note that before his

Speaker: NA
Text: election to this House he was involved in the

Speaker: NA
Text: administration of the University of Melbourne,

Speaker: NA
Text: including the administration of enrolment poli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cies. There has been some discussion at the uni-

Speaker: NA
Text: versity concerning entrance tests. I think that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: rather 'too early to draw any conclusions about the

Speaker: NA
Text: sorts of decisions that the University of Mel-

Speaker: NA
Text: bourne might make. In fact, some people at the

Speaker: NA
Text: University of Melbourne have complained that

Speaker: NA
Text: the publicity surrounding these discussions and in-

Speaker: NA
Text: vestigations has rather misrepresented their pos-

Speaker: NA
Text: ition. But basically the university seems to be con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned that the higher school certificate is no

Speaker: NA
Text: longer a sufficiently precise device in order to

Speaker: NA
Text: make an appropriate selection of students for the

Speaker: NA
Text: University of Melbourne, whereas, on the other

Speaker: NA
Text: hand, others involved in the debate are arguing

Speaker: NA
Text: that there needs to be a standardised process of

Speaker: NA
Text: selection for all tertiary institutions in Victoria.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think that the Australian Council for Edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cational Research has been invited to undertake

Speaker: NA
Text: some studies, and I note that David Beswick has

Speaker: NA
Text: also been doing some work in this area. It is obvi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ouslya very sensitive matter, because one does not

Speaker: NA
Text: want to see a process whereby some students are

Speaker: NA
Text: excluded from access to some particular universi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties or colleges of advanced education. But, just

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member mentioned in his ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, the overriding concern that we would have is

Speaker: NA
Text: with the way in which it might affect overall

Speaker: NA
Text: access to tertiary education. Of course, we would

Speaker: NA
Text: not be wanting to interfere, as a government, in

Speaker: NA
Text: the decisions that the universities make in terms

Speaker: NA
Text: their selection practices; but I think that we

Speaker: NA
Text: want to direct the attention of all universities

Speaker: NA
Text: CAEs throughout the country to the very import-

Speaker: NA
Text: ant preoccupation that they ought to have with

Speaker: NA
Text: ensuring that they get as many people as possible

Speaker: NA
Text: who are qualified for entrance and who are apply-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing for entrance actually into those tertiary insti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tutions. We have seen the number who have been

Speaker: NA
Text: unable to find places this year, and we need to

Speaker: NA
Text: have a concerted effort to ensure that as few as

Speaker: NA
Text: possible of those qualified for entrance and who

Speaker: NA
Text: apply for entrance next year are turned away.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is where we would want to be directing the

Speaker: NA
Text: attention of universities and CAEs around the

Speaker: NA
Text: country.

Speaker: NA
Text: MEAT IMPORTS FROM NEW ZEALAND

Speaker: Mr HICKS
Text: I direct a question to the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Primary Industry. Is the Government aware

Speaker: NA
Text: that imports of substantially subsidised lamb and

Speaker: NA
Text: sheep meat from New Zealand have quadrupled

Speaker: NA
Text: since last year and that subsidised New Zealand

Speaker: NA
Text: lamb was offered to Australian consumers at

Speaker: NA
Text: prices as low as 42c per kilogram? Is the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: aware that Australian domestic mutton prices

Speaker: NA
Text: have fallen 13 per cent in the past four to six

Speaker: NA
Text: weeks? In view of the New Zealand Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's high level of government support to its

Speaker: NA
Text: sheep meat industry, will the Government give

Speaker: NA
Text: urgent consideration to any request by the indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try to impose countervailing duties under the

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of the closer economic relations agreement

Speaker: NA
Text: in order to protect the Australian sheep meat in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry from a rapidly increasing flow of subsidised

Speaker: NA
Text: New Zealand lamb and sheep meat to our

Speaker: NA
Text: market?

Speaker: Mr KERIN
Text: The honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Hotham raised this question first in the House in

Speaker: NA
Text: the adjournment debate the other night. Of course

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government is aware of the concerns held by

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian producers that possible increases in

Speaker: NA
Text: imports of New Zealand sheep meat may be caus-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing or are threatening to cause injury to the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian industry. Sheep meat imports in January

Speaker: NA
Text: and February this year have been at values lower

Speaker: NA
Text: than those which applied last year. I am sympath-

Speaker: NA
Text: etic to the concerns of our industry to the extent

Speaker: NA
Text: that these imports may have resulted from sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: as sidies paid to the New Zealand industry. A recent

Speaker: NA
Text: statement by the Chairman of the New Zealand

Speaker: NA
Text: Meat Producers Board indicates that export mut-

Speaker: NA
Text: ton carcases are currently selling at a loss of be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween $3.50 and $6.50 each. Various Ministers

Speaker: NA
Text: have received representations from the Sheep-

Speaker: NA
Text: of meat Council of Australia seeking the imposition

Speaker: NA
Text: would of countervailing duties. There are recognised

Speaker: NA
Text: and procedures for investigating claims for protection

Speaker: NA
Text: against dumping and the matter of New Zealand

Speaker: NA
Text: subsidies should be considered in that context.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Sheepmeat Council is aware of these pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: cedures and is taking action.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe, however, that the claims that the New

Speaker: NA
Text: Zealand shipments constitute a breach of CER

Speaker: NA
Text: are unfounded. The CER trade agreement be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween Australia and New Zealand provides for

Speaker: NA
Text: the continued duty-free flow of sheep meat be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween the two countries. I will shortly be in New

Speaker: NA
Text: Zealand examining these broader questions. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government and the Australian Meat and Live-

Speaker: NA
Text: stock Corporation are monitoring the situation

Speaker: NA
Text: closely. Following an industry request the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Statistician recently refined the statistics

Speaker: NA
Text: obtained on sheep meat imports to differentiate

Speaker: NA
Text: between lamb and mutton because, quite frankly,

Speaker: NA
Text: it is our belief that most of the increase in imports,

Speaker: NA
Text: on the basis of the value of the product, is in

Speaker: NA
Text: mutton.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Fisher-But is New Zealand dumping?

Speaker: Mr KERIN
Text: That will be found out.

Speaker: NA
Text: HYDATIDS

Speaker: Mr SNOW
Text: Is the Minister for Primary In-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry aware of the great human suffering caused

Speaker: NA
Text: to children and adults who contract hydatids?

Speaker: NA
Text: These innocent victims have frequently to

Speaker: NA
Text: undergo extensive thoracic and abdominal sur-

Speaker: NA
Text: gery and they carry the scars for the rest of their

Speaker: NA
Text: life. Will the Minister expedite the control of this

Speaker: NA
Text: disease in animals and humans?

Speaker: Mr KERIN
Text: I thank the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for his question. He has been concerned with this

Speaker: NA
Text: issue for quite some time in his professional ca-

Speaker: NA
Text: pacity. Hydatids control affects city and country

Speaker: NA
Text: alike. There is little high technology needed to

Speaker: NA
Text: control the problem. In fact, if we.look at the his-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory of the issue we find that way back in 1929 Sir

Speaker: NA
Text: Ian Clunies-Ross lamented the fact that we had

Speaker: NA
Text: not tackled it effectively in Australia. It can be

Speaker: NA
Text: controlled by the application of simple measures

Speaker: NA
Text: of dog feeding and control. The electorate of

Speaker: NA
Text: Eden-Monaro is in an area of very high

Speaker: NA
Text: prevalance of hydatids. Also, in the electorate of

Speaker: NA
Text: the unemployed honourable member for Hume

Speaker: NA
Text: the rate of incidence of hydatids is probably the

Speaker: NA
Text: highest in the world. I recently met Dr Peter

Speaker: NA
Text: MCCullagh, who is the Chairman of the south-

Speaker: NA
Text: eastern New South Wales and Australian Capital

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory hydatids control campaign. I must say

Speaker: NA
Text: that I was very impressed by the community

Speaker: NA
Text: program that he and his colleagues have worked

Speaker: NA
Text: up. The program is community-based, as it has to

Speaker: NA
Text: be, and it is funded on a very lean budget from

Speaker: NA
Text: seven shire councils, one city council and three

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Capital Territory authorities. The dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ease of hydatids is controlled in New Zealand and

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmania. Various groups have been formed in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia in areas of high incidence, but unfortu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nately they have faltered. I think there has been

Speaker: NA
Text: lack of medical and veterinary input into the

Speaker: NA
Text: program. Doctors and vets should be involved in

Speaker: NA
Text: the program, together with the community groups

Speaker: NA
Text: that are formed.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a human and animal health problem

Speaker: NA
Text: that has a veterinary solution.

Speaker: NA
Text: mal Health within the Department of Primary In-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry is co-operating with this campaign in

Speaker: NA
Text: south-east New South Wales and the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Capital Territory. We are co-operating closely

Speaker: NA
Text: and effectively with it. The Government wishes to

Speaker: NA
Text: give every endorsement to its activities. As the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member has said, the effects on indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: viduals if hydatids is contracted is very severe

Speaker: NA
Text: indeed. The measures for controlling the disease

Speaker: NA
Text: are simple. It requires not only doctor and veter-

Speaker: NA
Text: inarian but also large community input to take the

Speaker: NA
Text: effective measures that are necessary.

Speaker: NA
Text: MEAT INDUSTRY

Speaker: Mr HAWKER
Text: My question is also directed

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Minister for Primary Industry. Following

Speaker: NA
Text: the suspension of 22 meat inspectors in relation

Speaker: NA
Text: the findings of the Woodward Royal Commission

Speaker: NA
Text: into the Australian Meat Industry in October

Speaker: NA
Text: 1982, why have all but one of those inspectors

Speaker: NA
Text: remained on full pay for 18 months at a cost

Speaker: NA
Text: exceeding half a million dollars without any effecwas

Speaker: NA
Text: tive action being taken? How much longer will

Speaker: NA
Text: this expensive delay continue before the matter is

Speaker: NA
Text: resolved? Why should the meat industry, which

Speaker: NA
Text: has already suffered heavy losses because of the

Speaker: NA
Text: meat substitution scandal, have to bear part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: cost of this inordinate delay?

Speaker: Mr KERIN
Text: Recent publicity has been given

Speaker: NA
Text: to this matter. It gives me serious concern on two

Speaker: NA
Text: fronts. There is concern with respect to the due

Speaker: NA
Text: processes of law and concern with respect to the

Speaker: NA
Text: individuals themselves. The time that it has taken

Speaker: NA
Text: to bring this case to finalisation is unacceptable to

Speaker: NA
Text: me but was a consequence of the due processes of

Speaker: NA
Text: law. When I became aware of the situation I con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tacted my Department to see what could be done

Speaker: NA
Text: and I also wrote to the Public Service Board.

Speaker: NA
Text: The inspectors were suspended in October 1982

Speaker: NA
Text: by the previous Government on the basis of

Speaker: NA
Text: charges laid under the criminal code. Following

Speaker: NA
Text: decisions on two of the cases in late 1983 it was

Speaker: NA
Text: decided by Commonwealth law authorities not to

Speaker: NA
Text: proceed with the remainder of the cases in court.

Speaker: NA
Text: They were consequently referred to my Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment for action under the disciplinary provisions

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Public Service Act. The reason there was so

Speaker: NA
Text: much delay was mainly the processes of law in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Northern Territory; simply the time taken to get

Speaker: NA
Text: a the people into court. Since the referral of the

Speaker: NA
Text: cases to my Department in January this year we

Speaker: NA
Text: have acted with maximum speed to complete the

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary action. As reported in an article re-

Speaker: NA
Text: cently in the Australian, the Department's chief

Speaker: NA
Text: officer has now all but finalised the case. I under-

Speaker: NA
Text: stand that I will get a report on my desk in the

Speaker: NA
Text: The Bureau of Ani- next day or two.

Speaker: NA
Text: Payment of hardship allowances during suspen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion was made in accordance with the conditions

Speaker: NA
Text: laid down under the Public Service Act. As these

Speaker: NA
Text: inspectors are employees of the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: under the Public Service Act, I, as the responsible

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister, have to follow those procedures. But I

Speaker: NA
Text: would like to make the point that the cases were

Speaker: NA
Text: referred to law; a decision was made by the law

Speaker: NA
Text: officers of the Commonwealth and, in addition,

Speaker: NA
Text: my Department has looked at the situation of

Speaker: NA
Text: these individuals. It is my understanding-I was

Speaker: NA
Text: informed on the telephone and I do not have the

Speaker: NA
Text: piece of paper with me yet-that penalties have

Speaker: NA
Text: been applied to these people in terms of the Public

Speaker: NA
Text: Service Act. I would just like to make it clear that

Speaker: NA
Text: to these cases have gone through the law and

Speaker: NA
Text: through the Public Service Act.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second part of my concern is with respect

Speaker: NA
Text: to the individuals themselves. In terms of my

Speaker: NA
Text: reading of the evidence on these individuals there

Speaker: NA
Text: no problem at any time with respect to the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: tegrity of the meat inspection procedures they

Speaker: NA
Text: were carrying out. In other words, there is no way

Speaker: NA
Text: that any inspection procedure was ever under-

Speaker: NA
Text: taken in an untoward fashion. As I have said,

Speaker: NA
Text: these people were apprehended under the crimi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nal code because of evidence they gave to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Royal Commission. That centred on their activi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties with respect to the trimming of meat in an

Speaker: NA
Text: abattoir; in other words, they were doing ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: ditional work. That was the basis of the charges

Speaker: NA
Text: that were laid.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am not going to go into the details

Speaker: NA
Text: ter because I am not going to put to the Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment my views about the rightness or wrongness

Speaker: NA
Text: of what they did. I will say that a test case, to all

Speaker: NA
Text: intents and purposes, went to the Northern Terri-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory courts. There was no conviction, and the case

Speaker: NA
Text: has been referred to the due procedures of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Public Service Act. Smaller penalties were ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: plied. The effect on these people has been devas-

Speaker: NA
Text: tating, and I think that is something of which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament should be mindful.

Speaker: NA
Text: STARLAB PROJECT

Speaker: Mr WELLS
Text: My question is directed to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Science and Technology. Does the

Speaker: NA
Text: withdrawal of Canada from the Starlab project

Speaker: NA
Text: mean that this project is unlikely to proceed? Is

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Government taking any interest in

Speaker: NA
Text: pursuing the possibility of space-related

Speaker: NA
Text: industries?

Speaker: Mr BARRY JONES
Text: The withdrawal of

Speaker: NA
Text: Canada from the Starlab project is serious but

Speaker: NA
Text: not, I believe, fatal. It will be necessary to find

Speaker: NA
Text: another partner who can be involved in the proj-

Speaker: NA
Text: ect and then it will have to be considered de novo,

Speaker: NA
Text: as they say in the classics. The division originally

Speaker: NA
Text: was that the United States of America would put

Speaker: NA
Text: Starlab into orbit, launch it, and provide the space

Speaker: NA
Text: platform, Canada would provide the telescope

Speaker: NA
Text: itself and we would provide the scientific

Speaker: NA
Text: instrumentation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Canadians were faced with the fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: they were involved in two very expensive space

Speaker: NA
Text: projects. The Spacelab project, which is different

Speaker: NA
Text: from Starlab, was really their No.1 priority and

Speaker: NA
Text: was one in which they had the dominant role. In

Speaker: NA
Text: the Starlab project they were simply making the

Speaker: NA
Text: instrument package. There certainly was a feeling

Speaker: NA
Text: in Canada, when I discussed it with Ministers in

Speaker: NA
Text: January this year, that we were getting the best

Speaker: NA
Text: end of the deal and they were not. For compara-

Speaker: NA
Text: tively modest sums we were getting the benefit of

Speaker: NA
Text: the scientific instrumentation package which they

Speaker: NA
Text: thought was likely to have a spin-off in the econ-

Speaker: NA
Text: omy gener-ally.

Speaker: NA
Text: The problem with the telescope, exciting proj-

Speaker: NA
Text: ect though it was, was that it was very difficult to

Speaker: NA
Text: see what one did for encore. It was not as if we

Speaker: NA
Text: were going to have another 50 or 100 ordered; it

Speaker: NA
Text: was an absolutely one-off exercise. It was very ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: citing and very challenging. The extension arm

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Canadians have made for the shuttle has

Speaker: NA
Text: been widely hailed; it is a great scientific achieve-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. But we do not find Boeing or Douglas say-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing: 'Terrific. We ought to get it on some of our

Speaker: NA
Text: aircraft'. It is simply sui generis; one cannot do

Speaker: NA
Text: of the mat- anything else with it.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, the consultancy report that we had

Speaker: NA
Text: indicated that Australia will do best out of it if the

Speaker: NA
Text: total project goes ahead. The two leading con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tenders at this moment are Japan and the

Speaker: NA
Text: European Space Agency. The Deputy Secretary

Speaker: NA
Text: to my Department, Dr Roy Green, is in Tokyo at

Speaker: NA
Text: the moment talking to the Japanese about it. It

Speaker: NA
Text: will be either Japan or the European Space

Speaker: NA
Text: Agency. Our future role will have to be deter-

Speaker: NA
Text: mined in the Budget context, of course. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed that Starlab will go up in 1988 and 1989,

Speaker: NA
Text: so there is some lead time on it. I think it is poten-

Speaker: NA
Text: tially the most exciting scientific experiment of

Speaker: NA
Text: the twentieth century.

Speaker: NA
Text: PATIENT BENEFITS

Speaker: Mr MILLAR
Text: The Minister for Health will be

Speaker: NA
Text: familiar with the recent restoration to category 2

Speaker: NA
Text: of a number of hospitals, including St Stephens at

Speaker: NA
Text: Maryborough, Queensland. Will the Minister in-

Speaker: NA
Text: form the House of the position of privately in-

Speaker: NA
Text: sured patient benefits for the period from I

Speaker: NA
Text: February 1984, the date of initial recategorisation

Speaker: NA
Text: downward, to 22 March 1984, when the hospitals

Speaker: NA
Text: in question were restored to their original

Speaker: NA
Text: category?

Speaker: Dr BLEWETT
Text: I am not quite clear from the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member's question about reca-

Speaker: NA
Text: tegorisation downwards. A number of hospitals

Speaker: NA
Text: were recategorised upwards from their original

Speaker: NA
Text: classification of category 3 or category 2 at a later

Speaker: NA
Text: date, on submissions that had been made and re-

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration of categorisation. I will look into

Speaker: NA
Text: the specific hospitals concerned and give the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member a detailed answer.

Text: Werriwa-Minister for Primary

Speaker: NA
Text: Industry)-Pursuant to section 16 of the Pig In-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry Research Act 1971, I present the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Pig Industry Research Committee annual

Speaker: NA
Text: report for 1982-83.

Speaker: NA
Text: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS

Speaker: Mr SPENDER
Text: North Sydney)- Mr Speaker,

Speaker: NA
Text: claim to have been misrepresented-

Speaker: NA
Text: inadvertently, no doubt.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order! The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for North Sydney knows that he must

Speaker: NA
Text: make the request to the Chair and be given the

Speaker: NA
Text: call. I call the honourable member for North Syd-

Speaker: NA
Text: ney to make his personal explanation.

Speaker: Mr SPENDER
Text: I am sorry, Mr Speaker. I

Speaker: NA
Text: apologise for overlooking that. Last night the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Aviation ( Mr Beazley) came into the

Speaker: NA
Text: House to defend himself in the adjournment de-

Speaker: NA
Text: bate concerning his handling of the Sydney

Speaker: NA
Text: (Kingsford-Smith) Airport question and the non-

Speaker: NA
Text: decision over the second airport site. In the course

Speaker: NA
Text: of doing so he said of me:

Speaker: NA
Text: , The honourable member for North Sydney implies that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government has somehow reached a position where

Speaker: NA
Text: absolutely no development of any sort improving oper-

Speaker: NA
Text: ations of Sydney will take place under this Government. If

Speaker: NA
Text: he really believes that, he has forgotten

Speaker: NA
Text: last Budget. We included in the last Budget provision for

Speaker: NA
Text: the development of fast taxiways at Sydney, which will in-

Speaker: NA
Text: crease and improve the traffic How there . . .

Speaker: NA
Text: I neither stated nor implied that the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: was not doing anything in relation to improving

Speaker: NA
Text: operations. I was well aware of that program. It

Speaker: NA
Text: was instituted by the honourable member for Far-

Speaker: NA
Text: rer ( Mr Fife) when he was Minister for Aviation.

Speaker: NA
Text: What the present Minister is doing is no more

Speaker: NA
Text: than continuing the implementation of that

Speaker: NA
Text: program.

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Text: Dundas)- Mr Speaker, I

Speaker: NA
Text: claim to have been misrepresented by the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter for Territories and Local Government ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Uren).

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Dundas may make a personal explanation.

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Text: Mr Speaker, during Ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion Time the Minister misrepresented comments

Speaker: NA
Text: made by me on Australian Broadcasting Corpor-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation radio this morning in relation to housing in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Capital Territory. This morning I

Speaker: NA
Text: was offering constructive comments to assist the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government in this important matter concerning

Speaker: NA
Text: the present housing crisis in Canberra. I regret

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Minister wants to claim credit for the im-

Speaker: NA
Text: proving local economy in this city but is unwilling

Speaker: NA
Text: to accept the consequences of that improvement

Speaker: NA
Text: as it relates to the housing area in particular.

Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

Speaker: NA
Text: The humble, petition of certain citizens of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: shows-

Speaker: NA
Text: That, with the exception of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: ritory and the Northern Territory, all State Parliaments

Speaker: NA
Text: have enacted chiropractic legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: That chiropractors provide a safe, effective and econ-

Speaker: NA
Text: omical health care service that is complementary to

Speaker: NA
Text: medicine.

Speaker: NA
Text: That the introduction of a Federally funded health care

Speaker: NA
Text: system restricted to the services provided almost exclus-

Speaker: NA
Text: ively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those

Speaker: NA
Text: citizens utilizing chiropractic care, many of whom find

Speaker: NA
Text: that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily

Speaker: NA
Text: to traditional approaches.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: practic services are included in Medicare when it is

Speaker: NA
Text: the detail of the introduced.

Speaker: NA
Text: National Life and Democratic Institutions

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

Speaker: NA
Text: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia respectfully showeth:

Speaker: NA
Text: That we, the loyal citizens of Australia firmly express

Speaker: NA
Text: our strong opposition to any proposals to remove or

Speaker: NA
Text: undermine the importance of the place of God and jor the

Speaker: NA
Text: Queen in our national life, and democratic institutions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Parliament assembled reaffirm our nation's

Speaker: NA
Text: PETITIONS total dependence on God the Creator in accordance with

Speaker: NA
Text: our Australian Constitution, which commences with the

Speaker: NA
Text: words "Humbly relying on the blessing of Almighty God",

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Standing Orders of both the Senate and the House

Speaker: NA
Text: of Representatives which prescribe that Parliament each

Speaker: NA
Text: day shall open with a special prayer to Almighty God and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Lord's Prayer.

Speaker: NA
Text: We also call on the Parliament assembled to re-affirm

Speaker: NA
Text: our genuine loyalty to our Head of State, the Queen of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, Elizabeth II-'God save the Queen'.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

Text: Capital Ter- by Mr Carlton and Mr Mountford.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: visions inconsistent with principles

Speaker: NA
Text: which could be used to:

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Entrench abortion funding and render liable to

Speaker: NA
Text: action Hospitals, Doctors and Nurses, who conscien-

Speaker: NA
Text: tiously refuse to become involved in morally objection-

Speaker: NA
Text: able operations;

Speaker: NA
Text: Deny to parents their rights to insist that the school

Speaker: NA
Text: "community" provide an environment conducive to the

Speaker: NA
Text: development, including moral development of their

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Proposed Airport at Scheyville, New South

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The

Speaker: NA
Text: humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: respectfully showeth:

Speaker: NA
Text: I. That an airport in the north-western region (com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monly called Scheyville) imposes disastrous econ-

Text: omic, environmental and social costs on our

Speaker: NA
Text: community.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. An airport would destroy 2,000 households and im-

Speaker: NA
Text: pose upheaval, noise and pollution on one million

Speaker: NA
Text: people presently unaffected.

Speaker: NA
Text: greater than the alternatives, whilst fog and close

Speaker: NA
Text: proximity to R.A.A.F. Base Richmond would make

Speaker: NA
Text: operations impractical.

Speaker: NA
Text: 4. It would destroy the historic village of Pitt Town,

Speaker: NA
Text: unique adherent wildlife.

Speaker: NA
Text: 5. Your petitioners reject these proposals and call for

Speaker: NA
Text: endorsement of the MANS Committee findings.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The

Speaker: NA
Text: humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: showeth:

Speaker: NA
Text: I. That Australia's meat exports are being placed in an

Speaker: NA
Text: uncompetitive position by the imposition of substan-

Speaker: NA
Text: tial export meat inspection charges whilst

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's competitors receive free inspection plus

Speaker: NA
Text: considerable subsidies.

Speaker: NA
Text: of justice and equality

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. These charges are causing substantial loss of business

Speaker: NA
Text: for export abattoir operators and loss of jobs for

Speaker: NA
Text: their employees due to the disparity in inspection

Speaker: NA
Text: costs of export and non-export works arising from a

Speaker: NA
Text: 200% increase in federal government charges at

Speaker: NA
Text: export works.

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. That immediate steps should be taken to end serious

Speaker: NA
Text: injury being done by these charges to export abattoir

Speaker: NA
Text: operators, their employees, live-stock producers and

Speaker: NA
Text: all others dependent on the Australian meat and

Speaker: NA
Text: livestock industry.

Text: by Mr Hodgman.

Speaker: NA
Text: National Flag

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable Members of the Australian Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: so as to prevent the possibility

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament. The humble petition of the undersigned citi-

Speaker: NA
Text: zens of Australia showeth that whereas:

Speaker: NA
Text: I. They are completely satisfied with the design of the

Speaker: NA
Text: existing Australian National Flag

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable

Speaker: NA
Text: characteristics of Australia, namely:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Chris-

Speaker: NA
Text: tian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical ori-

Speaker: NA
Text: gin and the source of its language and law

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales (b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background

Speaker: NA
Text: signifying its geographical location on this planet

Speaker: NA
Text: Earth

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration

Speaker: NA
Text: to generations of Australians in peace and war

Speaker: NA
Text: 4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the

Speaker: NA
Text: world have become united under its proud symbolism

Speaker: NA
Text: 5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will

Speaker: NA
Text: produce division in the Australian community

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: House will: Propose and pass a motion that "the existing

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian National Flag remains sacrosanct from

Speaker: NA
Text: change".

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Hodgman.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received.

Speaker: NA
Text: Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: GOVERNMENT'S DEFENCE AND

Speaker: NA
Text: FOREIGN AFFAIRS POLICIES

Speaker: NA
Text: Discussion of MaUer of Public Importance

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I have received a letter from

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: posing that a definite matter of public importance

Speaker: NA
Text: be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

Speaker: NA
Text: The concern and confusion created by the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's Defence and Foreign Affairs policies, as

Speaker: NA
Text: highlighted by the leaking of the Strategic Basis Paper.

Speaker: NA
Text: I call upon those members who approve of the

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed discussion to rise in their places.

Speaker: NA
Text: More than the number ofmembers required by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Standing Orders having risen in their

Speaker: NA
Text: places-

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition) (3.0)-The Opposition has proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: this matter of public importance today following

Speaker: NA
Text: the leaking of a document which appeared in the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Times last week. I remind honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members just what that document is. It is headed,

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Strategic Basis of Australian Defence Policy'.

Speaker: NA
Text: These strategic basis papers came before us when

Speaker: NA
Text: we were in government. The title indicates just

Speaker: NA
Text: how important the papers are. They form the

Speaker: NA
Text: strategic basis for the formulation of defence pol-

Speaker: NA
Text: icy. It is fatuous for honourable members opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: to question the document's authenticity, which in-

Speaker: NA
Text: cidentally has been answered today by Air Chief

Speaker: NA
Text: Marshal Sir Neville MCNamara, who conceded its

Speaker: NA
Text: authenticity, which is something that the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment ran from, despite the fact that if one puts

Speaker: NA
Text: this statement and that statement together one

Speaker: NA
Text: draws the obvious conclusion it is in fact auth-

Speaker: NA
Text: entic. The sight of the Government trying to deny

Speaker: NA
Text: of Ternot only the authenticity but also the importance

Speaker: NA
Text: of the document was embarrassing. The next step,

Speaker: NA
Text: I suppose, will see us getting into a situation which

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministers will be conceding either that they forgot

Speaker: NA
Text: to read the document or that it was endorsed by

Speaker: NA
Text: mistake. That is the sort of nonsense that seemed

Speaker: NA
Text: to be coming through in the vacuous allegations

Speaker: NA
Text: National Flag which were made yesterday when the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: was questioning Ministers in the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: There can be no doubt that, after the extraordi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nary events of last week and yesterday, Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: is now rudderless, not merely in the area of de-

Speaker: NA
Text: fence but also in the area of foreign affairs. These

Speaker: NA
Text: events confirm the fact that there is a lack of co-

Speaker: NA
Text: herence in defence and foreign affairs policy. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition has constantly said in this House that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government will never get its regional re-

Speaker: NA
Text: lationships right unless it understands what the

Speaker: NA
Text: coherent framework of its foreign policy. Is, it an-

Speaker: NA
Text: nounces it to its people and says: 'This is our stra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tegic assessment and where we sit within the globe

Speaker: NA
Text: itself'. Unless it th-n moves from analysing

Speaker: NA
Text: Soviet-United States relations, Sino-Soviet re-

Speaker: NA
Text: lations, et cetera, it will not get regional relations

Speaker: NA
Text: right. That is why, for example, time and again

Speaker: NA
Text: the current Minister for Foreign Affairs ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Hayden) simply gets policy toward Vietnam

Speaker: NA
Text: wrong. I know that he has sought desperately to

Speaker: NA
Text: be the honest broker in regard to Vietnam. The re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ality is that we are part of the Western alliance.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our interests put us with the Association of South

Speaker: NA
Text: East Asian Nations, which reads the movements

Speaker: NA
Text: of Vietnam differently. Vietnam is a client of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Soviet Union. Her invasion of Kampuchea was

Speaker: NA
Text: the invasion of a client of the Soviet Union against

Speaker: NA
Text: a client of the People's Republic of China. If the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government does not understand the background

Speaker: NA
Text: of that, it will not get any affairs, let alone its re-

Speaker: NA
Text: gional relationships, right.

Speaker: NA
Text: This paper seeks to come to grips with matters

Speaker: NA
Text: such as those I have just touched on very lightly

Speaker: NA
Text: indeed. But this Government not only has denied

Speaker: NA
Text: the authenticity of the documents, although

Speaker: NA
Text: others have indicated that they are authentic, but

Speaker: NA
Text: also from the moment of the leaking has sought, in

Speaker: NA
Text: insignificant areas, to move away from what is

Speaker: NA
Text: contained within a paper that it endorsed last

Speaker: NA
Text: year.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a strategic basis document endorsed by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Cabinet. When one reads it, it is worthy of en-

Speaker: NA
Text: dorsement. But the document is the antithesis of

Speaker: NA
Text: what the Australian Labor Party is all about. It

Speaker: NA
Text: goes against many of the Government's state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments in its platform and policy. If that is the case

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Government does not agree with what is

Speaker: NA
Text: in the document, why the devil endorse it as the

Speaker: NA
Text: strategic basis for the Government's defence pol-

Speaker: NA
Text: icy? The Government having endorsed it, why do

Speaker: NA
Text: we have the extraordinary shuffles day after day

Speaker: NA
Text: to point out the position in different areas,

Speaker: NA
Text: whether it be the relationship or the strategic bal-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance between the Soviet Union and the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States that the Foreign Minister disagreed with in

Speaker: NA
Text: the papers yesterday or elements relating to nu-

Speaker: NA
Text: clear non-proliferation? If the Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: endorsed it, that.is its view. Why does it not have

Speaker: NA
Text: the courage to say so? The answer is that the

Speaker: NA
Text: pacifist elements within the Government party

Speaker: NA
Text: and those who are opposed to the stockpiling of

Speaker: NA
Text: nuclear weapons cannot allow the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: publicly to endorse a paper that has reality shriek-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing throughout it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Even before the leaking of this document this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government had enough problems in the area of

Speaker: NA
Text: foreign affairs. But the document went to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Cabinet. It was endorsed; it was accepted; and it

Speaker: NA
Text: was approved. Madam Deputy Speaker, honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members opposite can use whatever words

Speaker: NA
Text: they like but last year the contents of the docu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment did receive the sanction of the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: and no amount of specious argument can change

Speaker: NA
Text: that. The document and all its contents therefore

Speaker: NA
Text: represent the corner-stone for the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: plans on vital defence and foreign policy matters.

Speaker: NA
Text: That document lays down the base for specific in-

Speaker: NA
Text: itiatives. It provides the yardstick by which indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: vidual actions are to be measured. Based on a sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: stantial proportion of that document now in the

Speaker: NA
Text: public domain, I have indicated already that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition endorses a great deal of it as being

Speaker: NA
Text: strategically sound. It seems to us, on the degree

Speaker: NA
Text: of reading that we have had before us in the

Speaker: NA
Text: article in the National Times, to be a cogent

Speaker: NA
Text: evaluation of Australia's position from a global

Speaker: NA
Text: perspective.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is extraordinary that the Hawke Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, having endorsed the document, is now in

Speaker: NA
Text: the process of disowning it. For example, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Foreign Minister has refused to accept that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Soviet Union has outstripped the United States in

Speaker: NA
Text: its nuclear capability. That is the net effect of

Speaker: NA
Text: what he. said yesterday. In the process he is

Speaker: NA
Text: disowning one of the corner-stones of our stra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tegic planning. All sorts of questions flow from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Foreign Minister's statement alone. It is well

Speaker: NA
Text: worth considering his change of face. Why is he

Speaker: NA
Text: doing it now? Why did he not raise last September

Speaker: NA
Text: the matters that he raised in the Parliament yes-

Speaker: NA
Text: terday? What has transpired between September

Speaker: NA
Text: and now that makes him the enlightened Foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister he seeks to present to the members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Centre Left and the Left? But he was so mute

Speaker: NA
Text: when the matter went before the Cabinet last

Speaker: NA
Text: year, unless-and I will be fair to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister-he was away at the time. He may have

Speaker: NA
Text: been out of the country.

Speaker: NA
Text: If he was out of the country, and perhaps he

Speaker: NA
Text: was, I am sure he would have done what any of his

Speaker: NA
Text: predecessors have done and let the Acting Foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister give the Minister's views on that docu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in the Cabinet. Itis too important if the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government is adopting a strategic basis to allow

Speaker: NA
Text: that plan to go through without having the Acting

Speaker: NA
Text: Foreign Minister advise the Cabinet of the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter's views. If he had not done that, when he got

Speaker: NA
Text: back from overseas he should have ensured that

Speaker: NA
Text: the matter came back to Cabinet again so that he

Speaker: NA
Text: could inject his view. So if the Minister were over-

Speaker: NA
Text: seas, as I suspect from the Mephistophelean leer

Speaker: NA
Text: on his face when I raised the question of why his

Speaker: NA
Text: views were not injected into the Cabinet, perhaps

Speaker: NA
Text: he can tell us why this matter was not brought

Speaker: NA
Text: back before Cabinet when he returned.

Speaker: NA
Text: What is the Government's view? What is the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's alternative? What will the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government base Australia's strategic planning

Speaker: NA
Text: on if it is rejecting this paper which has been

Speaker: NA
Text: leaked through the National Times? Yesterday

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government was at pains to state its commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to nuclear non-proliferation, to the Treaty

Speaker: NA
Text: on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons

Speaker: NA
Text: and to a range of disarmament initiatives. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Hawke Government has reverted to an expression

Speaker: NA
Text: of policy on nuclear issues based on idealism and

Speaker: NA
Text: on the love of peace, but for peace's sake. The

Speaker: NA
Text: salient fact about the strategic basis paper is that

Speaker: NA
Text: nuclear disarmament is endorsed not for idealistic

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons but for hard-nosed assessments of what is

Speaker: NA
Text: required in the world today. The Government

Speaker: NA
Text: and, indeed, the entire Labor Caucus have a ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to answer: Is our policy towards nuclear non-

Speaker: NA
Text: proliferation conditional on a realistic evaluation

Speaker: NA
Text: of the world and the regional balance of forces, as

Speaker: NA
Text: the strategic basis paper sensibly puts it, or is our

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment to nuclear disarmament uncon-

Speaker: NA
Text: ditional and unheeding of strategic and power

Speaker: NA
Text: realities? I inject the term 'power realities' be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause of the nonsense that is talked by Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment members from time to time.

Speaker: NA
Text: So long as the system of nation states exists,

Speaker: NA
Text: power will remain the major arbiter in world

Speaker: NA
Text: affairs. If Government members would recognise

Speaker: NA
Text: that as a basic fact, they would not be deluding

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves with the pacifist arguments they so

Speaker: NA
Text: frequently produce. That is an underlying reality

Speaker: NA
Text: accepted by every member on this side of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Hand-You are all right while you are

Speaker: NA
Text: sending people to Vietnam.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member speak because he is winning

Speaker: NA
Text: support, as are the honourable member for Casey

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Steedman) and the three left wing Ministers

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Government-the great anti-nuclear

Speaker: NA
Text: people, the great anti-uranium people. One of

Speaker: NA
Text: them is returning to the Cabinet today for 30

Speaker: NA
Text: pieces of silver-a Judas reward, if you like. What

Speaker: NA
Text: will these men of principle do after July? What

Speaker: NA
Text: will every member of this Cabinet who is a left

Speaker: NA
Text: wing member of the Caucus do? Will they put the

Speaker: NA
Text: proposition that there is an election at the end of

Speaker: NA
Text: the year and that that is more important than the

Speaker: NA
Text: principles they have carved on their sleeves for

Speaker: NA
Text: years? r can see now by the expression on the face

Speaker: NA
Text: of the honourable member for Melbourne ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Hand) that he would rather sit on this side of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament-that is where he will be after the

Speaker: NA
Text: election-than compromise his principles.

Speaker: NA
Text: I move sideways to the uranium issue because it

Speaker: NA
Text: is akin to what is happening now in regard to the

Speaker: NA
Text: strategic basis document. There are harsh realities

Speaker: NA
Text: contained within that document. They have to be

Speaker: NA
Text: accepted by any party in government that is fac-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the reality of the international scene today.

Speaker: NA
Text: But because it does not mirror the hearts and

Speaker: NA
Text: flowers nonsense of Government members' rhet-

Speaker: NA
Text: oric, they have step by step, day by day, jettisoned

Speaker: NA
Text: it as their strategic basis. We are left in a position

Speaker: NA
Text: of being unable to know what the Government's
