Speaker: NA
Text: foreign policy or defence policy is all about. If the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government accepted what is contained in that

Speaker: NA
Text: strategic basis paper, it would not be giving voice

Speaker: NA
Text: to the sort of nonsense that has been contained in

Speaker: NA
Text: so many statements of the Foreign Minister and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Defence ( Mr Scholes). That is

Speaker: NA
Text: the harsh reality. Their statements just do not sit

Speaker: NA
Text: together, nor does some of the nonsense in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Labor Party platform sit with what is

Speaker: NA
Text: in that document.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unless the Government can work out what it is

Speaker: NA
Text: on about, it will further confuse the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: people; nor can it endorse a strategic basis paper

Speaker: NA
Text: for the administration and formulation of defence

Speaker: NA
Text: programming in this country and allow the run-

Speaker: NA
Text: down in defence to occur, as was so well illus-

Speaker: NA
Text: trated by my colleagues in this House last week.

Speaker: NA
Text: The rundown in defence is shown by the 1983-84

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget. There was a cut of $164m from defence

Speaker: NA
Text: spending from the previous coalition Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's program, a rise of $3.9m in civilian man-

Speaker: NA
Text: power costs, and a fall of $20.7m in service man-

Speaker: NA
Text: power costs. The service manpower figures, which

Speaker: NA
Text: fell by 732, were referred to by my colleagues.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have had a series of conflicting statements

Speaker: NA
Text: from different Ministers, leading to continued em-

Speaker: NA
Text: barrassment and a lack of credibility. We have a

Speaker: NA
Text: Cabinet which endorses a major document in the

Speaker: NA
Text: secrecy of the Cabinet room, yet in the light of

Speaker: NA
Text: public scrutiny seeks to back away from it with

Speaker: NA
Text: indecent haste. We have an endless ambiguity in

Speaker: NA
Text: this Government between a desire to live in the

Speaker: NA
Text: real world of foreign affairs and defence, and a

Speaker: NA
Text: quasi-idealism dictated by the pressure of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Left. The net result is a hotchpotch of half-

Speaker: NA
Text: developed initiatives, undirected sentiments and

Speaker: NA
Text: contradictory actions. No government can play an

Speaker: NA
Text: effective role in the world or in the region if it

Speaker: NA
Text: lacks coherence and direction in its approach to

Speaker: NA
Text: defence and foreign policy. This Government is

Speaker: NA
Text: the architect of a situation in which our allies wit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness the blunders and the zigzags between the

Speaker: NA
Text: Right and the Left, between idealism and realism.

Speaker: NA
Text: They can have little confidence that Australia will

Speaker: NA
Text: playa sound and consistt:nt part in world affairs.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government stands condemned by its own

Speaker: NA
Text: words and by its own actions, lacking that innate

Speaker: NA
Text: quality of enlightened realism that is needed in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia today, in foreign affairs particularly.

Speaker: NA
Text: What we have is duplicity and deception, the

Speaker: NA
Text: adoption of a paper which shrieks common sense

Speaker: NA
Text: and the putting down of it publicly when it is re-

Speaker: NA
Text: leased to show the Government for what it is and

Speaker: NA
Text: what the policy ought to be about. Come clean!

Speaker: NA
Text: Tell us. Does the Government endorse that docu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment or is it going to continue to slide in the man-

Speaker: NA
Text: ner of the statements yesterday by the Prime Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister and the Foreign Minister?

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER ( Mrs Child)-

Speaker: NA
Text: Order! The honourable member's time has

Speaker: NA
Text: expired.

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Text: Oxley-Minister for Foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs)(3.15)-There was a lot of snorting and

Speaker: NA
Text: barking and a good deal of squealing and squeak-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing, but where was the major production we were

Speaker: NA
Text: promised? We were promised a sensation which

Speaker: NA
Text: would rock the Government. Instead, we got a

Speaker: NA
Text: squib. We did not get the Macbeth the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: We got Little Nell, and the Leader of the Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition cast in the main role. He gave us the whole

Speaker: NA
Text: tonal gamut, from Sistine Chapel choir falsetto to

Speaker: NA
Text: a dungeon deep bass. It was almost as if he were

Speaker: NA
Text: unsure whether he had brought all his necessary

Speaker: NA
Text: personal equipment with him into the House. His

Speaker: NA
Text: performance reminds me of Kingsley Amis's hero

Speaker: NA
Text: in his novel The Alteration, and I understand that

Speaker: NA
Text: many who sit behind him want to conduct the

Speaker: NA
Text: same sort of alteration on him. After listening to

Speaker: NA
Text: him today we can well understand why.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us look at some of the observations which

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the Opposition made. He says that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is lack of coherence in foreign affairs and de-

Speaker: NA
Text: fence policies. Then he went on in grandiloquent

Speaker: NA
Text: if not extravagant style to say that unless we pin-

Speaker: NA
Text: point the Soviet-United States strategic relation-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship and the Sino-Soviet relationship we will not

Speaker: NA
Text: get any of our policies right. Peacock, the super-

Speaker: NA
Text: bird, is going to fix all! But the trouble with pea-

Speaker: NA
Text: cocks is that they cannot fly, and neither will this

Speaker: NA
Text: nonsense he is going on with. He asked why we do

Speaker: NA
Text: not endorse this alleged document as the basis of

Speaker: NA
Text: our commitments and went on to state

Speaker: NA
Text: unequivocally that the Opposition bases all its

Speaker: NA
Text: foreign policy and defence thinking on this docu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. How remarkable! All its thinking on foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: affairs and defence is based on this document! It

Speaker: NA
Text: does not even know what is in the document. It

Speaker: NA
Text: knows a couple of small extracts from a document

Speaker: NA
Text: which is 100 pages or so in length, but it is pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared to endorse the lot as substantiating its

Speaker: NA
Text: thinking. That is very easy because it is evident

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Opposition just does not think.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Leader of the Opposition asked why I did

Speaker: NA
Text: not protest in Cabinet. The fact is, as he correctly

Speaker: NA
Text: divined-after all, I gave him a nudge and a

Speaker: NA
Text: wink-that I was overseas when it was in Cabinet.

Speaker: NA
Text: But it did go into the foreign affairs and defence

Speaker: NA
Text: committee, and the Leader of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: would be very interested to know my observations

Speaker: NA
Text: then. Would he like to hear them? Would he like

Speaker: NA
Text: to hear my observations in the foreign affairs and

Speaker: NA
Text: defence Cabinet sub-committee?

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Text: I knew he would, but I cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: tell him because there are prohibitions. He says

Speaker: NA
Text: that power remains the major arbiter in world

Speaker: NA
Text: affairs. The principle of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: going to send troops all over the world to solve its

Speaker: NA
Text: problems. Presumably it will send them on

Speaker: NA
Text: wooden hobby horses with broomstick swords be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause it so disastrously depleted the capability of

Speaker: NA
Text: our defence forces in the period in which it was in

Speaker: NA
Text: government:

Speaker: NA
Text: I understand that the Leader of the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Party ( Mr Sinclair)-Australia's richest grave-

Speaker: NA
Text: digger who has turned to politics as a hobby-will

Speaker: NA
Text: follow me as the second speaker for the Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition. If he treats the fortunes of the armed ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices in the way in which he treated the personal

Speaker: NA
Text: family heritage it will not be long before they are

Speaker: NA
Text: bankrupt and in the courts. The facts are that the

Speaker: NA
Text: condition of the defence forces today by no phan-

Speaker: NA
Text: tasmagorical stretch of the imagination can be

Speaker: NA
Text: attributed to a government which has been in

Speaker: NA
Text: office for scarcely 12 months. The condition of the

Speaker: NA
Text: defence forces in this country is a reflection of a

Speaker: NA
Text: long term rundown of quite malicious neglect on

Speaker: NA
Text: the part of the Opposition during the several years

Speaker: NA
Text: it was in government.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to come back to this matter, but first I

Speaker: NA
Text: will make a few comments which ought to go on

Speaker: NA
Text: the record. The Leader of the Opposition chal-

Speaker: NA
Text: lenges the Government to confirm the authen-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticity of the alleged document upon which the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ports in the National Times have been based. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition knows as well as I do

Speaker: NA
Text: that there is a practice, and a very well founded

Speaker: NA
Text: one, that governments do not confirm or deny

Speaker: NA
Text: matters which are sensitive where there is a claim

Speaker: NA
Text: that there has been a leak. The Opposition, in

Speaker: NA
Text: government, had more experience of this than we

Speaker: NA
Text: have had. There are, in this document, 15 in-

Speaker: NA
Text: stances of major sensitive leaks which occurred

Speaker: NA
Text: when the Opposition was in government and it

Speaker: NA
Text: followed that practice. It is soundly based. I in-

Speaker: NA
Text: tend to subscribe to it on this occasion. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: meantime, I request leave, Madam Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, to have incorporated in Hansard that

Speaker: NA
Text: list of instances of leaks.

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER ( Mrs

Speaker: NA
Text: Child)-Is leave granted?

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Text: No, I have asked for it to be

Speaker: NA
Text: incorporated. If the Opposition will not allow the

Speaker: NA
Text: incorporation, I shall not waste any more time. I

Speaker: NA
Text: do not know what honourable members opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: are frightened of. I do not know why they are

Speaker: NA
Text: worried about their record.

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER-Order! I am

Speaker: NA
Text: told that the document does not fall within the

Speaker: NA
Text: guidelines set down by Mr Speaker. The Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: is this: It is can table the document.

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Text: No, I shall let it go. A crucial

Speaker: NA
Text: ground upon which the Leader of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: developed his argument was that the Chief of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence Force Staff today confirmed the authen-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticity of the document. I have here a statement

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Defence Department that gives the lie to

Speaker: NA
Text: that. I suggest that the Leader of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: not fabricate his evidence to try to keep afloat a

Speaker: NA
Text: rather desperate case. He says that there is some-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing rather dubious about a decision of a govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in respect of a strategic basis submission

Speaker: NA
Text: which came to Cabinet-and such a submission

Speaker: NA
Text: did come to Cabinet; I make that distinction from

Speaker: NA
Text: speculation on what has appeared in the paper-

Speaker: NA
Text: that there is something dubious about such a

Speaker: NA
Text: document coming to Cabinet and being endorsed

Speaker: NA
Text: for guidance purposes. The honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: says that 'endorsed for guidance purposes' means

Speaker: NA
Text: that in all respects propositions which are pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sented explicitly or implicitly are accordingly

Speaker: NA
Text: endorsed. That is sheer nonsense. I accept, for in-

Speaker: NA
Text: stance, the telephone directory for general guid-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance. I endorse it for general guidance. But several

Speaker: NA
Text: months ago I had occasion to telephone my

Speaker: NA
Text: daughter in Sydney-she is now living there-and

Speaker: NA
Text: a strange male voice answered the phone. I

Speaker: NA
Text: thought that I had misdialled and I hung up and

Speaker: NA
Text: dialled again, and the same male voice came on

Speaker: NA
Text: the phone and abused rrie as a nuisance telephone

Speaker: NA
Text: caller. That was an unpleasant experience. But

Speaker: NA
Text: that does not mean that the telephone directory is

Speaker: NA
Text: no longer valid. It has its defects.

Speaker: NA
Text: Similarly, in the commercially available refer-

Speaker: NA
Text: dexes for the Brisbane area, one of the streets, at a

Speaker: NA
Text: junction at which we live in Ipswich is shown as a

Speaker: NA
Text: long, continuous street; but, in fact, it is not. A

Speaker: NA
Text: number of visitors to our place over the years

Speaker: NA
Text: have lost their way trying to follow this unfortu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nately misleading description of where we live.

Speaker: NA
Text: The referdex generally is reliable, and we endorse

Speaker: NA
Text: it. Unless it has been rectified in that respect,

Speaker: NA
Text: however, it certainly has a glaring deficiency

Speaker: NA
Text: there. So it is sheer nonsense on the part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition to try to fabricate that claim. The

Speaker: NA
Text: facts are that as a matter of sober concern we

Speaker: NA
Text: must all express some reservations about the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: pensity for the leakage of information over time.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have seen it. All governments, of aU colours,

Speaker: NA
Text: have seen it.

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Text: It never happened in our time.

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Text: I have just sought to have in-

Speaker: NA
Text: corporated in Hansard a list of nearly a score of

Speaker: NA
Text: cases in which it did happen, and I was prevented

Speaker: NA
Text: from having it incorporated by the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Party; but he has a lot of skeletons to

Speaker: NA
Text: keep hidden, and no doubt he does this as an auto-

Speaker: NA
Text: matic reflexive action.

Speaker: NA
Text: The former Prime Minister extolled the prin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciple of leaking. In July 1975, talking about leaks

Speaker: NA
Text: on a Four Corners program, he said:

Speaker: NA
Text: There could be circumstances, I believe, in which a

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasury official could regard his overriding duty to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia as being greater than his duty to a government;

Speaker: NA
Text: and ultimately our duty lies to Australia first.

Speaker: NA
Text: So he enshrined the principle of the leak. He con-

Speaker: NA
Text: firmed it on 17 November 1976 in this Parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is incitement for this sort of thing to hap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pen. I do not believe that the best interests of this

Speaker: NA
Text: country are served when there are leaks which

Speaker: NA
Text: take place on classified matters and which can be

Speaker: NA
Text: to the disadvantage of the national interest. I

Speaker: NA
Text: make that as a general statement, and I suggest

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Leader of the Opposition could perhaps

Speaker: NA
Text: soberly apply himself to this matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: If he asserts the principle that, in specific terms,

Speaker: NA
Text: leakage through the media of data on the strategic

Speaker: NA
Text: basis paper undermines the confidence of other

Speaker: NA
Text: countries in this country's foreign policy and de-

Speaker: NA
Text: fence policy, that it creates confusion, that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: disastrous, that the Government itself is recreant

Speaker: NA
Text: and culpable, let me remind him that under the

Speaker: NA
Text: Fraser Government, when he was a senior Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter, the 1975 and the 1976 strategic basis papers

Speaker: NA
Text: were leaked, and they were leaked through the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Times. That newspaper has a remark-

Speaker: NA
Text: able record-but gained under the previous

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. In 1980, documents on Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: defence and foreign policy for the period 1968 to

Speaker: NA
Text: 1975, in all their sensational detail, were

Speaker: NA
Text: published in a book. The Government, of which

Speaker: NA
Text: he was a senior member, had to take court action

Speaker: NA
Text: to prohibit the circulation of that publication. So

Speaker: NA
Text: there is nothing novel in it. What the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition is trying to do, confronted by his

Speaker: NA
Text: own sagging standing as Leader of the Opposition,

Speaker: NA
Text: both in the community before the eyes of the pub-

Speaker: NA
Text: lic and in his own organisation, is to resort to this

Speaker: NA
Text: rather unpersuasive tactic.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me deal quickly with the matter of defence.

Speaker: NA
Text: The fact is that the Government in which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition and the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Party were senior Ministers increased its

Speaker: NA
Text: spending on defence by an average of 2.5 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: in real terms throughout its disastrous seven years

Speaker: NA
Text: in office. Yet they are lecturing us and saying that

Speaker: NA
Text: we have not done enough, that we have a deplor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able set of conditions in defence in the country

Speaker: NA
Text: today. In our first Budget, we increased defence

Speaker: NA
Text: spending by 4.1 per cent in real terms. They say

Speaker: NA
Text: that we are not doing enough. We are not doing

Speaker: NA
Text: enough? We have just about doubled their real

Speaker: NA
Text: effort.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me put a new focus on the same set of cir-

Speaker: NA
Text: cumstances. The Leader of the National Party,

Speaker: NA
Text: preoccupied with appearing before courts or royal

Speaker: NA
Text: commissions, or defending his integrity-the last

Speaker: NA
Text: does not take long because there is not much of

Speaker: NA
Text: that left-was responsible for actually slashing

Speaker: NA
Text: defence spending by 1.7 per cent in real terms. We

Speaker: NA
Text: increased it by more than 4 per cent and he

Speaker: NA
Text: slashed it by nearly 2 per cent in real terms. In

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of opening up, developing, expanding de-

Speaker: NA
Text: fence spending, our effort was positively three

Speaker: NA
Text: times greater than his was. He was putting things

Speaker: NA
Text: into reverse gear and we are putting them into

Speaker: NA
Text: drive gear. Not only are we increasing defence

Speaker: NA
Text: spending; we are increasing it at a much faster

Speaker: NA
Text: rate.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members opposite ought not, in

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition, to resort to these miserable debating

Speaker: NA
Text: misrepresentations, as today the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Party has sought to do, complaining that

Speaker: NA
Text: defence forward capital programs were slashed by

Speaker: NA
Text: $160m in the last Budget. The slashing, as he de-

Speaker: NA
Text: scribed it, was from the notorious forward esti-

Speaker: NA
Text: mates of expenditure for 1983-84, which the pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: vious Government, from evidence I have

Speaker: NA
Text: available to me, intended to bury after the last

Speaker: NA
Text: election had the country suffered the misfortune

Speaker: NA
Text: of the coalition being re-elected. That is what they

Speaker: NA
Text: are about-a confidence trick from Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: leading confidence man in public life, the right

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for New England ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Sinclair). Let us go on. If they are arguing that

Speaker: NA
Text: that $160m ought to be restored, they are arguing

Speaker: NA
Text: for an increase of more then 7 per cent in real

Speaker: NA
Text: terms in defence spending. We increased it by

Speaker: NA
Text: more than 4 per cent; they are saying that it ought

Speaker: NA
Text: to be increased by more then 7 per cent. Yet the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the National Party slashed defence

Speaker: NA
Text: spending by nearly 2 per cent in the period in

Speaker: NA
Text: which he was Defence Minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us put in clear context

Speaker: NA
Text: the right honourable member for New England on

Speaker: NA
Text: the issue of defence. He talked about forward

Speaker: NA
Text: programs. We have seen them. We saw several of

Speaker: NA
Text: them when the Opposition was in government.

Speaker: NA
Text: They were empty promises, grand in their descrip-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and empty when it came to fulfilment. We

Speaker: NA
Text: saw the 1976 White Paper, which fell apart within

Speaker: NA
Text: about 18 months-in fact, it fell apart this way.

Speaker: NA
Text: The five-year defence program proposed a sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: stantial increase in spending. At the end of that

Speaker: NA
Text: five-year term some $3,OOOm of expenditure had

Speaker: NA
Text: been deferred. This Government is seeking to

Speaker: NA
Text: undertake a number of new spending commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments in defence, including spending on capital

Speaker: NA
Text: equipment. There is a very large accumulation of

Speaker: NA
Text: capital equipment spending obligations, some

Speaker: NA
Text: already in the pipeline and others unavoidable,

Speaker: NA
Text: which necessarily will have to be taken on in the

Speaker: NA
Text: future.

Speaker: NA
Text: This large bunching of capital spending was

Speaker: NA
Text: solely contributed to by the recklessness of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition when in government, a matter I have

Speaker: NA
Text: pointed out on many occasions. The previous

Speaker: NA
Text: Government deferred again and again important

Speaker: NA
Text: defence spending programs. The right honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for New England slashed the last defence

Speaker: NA
Text: budget. We are now in the business of trying to

Speaker: NA
Text: catch up the lost ground and establish an ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: equate and credible defence capability for this

Speaker: NA
Text: country.

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER ( Mrs Child)-

Speaker: NA
Text: Order! The Minister's time has expired.

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Text: New England-Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Party of Australia) (3.32)-It used to be

Speaker: NA
Text: said that there were three kinds of lies: Lies,

Speaker: NA
Text: damned lies and statistics. To modify that adage a

Speaker: NA
Text: little, we now know that there are liars, damned

Speaker: NA
Text: liars and the Minister for Foreign Affairs ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Hayden). Madam Deputy Speaker--

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Text: Madam Deputy Speaker, I take

Speaker: NA
Text: a point of order. I object very strongly to the right

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for New England associating

Speaker: NA
Text: me with those remarks.

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER-Order! Is the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister asking for a withdrawal?

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Text: Yes.

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Text: After the things the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: has said about me I think that is very mild indeed.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are false and he knows it. I believe--

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER-I ask the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the National Party to withdraw his

Speaker: NA
Text: the grand illusions of comments.

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Text: Madam Deputy Speaker, I

Speaker: NA
Text: withdraw them. I believe it is necessary for

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable members to remember that today the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: West) has been returned to Cabinet. All people in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia will be interested to know that the high

Speaker: NA
Text: principle on which he withdrew from the inner

Speaker: NA
Text: Cabinet to the outer Ministry was his disagree-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment with the principle that the Government was

Speaker: NA
Text: adopting in allowing Roxby Downs to go ahead.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members will remember that selec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive uranium export policy. We learned then that

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the outer Ministry do not need to sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: scribe to the policies of government. Today we

Speaker: NA
Text: have learnt that it is necessary for the--

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Chynoweth-Madam Deputy Speaker, I

Speaker: NA
Text: take a point of order. This has nothing to do with

Speaker: NA
Text: the debate.

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER-I suggest that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the National Party is leading up to

Speaker: NA
Text: his argument.

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Text: Madam Deputy Speaker, I

Speaker: NA
Text: assure you that it is very central to the target, that

Speaker: NA
Text: is, that this Government cannot be trusted. If

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable members care to look at the terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: the matter of public importance they will see that

Speaker: NA
Text: it states:

Speaker: NA
Text: The concern and confusion created by the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's defence and foreign affairs policies, as highlighted

Speaker: NA
Text: by the leaking of the Strategic Basis Paper.

Speaker: NA
Text: The strategic basis paper relates, inter alia, to the

Speaker: NA
Text: question of whether there should be a develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of a nuclear capability in Australia. The

Speaker: NA
Text: hypocrisy of the Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke) and

Speaker: NA
Text: his Ministers cannot be better illustrated than by

Speaker: NA
Text: the fact that they are prepared to have within

Speaker: NA
Text: their ranks one who says that he disagrees, at least

Speaker: NA
Text: in private, within the left wing of the Party on the

Speaker: NA
Text: question of uranium exports, yet he is prepared to

Speaker: NA
Text: accept, as he now has, a strategic basis paper that

Speaker: NA
Text: foreshadows the development in some circum-

Speaker: NA
Text: stances of a nuclear capability by Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: Only last week we heard Cliff Dolan of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Council of Trade Unions ten us that it

Speaker: NA
Text: was the Minister for Resources and Energy

Speaker: NA
Text: (Senator Walsh) who released that document on

Speaker: NA
Text: uranium exports. We an know that leaks are very

Speaker: NA
Text: common within some parts of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party. One can only suspect that it was a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of the left wing of the Cabinet who

Speaker: NA
Text: leaked the strategic basis paper. But, of course,

Speaker: NA
Text: one cannot expect national security to be

Speaker: NA
Text: regarded very highly in a Cabinet that includes in

Speaker: NA
Text: its number a Special Minister of State who, in a

Speaker: NA
Text: rather memorable discussion in a car park, was

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared to breach national security.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us go back to the comments that were made

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Foreign Minister. He suggested that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Chief of Defence Force Staff, Air Chief Marshal

Speaker: NA
Text: MCNamara, in a statement today did not auth-

Speaker: NA
Text: enticate the strategic basis paper. The Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Associated Press bulletin that was issued earlier

Speaker: NA
Text: today states:

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's Defence supremo Air Chief Marshal Sir

Speaker: NA
Text: Neville MCNamara today authenticated the leaked secret

Speaker: NA
Text: defence strategy papers published last week but stressed

Speaker: NA
Text: they did not represent government policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know that, nonetheless, they were endorsed

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Government. The Prime Minister has ack-

Speaker: NA
Text: nowledged that they were there for the guidance

Speaker: NA
Text: of government policy in defence.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians have been let down badly by this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government in defence and foreign affairs. We an

Speaker: NA
Text: know the confusion between the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: public position and its private stance. Regret-

Speaker: NA
Text: tably, time after time, particularly in defence mat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ters, the Government has shown its total and utter

Speaker: NA
Text: ineptitude. Time and again it has shown that, even

Speaker: NA
Text: when it does act, it does so in ignorance, haste and

Speaker: NA
Text: confusion. We have a Minister for Defence who

Speaker: NA
Text: behaves like a cross between a Zen Buddhist and a

Speaker: NA
Text: slapstick comedian. Most of the time he sits in his

Speaker: NA
Text: office contemplating his navel. If he decided to go

Speaker: NA
Text: to sea, he would find that there was no fuel for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Royal Australian Navy. When disturbed by a loud

Speaker: NA
Text: noise he jumps up and promptly fans over one of

Speaker: NA
Text: the stock of banana skins he apparently keeps for

Speaker: NA
Text: the purpose. The view of the Opposition and the

Speaker: NA
Text: defence community of the performance of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Defence ( Mr Scholes) and, indeed,

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Government can be summed up in the

Speaker: NA
Text: words of the dangling rigger to his mate in the

Speaker: NA
Text: famous Bulletin cartoon: 'For God's sake stop

Speaker: NA
Text: laughing, this is serious'. This Government and

Speaker: NA
Text: this Minister for Defence have run down

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's defences close to desperation point.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tragicany, it has come at a time when the stra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tegic basis document illustrates that Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot afford that to happen. We were told last

Speaker: NA
Text: week in the debate on a matter of public import-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance and in a censure motion: There is no fuel for

Speaker: NA
Text: ships, no bunets for rifles, no boots for soldiers

Speaker: NA
Text: and no money for reserves. Those circumstances

Speaker: NA
Text: occurred over the last 12 months. There should be

Speaker: NA
Text: none of this business of blaming the previous

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. Those circumstances are an as a

Speaker: NA
Text: consequence of this Government not being pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared to meet both forward, necessary capital

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure and the necessary running and main-

Speaker: NA
Text: tenance costs of the Australian defence forces.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government's total failure in defence was

Speaker: NA
Text: speJt out coldly and objectively in the testimony

Speaker: NA
Text: of members of the Department of Defence to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence Sub-Committee of the Joint Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: on Foreign Affairs and Defence on 20 March.

Speaker: NA
Text: That submission stated that Australia was in-

Speaker: NA
Text: capable of supporting any sustained combat in-

Speaker: NA
Text: volvement. The submission spelt out the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's failure to respond to the circumstances, of

Speaker: NA
Text: which it was aware in September last year, when

Speaker: NA
Text: it endorsed the strategic basis document. In Sep-

Speaker: NA
Text: tember the Government endorsed that document

Speaker: NA
Text: which stated:

Speaker: NA
Text: While working to maximise the prospect of U.S. sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port in any national defence emergency, Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: governments have . . . required clear priority to be

Speaker: NA
Text: given to the development of capacity to conduct and sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port military operations for the independent defence of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Yet this Government provides no money for

Speaker: NA
Text: training, no money for ships to sail, and little

Speaker: NA
Text: money for aircraft to fly. Six months later, a docu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment was released to the Joint Committee which

Speaker: NA
Text: stated that low reserve stocks of ammunition,

Speaker: NA
Text: weapons and spare parts meant that only low

Speaker: NA
Text: level operations by our defence forces could be

Speaker: NA
Text: sustained. Those measures should have been cor-

Speaker: NA
Text: rected in this year's Budget; they are not old mat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ters. It is not a matter of developing new capa-

Speaker: NA
Text: bility; it is a matter of providing the sinews of

Speaker: NA
Text: survival and present capability to the Services.

Speaker: NA
Text: Funds should have been allocated for that

Speaker: NA
Text: purpose.

Speaker: NA
Text: The AAP bulletin also states in respect of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Chief of Defence Force Staff:

Speaker: NA
Text: His major concern on retiring . . . was that

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia lacked adequate controls over its air space,

Speaker: NA
Text: although he accepted that budget constraints ruled out

Speaker: NA
Text: funding for airborne radar aircraft for the RAAF.

Speaker: NA
Text: Yet we know that Singapore is acquiring three

Speaker: NA
Text: Grumman E2C Tracker aircraft at a cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: $USI50m. We will have a position in which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian defence forces, under this Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, are run below the capability of our

Speaker: NA
Text: near Association of South East Asian Nations

Speaker: NA
Text: neighbour.

Speaker: NA
Text: There can be no doubt about the spirit of our expired.

Speaker: NA
Text: defence forces, their dedication or their ability to

Speaker: NA
Text: perform. What they need is a government that is

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared to give them the opportunity to do so.

Speaker: NA
Text: The language of the strategic assessment docurelevance

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is clear and unequivocal. Yet, six months

Speaker: NA
Text: after endorsing that document, the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence stood up, without a trace of shame, and

Speaker: NA
Text: admitted that nothing was being done. His conbombast,

Speaker: NA
Text: fession last week was one of failure. The biggest

Speaker: NA
Text: concern that we have is that, in order to meet

Speaker: NA
Text: ward capital procurement commitments that we

Speaker: NA
Text: entered into, this Government is today prepared

Speaker: NA
Text: to let day to day defence capabilities run down.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Foreign Minister has just made a great to-do

Speaker: NA
Text: about the consequence of that $160m cut in forcation

Speaker: NA
Text: ward capital funds. The reason the former

Speaker: NA
Text: Government committed itself forward was that

Speaker: NA
Text: was absolutely essential to upgrade the Defence

Speaker: NA
Text: Force. But in the level of funds for training for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Services themselves, we ensured that we provided

Speaker: NA
Text: funds so that the sharp end of the Services was not

Speaker: NA
Text: prejudiced. It is in that area that this Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has failed miserably.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have no criticisms of the strategic basis docu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. It is a sober, realistic appraisal of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's strengths and weaknesses. The fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that this document was published was a serious se-

Speaker: NA
Text: curity breach. What is possibly worse was the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's reaction. The document was

Speaker: NA
Text: endorsed by Cabinet in September. Cabinet

Speaker: NA
Text: members might have been euphoric in the after-

Speaker: NA
Text: math of the America's Cup, but they are supposed

Speaker: NA
Text: to be able to read. Yet when the document they

Speaker: NA
Text: endorsed was published it was immediately disowone

Speaker: NA
Text: ned. The Government's media corps tried to per-

Speaker: NA
Text: suade other newspapers that it was not important.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister for Defence and the Attorneygovernment.

Speaker: NA
Text: General (Senator Gareth Evans) said it was only

Speaker: NA
Text: for guidance. Yet the Prime Minister authenticularly

Speaker: NA
Text: ticated it and so too did the Chief of Defence

Speaker: NA
Text: Force Staff today.

Speaker: NA
Text: The important aspect of the document is that it

Speaker: NA
Text: has highlighted the concern Australia should have

Speaker: NA
Text: for the conditions we face today, the concern the

Speaker: NA
Text: people need to have in the application of our

Speaker: NA
Text: foreign policy under this Minister. In the appli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation of our defence policy under the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Defence there is a serious run-down which will

Speaker: NA
Text: prejudice our ability to meet the strategic situa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion which that authenticated document ident-

Speaker: NA
Text: ified. It is not sufficient for this Government to

Speaker: NA
Text: come out with rhetoric and say it does not matter,

Speaker: NA
Text: to blame it on the past. The responsibility is the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's and it should meet it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER ( Mrs Child)-

Speaker: NA
Text: Order! The right honourable member's time has

Speaker: Mr BILNEY
Text: Kingston) (3.42)-People who

Speaker: NA
Text: have listened to this debate would be in no doubt

Speaker: NA
Text: about why the Opposition has become of such ir-

Speaker: NA
Text: in this debate, in matters of defence, in

Speaker: NA
Text: matters of foreign policy and in any other import-

Speaker: NA
Text: for ant issue. Members of the Opposition have

Speaker: NA
Text: treated us to a display of windy rhetoric, of empty

Speaker: NA
Text: of unconstructive irrelevance, which is

Speaker: NA
Text: all of a piece with the attempts they have made

Speaker: NA
Text: forsince we came to government to stir up trouble

Speaker: NA
Text: with our neighbours and to trivialise some import-

Speaker: NA
Text: ant issues. It would be pathetic if it were not such

Speaker: NA
Text: a serious issue. No one knows as well as honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members on this side of the House the dedi-

Speaker: NA
Text: of people in the defence forces and in the

Speaker: NA
Text: foreign service. This kind of performance lets

Speaker: NA
Text: it those people down and lets Australia down.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Opposition, when in government, had the

Speaker: NA
Text: most extraordinary record on defence matters. It

Speaker: NA
Text: treated us first of all to the great debate between

Speaker: NA
Text: forward defence and fortress Australia. This was

Speaker: NA
Text: . put forward by such wonderful proponents as

Speaker: NA
Text: William MCMahon and John Gorton, who

Speaker: NA
Text: engaged in a debate which was as irrelevant as

Speaker: NA
Text: anything that has been said today by either the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the National Party ( Mr Sinclair) or the

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: position, when in government, gave us the great

Speaker: NA
Text: debate about Vietnam. One of the major issues

Speaker: NA
Text: was which group of people-not themselves-

Speaker: NA
Text: they would ballot to send to fight in a war that

Speaker: NA
Text: fitted in with a particular strategic preconception,

Speaker: NA
Text: which, to its eternal credit, the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party never shared and from which it

Speaker: NA
Text: extricated us as soon as it last came into

Speaker: NA
Text: This is the Opposition which gave us the par-

Speaker: NA
Text: instructive debate about Pol Pot. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: sure the Leader of the Opposition would not wish

Speaker: NA
Text: me to remind him of the reason why he ostensibly

Speaker: NA
Text: resigned from the Government, but it was over a

Speaker: NA
Text: question of strategic and foreign policy, that is,

Speaker: NA
Text: whether the Government of which he was then

Speaker: NA
Text: part should support the butcher of Kampuchea or

Speaker: NA
Text: not. It is to his credit that he resigned. It is perhaps

Speaker: NA
Text: to his discredit that he goes on with the nonsense

Speaker: NA
Text: he has given us today. Finally, in the field of stra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tegic and defence policy, this Opposition in

Speaker: NA
Text: government actually predicted the date of World

Speaker: NA
Text: War III. I have in front of me an extract from the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Times, believe it or not, of 22 June 1980

Speaker: NA
Text: entitled: 'World War III: PM names the day-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr ChynowethWho was that?

Speaker: Mr BILNEY
Text: This is Prime Minister Fraser.

Speaker: NA
Text: It reads:

Speaker: NA
Text: The Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser, told the II

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the Australian Olympic Federation last

Speaker: NA
Text: Thursday that he believed there would be a world war in

Speaker: NA
Text: three years' time.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Prime Minister's warning followed a'long discourse

Speaker: NA
Text: in which he described Soviet moves into Afghanistan, its

Speaker: NA
Text: involvement in Vietnam, the Vietnamese invasion of

Speaker: NA
Text: Kampuchea and Soviet involvement in the Horn of Africa

Speaker: NA
Text: and Yemen.

Speaker: NA
Text: At one stage Fraser predicted World war in the 1980s.

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Prime Minister, Doug Anthony interjected: 'It

Speaker: NA
Text: could be sooner.' Fraser subsequently gave the three-year

Speaker: NA
Text: deadline.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is the record of the previous Government. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is like Madam Zara in the circus tent looking at

Speaker: NA
Text: the lines on one's hands. That is approximately

Speaker: NA
Text: the standard of crystal ball gazing on the question

Speaker: NA
Text: of defence and strategic assessment we came to

Speaker: NA
Text: expect from Opposition members when they were

Speaker: NA
Text: in government.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have heard it said by members of the Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition on three or four or probably 19 occasions in

Speaker: NA
Text: the debate that this paper is supposedly authen-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticated. They have quoted at some length from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Chief of Defence Force Staff, who they say

Speaker: NA
Text: said that this morning. Here is what he actually

Speaker: NA
Text: said. He was asked by a reporter in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: these documents:

Speaker: NA
Text: Are you prepared to publicly endorse those views?

Speaker: NA
Text: He replied:

Speaker: NA
Text: I was on the Defence Committee which considered the

Speaker: NA
Text: strategic basis paper and therefore at least on a consensus

Speaker: NA
Text: basis I have to acknowledge that I was party to those

Speaker: NA
Text: decisions.

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Text: Who was that?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr BILNEYThis is the Chief of Defence

Speaker: NA
Text: Force Staff. If that is an endorsement of the auth-

Speaker: NA
Text: enticity then I am King Kong. The Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence goes on to say that the transcript of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Press conference reveals nothing to suggest that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Chief of Defence Force Staff has either con-

Speaker: NA
Text: firmed or denied the authenticity of those papers.

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Text: The right honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for New England is forging again.

Speaker: Mr BILNEY
Text: As the Minister says, it would

Speaker: NA
Text: not be the first occasion on which the right

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for New England ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Sinclair) has forged something.

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Text: Madam Deputy Speaker, I raise

Speaker: NA
Text: a point of order. I ask that the honourable gentle-

Speaker: NA
Text: man withdraw that remark. I take strong excep-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to it.

Speaker: Mr BILNEY
Text: I withdraw. This is, after all,

Speaker: NA
Text: the person who, when Minister for Defence,

Speaker: NA
Text: thought that the best way of defending Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: was to buy the Invincible. That would have invol-

Speaker: NA
Text: ved an expenditure of something like

Speaker: NA
Text: $1,400m-in fact, a straight transfer out of the

Speaker: NA
Text: country which would not have created one job in

Speaker: NA
Text: this country. It is to this Government's credit that

Speaker: NA
Text: it has adopted a very different defence policy

Speaker: NA
Text: which involves using Australian skills and Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian resources to build Australian ships in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country in a way that defends us far better.

Speaker: NA
Text: Turning to the paper itself, I must say that I

Speaker: NA
Text: have had a certain amount of personal experience

Speaker: NA
Text: with the drafting of strategic basis papers. My

Speaker: NA
Text: reaction is extremely similar to that of Peter

Speaker: NA
Text: Robinson which was reflected in his column en-

Speaker: NA
Text: titled 'Candid Comment'. He stated:

Speaker: NA
Text: The most amazing thing about the so-called leak of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's Strategic Basis papers last week is that

Speaker: NA
Text: there seems to be some attempt to treat it with old-

Speaker: NA
Text: fashioned shock and horror.

Speaker: NA
Text: It was difficult to avoid doubling up with laughter when

Speaker: NA
Text: that well-known politician of wide-ranging probity Mr Ian

Speaker: NA
Text: Sinclair began talking about a 'massive security' breach.

Speaker: NA
Text: If Mr Sinclair thinks he can make political capital out

Speaker: NA
Text: of it, then normal people can probably reject the whole

Speaker: NA
Text: thing as being of monumental insignificance.

Speaker: NA
Text: He went on to say:

Speaker: NA
Text: The extracts from the Strategic Basis published last

Speaker: NA
Text: week are not reassuring in the sense that they probably

Speaker: NA
Text: took months of highly paid bureaucratic time to prepare,

Speaker: NA
Text: but could equally have been written by any competent

Speaker: NA
Text: journalist in a week or two.

Speaker: NA
Text: That accords with my own experience of drafting

Speaker: NA
Text: strategic basis papers. They very rarely have any-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing to do with what the government does. They

Speaker: NA
Text: have to be specifically endorsed, and in detail, by

Speaker: NA
Text: the government before they become a document

Speaker: NA
Text: of any use or relevance to anything that happens

Speaker: NA
Text: in the real world. The one sentence that has been

Speaker: NA
Text: authenticated was that which the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: quoted yesterday and which related to the nuclear

Speaker: NA
Text: weapons issue. He asked the House to take notice

Speaker: NA
Text: of this sen tence:

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's interests continue to be served by adherence

Speaker: NA
Text: to, and support for wider acceptance of. the Treaty on

Speaker: NA
Text: Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons and for strength-

Speaker: NA
Text: ening nuclear safeguards measures generally.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is the one sentence which did not appear in

Speaker: NA
Text: the account that was published in the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Times. It is interesting that the Opposition-

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly the Leader of the National Party of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia-should raise the question of leaks. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Foreign Affairs ( Mr Hayden) has

Speaker: NA
Text: already quoted from that well known beneficiary

Speaker: NA
Text: of leaks, the former Prime Minister. On 21 May

Speaker: NA
Text: 1981 the right honourable member for New

Speaker: NA
Text: England said this:

Speaker: NA
Text: It's obviously very true . . . that in Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: you're very dependent on the public servant who is going

Speaker: NA
Text: to give you a little bit of insight into matters that are not

Speaker: NA
Text: otherwise freely available. I've tried in what I've said to

Speaker: NA
Text: suggest that all leaks are not bad but that some leaks are

Speaker: NA
Text: certainly very bad. The difficulty is to try and define the

Speaker: NA
Text: difference, and I suspect that in Opposition most leaks are

Speaker: NA
Text: good.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is of no surprise then that there is this breast

Speaker: NA
Text: beating about the dreadfulness of leaks when, as

Speaker: NA
Text: we all know, the record of the previous Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, so far as leaks were concerned, was absol-

Speaker: NA
Text: utely horrifying. It is not surprising to me that per-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission was refused a previous speaker in this

Speaker: NA
Text: debate to table the list of leaks. I will read from

Speaker: NA
Text: the list, which is quite instructive. It states:

Speaker: NA
Text: CIA cable to ASIO leaked on February 1976--

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER-Order! The

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member's time has expired. The dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: cussion is concluded.

Speaker: NA
Text: PERSONAL EXPLANATION

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER ( Mrs Child)-

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister for Aviation has sought the indul-

Speaker: NA
Text: gence of the Chair to make a personal expla-

Speaker: NA
Text: nation. Does the Minister claim to have been

Speaker: NA
Text: misrepresented?

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Text: Swan-Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Aviation)-Yes, Madam Deputy Speaker. I was

Speaker: NA
Text: misrepresented by the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: North Sydney ( Mr Spender) a few moments ago

Speaker: NA
Text: when he claimed that the decisions we had under-

Speaker: NA
Text: taken on the development of a taxiway system at

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport were as a re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sult of decisions taken and announced by the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Farrer ( Mr Fife), the

Speaker: NA
Text: former Minister for Aviation. That is not the case.

Speaker: NA
Text: The previous Government's policy on the devel-

Speaker: NA
Text: opments at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport

Speaker: NA
Text: did not contain such a package. I developed that

Speaker: NA
Text: package in connection with the new policy pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posals that were brought forward in the last

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget session and following upon our decision

Speaker: NA
Text: not to proceed with the creation of the third run-

Speaker: NA
Text: way at Sydney Airport. It was a new package de-

Speaker: NA
Text: veloped by us to improve movement at Sydney

Speaker: NA
Text: Airport.

Speaker: NA
Text: BILLS RETURNED FROM THE SENATE

Speaker: NA
Text: The following Bills were returned from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate without amendment or requests:

Speaker: NA
Text: Health Insurance Amendment Bill 1984

Speaker: NA
Text: Advance Australia Logo Protection Bill 1984

Speaker: NA
Text: JUDICIARY AMENDMENT BILL (No.2)

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill received from the Senate, and read a" first

Speaker: NA
Text: time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ordered that the second reading be made an

Speaker: NA
Text: order of the day for a later hour this day.

Speaker: NA
Text: FEDERAL COURT OF AUSTRALIA

Speaker: NA
Text: AMENDMENT BILL 1984

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first

Speaker: NA
Text: time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ordered that the second reading be made an

Speaker: NA
Text: order of the day for a later hour this day.

Speaker: NA
Text: AUSTRALIAN GOVERNMENT

Speaker: NA
Text: SOLICITOR (CONSEQUENTIAL

Speaker: NA
Text: AMENDMENTS) BILL 1984

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first

Speaker: NA
Text: time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ordered that the second reading be made an

Speaker: NA
Text: order of the day for a later hour this day.

Speaker: NA
Text: ACTS INTERPRETATION AMENDMENT

Speaker: NA
Text: BILL 1984

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first

Speaker: NA
Text: time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ordered that the second reading be made an

Speaker: NA
Text: order of the day for a later hour this day.

Speaker: NA
Text: APPROPRIATION BILL (No.3) 1983-84

Speaker: NA
Text: [COGNATE BILLS:

Speaker: NA
Text: APPROPRIATION BILL (No.4) 1983-84

Speaker: NA
Text: APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY

Speaker: NA
Text: DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No.2) 1983-84]

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed from 30 March, on motion by

Speaker: NA
Text: MrDawkins:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Text: Oxley-Minister for Foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs)-Madam Deputy Speaker, may I have

Speaker: NA
Text: your indulgence to suggest that the House have a

Speaker: NA
Text: general debate covering this Bill, appropriation

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill (No.4) 1983-84 and the Appropriation (Par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liamentary Departments) Bill (No.2) 1983-84 as

Speaker: NA
Text: they are associated measures. Separate questions

Speaker: NA
Text: will, of course, be put on each of the Bills at the

Speaker: NA
Text: conclusion of the debate.

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER ( Mrs

Speaker: NA
Text: Child)-Is it the wish of the House to have a gen-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral debate covering the three measures? There

Speaker: NA
Text: being no objection, I will allow that course will

Speaker: NA
Text: followed.

Speaker: Mr MOORE
Text: Ryan)(3.57)-These three Bills

Speaker: NA
Text: allow Parliament to speak on a wide-ranging

Speaker: NA
Text: number of subjects which affect the economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: They give us the opportunity to discuss here today

Speaker: NA
Text: the performance of the Government in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: economic matters, not foreign affairs. I hope all

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable members will participate and make

Speaker: NA
Text: known their views of the first year of the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. In looking at the economy today

Speaker: NA
Text: and the general beat-up that has been given in re-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation to economic performance, we have to ana-

Speaker: NA
Text: lyse precisely what has occurred. We have seen a

Speaker: NA
Text: quite dramatic turnaround in the rural sector,

Speaker: NA
Text: brought about by the change from the severest

Speaker: NA
Text: drought for many years to one of the best seasons

Speaker: NA
Text: for many years. As a consequence we have seen

Speaker: NA
Text: demand in areas such as restocking and machin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ery, which has flowed on to the general economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: On top of that we have had a very significant

Speaker: NA
Text: push in housing. The number of commencements

Speaker: NA
Text: has gone from 110,000 to 125,000 units. We now

Speaker: NA
Text: hear optimistic talk of the number of commence-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments heading towards 140,000 units. That in

Speaker: NA
Text: itself will bring out and point to a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: of congestion which will result in a wage push and

Speaker: NA
Text: cost price increase of the building industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: Already price increases in the order of 15 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: have been effected in certain material sectors of

Speaker: NA
Text: the building industry. This has really been a

Speaker: NA
Text: catch-up position as the building sector has not

Speaker: NA
Text: been able to obtain a profit margin for many

Speaker: NA
Text: years. The much improved conditions of trading

Speaker: NA
Text: in that area have added to the price structure and

Speaker: NA
Text: I forecast more increases in the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: The third prong of the government-led recov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ery has been the continuation of sizable govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment deficits. There is no doubt that the level of

Speaker: NA
Text: government spending has been a significant factor

Speaker: NA
Text: in the appearance of an economy which gives the

Speaker: NA
Text: impression of being in reasonable shape. Apart

Speaker: NA
Text: from those three prongs-the rural sector, the

Speaker: NA
Text: housing recovery and government spending-one

Speaker: NA
Text: would have to regard the current scene as patchy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Very few in the economic or financial world

Speaker: NA
Text: would make any other assessment. Because of

Speaker: NA
Text: that we have to assess the likely impact of these

Speaker: NA
Text: factors.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is interesting to note that the Treasurer ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Keating) even admitted at a meeting of the Econ-

Speaker: NA
Text: omic Planning Advisory Council recently that the

Speaker: NA
Text: recovery was not guaranteed. In a report to

Speaker: NA
Text: EPAC on economic conditions and prospects he

Speaker: NA
Text: said that to achieve a sustained recovery the econ-

Speaker: NA
Text: omy needed business investment to replace the

Speaker: NA
Text: be 'temporary influences which are operating at the

Speaker: NA
Text: moment'. That is quite some statement by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer. About a week later, during the New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales election campaign, he was quick to

Speaker: NA
Text: change course on that. But I have no doubt that,

Speaker: NA
Text: given the flexibility applied by the Government,

Speaker: NA
Text: he will be back on that tack when he approaches

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget considerations, because it must be causing

Speaker: NA
Text: concern in informed areas.

Speaker: NA
Text: Despite all these circumstances, there is no

Speaker: NA
Text: doubt that consumer confidence has vastly

Speaker: NA
Text: improved. This is borne out by the profit perform-

Speaker: NA
Text: ances of the major retailing chains in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: and by statistical services, particularly, going be-

Speaker: NA
Text: yond the area of corporate profitability, the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Bureau of Statistics. To add to that, to the

Speaker: NA
Text: half-year to 31 December corporate profits,

Speaker: NA
Text: which were reported on by the end of March, gen-

Speaker: NA
Text: erally reflected an improvement. The perform-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance of certain industries-those in the manufac-

Speaker: NA
Text: turing area in particular-was dismal. Those

Speaker: NA
Text: industries missed the bus. But the areas associated

Speaker: NA
Text: with the rural sector, finance and housing have all

Speaker: NA
Text: experienced substantial improvement. In my

Speaker: NA
Text: view, those improvements in profitability will

Speaker: NA
Text: continue right through to 30 June and probably to

Speaker: NA
Text: areas the end of calendar year 1984 will be used to

Speaker: NA
Text: heighten expectations.

Speaker: NA
Text: The fact is that we are very evenly balanced be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween a continued growth pattern and a conver-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion to stagflation. The general areas of concern

Speaker: NA
Text: are mounting. There are pressures on the wages

Speaker: NA
Text: accord. There are claims outside the general

Speaker: NA
Text: ambit of the accord. There are pressures on prices.

Speaker: NA
Text: Corporations are upping margins at present in

Speaker: NA
Text: view of better economic trading. All these matters

Speaker: NA
Text: must be of concern for 1985. There is little in the

Speaker: NA
Text: way of capital reinvestment. Few firms have

Speaker: NA
Text: increased their capacity. Until fairly recent times

Speaker: NA
Text: capacity usage certainly had not passed the magi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal level of 85 per cent within industry. Those

Speaker: NA
Text: firms which have approached those levels-as I

Speaker: NA
Text: said, only recently-have deferred any significant

Speaker: NA
Text: increase in private capital investment because

Speaker: NA
Text: they are concerned about whether, in the 1985-86

Speaker: NA
Text: period, profitability and the prices and incomes

Speaker: NA
Text: accord can be maintained, the latter on which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Governmentplaces so much reliance.

Speaker: NA
Text: The encouragement of the private sector by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Government is new-found. I remember one

Speaker: NA
Text: of its honourable members from Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia saying that he represented the private

Speaker: NA
Text: sector. I found that quite incredible. Nevertheless,

Speaker: NA
Text: this new-found love for the private sector will be

Speaker: NA
Text: tested by the disbelief of industry in its long term

Speaker: NA
Text: prospects. Only a week or so ago the mining sector

Speaker: NA
Text: indicated in a speech that it could see no reason

Speaker: NA
Text: for any substantial capital investment in the fore-

Speaker: NA
Text: seeable future, that world metal prices were not

Speaker: NA
Text: sufficient to meet the huge capital costs which

Speaker: NA
Text: were required for any further development, that

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure development in Australia had been

Speaker: NA
Text: such in the last four years as to signal a very sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: stantial fall in that area in the coming period.

Speaker: NA
Text: That fall would be such that any improvement in

Speaker: NA
Text: the private housing sector would certainly be

Speaker: NA
Text: offset by the falls in the commercial building area.

Speaker: NA
Text: These matters must be causing concern to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the same time we have seen the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: continue with the third leg of its improvement,

Speaker: NA
Text: government deficits. A very great sales job was

Speaker: NA
Text: done on the business world last year by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government to sell a deficit of over $8 billion.

Speaker: NA
Text: This year we have had a general beat-around for

Speaker: NA
Text: the acceptance of a deficit of $7.5 billion which

Speaker: NA
Text: seems to be the general norm pushed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. As a background to that, we have

Speaker: NA
Text: seen the performance in the money market in

Speaker: NA
Text: which very substantial amounts. of money have

Speaker: NA
Text: been raised to cover the deficit in terms of both

Speaker: NA
Text: the direct funding of the Government's Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: and the funding of semi-government borrowings,

Speaker: NA
Text: both through the States and through the shire

Speaker: NA
Text: councils. You will recall, Madam Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, the recent decision of the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: to continue to expand that area so that more

Speaker: NA
Text: money can be borrowed outside the control of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Federal Government. So in that way the area of

Speaker: NA
Text: debt will be expanded significantly in regard to

Speaker: NA
Text: the States. Given the style of management that

Speaker: NA
Text: the States have put up over the last few years,

Speaker: NA
Text: there is little wonder that sections of the financial

Speaker: NA
Text: world are concerned about the future of govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment debt.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is worth spending a few minutes on saying

Speaker: NA
Text: that approximately half the deficit is now going

Speaker: NA
Text: towards meeting interest payments on debts. With

Speaker: NA
Text: the prospect of yet another $7.5 billion-plus

Speaker: NA
Text: deficit, that pressure will be maintained. If one

Speaker: NA
Text: accepts the projection that the deficit in 1985-86

Speaker: NA
Text: will be even higher, with a dismal economic

Speaker: NA
Text: record and a $10 billion deficit talked of,

Speaker: NA
Text: lem ,of interest payments becomes a major struc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tural jam within the Government's spending

Speaker: NA
Text: program. I think we need to take that into con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sideration when we look at some of the money

Speaker: NA
Text: market problems of 1984-85.

Speaker: NA
Text: To cover this area, particularly the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's stated intention to have a M3 target of 12

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent,'the Government will be forced either to

Speaker: NA
Text: raise interest rates substantially before 30 June or

Speaker: NA
Text: not to allow the general credit creation which goes

Speaker: NA
Text: with this period of the year. With the advent of

Speaker: NA
Text: the actions by commercial banks to seek more

Speaker: NA
Text: profitability, they have not allowed their annual

Speaker: NA
Text: build-up on the liquid and government securities

Speaker: NA
Text: ratio to occur. As a result of that, the banks do not

Speaker: NA
Text: carry the margin they once carried at this time of

Speaker: NA
Text: the year. If the Government is to apply any press-

Speaker: NA
Text: ure in terms of funding its debt at this point, quite

Speaker: NA
Text: clearly a substantial rise in interest rates could

Speaker: NA
Text: occur. The consequence of that for the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: savings bonds, which have been a very successful

Speaker: NA
Text: means of funding government deficits in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: in the last few years, is that it is likely that they

Speaker: NA
Text: will come under pressure. Redemptions could re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sult from that which would further add to the

Speaker: NA
Text: growth of M3. I make these points because,

Speaker: NA
Text: although I know they are not of enormous public

Speaker: NA
Text: interest, they are terribly important to the man-

Speaker: NA
Text: agement of the economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam Deputy Speaker, this brings me to

Speaker: NA
Text: another leg of the Government's problem, that

Speaker: NA
Text: which lies with the balance of payments. While in

Speaker: NA
Text: the last 12 months there has been a significant im-

Speaker: NA
Text: provement in the balance of trade, we have not as

Speaker: NA
Text: yet seen an improvement in our competitive pos-

Speaker: NA
Text: ition that will match the flow of imports, and im-

Speaker: NA
Text: ports on a lagged period will not start to show up

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia's balance of payments probably until

Speaker: NA
Text: the end of 1984. At that point, with the increase in

Speaker: NA
Text: irtvisibles, it is highly likely that the balance of

Speaker: NA
Text: payments will drift into debt and with that will

Speaker: NA
Text: come some pressure on the exchange rates, which

Speaker: NA
Text: are now floating. As a consequence we can only

Speaker: NA
Text: reflect back on to interest rates and the general

Speaker: NA
Text: competitive position in which Australia will find

Speaker: NA
Text: itself because as a trading nation we compare our-

Speaker: NA
Text: selves with the Organisation for Economic Co-

Speaker: NA
Text: operation and Development, which has an aver-

Speaker: NA
Text: age level of inflation of around 5 per cent. In

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia it is currently running at 9 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: With the new-found fix on the consumer price

Speaker: NA
Text: index which is coming up, it will be reduced to

Speaker: NA
Text: something like 6 per cent or 7 per cent, but the

Speaker: NA
Text: underlying level, the real level, is unlikely to go

Speaker: NA
Text: below 9 or 10 per cent. As a consequence our

Speaker: NA
Text: competitive position will deteriorate as opposed

Speaker: NA
Text: the prob- to that of our trading competitors.

Speaker: NA
Text: I add to those observations some of the fore-

Speaker: NA
Text: casts which were put out by the Victorian

Speaker: NA
Text: Chamber of Manufactures, which pointed to the

Speaker: NA
Text: fact that the annual level of inflation is likely to

Speaker: NA
Text: rise to 9 per cent, compared with the average of

Speaker: NA
Text: 5.7 per cent in countries in the OECD. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Chamber goes on to estimate that real gross dom-

Speaker: NA
Text: estic product will fall from around 5.1 per cent in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1983-84 to 1.2 per cent in 1984-85, and unemploy-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is likely to increase at the same time in the

Speaker: NA
Text: order of9.9 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: These are very different forecasts and put a

Speaker: NA
Text: very different emphasis on the development of

Speaker: NA
Text: economic policy in Australia from that which we

Speaker: NA
Text: have been getting in the last six months. But these

Speaker: NA
Text: are very real forecasts based on the facts as they

Speaker: NA
Text: exist, not on the political likelihood which suits a

Speaker: NA
Text: government, a government which is intent on

Speaker: NA
Text: going to the polls in December to maximise its

Speaker: NA
Text: position before these forecasts come to bear and

Speaker: NA
Text: before the people of Australia recognise the prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lems with which the Government is confronted.

Speaker: NA
Text: To ensure its position, the Government will

Speaker: NA
Text: now be facing the long winter of Budget forma-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. It is a major challenge as to how the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment will come to match up the spending require-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments, particularly those of the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Home Affairs and Environment ( Mr Cohen),

Speaker: NA
Text: who is at the table, and the ability of the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian taxpayer in the corporate area to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: the funds. That in itself was a challenge to oUr

Speaker: NA
Text: Government and will certainly be a challenge to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Labor Government. I can see in the future

Speaker: NA
Text: that to meet these requirements it is probable that

Speaker: NA
Text: the deficit will be sorely pressed to rise to $7.5

Speaker: NA
Text: billion. The estimate of expenditure on forward

Speaker: NA
Text: Estimates that was provided was for $64 billion,

Speaker: NA
Text: but at least it was provided. Estimates of receipts,

Speaker: NA
Text: not provided but estimated on the basis of in-

Speaker: NA
Text: flation, fiscal creep and the effect of inflation on

Speaker: NA
Text: income, is of the order of $55 billion, giving an

Speaker: NA
Text: overall deficit of $9 billion.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have had endless promises of tax cuts, not

Speaker: NA
Text: only in the lead up to the election; 'Ninety-nine

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent of Australians will get

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke). In the year from

Speaker: NA
Text: March 1983 to 1984 we saw the biggest single in-

Speaker: NA
Text: crease in tax in any year since the Second World

Speaker: NA
Text: War. That is quite a comparison.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr MCVeigh-What year was that?

Speaker: Mr MOORE
Text: -Jt was from 1983 to 1984. The

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Darling Downs, as a

Speaker: NA
Text: prominent citizen, would know this only too well

Speaker: NA
Text: from his tax bill. The Government is now talking

Speaker: NA
Text: of making a tax cut this year; not the promised

Speaker: NA
Text: one last year, not the one based on the substantial

Speaker: NA
Text: increase in income which the Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: received in the current year, but one that is being

Speaker: NA
Text: forecast for the election. So if there is to be a $1

Speaker: NA
Text: billion tax cut, as has been freely thrown around,

Speaker: NA
Text: it will add another $1 billion to the deficit taking it

Speaker: NA
Text: to just on $10 billion. How do we reach the magi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal sole figure of $7.5 billion? Where is the missing

Speaker: NA
Text: $2 billion to $2.5 billion? The long winter ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion for the Australian Labor Party will be how it

Speaker: NA
Text: can get to that point. Will it be raised in extra

Speaker: NA
Text: taxes when we have already been promised a tax

Speaker: NA
Text: cut? This will mean that we will be given a tax cut

Speaker: NA
Text: with one hand but it will be clawed back through

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure taxes, through indirect charges. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has already indexed excise taxes; so

Speaker: NA
Text: it cannot slather it on the beer drinkers and the

Speaker: NA
Text: cigarette smokers as the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Griffith ( Mr Humphreys) would recognise. But I

Speaker: NA
Text: forecast that the Government will find that it will

Speaker: NA
Text: have to expand its taxation areas into sales taxes,

Speaker: NA
Text: a capital gains tax and other charges to meet that

Speaker: NA
Text: end of the equation or will it attempt to cut

Speaker: NA
Text: Government spending? I have never known a

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor government that cut government spending.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor governments have always been great

Speaker: NA
Text: spenders and politicians as a whole have loved

Speaker: NA
Text: handing money out, so why should not this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government? It is the easy thing to do. It is a

Speaker: NA
Text: wonderful thing to do, particularly when in

Speaker: NA
Text: government. I have even seen the Minister's name

Speaker: NA
Text: in one or two places and I am sure that he did not

Speaker: NA
Text: pay for the plaques that were put up. He is enjoy-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing this new-found money bin.

Speaker: NA
Text: So as the Government addresses itself to these

Speaker: NA
Text: problems I wonder whether the taxpayers of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia really know which way they will go.

Speaker: NA
Text: Will they be treated to a realistic tax cut to find

Speaker: NA
Text: the $2.5 billion or will they be treated to an il-

Speaker: NA
Text: lusory cut with extra tax at the edges? Will they

Speaker: NA
Text: be treated to a rigged Budget which will present a

Speaker: NA
Text: point of view in August for an election in

Speaker: NA
Text: December, with a totally different result in

Speaker: NA
Text: March?

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr TheophanousYou have not used that tac-

Speaker: NA
Text: a tax cut', to quote tic, have you?

Speaker: Mr MOORE
Text: The honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Burke would have a fair bit to say on that matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am sure that he would not stand by and vote for

Speaker: NA
Text: a Budget that looked as bad as that.

Speaker: Mr COHEN
Text: You did, on quite a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: occasions. What did you do in 1977? What about

Speaker: NA
Text: the fistful of dollars?

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER ( Mrs Child)-

Speaker: NA
Text: Order! I do not think that the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Ryan needs any assistance.

Speaker: Mr MOORE
Text: Thank you very much, Madam

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Speaker. I thought the Minister needed

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance from time to time. 1 want to concen-

Speaker: NA
Text: trate finally on the question of where we are

Speaker: NA
Text: today, having seen the difficulties and pointed out

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Government that it will need to improve

Speaker: NA
Text: substantially its outlook on business and its ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: proach to the economy because things will be

Speaker: NA
Text: difficult in 1985-86 and a Budget of this size will

Speaker: NA
Text: only produce a bigger deficit in the future. It will

Speaker: NA
Text: produce areas which will be unmanageable unless

Speaker: NA
Text: attempts are taken to cut the deficit at this point. 1

Speaker: NA
Text: do not believe for a moment that that will occur

Speaker: NA
Text: and as a consequence we will go into the high

Speaker: NA
Text: areas of stagflation in 1985-86, a dismal outlook

Speaker: NA
Text: indeed. The Bills before the House do point to a

Speaker: NA
Text: major problem which will face us all. It is some-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing to which 1 hope all honourable members of

Speaker: NA
Text: this House, particularly Opposition members, will

Speaker: NA
Text: apply themselves. 1 hope they use their time to ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: ploit all the weaknesses that occur. With those

Speaker: NA
Text: thoughts in mind, 1 indicate that the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: will not oppose the Bills.

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER-Order! Before

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 call the honourable member for Hughes, 1 point

Speaker: NA
Text: out to the House that this a maiden speech and I

Speaker: NA
Text: ask the House to extend to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Hughes the normal courtesies.

Speaker: Mr TICKNER
Text: Hughes) (4.19)-1 rise for the

Speaker: NA
Text: first time in this House to speak in support of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Appropriation Bills before the House. As is the

Speaker: NA
Text: custom in this place, I propose to speak in general

Speaker: NA
Text: terms on the state of Australian society and on the

Speaker: NA
Text: issues that I see as crucial to the future of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia in the 1980s and beyond. May I say,

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam Deputy Speaker, how privileged 1 am to

Speaker: NA
Text: make my maiden speech with you in the chair as

Speaker: NA
Text: the first woman Deputy Speaker in the history of

Speaker: NA
Text: this Parliament. 1 take my place in this House as

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Hughes, having been elected in

Speaker: NA
Text: the recent by-election which took place following

Speaker: NA
Text: the retirement of Mr Les Johnson. Mr Johnson

Speaker: NA
Text: was an extremely popular and effective local

Speaker: NA
Text: member and faithfully served the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party and the people of Hughes for a

Speaker: NA
Text: period spanning 28 years. 1 take the opportunity,

Speaker: NA
Text: on behalf of the Parliament, to wish Les Johnson

Speaker: NA
Text: and his wife Peggy a happy and rewarding future.

Speaker: NA
Text: Following my preselection by the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party to contest the seat of Hughes,

Speaker: NA
Text: another former member of this Parliament sent

Speaker: NA
Text: me a congratulatory telegram from Paris, where

Speaker: NA
Text: he conducts certain business on behalf of the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Government. His message read:

Speaker: NA
Text: May you continue to represent your part of my former

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate for many decades to come.

Speaker: NA
Text: I take this opportunity to thank Mr Whitlam for

Speaker: NA
Text: his good wishes. My first and foremost responsi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bility as a member of this Parliament is to serve

Speaker: NA
Text: the people of the Hughes electorate with the same

Speaker: NA
Text: dedication as that shown by my predecessor. I

Speaker: NA
