Text: shall endeavour to do so to the best of my ability.

Speaker: NA
Text: The rank and file members of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party in the electorate of Hughes selected

Speaker: NA
Text: me to contest the seat for the Australian Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party. To them, too, lowe a great debt and a re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsibility to maintain my commitment to fight

Speaker: NA
Text: for reform and social justice in this country. The

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate of Hughes presents great challenges

Speaker: NA
Text: and contrasts. No other electorate in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: has both an active peace movement and a large

Speaker: NA
Text: Army establishment, two national parks, coal

Speaker: NA
Text: mines, a vigorous community-based anti-uranium

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign and Australia's only nuclear reactor,

Speaker: NA
Text: and all on the doorstep of Sydney.

Speaker: NA
Text: I take great pride in being the newest member

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Hawke Labor Government. Our Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has the opportunity to cement itself as the

Speaker: NA
Text: natural party of government for Australia. Both

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister and the Government as a

Speaker: NA
Text: whole continue to enjoy high levels of public ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: proval. We have gained, and clearly continue to

Speaker: NA
Text: retain, the confidence of the Australian people.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our Government, elected only one year ago, has

Speaker: NA
Text: already undertaken significant steps as a govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of reform, and has begun to remove the leg-

Speaker: NA
Text: acy of gross inequalities and bitter divisions that

Speaker: NA
Text: so typified the Fraser years. Much still remains to

Speaker: NA
Text: be done, and 1 look forward to the many

Speaker: NA
Text: foreshadowed government initiatives, such as the

Speaker: NA
Text: enactment of national Aboriginal land rights legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation so desperately needed by Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: . Australians.

Speaker: NA
Text: Like the Minister for Finance ( Mr Dawkins),

Speaker: NA
Text: who in his speech to the National Press Club last

Speaker: NA
Text: Wednesday described his political philosophy as

Speaker: NA
Text: that of a democratic socialist, I too embrace that

Speaker: NA
Text: philosophy. The road of a reforming government

Speaker: NA
Text: in this country is a hard one. That is so principally

Speaker: NA
Text: because of the dead hand of the conservative

Speaker: NA
Text: governments which have occupied the treasury

Speaker: NA
Text: bench in this House for most of my lifetime. The

Speaker: NA
Text: enduring contribution of Malcolm Fraser to the

Speaker: NA
Text: conservative forces in this country was the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: motion of the myth that the Whitlam Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment did too much too quickly, and for that

Speaker: NA
Text: reason was rejected by the Australian people.

Speaker: NA
Text: This conservative fabrication does a disservice to

Speaker: NA
Text: the intelligence of the Australian people. It has

Speaker: NA
Text: been accepted uncritically by a huge section of the

Speaker: NA
Text: media and warmly welcomed by the privileged

Speaker: NA
Text: and vested interests, who seek to defend by any

Speaker: NA
Text: means available their privileged position.

Speaker: NA
Text: The reality is, of course, that the reforming

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Whitlam Government was most clearly in

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence following the election of that Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in December 1972 and throughout 1973,

Speaker: NA
Text: when the Sydney Morning Herald consistently

Speaker: NA
Text: carried banner headlines announcing: 'What the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government did today'. The Whitlam Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Government was re-elected in 1974, thus dispel-

Speaker: NA
Text: ling the myth that the Australian people were not

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared to welcome innovative and radical re-

Speaker: NA
Text: forms. To understand the reasons for Labor's loss

Speaker: NA
Text: of office in 1975 we should look primarily not to

Speaker: NA
Text: the speed of Labor's reforms but to t-e undemo-

Speaker: NA
Text: cratic institution of the Senate, the infamous role

Speaker: NA
Text: of the discredited Governor-General of the time,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the role of the privileged and vested interests

Speaker: NA
Text: to whom I have already referred.

Speaker: NA
Text: This Parliament has in its hands the power to

Speaker: NA
Text: influence the course of Australia for decades to

Speaker: NA
Text: come and is responsible for the future quality of

Speaker: NA
Text: life of young Australians. Last year I had the op-

Speaker: NA
Text: portunity to officiate at the annual open air

Speaker: NA
Text: speech night of the Bundeena public school,

Speaker: NA
Text: situated in the Royal National Park in the neigh-

Speaker: NA
Text: bouring electorate of Cook. On that night, under

Speaker: NA
Text: the stars, I had time to reflect on the future of

Speaker: NA
Text: young children at the school. At one time in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's history the children growing up in that

Speaker: NA
Text: small town in a national park may have been able

Speaker: NA
Text: to remain isolated from the economic dislocation

Speaker: NA
Text: evident in the world and from the threat of war.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is no longer the case. Perhaps for this reason

Speaker: NA
Text: those children had just finished writing an essay

Speaker: NA
Text: entitled: 'When I grow up I want the world to be

Speaker: NA
Text: here'.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe that young Australians are

Speaker: NA
Text: increasingly conscious of the need to work collec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tively to build a better world. I am convinced that

Speaker: NA
Text: the quality of life of those children from Bun-

Speaker: NA
Text: deena will depend upon whether or not we, as a

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor government, are able to develop and pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: mote Labor's adopted alternative policies to re-

Speaker: NA
Text: place the policies of free market forces promoted

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Liberal and National parties. There is no

Speaker: NA
Text: doubt in my mind that if the market forces of the

Speaker: NA
Text: conservatives were allowed to prevail, Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: would continue to become an industrial back-

Speaker: NA
Text: water of mass unemployment and human despair,

Speaker: NA
Text: while transnational corporations plundered our

Speaker: NA
Text: rich national resources to their hearts' content.

Speaker: NA
Text: The reign of three decades of conservative

Speaker: NA
Text: government since World War II has resulted in

Speaker: NA
Text: the wealthiest one per cent of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: population owning 22 per cent of the total wealth,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the richest 2,000 people in Australia owning

Speaker: NA
Text: as much as the poorest two and a half million Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralians. The Brotherhood of St Laurence has

Speaker: NA
Text: zeal estimated that over 2 million Australians live in

Speaker: NA
Text: poverty. The unrestrained operation of those free

Speaker: NA
Text: market forces and the record level of unrestrained

Speaker: NA
Text: foreign ownership of our industries and natural

Speaker: NA
Text: resources has resulted in a loss of economic

Speaker: NA
Text: sovereignty by the Australian people and their

Speaker: NA
Text: government. Crucial decisions affecting the well-

Speaker: NA
Text: being of Australians are taken not by the Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, not by the Government, not by the trade

Speaker: NA
Text: union movement, but by the controllers of trans-

Speaker: NA
Text: national corporations in the boardrooms of Lon-

Speaker: NA
Text: don, New York, Tokyo, and elsewhere. Those

Speaker: NA
Text: corporations have shown time and again their

Speaker: NA
Text: contempt for national and State governments as

Speaker: NA
Text: they move to organise their production on a global

Speaker: NA
Text: basis to maximise their profits. If national govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments get squashed in the process, that is just too

Speaker: NA
Text: bad.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of our major tasks as a Labor government

Speaker: NA
Text: is to initiate policies in co-operation with the trade

Speaker: NA
Text: union movement to force those corporations to be

Speaker: NA
Text: accountable to national governments. There can

Speaker: NA
Text: be no better example of this transnational tyranny

Speaker: NA
Text: than the actions of General Motors-Holden's Ltd

Speaker: NA
Text: when that company closed down its Pagewood

Speaker: NA
Text: the plant in Sydney in 1980. On the very day of the

Speaker: NA
Text: closure the New South Wales Minister for Decen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralisation and Minister for Industrial Develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment was in Detroit as the Government represen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tative, trying to find out the future of the plant.

Speaker: NA
Text: On that day the General Motors official, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Chuck Chapman representing what must be seen

Speaker: NA
Text: by all decent Australians as the ugliest face of

Speaker: NA
Text: American capitalism, arranged for security guards

Speaker: NA
Text: to hand the workers their dismissal notices at the

Speaker: NA
Text: factory while he organised a slick Press confer-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence at an international city hotel to try to sell this

Speaker: NA
Text: company decision to the public.

Speaker: NA
Text: The core of the Liberal and National parties'

Speaker: NA
Text: philosophy is that individualism is put on a ped-

Speaker: NA
Text: estal. Solidarity with disadvantaged groups in this

Speaker: NA
Text: society is rejected and, as a result, injustice in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creases. This philosophy is spreading in many

Speaker: NA
Text: countries which have cut back on public expendi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture, purportedly because of large budget deficits.

Speaker: NA
Text: The cuts which conservatives make hit the social

Speaker: NA
Text: welfare sector, and those who are worst off have

Speaker: NA
Text: to bear the brunt of those ill-conceived and con-

Speaker: NA
Text: servative responses. The free marketeer opinion

Speaker: NA
Text: moulders say that people must make it on their

Speaker: NA
Text: own. They say: 'You fend for yourself and I will

Speaker: NA
Text: fend for myself. If I make it, that is fine, I will get

Speaker: NA
Text: my reward; but if you fail, it is your own fault and

Speaker: NA
Text: you have to take the consequences of that failure'.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe that all decent Australians reject that

Speaker: NA
Text: philosophy as a dangerous and unjust creed to

Speaker: NA
Text: preach. Under that philosophy the weak are left

Speaker: NA
Text: to their fate while the strong, with good incomes

Speaker: NA
Text: and property, are left free to develop their indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: vidualism and further increase their profits and

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth.

Speaker: NA
Text: The end target of this conservative criticism is

Speaker: NA
Text: the public sector at the Federal, State and local

Speaker: NA
Text: levels. We on this side of the chamber recognise

Speaker: NA
Text: the crucial role played by the public sector in the

Speaker: NA
Text: future progress of Australia and the planning of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian economy. This applies, for

Speaker: NA
Text: example, to communications, education, research,

Speaker: NA
Text: social welfare services, water supplies, sewerage,

Speaker: NA
Text: occupational health and safety, environmental

Speaker: NA
Text: protection and many other areas. There is also

Speaker: NA
Text: tremendous potential for public ownership, the

Speaker: NA
Text: peoples' ownership, of productive enterprises and

Speaker: NA
Text: natural resources to generate profits not for

Speaker: NA
Text: foreign shareholders but for the benefit of all the

Speaker: NA
Text: people of Australia. I sit amongst a Western Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian contingent in this Parliament, and it is to

Speaker: NA
Text: the credit of the Western Australian Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Government that it has already implemented the

Speaker: NA
Text: significant step of gaining public equity in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Argyle diamond mine in that State. I commend it

Speaker: NA
Text: for that.

Speaker: NA
Text: Many of those who criticise the public sector in

Speaker: NA
Text: this place forget that the activities of national,

Speaker: NA
Text: State and local governments influence favourably

Speaker: NA
Text: the profitability and production of the private sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor in a direct way through the extensive procure-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of goods and services. Those critics also for-

Speaker: NA
Text: get that millions of Australians are directly or

Speaker: NA
Text: indirectly dependent upon government activities

Speaker: NA
Text: for their livelihood. The public sector can be an

Speaker: NA
Text: economic incentive in the development of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's economy, for example, by target-

Speaker: NA
Text: oriented procurement of technology, by public in-

Speaker: NA
Text: vestments and by increased exports. I welcome

Speaker: NA
Text: the commitment of this Labor Government to en-

Speaker: NA
Text: suring the efficient operation of the public sector,

Speaker: NA
Text: to increase its accountability and yet to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: and to enable the pursuit of important social

Speaker: NA
Text: objectives. This Government does not seek to

Speaker: NA
Text: build monolithic state bureaucracies which differ

Speaker: NA
Text: little in their operation from profit-oriented cor-

Speaker: NA
Text: porations in the private sector.

Speaker: NA
Text: The public sector is not only a support to and a

Speaker: NA
Text: condition necessary for the development of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian economy. Its activities are also necess-

Speaker: NA
Text: ary for the personal development and freedom of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian people. This freedom is not only

Speaker: NA
Text: the right to vote in general elections or the right

Speaker: NA
Text: express one's opinion freely. Freedom is also the

Speaker: NA
Text: right to live and work in a decent environment, to

Speaker: NA
Text: have acceptable living conditions and the scope to

Speaker: NA
Text: develop as a person and to take part in the build-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing of the community. Freedom and democracy,

Speaker: NA
Text: in democratic socialist philosophy, recognises the

Speaker: NA
Text: right of people, in co-operation with others, to be

Speaker: NA
Text: able to influence and to participate in the building

Speaker: NA
Text: of society.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Liberal-National Party concept of freedom

Speaker: NA
Text: and democracy recognises, and then only grudg-

Speaker: NA
Text: ingly, the right to vote once every three years to

Speaker: NA
Text: elect a government. This right to vote, important

Speaker: NA
Text: though it is, is really only the right to sign a politi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal blank cheque and on its own amounts to the

Speaker: NA
Text: abdication of the political responsibility of indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: vidual Australians to a handful of elected poli-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticians. Real democracy and freedom in other

Speaker: NA
Text: spheres of life-in the work place, at the local

Speaker: NA
Text: community level and in public institutions-are

Speaker: NA
Text: rejected by the conservatives. This participation is

Speaker: NA
Text: essential if people are to have confidence in the

Speaker: NA
Text: building of the future Australian society. Where

Speaker: NA
Text: were the democratic rights of the workers at

Speaker: NA
Text: Pagewood when the General Motors Corporation

Speaker: NA
Text: decision makers in Detroit took away their

Speaker: NA
Text: livelihood?

Speaker: NA
Text: The need to participate in decisions affecting

Speaker: NA
Text: the future of Australia applies particularly to

Speaker: NA
Text: young people. In fact it is my belief that the mass

Speaker: NA
Text: participation of Australians in the political pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: cess is the precondition of long term and sus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainable progressive social change in this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: Thus, we would never have had a national sex dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: crimination law without the active participation

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australian women in the political process. I

Speaker: NA
Text: daresay that you, Madam Deputy Speaker, may

Speaker: NA
Text: not even have been a member of this Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: had it not been for that political participation.

Speaker: NA
Text: In another sphere, and by the method of exer-

Speaker: NA
Text: cising the democratic right of peaceful protest,

Speaker: NA
Text: hundreds of thousands of Australians from all

Speaker: NA
Text: walks of life will march on Palm Sunday, 15 April,

Speaker: NA
Text: to echo their message that Australia ought to be

Speaker: NA
Text: doing even more to promote nuclear dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: armament. If we are able to achieve a society in

Speaker: NA
Text: which the great worth of all its members is a re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ality and in which all people have the right to a

Speaker: NA
Text: free and independent life, we Australians who

Speaker: NA
Text: share these goals must, in a spirit of solidarity,

Speaker: NA
Text: take responsibility for the economic and social

Speaker: NA
Text: situation of our fellow Australians.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians are not worried only about their

Speaker: NA
Text: material welfare. They are concerned also about

Speaker: NA
Text: issues which impinge upon our very existence and

Speaker: NA
Text: to our prospects for survival. These are the issues of

Speaker: NA
Text: war and peace, of our life environment, of food,

Speaker: NA
Text: water and shelter for the starving millions of the

Speaker: NA
Text: world and of our ability to stop the continuing

Speaker: NA
Text: arms race. The growth of the anti-nuclear

Speaker: NA
Text: movement in recent years is tangible evidence of

Speaker: NA
Text: the serious concerns that people around the world

Speaker: NA
Text: feel about these issues. In a nuclear war there will

Speaker: NA
Text: be no winners, only losers. Political and ideologi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal opponents must for that reason work together

Speaker: NA
Text: for disarmament and common security.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is for this reason that I view with alarm the

Speaker: NA
Text: pUblication in the last few days of a purported

Speaker: NA
Text: confidential Cabinet document entitled 'Strategic

Speaker: NA
Text: Basis of Australian Defence Policy'. I welcome

Speaker: NA
Text: and support the Government's assurance that the

Speaker: NA
Text: specific policy proposals in the document have

Speaker: NA
Text: not been endorsed and I place On record my sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port for the Government's view that we will not

Speaker: NA
Text: tolerate the importation or development of nu-

Speaker: NA
Text: clear weapons by Australia. I regret that this view

Speaker: NA
Text: is not shared by a selection of the mad bombers on

Speaker: NA
Text: the other side of this House. We have suffered

Speaker: NA
Text: from decades of cold war hysteria, and its sole leg-

Speaker: NA
Text: acy is to leave arsenals of nuclear destruction in

Speaker: NA
Text: the hands of the super-powers. The development

Speaker: NA
Text: 'of the non-aligned movement is, in my view,

Speaker: NA
Text: further evidence of the quest of nations to find a

Speaker: NA
Text: role in international relations outside the shadow

Speaker: NA
Text: of the super-powers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Although differences exist throughout the

Speaker: NA
Text: world, we must remember that most of the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: variables in people's lives-their big life project-

Speaker: NA
Text: are the same for all people right across national

Speaker: NA
Text: borders and for all time. They are the rights to

Speaker: NA
Text: grow up and be reared; to find playmates and

Speaker: NA
Text: friends; to get an education when one is young and

Speaker: NA
Text: prepare oneself for the various roles in adult life;

Speaker: NA
Text: to find a place in working life and to make one's

Speaker: NA
Text: living; to live in adequate housing; to have the

Speaker: NA
Text: right to select a lifestyle of one's own choosing;

Speaker: NA
Text: and, if chosen, to establish a family and bring chil-

Speaker: NA
Text: dren into the world. All these are the invariables

Speaker: NA
Text: of human life. It is that simple or it is that remark-

Speaker: NA
Text: able. These are some of the common bonds of hu-

Speaker: NA
Text: manity which ought to unite us all.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our task as members of parliament is to play

Speaker: NA
Text: our part in organising Australian society so as to

Speaker: NA
Text: allow all Australians the right to realise their life

Speaker: NA
Text: projects. The efforts of this Labor Government, I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe, are directed to these ends. To achieve our

Speaker: NA
Text: goals, I urge all Australians who share these ideals

Speaker: NA
Text: to take an active and continuing part in the efforts

Speaker: NA
Text: to achieve freedom and justice not only in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia but also throughout the world.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Text: Bennelong) (4.38)-Before

Speaker: NA
Text: starting my remarks I would like to join the col-

Speaker: NA
Text: leagues of the honourable member for Hughes

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Tickner) on the other side of the House in

Speaker: NA
Text: congratulating the honourable gentleman on his

Speaker: NA
Text: maiden speech. Having listened to it very care-

Speaker: NA
Text: fully, I must say that over the months and years

Speaker: NA
Text: ahead there may well be occasions when I mar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ginally disagree with some of the things that the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable gentleman says. But can I say in no

Speaker: NA
Text: sense of humbug or cant that I believe he

Speaker: NA
Text: delivered his speech in a very articulate and well-

Speaker: NA
Text: reasoned manner and I respect the integrity with

Speaker: NA
Text: which he holds to a genuine Labor viewpoint. I

Speaker: NA
Text: welcome the prospect of a sharpened debate

Speaker: NA
Text: along ideological lines with Labor opponents es-

Speaker: NA
Text: pousing what I have always understood to be the

Speaker: NA
Text: essence of Labor Party policies.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am, therefore, indebted to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Hughes for reminding the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: public and this Parliament that there are very

Speaker: NA
Text: large numbers of people in the Australian Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party who want their Party back. The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman has certainly done that, and he has

Speaker: NA
Text: done the House and his Party a very great service

Speaker: NA
Text: in reminding us of just precisely what political dif-

Speaker: NA
Text: ference in this House is all about. For that reason,

Speaker: NA
Text: I doubly welcome and compliment the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Hughes on the remarks that he

Speaker: NA
Text: has made.

Speaker: NA
Text: - I should like to direct my remarks in this debate

Speaker: NA
Text: on the Appropriation Bills to the appropriation in

Speaker: NA
Text: regard to the Department of the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: and Cabinet. To be more precise, I should like to

Speaker: NA
Text: direct my remarks to the Minister in charge of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. I

Speaker: NA
Text: should like to make a few comments about the

Speaker: NA
Text: present Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke). I should

Speaker: NA
Text: like to make a few comments about the political

Speaker: NA
Text: conduct of the present Prime Minister, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: should like to make a few comments about his

Speaker: NA
Text: political double standards.

Speaker: Mr COHEN
Text: Are you going to be nasty?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Text: I am going to talk about the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister's politics. I am interested in his

Speaker: NA
Text: politics, and I am interested in the double stan-

Speaker: NA
Text: dards of his politics, because I think that the

Speaker: NA
Text: double standards of his politics are very important

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Australian public, as, indeed, they are im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portant to the members of the Party that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister leads.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those who follow politics in Australia ought to

Speaker: NA
Text: be very indebted to the head of the Canberra Bu-

Speaker: NA
Text: reau of the Sydney Morning Herald, Paul Kelly,

Speaker: NA
Text: for his book entitled The Hawke Ascendancy. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think that anyone who has read that book would

Speaker: NA
Text: agree that it is fairly complimentary about the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister. I think that it is a very good book,

Speaker: NA
Text: and it is complimentary about the Prime Minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: But I think that we should be particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: indebted to Paul Kelly for doing one thing in par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticular, and that is putting to an end the myth and

Speaker: NA
Text: the idea that in some way the present Prime Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister is a person who, although he is part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: political process in Australia, is some kind of

Speaker: NA
Text: supra-political figure who stands above it all and

Speaker: NA
Text: never dirties his hands in a political sense, who

Speaker: NA
Text: never gets involved in any kind of machination,

Speaker: NA
Text: and that in some way the present Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: is the fortunate beneficiary, in a benign unsuspect-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing sense, of circumstances that carried him along

Speaker: NA
Text: to high pinnacles of political success and auth-

Speaker: NA
Text: ority. Really, Paul Kelly has done a great service

Speaker: NA
Text: in spelling out in a very accurate manner that it

Speaker: NA
Text: really is not like that.

Speaker: NA
Text: Far from the Prime Minister, some 14 months

Speaker: NA
Text: ago, going away, sitting down and contemplating

Speaker: NA
Text: matters in a very philosophical manner and sud-

Speaker: NA
Text: denly finding out, quite without design and with-

Speaker: NA
Text: out effort, that things were moving in his direction

Speaker: NA
Text: so far as the leadership of his own Party was con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned. Paul Kelly's book spells it out fairly

Speaker: NA
Text: clearly that the Prime Minister was up to his arm-

Speaker: NA
Text: pits in all the manoeuvring and all the machi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nations that were going on at that time. Paul

Speaker: NA
Text: Kelly describes in great detail how the Prime Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister worked very closely with the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Council of Trade Unions to delay the announce-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment and the unveiling of the then Labor Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition's economic policy, so that all of it would

Speaker: NA
Text: work to the disadvantage of the then Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition and, of course, to the advantage of

Speaker: NA
Text: the putative Leader of the Opposition, the present

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is very interesting for any student of recent

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian politics to understand that that book

Speaker: NA
Text: destroys for all time the myth and the idea that

Speaker: NA
Text: many Australians hold that in some way Bob

Speaker: NA
Text: Hawke is above all of us, that he is quite different

Speaker: NA
Text: from any of us, and that in no way does he get in-

Speaker: NA
Text: volved in any of the unseemly machinations

Speaker: NA
Text: which are characteristic of his Party. The book

Speaker: NA
Text: brings it home very clearly that he is right there

Speaker: NA
Text: the thick of it. Any suggestion that in some way he

Speaker: NA
Text: is apart from it is absolute nonsense.

Speaker: NA
Text: That really exposes the first double standard.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have heard a great deal from the Prime Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter since he has occupied the office about how

Speaker: NA
Text: people should get around the table and different

Speaker: NA
Text: sections of the community should sink their differ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ences. I want to analyse that proposition. I want

Speaker: NA
Text: also to analyse another proposition that the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister has constantly put and that is that oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sitions should be constructive, that they should

Speaker: NA
Text: not be negative and that they should adopt a posi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive attitude towards sensible government initiat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ives that might be unpopular in the short term but

Speaker: NA
Text: important to the long term benefit of the country.

Speaker: NA
Text: ] would have to say that in theory I agree with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister that there are occasions on which

Speaker: NA
Text: an opposition ought not to take political advan-

Speaker: NA
Text: tage of the short term discomfort caused by a pol-

Speaker: NA
Text: icy which is being promoted or being canvassed by

Speaker: NA
Text: the government of the day.

Speaker: NA
Text: Perhaps the present Prime Minister in particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lar and the. Government in general would be

Speaker: NA
Text: having a little more success in their bipartisan

Speaker: NA
Text: appeals to the present Opposition and to the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity if their track record of bipartisan

Speaker: NA
Text: approaches to difficult issues when they were in

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition had been a little better. There are a

Speaker: NA
Text: few of us on our side of politics who get just a little

Speaker: NA
Text: cynical and a little fed up with the way in which

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister in particular regales us and

Speaker: NA
Text: says: 'You are a negative, destructive opposition,

Speaker: NA
Text: and you never adopt a positive attitude or make a

Speaker: NA
Text: positive response to anything that vre propose'.

Speaker: NA
Text: Has the Prime Minister forgotten the record of

Speaker: NA
Text: negativism of the Labor Party over the last few

Speaker: NA
Text: years to each and every long term policy proposal

Speaker: NA
Text: put forward or canvassed by the Fraser Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment which inevitably involved some kind of

Speaker: NA
Text: short term unpopularity and discomfort?

Speaker: NA
Text: Has he forgotten the attitude that he and his

Speaker: NA
Text: colleagues took to the crude oil pricing policy?

Speaker: NA
Text: Has he forgotten that his colleague the present

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer ( Mr Keating) said that that policy

Speaker: NA
Text: represented the establishment of a branch of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Taxation Office at every petrol bowser

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia? Not only has the present Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment embraced the policy, but also it has not

Speaker: NA
Text: closed down any branches of that Taxation Office.

Speaker: NA
Text: It has gone on collecting the tax in exactly the

Speaker: NA
Text: same way, and now that members of the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party are in government they are quite happy to

Speaker: NA
Text: accept the logic of that policy, but they were per-

Speaker: NA
Text: fectly prepared to take short term advantage of

Speaker: NA
Text: the discomfort and the unpopularity. What did

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Prime Minister say about that when he was in

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition? He supported that totally negative

Speaker: NA
Text: approach.

Speaker: NA
Text: What about the wage pause which has done so

Speaker: NA
Text: much to deliver the lower inflation about which

Speaker: NA
Text: the Treasurer and the Prime Minister now crow

Speaker: NA
Text: on every occasion on which they talk about the

Speaker: NA
Text: economy? That wage pause has contributed more

Speaker: NA
Text: to reducing Australia's inflation rate over the last

Speaker: NA
Text: year than the prices and incomes accord will do in

Speaker: NA
Text: 10 years. Yet what was the Prime Minister's atti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tude when that was introduced? It was one of a

Speaker: NA
Text: negative response. He described it as counter-

Speaker: NA
Text: productive. He said that it was a gimmick. His

Speaker: NA
Text: views were consistent with those of the President

Speaker: NA
Text: of the ACTU, Mr Dolan, who said in January

Speaker: NA
Text: I don't want to sound cynical about this and I'm

Speaker: NA
Text: nitely not trying to, but while there are 10 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: workers unemployed there are 90 per cent in employment.

Speaker: NA
Text: In other words, the view was: 'Do not worry about

Speaker: NA
Text: the 10 per cent who are out of work; there are 90

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent employed. So the idea that that 90 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent should make a sacrifice, in terms of their real

Speaker: NA
Text: income, to help the 10 per cent who are out of

Speaker: NA
Text: work is something that we dismiss out of hand'.

Speaker: NA
Text: That was a very constructive response! In other

Speaker: NA
Text: words, it was a totally negative response from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister and from the Party of which he is

Speaker: NA
Text: a member when the wage pause was introduced.

Speaker: NA
Text: It gives the lie to any suggestion that in opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor members were prepared to behave in any-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing other than a totally destructive and negative

Speaker: NA
Text: fashion.

Speaker: NA
Text: We all remember the way in which members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the present Government reacted when the report

Speaker: NA
Text: uf the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Financial System was tabled in

Speaker: NA
Text: November 1981. We had the Treasurer talking

Speaker: NA
Text: yesterday about all the deregulatory things that he

Speaker: NA
Text: was going to do. But when the Campbell report

Speaker: NA
Text: was tabled in this Parliament, I felt on a number

Speaker: NA
Text: of occasions that I was the only person who was

Speaker: NA
Text: the least bit supportive of it. Not one member of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Labor Party had any kind of sympathy or

Speaker: NA
Text: adopted any kind of approach other than a totally

Speaker: NA
Text: negative and totally critical response. In fact, in

Speaker: NA
Text: January of last year, when I announced on behalf

Speaker: NA
Text: of the former Government that we would be

Speaker: NA
Text: licensing the introduction into Australia of about

Speaker: NA
Text: 10 foreign banks, the present Treasurer said that I

Speaker: NA
Text: was a tool of overseas financial interests, that I

Speaker: NA
Text: was selling out Australia's interests to foreigners,

Speaker: NA
Text: and that I was behaving in a way that was totally

Speaker: NA
Text: inconsistent with the interests of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: community. So much for the constructive oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition of the Labor Party. So much for the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party's desire on that occasion to behave in a posi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive manner.

Speaker: NA
Text: Finally in that vein let us look at taxation. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has talked a great deal about the

Speaker: NA
Text: need to reform the Australian taxation system. I

Speaker: NA
Text: agree with it. I have made no secret of the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that I believe that a number of major reforms to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian taxation system are needed. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: also indicated that, if some of those reforms are

Speaker: NA
Text: adopted by the present Government, I for one will

Speaker: NA
Text: support its initiatives in that area. But let us take

Speaker: NA
Text: our minds back only a couple of years to the atti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tude of the Prime Minister and his colleagues

Speaker: NA
Text: when the former Government was canvassing

Speaker: NA
Text: proposals to change the taxation system. Their re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponse was totally negative. Their response was

Speaker: NA
Text: totally opportunist. Their response was totally

Speaker: NA
Text: deficritical and destructive and was one that left no

Speaker: NA
Text: political room to manoeuvre as far as the then

Speaker: NA
Text: Government was concerned. Their response flew

Speaker: NA
Text: totally in the face of any proposition that we

Speaker: NA
Text: could have a bipartisan approach from the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Labor Party, of which the present Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister was then a member in opposition, and

Speaker: NA
Text: gave the lie completely to the argument that he

Speaker: NA
Text: now advances that he has always been a supporter

Speaker: NA
Text: of a bipartisan approach.

Speaker: NA
Text: That brings me to another area, that is, the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: lations between the present Government and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian business community. I think that one

Speaker: NA
Text: of the interesting commentaries that ought to be

Speaker: NA
Text: made on the politics of Australia over recent years

Speaker: NA
Text: is that, to its great credit, the Australian business

Speaker: NA
Text: community has been willing to give to the new

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Government the go that the trade union

Speaker: NA
Text: movement was totally unwilling to give to the

Speaker: NA
Text: former Government when it was elected in 1976. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think it is the role of all sections of Australian so-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciety to co-operate with elected governments,

Speaker: NA
Text: whether they approve of those elected govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments or not. That applies to all people, be they in

Speaker: NA
Text: the trade union movement, a member of the busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness community or whatever. I think it is proper

Speaker: NA
Text: that large sections of the business community-

Speaker: NA
Text: indeed, that all sections-should co-operate and

Speaker: NA
Text: should deal and in every way associate with the

Speaker: NA
Text: elected government of the day, be it a Liberal or a

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, that is a concept that the Prime Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister is now very happy to embrace. He prides

Speaker: NA
Text: himself on being able, he keeps talking about how

Speaker: NA
Text: he is able, to talk to the business community. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think that is a good thing. A Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: should have very good relations with the business

Speaker: NA
Text: community and should be willing to do so. But the

Speaker: NA
Text: interesting thing about the Prime Minister is that

Speaker: NA
Text: when the boot was on the other foot where was he

Speaker: NA
Text: to be found? Where was he to be found as the

Speaker: NA
Text: President of the Australian Council of Trade

Speaker: NA
Text: Unions in 1977 when that body, representing the

Speaker: NA
Text: trade unionists of Australia, had a fiftieth anniver-

Speaker: NA
Text: sary dinner? What did it do? It was so narrow-

Speaker: NA
Text: minded, so mean-minded, that it refused to invite

Speaker: NA
Text: the elected leader of the Government of the day

Speaker: NA
Text: to that gathering. Honourable members opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: seem to think that is terribly amusing. We can im-

Speaker: NA
Text: agine what would happen if today the Confeder-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation of Australian Industry were to hold a dinner

Speaker: NA
Text: or a function of that magnitude and were to refuse

Speaker: NA
Text: to invite the Labor Prime Minister. If that were to

Speaker: NA
Text: happen we would have all the Labor members, in-

Speaker: NA
Text: cluding those on the Right, coming into this

Speaker: NA
Text: House and saying: 'That is yet another example of

Speaker: NA
Text: the negative attitude of large corporations and

Speaker: NA
Text: multinationals in Australia towards the elected

Speaker: NA
Text: government of the day'. That is yet another illus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tration of what happens when the boot is on the

Speaker: NA
Text: other foot.

Speaker: NA
Text: This Prime Minister who now craves consensus,

Speaker: NA
Text: this Prime Minister who now believes in a biparti-

Speaker: NA
Text: san approach, this Prime Minister who now asks

Speaker: NA
Text: for positive, constructive opposition, this Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister who quite rightly expects all sections of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian community to deal with the elected

Speaker: NA
Text: Government and to accept the elected Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, which of course they do, when the boot was

Speaker: NA
Text: on the other foot and he was in another situation

Speaker: NA
Text: and acting in another capacity was willing to take

Speaker: NA
Text: a totally partisan approach, a totally negative ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: proach, a totally mean-minded approach and an

Speaker: NA
Text: approach that compares very unfavourably with

Speaker: NA
Text: the approach that he now expects from the rest of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian community.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is little wonder that, when one goes back over

Speaker: NA
Text: the period of the 1960s and 1970s, one can find

Speaker: NA
Text: that the contribution made by the present Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister in a former capacity towards a wages ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: plosion and therefore the increase in unemploy-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in Australia was a very big one indeed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Many people who have studied the development

Speaker: NA
Text: of unemployment in Australia during that period

Speaker: NA
Text: talk very deliberately of the Hawke factor in un-

Speaker: NA
Text: employment. One is reminded of the impetus

Speaker: NA
Text: given by the present Prime Minister when he was

Speaker: NA
Text: President of the ACTU to so many excessive wage

Speaker: NA
Text: increases which cost so many jobs, to the fuelling

Speaker: NA
Text: of so many industrial disputes and to the adoption

Speaker: NA
Text: of a far more militant and destructive stance by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian trade union movement when he

Speaker: NA
Text: occupied that position. Regrettably, some of those

Speaker: NA
Text: things have passed from the immediate conscious-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness of many people in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think that, when we reflect upon the appro-

Speaker: NA
Text: priations for the Department of the Prime Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter and Cabinet, it is as well to remind ourselves

Speaker: NA
Text: the political double standards of the present

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister of Australia, a person who

Speaker: NA
Text: preaches and advocates consensus and a biparti-

Speaker: NA
Text: san approach now that he is in government. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: great to have a bipartisan approach when in

Speaker: NA
Text: government; I can tell the House that. Of course

Speaker: NA
Text: the present Prime Minister is no exception to that

Speaker: NA
Text: rule. His only problem is that when he was in op-

Speaker: NA
Text: position he was not the least bit interested in

Speaker: NA
Text: adopting a bipartisan approach. He was there up

Speaker: NA
Text: to his armpits in the most partisan behaviour of a

Speaker: NA
Text: political kind imaginable.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is demonstrated very clearly in the events

Speaker: NA
Text: that are traversed in Paul Kelly's book, The

Speaker: NA
Text: Hawke Ascendancy, which ends the myth that in

Speaker: NA
Text: some way the Prime Minister is above it all, that

Speaker: NA
Text: even though we can criticise all the other people

Speaker: NA
Text: on the front bench we must not criticise the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister because he is different from everybody

Speaker: NA
Text: else and if anything goes wrong with the present

Speaker: NA
Text: Government it is Scholes's fault or Cohen's fault,

Speaker: NA
Text: or maybe somebody else's fault.

Speaker: Mr COHEN
Text: He's got 78 per cent popularity.

Speaker: NA
Text: That's where he is different.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Text: I do not care what percent-

Speaker: NA
Text: age popularity the Prime Minister has; the fact of

Speaker: NA
Text: the matter is that the events of the last year and

Speaker: NA
Text: the events of recent years demonstrate that, far

Speaker: NA
Text: from the present Prime Minister being above it all

Speaker: NA
Text: and being immune to criticism, he has been there

Speaker: NA
Text: in the thick of it. He has been as divisive, as

Speaker: NA
Text: confrontationist, as negative and as partisan as

Speaker: NA
Text: any other political leader in Australia. He demon-

Speaker: NA
Text: strated that when he was President of the ACTO,

Speaker: NA
Text: He demonstrated that when he was a member of

Speaker: NA
Text: the then Labor Opposition. He is perfectly happy

Speaker: NA
Text: to join in criticism of the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Hume ( Mr Lusher), but does he offer a word of

Speaker: NA
Text: criticism of the Minister for Territories and Local

Speaker: NA
Text: Government ( Mr Uren) for what he is doing?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr MCGauran-No.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Text: Does he talk about that Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister's subsidised flat? Of course he does not. He is

Speaker: NA
Text: perfectly happy to stand by and laugh at the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Transport Workers Union has put a ban

Speaker: NA
Text: on the honourable member for Hume, but is he

Speaker: NA
Text: willing to criticise the conduct of his own Special

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister of State, whose crime was much greater

Speaker: NA
Text: because that Minister was responsible for leaking

Speaker: NA
Text: information that could have been dangerous to

Speaker: NA
Text: national security.

Speaker: Mr COHEN
Text: Oh!

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Text: The Minister for Home

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs and Environment, who is at the table, says:

Speaker: NA
Text: of 'Oh'. I know that he does not like being reminded

Speaker: NA
Text: of these things. I know that he does not like being

Speaker: NA
Text: told about the double standards of his Leader, but

Speaker: NA
Text: they are double standards. I can tell the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: that a lot more reminding about the double stan-

Speaker: NA
Text: dards of the Prime Minister is going to go on in the

Speaker: NA
Text: months ahead.

Speaker: Mrs KELLY
Text: Canberra)(4.59)-Before I

Speaker: NA
Text: begin my comments on the Appropriation Bills, I

Speaker: NA
Text: offer my congratulations to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Hughes ( Mr Tickner) on his maiden

Speaker: NA
Text: speech. It was a wonderful speech and I look for-

Speaker: NA
Text: ward to working with him for many years in this

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was interested in the new-found obsession

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke) of the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Bennelong ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Howard). Obviously he was attempting to find

Speaker: NA
Text: out how the Prime Minister manages to get his 78

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent popularity polling. I imagine he is par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticularly interested in the fact that the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: ister holds a higher level of popularity among Lib-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral supporters than does his own Leader, the

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: he should devote some of his attention to looking

Speaker: NA
Text: to his own Party and should let us look after our

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also noted with interest the reference of the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Bennelong to Paul

Speaker: NA
Text: Kelly's excellent book, The Hawke Ascendancy.

Speaker: NA
Text: The chapters I was particularly interested in were

Speaker: NA
Text: those containing the comments about the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member's own performance when Treasurer,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly the difficulties he experienced in get-

Speaker: NA
Text: ting so many of his policies accepted by the pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: vious Prime Minister. I think he would do much

Speaker: NA
Text: better if he were to look at the problems he ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: perienced in government and were to look

Speaker: NA
Text: towards reforms in his own Party.

Speaker: NA
Text: Today I wish to speak on the issue of consumer

Speaker: NA
Text: affairs. This is a topic which has been neglected by

Speaker: NA
Text: this House. It is an area which has an enormous

Speaker: NA
Text: impact on individuals' lives and it is an area in

Speaker: NA
Text: which this Government has made a substantial

Speaker: NA
Text: impact despite the fact that this issue has

Speaker: NA
Text: discussed in this House. The consumer movement

Speaker: NA
Text: is a creation of the generation represented by the

Speaker: NA
Text: younger members of this House. When I was a

Speaker: NA
Text: child there was no consumer movement in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. During the 1960s the Australian con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumer movement grew from nothing to a force to

Speaker: NA
Text: be reckoned with in Australian politics. The new

Speaker: NA
Text: movement successfully lobbied for the creation of

Speaker: NA
Text: State consumer affairs bureaus. Between 1969

Speaker: NA
Text: and 1974 every State and Territory established a

Speaker: NA
Text: consumer affairs bureau or department. Then, in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1974, the Whitlam Government created

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's premier consumer protection

Speaker: NA
Text: agency-the Trade Practices Commission.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unfortunately, Australia's major political par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties have been slow to recognise consumerism as a

Speaker: NA
Text: significant new social movement. I include my

Speaker: NA
Text: own Party in this criticism. Too many old style

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor people view the consumer movement as

Speaker: NA
Text: trendy and middle class or, alternatively, as not to

Speaker: NA
Text: be taken seriously because it is predominated by

Speaker: NA
Text: women. I recall references by some of my col-

Speaker: NA
Text: leagues in past years to 'strident housewives

Speaker: NA
Text: whinging about food prices'. On the other side of

Speaker: NA
Text: politics, even more simplistic views of the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumer movement were put. It was regarded as a

Speaker: NA
Text: new power base for the radical Left and the

Speaker: NA
Text: blindly anti-business. These are the sorts of

Speaker: NA
Text: slogans that we have heard issued by the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: servative members of this House. Fortunately,

Speaker: NA
Text: those honourable members in the Labor Party

Speaker: NA
Text: who want to discount consumerism have now be-

Speaker: NA
Text: Min- come a minority. This Government is building a

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment to consumer protection reform

Speaker: NA
Text: which will be of historic significance. I am glad to

Speaker: NA
Text: see the Minister for Home Affairs and Environ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment ( Mr Cohen), who is responsible for these

Speaker: NA
Text: matters, in the House today.

Speaker: NA
Text: Consumerism is not a passing fad. Choice

Speaker: NA
Text: magazine now has a circulation of over

Speaker: NA
Text: 200,000-an understatement of its impact be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause so many families share subscriptions and, as

Speaker: NA
Text: any librarian would tell us, so many read it in pub-

Speaker: NA
Text: lic libraries.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs Darling-It is a good magazine.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs KELLy-It is indeed. It provides a lot of

Speaker: NA
Text: valuable information. In 1974, the Labor Party

Speaker: NA
Text: came to realise that the consumer movement was

Speaker: NA
Text: the important new social movement of the late

Speaker: NA
Text: twentieth century, just as trade unionism was the

Speaker: NA
Text: emerging great social movement of the late nine-

Speaker: NA
Text: teenth century. Exactly 10 years ago the Whitlam

Speaker: NA
Text: Government encouraged and funded the estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: lishment of a peak council for the consumer

Speaker: NA
Text: movement-the Australian Federation of Con-

Speaker: NA
Text: not been sumer Organisations, or AFCO. AFCO has a

Speaker: NA
Text: membership of 55 consumer groups. Through reg-

Speaker: NA
Text: ular conferences, AFCO builds consensus within

Speaker: NA
Text: the movement so that it speaks to governments

Speaker: NA
Text: with one voice on matters of policy. The other im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portant function of AFCO is to co-ordinate the

Speaker: NA
Text: activities of consumer representatives on some 70

Speaker: NA
Text: governmental or quasi-governmental committees.

Speaker: NA
Text: No government has given greater recognition to

Speaker: NA
Text: the principle of balancing producer represen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tation with consumer representation than the

Speaker: NA
Text: Hawke Government. The Prime Minister has

Speaker: NA
Text: appointed Dr John Braithwaite from AFCO to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Economic Planning Advisory Council-the

Speaker: NA
Text: most important advisory council in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: This Government has a philosophy of con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumer representation which the conservative par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties lack. The main points of this philosophy are:

Speaker: NA
Text: Producer representatives on government com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittees or councils should be balanced by con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumer representatives wherever possible. Con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumer representatives should be selected from

Speaker: NA
Text: nominees of a democratically constituted con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumer movement just as trade union representa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tives are selected from nominees by the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Council of Trade Unions. The Fraser

Speaker: NA
Text: Government had a propensity to appoint political

Speaker: NA
Text: hacks and call them consumer representatives.

Speaker: NA
Text: These people had no means of consulting with

Speaker: NA
Text: and reporting to a wide base of consumers. Often

Speaker: NA
Text: they were no match for business representatives

Speaker: NA
Text: because they lacked a support network for infor-

Speaker: NA
Text: mation and research.

Speaker: NA
Text: Consumer representatives should be dispro-

Speaker: NA
Text: portionately women. While most business and

Speaker: NA
Text: trade union leaders are men, large numbers of

Speaker: NA
Text: women active in the consumer movement give

Speaker: NA
Text: governments a chance to 'increase the voice of

Speaker: NA
Text: women. I note with satisfaction the recent

Speaker: NA
Text: appointment by my colleague, the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Primary Industry ( Mr Kerin), of a female AFCO

Speaker: NA
Text: representative, Mrs Suzanne Russel, to the In-

Speaker: NA
Text: terim Inspection Policy Council, the recent

Speaker: NA
Text: appointment of Dr Kate Harrison to the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Broadcasting Corporation's National

Speaker: NA
Text: Program Advisory Committee, and the suggestion

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Minister for Health, (Dr Blewett), that

Speaker: NA
Text: AFCO's current male appointee to the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Health and Medical Research Council be

Speaker: NA
Text: replaced by a female appointee during the next

Speaker: NA
Text: triennium.

Speaker: NA
Text: In June 1983, soon after the election of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Hawke Government, AFCO published a policy

Speaker: NA
Text: paper proposing a wide range of reforms the new

Speaker: NA
Text: government should consider to give consumers a

Speaker: NA
Text: better deal. One of them was for enhanced con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumer representation. I have already dealt with

Speaker: NA
Text: the progress of this Government in this area. Be-

Speaker: NA
Text: yond that, it is remarkable to run through this

Speaker: NA
Text: document just nine months after it was released,

Speaker: NA
Text: and just over one year after the Hawke Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Government came into power, to note how many

Speaker: NA
Text: of the proposed reforms have already been

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced by the Government. Let me list some

Speaker: NA
Text: of them.

Speaker: NA
Text: In its June 1983 paper, AFCO urged that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth be given power to order the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: call of hazardous consumer products. At the mo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, governments can only try to persuade

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacturers to recall dangerous goods. By Sep-

Speaker: NA
Text: tember last year, State Ministers had agreed with

Speaker: NA
Text: the Federal Minister that the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: should have a reserve power to force unscrupu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lous traders into recalls which they refuse to do

Speaker: NA
Text: voluntarily. The Department of Home Affairs

Speaker: NA
Text: and Environment is currently working on appro-

Speaker: NA
Text: priate legislation. It is notable that the Confeder-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation of Australian Industry has decided not to

Speaker: NA
Text: oppose this progressive legislation. The AFCO

Speaker: NA
Text: paper also proposed that the Trade Practices Act

Speaker: NA
Text: be amended to forbid the export of banned prod-

Speaker: NA
Text: ucts. This suggestion has been adopted in the

Speaker: NA
Text: paper of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth

Speaker: NA
Text: Evans) outlining possible amendments to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Trade Practices Act. It is a very welcome ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: vance. I understand that legislation will come be-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore the House during its Budget session.

Speaker: NA
Text: AFCO urged implementation of the report of

Speaker: NA
Text: the inquiry into hazardous chemicals by the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives Standing Committee on

Speaker: NA
Text: Environment and Conservation. Included among

Speaker: NA
Text: the initiatives of this Government to implement

Speaker: NA
Text: that report are moves to establish a national insti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tute of environmental and occupational health

Speaker: NA
Text: and a chemical hazards assessment unit to evalu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate toxicological data oq chemicals in the Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of Health. Drafting of legislation to control

Speaker: NA
Text: hazardous chemicals in the Australian Capital

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory has also finally begun. Much still re-

Speaker: NA
Text: mains to be done, however, to protect Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: consumers and workers from hazardous chemi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cals. However, progress is under way.

Speaker: NA
Text: AFCO also urged the Government to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: for legal action by groups of consumers who have

Speaker: NA
Text: suffered a common harm. This is Labor policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government is awaiting a report of the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Law Reform Commission on access to the

Speaker: NA
Text: courts before introducing fully fledged represen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tative actions. In the meantime, however, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Attorney-General and the Minister for Home

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs and Environment have announced that it

Speaker: NA
Text: is proposed to allow the Trade Practices Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission to seek redress on behalf of consumers

Speaker: NA
Text: harmed as a result of business conduct which has

Speaker: NA
Text: been the subject of a successful Commission legal

Speaker: NA
Text: action. In the past, the Commission has been able

Speaker: NA
Text: to convict companies only to find that it has now

Speaker: NA
Text: power to act collectively on behalf of the large

Speaker: NA
Text: numbers of consumers injured by the companies.

Speaker: NA
Text: AFCO urged reform to deal with problems of

Speaker: NA
Text: discrimination in the market place, such as dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: crimination against women in the granting of

Speaker: NA
Text: credit. The sex discrimination legislation of my

Speaker: NA
Text: colleague, the Minister for Education and Youth

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs (Senator Ryan), will go a long way

Speaker: NA
Text: towards dealing with these problems. AFCO

Speaker: NA
Text: urged that the warranty provisions of the Trade

Speaker: NA
Text: Practices Act be available against inadequate ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices, such as insurance, as well as inadequate

Speaker: NA
Text: goods. The Government has also indicated a de-

Speaker: NA
Text: sire to introduce this reform in the exposure draft

Speaker: NA
Text: Trade Practices Act amendments.

Speaker: NA
Text: AFCO complained of the unreasonable limi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tations of the razor gang ministerial directive to

Speaker: NA
Text: confine Trade Practices Commission consumer

Speaker: NA
Text: protection work to cases arising from complaints

Speaker: NA
Text: and only to cases affecting more than one State.

Speaker: NA
Text: This directive has been lifted. AFCO urged a need

Speaker: NA
Text: for energy labelling on major household ap.

Speaker: NA
Text: pliances such as refrigerators, freezers, heaters,

Speaker: NA
Text: and so on. Such labels would allow comparative

Speaker: NA
Text: shopping on the basis of the amount of energy

Speaker: NA
Text: consumed by competing brands. The Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) has made

Speaker: NA
Text: this a priority since March 1983. AFCO has been

Speaker: NA
Text: given representation on the Minister's Energy

Speaker: NA
Text: Labelling Implementation Code of Practice

Speaker: NA
Text: Drafting Committee.

Speaker: NA
Text: The consumer movement expressed a variety of

Speaker: NA
Text: deep concerns about the Australian Broadcasting

Speaker: NA
Text: Tribunal's report on cable and subscription tele-

Speaker: NA
Text: vision. Since the honourable member for Holt

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Duffy) became Minister for Communi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cations, the Government has been responsive to

Speaker: NA
Text: the consumer movement's concerns for a cautious

Speaker: NA
Text: approach to cable and subscription television

Speaker: NA
Text: which guarantees public participation rather than

Speaker: NA
Text: monopolisation of the new technology, which

Speaker: NA
Text: protects Australian content and the quality of

Speaker: NA
Text: programs.

Speaker: NA
Text: I could outline many of the other developments

Speaker: NA
Text: in this area, but before I conclude I would like to

Speaker: NA
Text: make reference to some areas where progress

Speaker: NA
Text: should be made to give consumers in Australia the

Speaker: NA
Text: protection they need. Consumer education is one

Speaker: NA
Text: area where Federal initiatives are needed. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Fraser Government scrapped the Curriculum De-

Speaker: NA
Text: velopment Centre in the Department of Edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation and Youth Affairs. The Centre has now

Speaker: NA
Text: been restored by this Government. There is a need

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Consumer Affairs Division in the Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of Home Affairs and Environment to do a

Speaker: NA
Text: lot more on consumer education. Another area

Speaker: NA
Text: that needs to be examined is that of electronic

Speaker: NA
Text: funds transfer systems. This new technology mys-

Speaker: NA
Text: tifies consumers and puts them at some risk of

Speaker: NA
Text: being victims of computer error or inadequate se-

Speaker: NA
Text: curity over their plastic transaction cards. In the,

Speaker: NA
Text: past, the .Commonwealth has simply hot done

Speaker: NA
Text: enough to ensure that new technology such as this

Speaker: NA
Text: is introduced in a way which provides maximum

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit to consumers and builds in guarantees of

Speaker: NA
Text: consumer education. Soon shoppers all over

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia will be putting a plastic card in an

Speaker: NA
Text: automated teller machine to pay their grocery

Speaker: NA
Text: bills. Unfortunately, the race between financial

Speaker: NA
Text: institutions to get in first with this technology may

Speaker: NA
Text: mean that consumers will have to confront a row

Speaker: NA
Text: of incompatible automated teller machines at the

Speaker: NA
Text: checkout-one for the banks, one for the building

Speaker: NA
Text: societies, one for the credit unions, and so on.

Speaker: NA
Text: important that the interests of consumers are pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: tected as well as the interests of financial insti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tutions when we are looking at new technology.

Speaker: NA
Text: Other areas need to be looked at in the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of them is the possibility of establishing an

Speaker: NA
Text: adequately resourced consumer product safety

Speaker: NA
Text: authority. Hazardous products traded interstate

Speaker: NA
Text: and internationally must be accepted as a national

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility if we are to shake off our status as a

Speaker: NA
Text: Third World country with respect to product

Speaker: NA
Text: safety, a country in which other nations feel they

Speaker: NA
Text: can dump banned products with immunity.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia needs a consumer product safety auth-

Speaker: NA
Text: ority to get down to the job of writing mandatory

Speaker: NA
Text: standards in areas where there is evidence of

Speaker: NA
Text: serious injury to consumers. Examples of

Speaker: NA
Text: unregulated products which need national

Speaker: NA
Text: mandatory safety standards include plastics

Speaker: NA
Text: which come in contact with food, where a stan-

Speaker: NA
Text: dard is needed to prevent migration of chemicals

Speaker: NA
Text: into food from plastic packaging, and particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: plastics which might be used in microwave ovens;

Speaker: NA
Text: constructional and flammability requirements to

Speaker: NA
Text: protect children from death and injury from toys;

Speaker: NA
Text: a standard to prevent the risk of eye damage from

Speaker: NA
Text: poor quality lenses in sunglasses; for motor ve-

Speaker: NA
Text: hicle tyres, new and replacement, a standard to

Speaker: NA
Text: prevent fatalities on the road from defective tyres;

Speaker: NA
Text: labelling of solariums to advise on the severe risk

Speaker: NA
Text: of skin damage; labelling of sun screen agents, to

Speaker: NA
Text: advise on the products' screening effectiveness;

Speaker: NA
Text: labelling of kerosene heaters to prevent use of

Speaker: NA
Text: dangerous fuels. I could give many other

Speaker: NA
Text: examples. I have outlined some of the develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments that have taken place in the consumer area

Speaker: NA
Text: under the Hawke Government. At the same time,

Speaker: NA
Text: I hope that we will continue our advancement in

Speaker: NA
Text: the field of consumer protection. The philosophy

Speaker: NA
Text: of this Government is that some areas of con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumer protection are a national responsibility.

Speaker: NA
Text: Not everything can be left to the States. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government acknowledges that there must be

Speaker: NA
Text: consultation with the States, but it is important

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Federal Government take responsibility

Speaker: NA
Text: for certain areas of national legislation in the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumer area.

Speaker: NA
Text: Over the last year I have outlined many specific

Speaker: NA
Text: developments in the consumer area. Of course,

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian consumers are affected by a wide

Speaker: NA
Text: range of policy issues, including Medicare, the es-

Speaker: NA
Text: tablishment of the Prices Surveillance Authority,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the improvement in the economy. All of these

Speaker: NA
Text: areas work towards making Australia a better

Speaker: NA
Text: place for the consumer. The Hawke Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Government must continue its initiative in this

Speaker: NA
Text: area. I believe that it is an area which should re-

Speaker: NA
Text: It is ceive a great deal more consideration by this

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Millar)-

Speaker: NA
Text: Before calling the honourable member for Rich-

Speaker: NA
Text: mond ( Mr Blunt), I remind the House that the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member is about to make his maiden

Speaker: NA
Text: speech. I ask the House to extend the customary

Speaker: NA
Text: courtesies.

Speaker: Mr BLUNT
Text: Richmond) (5.15)-On rising in

Speaker: NA
Text: this House to speak for the first time I should like

Speaker: NA
Text: to express my sincere thanks to honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members. I am appreciative of the cordial and

Speaker: NA
Text: friendly way in which they have received me and

Speaker: NA
Text: helped me in recent weeks. It is my sincere hope

Speaker: NA
Text: that the cordial relationships which have devel-

Speaker: NA
Text: oped in the recent past will continue for all my

Speaker: NA
Text: time in this place. Additionally, I should like to

Speaker: NA
Text: thank the parliamentary officers for their help in

Speaker: NA
Text: explaining the procedures and formalities of this

Speaker: NA
Text: House. If I fail to observe all of these formalities

Speaker: NA
Text: will not be the fault of those who have tutored me.

Speaker: NA
Text: The electoral division of Richmond, which I

Speaker: NA
Text: have the honour to represent, was created at Fed-

Speaker: NA
Text: eration and in that time has been represented by

Speaker: NA
Text: only six members, of whom I am the sixth. All my

Speaker: NA
Text: predecessors have been distinguished parliamen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tarians, all have been non-Labor, predominantly

Speaker: NA
Text: National Party or its predecessor, the Coun-ry

Speaker: NA
Text: Party. The first member was Sir Thomas Ewing.

Speaker: NA
Text: He was followed by Sir Walter Massey-Greene,

Speaker: NA
Text: then Roland Green, and then Larry Anthony, the

Speaker: NA
Text: father of the former member, the Rt Hon. Doug

Speaker: NA
Text: Anthony. Larry Anthony and his son Doug

Speaker: NA
Text: Anthony represented the electorate of Richmond

Speaker: NA
Text: for almost 50 years. I am extremely conscious of

Speaker: NA
Text: the responsibility and standard that both the

Speaker: NA
Text: Anthonys set and which I have to live up to. I take

Speaker: NA
Text: this opportunity to wish Doug Anthony and his

Speaker: NA
Text: wife Margot a long, happy and satisfying retire-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. I also thank the National Party organis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation in Richmond for selecting me to carry the

Speaker: NA
Text: Party's banner. I sincerely hope that I will be able

Speaker: NA
Text: to fulfil its confidence in me.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of the previous representatives for Richmond,

Speaker: NA
Text: undoubtedly the most distinguished was my pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: decessor, the Rt Hon. 1. D. Anthony. He is well

Speaker: NA
Text: known not only to members of this House but also

Speaker: NA
Text: to Australians at large and to many people over-

Speaker: NA
Text: seas. Doug Anthony represented the people of

Speaker: NA
Text: Richmond well. He served his country with dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinction and credit, both at home and overseas. In

Speaker: NA
Text: the course of his long parliamentary career he

Speaker: NA
Text: held many high offices, including the positions of

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Prime Minister and Leader of my Party,

Speaker: NA
Text: the National Party of Australia. He will be

Speaker: NA
Text: recorded in the history of our Party as a great and

Speaker: NA
Text: successful leader. In the course of his long career,

Speaker: NA
Text: which extended over 27 years, Doug Anthony

Speaker: NA
Text: earned a reputation as a capable parliamentarian,

Speaker: NA
Text: a strong leader and an astute politician. To his

Speaker: NA
Text: great credit, he earned and maintained a repu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tation for honesty and integrity, a reputation that

Speaker: NA
Text: has never been questioned. It is an honour to fol-

Speaker: NA
Text: Iowa man of the calibre of Doug Anthony. It is an

Speaker: NA
Text: honour to represent the people of Richmond. I

Speaker: NA
Text: thank'the people of Richmond for their support

Speaker: NA
Text: and pledge to work to promote and advance their

Speaker: NA
Text: interests.

Speaker: NA
Text: Richmond is perhaps one of the most beautiful

Speaker: NA
Text: and diverse electorates in Australia. The climate

Speaker: NA
Text: is warm, the beaches are magnificent, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: landscape is nearly always green. It has been de-

Speaker: NA
Text: scribed, justifiably I believe, as Eden. These basic

Speaker: NA
Text: attributes have been the foundation of the ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: tremely rapid growth that has taken place in re-

Speaker: NA
Text: it cent years. Our major industries are the tra-

Speaker: NA
Text: ditional rural industries of the region and also the

Speaker: NA
Text: new industries based on the region's natural

Speaker: NA
Text: advantages. New crops such as avocadoes and

Speaker: NA
Text: macadamias have been introduced. Additionally,

Speaker: NA
Text: the tourist industry has grown. Richmond has be-

Speaker: NA
Text: come a playground for the residents of the metro-

Speaker: NA
Text: politan areas. To further our development in

Speaker: NA
Text: Richmond and to further the growth of the tourist

Speaker: NA
Text: industry, it is essential that priority be given to

Speaker: NA
Text: developing rational and economical air fare poli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cies in Australia, and greater emphasis must be

Speaker: NA
Text: placed on road funding. The potential for growth

Speaker: NA
Text: in Richmond is almost unlimited, but we must be

Speaker: NA
Text: careful not to damage our natural environment.

Speaker: NA
Text: In my opinion if the so-called sunrise ind1.istries

Speaker: NA
Text: are to be encouraged anywhere in Australia they

Speaker: NA
Text: should be encouraged in the Northern Rivers re-

Speaker: NA
Text: gion as that would appear to be the most logical

Speaker: NA
Text: place for them to grow and develop. Industry

Speaker: NA
Text: should be encouraged where people are and

Speaker: NA
Text: where jobs are needed. It is futile to fight econ-

Speaker: NA
Text: omic and population trends. Why attempt to lo-

Speaker: NA
Text: cate industries in cold southern climes except for

Speaker: NA
Text: short term political expediency? The Northern

Speaker: NA
Text: Rivers region is one of the fastest growing areas in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia and it is common sense to encourage

Speaker: NA
Text: new industries to this area. The high technology

Speaker: NA
Text: sunrise industries are the logical choice to encour-

Speaker: NA
Text: age to Richmond. They are clean, they do not

Speaker: NA
Text: damage the environment, and they provide em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment for young people who are able to grow

Speaker: NA
Text: and develop with them.

Speaker: NA
Text: If we are to provide the right foundation for

Speaker: NA
Text: these new and exciting industries we must ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that our work force can cope with the challenges

Speaker: NA
Text: that they provide and supply the work skills

Speaker: NA
Text: needed by them. Without doubt the Northern

Speaker: NA
Text: Rivers region requires additional education facili-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties. Priority must be given to developing fully the

Speaker: NA
Text: Northern Rivers College of Advanced Education

Speaker: NA
Text: at Lismore and more funds must be made avail-

Speaker: NA
Text: able for technical education.

Speaker: NA
Text: The rapid population growth of the north coast

Speaker: NA
Text: region in recent years is a result of decisions

Speaker: NA
Text: tired people, families and young people to enjoy

Speaker: NA
Text: the tremendous natural advantages of the region.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am committed to working to ensure that the

Speaker: NA
Text: people of Richmond enjoy a high and rising stan-

Speaker: NA
Text: dard of living. I am concerned to protect our

Speaker: NA
Text: environment, to enhance the community's ameni-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties and to promote economic development to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide prosperity and security. It is essential that

Speaker: NA
Text: we have a stable social and economic environ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in which individuals and families can plan

Speaker: NA
Text: their future.

Speaker: NA
Text: In Richmond, small business is big business. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: the largest employer and the most important sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor of our economy. Small business is suffering in

Speaker: NA
Text: the current economic environment. It is suffering

Speaker: NA
Text: because the Government does not understand

Speaker: NA
Text: business. It does not understand the need of busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness to make a profit. The Government feels that

Speaker: NA
Text: business is the goose that laid the golden egg, that

Speaker: NA
Text: it can be taxed and can pay increasing govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment charges to finance government largesse, for

Speaker: NA
Text: political reasons, in other sectors of the economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is the state and development of the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian economy that now I propose to address.

Speaker: NA
Text: Governments in the Western world face a di-

Speaker: NA
Text: lemma. On the one hand economists tell us to

Speaker: NA
Text: spend less, to restrict the size of Budget deficits

Speaker: NA
Text: and to limit the growth in the supply of money.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, on the other hand there are consider-

Speaker: NA
Text: able and often irresistible electoral pressures on

Speaker: NA
Text: government to spend more. Considered in iso-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation, every individual cause or case is worthy of

Speaker: NA
Text: support or special consideration. However, the

Speaker: NA
Text: basic law of economics-limited resources to

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfy unlimited demands-restrains the

Speaker: NA
Text: generosity of government. This conflict-the

Speaker: NA
Text: spend more, spend less conflict-extends to other

Speaker: NA
Text: aspects of government activity. Often we are told

Speaker: NA
Text: that government has become too big; that there is

Speaker: NA
Text: too much law, too many regulations and too many

Speaker: NA
Text: obstacles in the way of individuals or the other
