Speaker: NA
Text: entities that make up our economy to permit them

Speaker: NA
Text: to grow and develop. Most laws and regulations

Speaker: NA
Text: are to stop people doing"things; they are negative

Speaker: NA
Text: in their impact.

Speaker: NA
Text: We hear cries for small government and the

Speaker: NA
Text: need to limit the size and power of the public sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor. However, there is an essential conflict. While

Speaker: NA
Text: many people cry small government, the same

Speaker: NA
Text: people, in a different context, cry with equal con-

Speaker: NA
Text: viction that government should do something

Speaker: NA
Text: about it, or them. Again a dilemma faces govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. It is a dilemma arising from the contradic-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory attitudes that exist within our society. These

Speaker: NA
Text: contradictory attitudes exist simultaneously

Speaker: NA
Text: within each and everyone of us. No one is im-

Speaker: NA
Text: by remune; we are all susceptible. It depends on the

Speaker: NA
Text: issue. There is no simple answer to this problem

Speaker: NA
Text: which I believe is a major philosophical question

Speaker: NA
Text: facing any democratic government in a developed

Speaker: NA
Text: mixed economy today. It is possible to spend more

Speaker: NA
Text: and to have huge deficits and massive taxation. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is possible-it is attempted by some parties-to

Speaker: NA
Text: regulate everything that moves, to encumber the

Speaker: NA
Text: individual and enterprise with so much red tape

Speaker: NA
Text: that they cease to work. The result is to remove

Speaker: NA
Text: incentive from society, to tax away the will to

Speaker: NA
Text: work and to regulate to submission the incentive

Speaker: NA
Text: of the entrepreneur. The consequence is a society

Speaker: NA
Text: totally dominated by government and a popu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation lacking in spirit. This is not what I want for

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia and it is not what Australians want for

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves and their children.

Speaker: NA
Text: The real answer to this philosophical problem is

Speaker: NA
Text: for government to recognise its responsibility and

Speaker: NA
Text: to adhere to that responsibility; to resist the temp-

Speaker: NA
Text: tation, which arises from political grounds, to be-

Speaker: NA
Text: come involved in areas that are more properly or

Speaker: NA
Text: best left to other institutions or to individuals

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves. The proper role of government is to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide a framework within which our society can

Speaker: NA
Text: operate in a social, commercial and industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: sense. It is always dangerous to simplify but the

Speaker: NA
Text: legitimate objective and role of government in our

Speaker: NA
Text: society is to provide for Australia's people a better

Speaker: NA
Text: place in which to live and work. It is not the role

Speaker: NA
Text: of government to employ everyone in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Governments do not create wealth. If govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments attempt to increase the size of the public

Speaker: NA
Text: sector beyond the capacity of the private sector to

Speaker: NA
Text: support it, there will be no Australia; we, will all

Speaker: NA
Text: be on the dole of some other more far-sighted

Speaker: NA
Text: foreign country that allows the private sector to

Speaker: NA
Text: continue.

Speaker: NA
Text: A rational and objective consideration of the

Speaker: NA
Text: factors affecting life in Australia today will show,

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe, that this is the only approach that will

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure progress and growth. Ad hoc policies de-

Speaker: NA
Text: signed to provide short term solutions for the sake

Speaker: NA
Text: of political expediency do not stand up to scrutiny

Speaker: NA
Text: and will not endure. Ad hoc policies are in the

Speaker: NA
Text: nature of tactical decisions-tactical political de-

Speaker: NA
Text: cisions. If the motivation for such decisions is gen-

Speaker: NA
Text: erally false then the response that they initiate in

Speaker: NA
Text: government will also be false. There is nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: more certain than the fate of governments with-

Speaker: NA
Text: out commitment to providing enduring solutions

Speaker: NA
Text: to the real problems that face Australia today.

Speaker: NA
Text: Superficial governments-governments that live

Speaker: NA
Text: by tactics-will die by those tactics.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian people are mature and sophisti-

Speaker: NA
Text: cated. They will inevitably reject the shadow of

Speaker: NA
Text: appearances for the reality of policy-providing,

Speaker: NA
Text: of course, that these policies are designed to make

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia a better place in which to live and work;

Speaker: NA
Text: a place where the average person can be confident

Speaker: NA
Text: of his or her future, where there are more jobs,

Speaker: NA
Text: less tax, freedom for the individual and a free

Speaker: NA
Text: enterprise economy which provides a rising stan-

Speaker: NA
Text: dard of living.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe that Australians are basically self-

Speaker: NA
Text: reliant, with a preference for looking after them-

Speaker: NA
Text: selves rather than being looked after-especially

Speaker: NA
Text: if the price of being looked after is a loss of free-

Speaker: NA
Text: dom. This loss of freedom is inherent in the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinued growth in the public sector. This growth re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quires, for example, all Australians to carry a

Speaker: NA
Text: plastic card bearing a number and to submit to

Speaker: NA
Text: lodging returns for simple, basic health care for

Speaker: NA
Text: their families.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians will not tolerate indecisive govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments. Governments must not, under any circum-

Speaker: NA
Text: stances, create feelings of insecurity or uncer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainty among the people of Australia. This is a

Speaker: NA
Text: basic responsibility of government, a responsi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bility which must be lived up to. It should be of

Speaker: NA
Text: paramount consideration, especially in regard to

Speaker: NA
Text: the aged or families. It is grossly irresponsible

Speaker: NA
Text: government to create feelings of insecurity and

Speaker: NA
Text: uncertainty in a sector of our society-one which

Speaker: NA
Text: has contributed to our country for 40 years or 50

Speaker: NA
Text: years in the work place-when people in that sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor are trying to plan for their retirement in their

Speaker: NA
Text: old age without knowing the guidelines and rules

Speaker: NA
Text: which the Government will apply to their retire-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. All government policies should be even-

Speaker: NA
Text: handed. They should not discriminate between

Speaker: NA
Text: our citizens. We should not create classes of citi-

Speaker: NA
Text: zens within Australia. There is no role for positive

Speaker: NA
Text: discrimination in favour of one Australian on the

Speaker: NA
Text: ground that other Australians can look after

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves. All Australians should be equal be-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore the government and should have equal op-

Speaker: NA
Text: portunity. All Australians should have the oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunity to benefit from all the laws and provisions

Speaker: NA
Text: of this country irrespective of their sex, the colour

Speaker: NA
Text: of their skin or their religion. Australia is one

Speaker: NA
Text: nation and unless we are to face major social

Speaker: NA
Text: problems in the future it is essential that all

Speaker: NA
Text: government policies, as well as the public pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: nouncements and rhetoric associated with them,

Speaker: NA
Text: actually encourage unity.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's future lies as a trading nation. If we

Speaker: NA
Text: are to exploit and prosper from the natural

Speaker: NA
Text: advantages and resources of this nation we must

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that they are available to the people of the

Speaker: NA
Text: world. Australians will maximise their standard of

Speaker: NA
Text: living only if the resources of this country are de-

Speaker: NA
Text: veloped. It is total economic nonsense to attempt

Speaker: NA
Text: to be self-sufficient. Australia must trade. If we do

Speaker: NA
Text: not trade we will decline. We must sell what we

Speaker: NA
Text: can produce cheaply and well and we must buy

Speaker: NA
Text: the best products of our trading partners. All sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tors of the Australian economy must recognise

Speaker: NA
Text: this economic truism.

Speaker: NA
Text: All Australians must be made aware of the

Speaker: NA
Text: costs of government intervention in the economy,

Speaker: NA
Text: the impact that government intervention has on

Speaker: NA
Text: the markets, the costs of distortion and the conse-

Speaker: NA
Text: quences of disrupting the rational allocation ofre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sources throughout the economy. It is essential

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Government begin to dismantle the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: tection and support schemes which are burdens

Speaker: NA
Text: on our industries-burdens which cost jobs, in-

Speaker: NA
Text: crease taxes and depress our standard of living.

Speaker: NA
Text: Briefly,these are the objectives w'hich I propose to

Speaker: NA
Text: work for in order to advance the interests of the

Speaker: NA
Text: people of Richmond and of Australia as a whole. I

Speaker: NA
Text: thank honourable members for listening in

Speaker: NA
Text: silence.

Speaker: Mr MAHER
Text: Lowe)(5.33)-I congratulate

Speaker: NA
Text: the two honourable members who have given

Speaker: NA
Text: their maiden speeches today-the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Hughes ( Mr Tickner) and the

Speaker: NA
Text: for a honourable member for Richmond ( Mr Blunt).

Speaker: NA
Text: Both of them were really quite impressive in their

Speaker: NA
Text: delivery and in their subject matter. I am sure that

Speaker: NA
Text: both of them will have a distinguished career in

Speaker: NA
Text: this House. I wish them well and I know that

Speaker: NA
Text: every honourable member who speaks in this de-

Speaker: NA
Text: bate later will also wish them well and will con-

Speaker: NA
Text: gratulate them on well delivered speeches.

Speaker: NA
Text: The House witnessed a rather unusual demon-

Speaker: NA
Text: stration last week on behalf of a number of people

Speaker: NA
Text: who want more money allocated in the Budget to

Speaker: NA
Text: low cost housing. While no one can condone such

Speaker: NA
Text: an interruption of the business of the House, one

Speaker: NA
Text: can understand the frustrations and the anger of

Speaker: NA
Text: the lobbyists who came here trying to get low cost

Speaker: NA
Text: housing. I am pleased to note that the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Housing and Construction ( Mr Hurford) is assur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing people who are lobbying for housing that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget will not forget these important interests.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, the Government's first priority must be'

Speaker: NA
Text: to the citizens who have been working and paying

Speaker: NA
Text: rent and who suddenly find when they go on the

Speaker: NA
Text: pension that they have an enormous cut in

Speaker: NA
Text: income-perhaps their income drops by two-

Speaker: NA
Text: thirds or more-and they can no longer pay rent

Speaker: NA
Text: and must, therefore, throw themselves on the

Speaker: NA
Text: mercy of the State housing commissions.

Speaker: NA
Text: We all know and we all see people in our consti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tuencies who are faced with this dilemma of a cut

Speaker: NA
Text: in income once they reach the age of 65 or 60

Speaker: NA
Text: years. These people must have first claim on the

Speaker: NA
Text: limited stock of public housing. The previous

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, much to its disgrace and shame,

Speaker: NA
Text: provided no funds at all for public housing except

Speaker: NA
Text: for the aged. The whole problem regarding the

Speaker: NA
Text: rundown of public housing and the calamitous

Speaker: NA
Text: shortage of housing for families is a disgrace to our

Speaker: NA
Text: nation, particularly when we compare ourselves

Speaker: NA
Text: with other countries. It has also caused a great

Speaker: NA
Text: heating-up of the rental market for housing, both

Speaker: NA
Text: in the big cities and in country areas.

Speaker: NA
Text: During the debate today on the Appropriation

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill (No.3) 1983-84, the Appropriation Bill (No.

Speaker: NA
Text: 4) 1983-84 and the Appropriation (Parliamen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary Departments) Bi1l (No.2) 1983-84, which

Speaker: NA
Text: are before the House, I wish to say a word for the

Speaker: NA
Text: provision of additional funding for education in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Budget-funding for our children, our future

Speaker: NA
Text: generations. I want to canvass generally the need

Speaker: NA
Text: for extra funds for the state schools and for the

Speaker: NA
Text: non-state schools. These schools are filled with

Speaker: NA
Text: the young people of our own areas who in many

Speaker: NA
Text: cases, I believe, are not getting a fair go. They are

Speaker: NA
Text: not getting an education in decent schools because

Speaker: NA
Text: many schools which I visit, particularly in my

Speaker: NA
Text: area, are very old, very run down and consider-

Speaker: NA
Text: ably lacking in facilities. I believe that the Departmothers

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of Education in New South Wales is unsure

Speaker: NA
Text: whether to keep some of them going. Perhaps for

Speaker: NA
Text: some reason those schools have missed out on

Speaker: NA
Text: funding over the years.

Speaker: NA
Text: Several weeks ago I visited Homebush West

Speaker: NA
Text: Public School in the electorate of Lowe. The situ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation there was so disgraceful that I came away

Speaker: NA
Text: quite upset. I felt that the little children in this

Speaker: NA
Text: school do not have a reasonably satisfactory es-

Speaker: NA
Text: tablishment to attend for their daily education.

Speaker: NA
Text: The teachers there are dedicated and the children

Speaker: NA
Text: are very keen but the school is disgustingly run

Speaker: NA
Text: down. The school is essentially an ethnic school.

Speaker: NA
Text: The largest ethnic groups in the school are the

Speaker: NA
Text: Chinese and Vietnamese children who are mainly

Speaker: NA
Text: the sons and daughters of the boat people who

Speaker: NA
Text: have come here. Thirty-two per cent of the 183

Speaker: NA
Text: children in that school fit into that category. The

Speaker: NA
Text: second group in the. school comprises the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian-born children or United Kingdom

Speaker: NA
Text: nationals, who make up 26 per cent of enrol-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments. The third largest group comprises the

Speaker: NA
Text: Turkish children, who speak Turkish at home and

Speaker: NA
Text: who make up 10 per cent of enrolments. The prin-

Speaker: NA
Text: cipal of the school, Mr Bill Allen, and his small

Speaker: NA
Text: staff work well and as hard as they possibly can to

Speaker: NA
Text: stimulate the children. Most of the classes are

Speaker: NA
Text: held in old buildings which comprised a former

Speaker: NA
Text: home science school for many years. It was called

Speaker: NA
Text: the Homebush West Girls Home Science School.

Speaker: NA
Text: In 1974 the secondary girls were sent off to Strath-

Speaker: NA
Text: field Girls High School and the school became a

Speaker: NA
Text: primary school.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I went around the school and looked at some

Speaker: NA
Text: of the old demountable classrooms, one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: teachers said to me in all frustration: 'I have 26

Speaker: NA
Text: children in the class, which is not very many, but

Speaker: NA
Text: only one of these kiddies speaks English at home.

Speaker: NA
Text: The rest speak other languages. Can't you do

Speaker: NA
Text: something to help me?' I really felt sorry for this

Speaker: NA
Text: teacher because it was a very hot day, the kinder-

Speaker: NA
Text: garten section of the school was housed in old,

Speaker: NA
Text: wooden, demountable buildings, there was no

Speaker: NA
Text: connection between the buildings and no covered

Speaker: NA
Text: way to the toilets for the little children in inclem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ent weather. I felt that this teacher was almost at

Speaker: NA
Text: the point of despair when she said: 'Can't you do

Speaker: NA
Text: something to help me? I am trying to battle with

Speaker: NA
Text: 26 children, only one of whom has English as a

Speaker: NA
Text: first language'. These are some of the problems.

Speaker: NA
Text: The school receives funding from the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth under the assisted schools program, which

Speaker: NA
Text: used to be called the disadvantaged schools

Speaker: NA
Text: program. But being such an ethnic school, there is

Speaker: NA
Text: no parents and citizens association. There is a

Speaker: NA
Text: club, which I am assured -y the principal

Speaker: NA
Text: is very active, but in which only a small number of

Speaker: NA
Text: mothers are involved. The school has a small li-

Speaker: NA
Text: brary but it is open only two days a week, despite

Speaker: NA
Text: the fact that such a preponderance of the children

Speaker: NA
Text: at this school come from families which may have

Speaker: NA
Text: no English language books or newspapers. So

Speaker: NA
Text: when we start planning for the Budget I hope and

Speaker: NA
Text: pray that there will be some real commitment to

Speaker: NA
Text: the capital funding of state schools in New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales and in every other State of Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Homebush West is not an exception. Unfortu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nately such schools are quite common in a State

Speaker: NA
Text: which must rely on Commonwealth funding and

Speaker: NA
Text: which must look to the Commonwealth for any

Speaker: NA
Text: capital injection to assist its state schools. Bur-

Speaker: NA
Text: wood Public School is a very large primary school

Speaker: NA
Text: in my electorate. As I have mentioned before in

Speaker: NA
Text: this House, the entire infants department of that

Speaker: NA
Text: school is housed in demountable classrooms. Also

Speaker: NA
Text: present at that school is that great ethnic mix of

Speaker: NA
Text: young children who have come to our nation and

Speaker: NA
Text: into its schools, perhaps not speaking English but

Speaker: NA
Text: speaking other languages. It is my hope that they

Speaker: NA
Text: will leave school not only able to read and write

Speaker: NA
Text: English but also perhaps able to read and write

Speaker: NA
Text: their own family languages. That will help to

Speaker: NA
Text: make our nation a greater place than it even is

Speaker: NA
Text: now.

Speaker: NA
Text: The whole of the infants department at Bur-

Speaker: NA
Text: wood Public School is housed in demountable

Speaker: NA
Text: classrooms. This is very pleasant on a nice, mild

Speaker: NA
Text: day but in the summer and in the winter it is ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: palling. It is a very sad commentary that parents

Speaker: NA
Text: have to take little children to start in demountable

Speaker: NA
Text: classrooms at a school which is crowded on a most

Speaker: NA
Text: unimpressive school playground which the State

Speaker: NA
Text: was to beautify some years ago but for which

Speaker: NA
Text: there has been no money available. Enfield Public

Speaker: NA
Text: School, North Strathfield Public School and

Speaker: NA
Text: many other schools in my electorate have similar

Speaker: NA
Text: problems. I know that the Prime Minister ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Hawke) came with me to visit Enfield Public

Speaker: NA
Text: School in my electorate in 1982. He was appalled

Speaker: NA
Text: at what he saw there. A parents action group was

Speaker: NA
Text: formed at that school and the State Government

Speaker: NA
Text: made some alterations. A certain amount of

Speaker: NA
Text: money was spent.

Speaker: NA
Text: The funds must come from the Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. The previous Government starved

Speaker: NA
Text: the States of funds. It cut back all the money

Speaker: NA
Text: available for this type of development. No money

Speaker: NA
Text: was available in the kitty to make any real injec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of funding to improve the run-down State

Speaker: NA
Text: schools in New South Wales or elsewhere in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. The schools in the non-government sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor, and 90 per cent of the non-government sector

Speaker: NA
Text: is the Catholic education sector, are just as bad. In

Speaker: NA
Text: some cases they are even worse. Newspaper

Speaker: NA
Text: articles which talk about state aid and the funding

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Catholic school systems of the various dio-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceses make the point that many of the parish

Speaker: NA
Text: schools operate on funding levels 30 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: below those of state schools.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think that, on the same day as I visited the

Speaker: NA
Text: Homebush West Public School, I visited also

Speaker: NA
Text: Saint Martha's parish school in Strathfield. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is also a small school and somewhat comparable,

Speaker: NA
Text: with an enrolment of 202 children, 50 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: whom are ethnic. The Principal, Sister Patricia

Speaker: NA
Text: Murray, OP, showed me around the school, which

Speaker: NA
Text: I had visited before, and explained that the big

Speaker: NA
Text: problem for the school is its total lack of play-

Speaker: NA
Text: ground space. The school is jammed right in next

Speaker: NA
Text: to the parish church. It makes use of an old

Speaker: NA
Text: church building in the grounds-the original St

Speaker: NA
Text: Martha's Church.

Speaker: NA
Text: The children have absolutely nowhere to play

Speaker: NA
Text: and this is a problem particularly with the ethnic

Speaker: NA
Text: kiddies who do not perhaps join in after-school

Speaker: NA
Text: activities as much as they might or who are not in

Speaker: NA
Text: sporting groups which meet at weekends. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: essential, if anything is to be done to help schools

Speaker: NA
Text: to get adequate playgrounds and facilities, that

Speaker: NA
Text: there must be a massive injection of Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth funding. I do not see that massive injection

Speaker: NA
Text: of education funding going hand in hand with the

Speaker: NA
Text: tax cuts that the community is expecting and to

Speaker: NA
Text: which it is looking forward. I believe that the

Speaker: NA
Text: trade union movement and the others who are

Speaker: NA
Text: pressing for tax cuts will sell short the children of

Speaker: NA
Text: our nation if they want tax cuts at the expense of

Speaker: NA
Text: adequate funding of education.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also recently visited another parish school in

Speaker: NA
Text: my electorate, St Ambrose's school at Concord

Speaker: NA
Text: West. There the new principal, Miss Denise De

Speaker: NA
Text: Lean, was delighted to welcome me and with the

Speaker: NA
Text: new parish priest, Father Bayada, showed me

Speaker: NA
Text: around the school. She explained that no remedial

Speaker: NA
Text: teachers are provided in the Catholic primary

Speaker: NA
Text: schools. That rather surprised me because that

Speaker: NA
Text: school also has a very significant ethnic com-

Speaker: NA
Text: ponent. Miss De Lean explained to me that in the

Speaker: NA
Text: upper school classes she finds some children who

Speaker: NA
Text: have missed out on basic concepts and that with-

Speaker: NA
Text: out remedial teaching these kiddies are sent off to

Speaker: NA
Text: secondary schools lacking the basic concepts of

Speaker: NA
Text: education. They might have been ill. They might

Speaker: NA
Text: have come into the school system from overseas at

Speaker: NA
Text: a late stage. Having no remedial teaching was in

Speaker: NA
Text: this principal's view a serious problem. This situa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion can be overcome only by adequate funding

Speaker: NA
Text: from Canberra.

Speaker: NA
Text: The non-government schools look essentially to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Federal Government for much of their fund-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing and it is a very sad commentary on our edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation systems that the whole of the Catholic

Speaker: NA
Text: parochial school system can operate without re-

Speaker: NA
Text: medial teachers in an atmosphere in which the

Speaker: NA
Text: class teacher, perhaps battling with a big ethnic

Speaker: NA
Text: group of kiddies, has at the same time to run re-

Speaker: NA
Text: medial courses. Teachers are very talented

Speaker: NA
Text: people, in my experience, and I admire what I

Speaker: NA
Text: have seen in the Catholic schools and in the state

Speaker: NA
Text: schools that I have always visited on a regular

Speaker: NA
Text: basis. There is a Catholic teachers college in

Speaker: NA
Text: Strathfield in my electorate and I am impressed by

Speaker: NA
Text: the training that the teachers obtain. I do not be-

Speaker: NA
Text: lieve that at the same time a primary school

Speaker: NA
Text: teacher can teach some children, teach others to

Speaker: NA
Text: speak English and also, while trying to teach those

Speaker: NA
Text: two groups, run remedial courses for children who

Speaker: NA
Text: have perhaps missed out on basic concepts in

Speaker: NA
Text: lower classes.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian Teachers Federation is running

Speaker: NA
Text: a campaign against aid to non-government

Speaker: NA
Text: schools. It wants a moratorium on aid to non-

Speaker: NA
Text: government schools. I believe that is a short-

Speaker: NA
Text: sighted campaign. I think that the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Teachers Federation and other groups interested

Speaker: NA
Text: in education have far more to gain and far more

Speaker: NA
Text: possibility of success if they combine with the

Speaker: NA
Text: other forces in our nation seeking more aid for all

Speaker: NA
Text: schools. The Catholic system and the state system

Speaker: NA
Text: must be helped by any government with any com-

Speaker: NA
Text: passion. Our Party, the Australian Labor Party,

Speaker: NA
Text: has a clear mandate and a clear policy to help the

Speaker: NA
Text: needy schools in our nation. Having been around

Speaker: NA
Text: practically every school in my electorate, some of

Speaker: NA
Text: them on two or three occasions, I know that the

Speaker: NA
Text: state schools and the non-state schools are ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: tremely needy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Everyone of these schools has problems, like

Speaker: NA
Text: Homebush West where the library is open only

Speaker: NA
Text: two days a week. It is much the same in many of

Speaker: NA
Text: the parish schools. There are accommodation and

Speaker: NA
Text: library problems in the secondary schools and in

Speaker: NA
Text: the high schools at Drummoyne, Burwood and at

Speaker: NA
Text: many of the non-government schools also. Many

Speaker: NA
Text: of the private schools in my electorate have prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lems. They have old buildings; they have difficulty

Speaker: NA
Text: in paying teachers wages and in keeping costs

Speaker: NA
Text: down. There are many problems and many needs

Speaker: NA
Text: in all of the non-government schools with which I

Speaker: NA
Text: am acquainted.

Speaker: NA
Text: State aid and aid to non-government schools is

Speaker: NA
Text: an emotive issue but it is an issue that I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: needs far more debate and rational clear-headed

Speaker: NA
Text: discussion than it has been getting in the past 12

Speaker: NA
Text: months. We have witnessed heady meetings in

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney, Melbourne and other places and have

Speaker: NA
Text: noted rhetoric and abuse being poured on a hard-

Speaker: NA
Text: working Federal Minister for Education and

Speaker: NA
Text: Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan).

Speaker: NA
Text: Another matter that I want to mention in the

Speaker: NA
Text: House relates to some comments that I noted in a

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne diocesan paper, the Advocate. These

Speaker: NA
Text: comments were attributed to Bishop Eric D'Arcy,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Bishop of Sale, a man for whom I have the

Speaker: NA
Text: greatest respect. At a recent opening of a school

Speaker: NA
Text: by Senator Ryan, the bishop compared the fund-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing of schools with the funding of universities and

Speaker: NA
Text: colleges of advanced education. Having been an

Speaker: NA
Text: academic, he made the point that tertiary edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation is free to all Australians but that schools,

Speaker: NA
Text: certainly non-government schools, are not free. I

Speaker: NA
Text: fully support these comments of Bishop Eric

Speaker: NA
Text: D'Arcy if he means that there should be no fees in

Speaker: NA
Text: schools. I have always taken the point of view as a

Speaker: NA
Text: State member of parliament for nearly 10 years

Speaker: NA
Text: and since I have been in this House that there

Speaker: NA
Text: should be no fees for state schools, no service fees

Speaker: NA
Text: or any sort of fees and that there should be no fees

Speaker: NA
Text: non-state schools.

Speaker: NA
Text: Any school which takes all comers from its area

Speaker: NA
Text: should not have to charge fees which would ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: clude anyone. Many people in our nation are un-

Speaker: NA
Text: employed. There is a vast pool of unemployed

Speaker: NA
Text: people, unfortunately. Many people such as single

Speaker: NA
Text: parents, widows or deserted wives cannot pay

Speaker: NA
Text: school fees, either state school fees, service fees or

Speaker: NA
Text: the fees in parish schools. These people should not

Speaker: NA
Text: have to pay fees, and I agree with Bishop Eric

Speaker: NA
Text: D'Arcy. But I am not sure that that is what the

Speaker: NA
Text: Catholic school authorities really want because

Speaker: NA
Text: when I talk to the people from the Catholic Edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation Office they say: 'Oh, no, there must be

Speaker: NA
Text: some element of fees. There must be an element

Speaker: NA
Text: of sacrifice by the parents'. I cannot reconcile

Speaker: NA
Text: these two viewpoints, but I certainly opt for what

Speaker: NA
Text: Bishop Eric D'Arcy mentioned in the article in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Advocate, which I have in the House today. I

Speaker: NA
Text: have also read that statement in several of the

Speaker: NA
Text: daily papers.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe that, if a school picks its children with-

Speaker: NA
Text: out selecting them by competitive examination to

Speaker: NA
Text: weed out the duller ones from the brighter pupils,

Speaker: NA
Text: that school should not have to charge fees as it is

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared to take all comers. If a school wants to

Speaker: NA
Text: be selective and take only the brighter pupils, that

Speaker: NA
Text: is another question. A school that is scholastically

Speaker: NA
Text: selective cannot expect to receive a vast sum of

Speaker: NA
Text: government funding and very big money is invol-

Speaker: NA
Text: ved in the non-government sector and in the

Speaker: NA
Text: government sector. I believe that there can be

Speaker: NA
Text: much criticism of some of the selective govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment high schools in New South Wales which

Speaker: NA
Text: take pupils who are the children of old boys or old

Speaker: NA
Text: girls from outside their drawing areas. Such a pol-

Speaker: NA
Text: icy is discriminatory against people who have

Speaker: NA
Text: come here from other lands and who are not old

Speaker: NA
Text: boys or old girls of these schools. I believe that the

Speaker: NA
Text: State must look to its own system and get it in

Speaker: NA
Text: order. I have raised these matters in the House

Speaker: NA
Text: today because we are in the process of this debate

Speaker: NA
Text: around our nation as to what should go into the

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget and which areas should receive additional

Speaker: NA
Text: funding. I am making a simple plea for the fund-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing of schools, government and non-government,

Speaker: NA
Text: which I know to be in great need.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also believe there must be more debate about

Speaker: NA
Text: exactly where the non-government schools are

Speaker: NA
Text: heading and what they want in relation to fund-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing. Do they really want to be funded, in the same

Speaker: NA
Text: manner as colleges of advanced education and

Speaker: NA
Text: universities, as private institutions but totally

Speaker: NA
Text: funded by the Government? That is not the mess-

Speaker: NA
Text: age I get from some of the people who set the phil-

Speaker: NA
Text: osophy for the biggest non-government school sys-

Speaker: NA
Text: tem in the State of New South Wales, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Catholic Education Office. I trust that, in for-

Speaker: NA
Text: mulating the Budget, the Prime Minister, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer ( Mr Keating), and other Ministers will

Speaker: NA
Text: not forget that the children of Australia are our

Speaker: NA
Text: future. Their future is essentially tied up with the

Speaker: NA
Text: quality of education they receive. The schools

Speaker: NA
Text: have wonderful, dedicated teachers, but the

Speaker: NA
Text: teachers will lose heart and lose interest and the

Speaker: NA
Text: children will be disinterested unless they have

Speaker: NA
Text: basic facilities, teaching aids, decent classrooms,

Speaker: NA
Text: and adequate playgrounds in which they can be

Speaker: NA
Text: educated. I trust that my words to the Prime Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister and the Cabinet will not fall on deaf ears.

Speaker: Mr ROCHER
Text: Curtin) (5.51)-1 join in con-

Speaker: NA
Text: gratulating the honourable member for Hughes

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Tickner) and the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Richmond ( Mr Blunt) on the occasion of their

Speaker: NA
Text: maiden speeches in this place. 1 hope that my col-

Speaker: NA
Text: league the honourable member for Richmond

Speaker: NA
Text: continues to enjoy the confidence of his electorate

Speaker: NA
Text: for many years to come and that both honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members obtain satisfaction from their time in

Speaker: NA
Text: this Parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: The promise of the Prime Minister ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Hawke) to 'not take money out of pensioners'

Speaker: NA
Text: cheques' has become one of a long list of broken

Speaker: NA
Text: promises. It was first broken with the application

Speaker: NA
Text: of a means test on pensioners of over 70 in

Speaker: NA
Text: November last year. To that may be added the

Speaker: NA
Text: promised application of an assets test at some

Speaker: NA
Text: time in the future. 1 want to speak briefly about

Speaker: NA
Text: the assets test and one aspect which has flowed

Speaker: NA
Text: from it. The Prime Minister's deferral of im-

Speaker: NA
Text: plementation of the assets test when the heat from

Speaker: NA
Text: his back bench became too great was not without

Speaker: NA
Text: significant cost to the Australian taxpayer. Apart

Speaker: NA
Text: from the cost of yet another government inquiry,

Speaker: NA
Text: there is the enormous cost of the continuing

Speaker: NA
Text: employment of staff recruited in anticipation of

Speaker: NA
Text: the scheme being introduced, as originally

Speaker: NA
Text: intended, on I November this year. Continuation

Speaker: NA
Text: of their employment must be regarded as strong

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence of the Hawke Government's ultimate in-

Speaker: NA
Text: tention to impose an assets test on age pensions,

Speaker: NA
Text: but it will probably occur after the next election.

Speaker: NA
Text: What other conclusion can reasonably be drawn?

Speaker: NA
Text: Some 1,400 people were recruited to oversee

Speaker: NA
Text: the introduction of an assets test in November.

Speaker: NA
Text: The assets test was subsequently deferred. The

Speaker: NA
Text: 1,400 people remain on the books. It is perfectly

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonable to assume that the 1,400 jobs in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of Social Security, specifically

Speaker: NA
Text: created to introduce and police a measure now de-

Speaker: NA
Text: ferred until after the next election, did not exist

Speaker: NA
Text: previously. It is equally reasonable to assume that

Speaker: NA
Text: those jobs no longer exist in terms of useful

Speaker: NA
Text: employment. Useful employment notwithstand-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing, those 1,400 public servants remain, and have

Speaker: NA
Text: not been made redundant. It is incomprehensible

Speaker: NA
Text: that the taxpayers of Australia are obliged to foot

Speaker: NA
Text: the bill for the salaries of those people to do work

Speaker: NA
Text: which is no longer available. It is an outrageous

Speaker: NA
Text: state of affairs. It is equally outrageous that

Speaker: NA
Text: 170 employees of the Reserve Bank of Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: who had the task of administering exchange con-

Speaker: NA
Text: trols, are still employed. Honourable members

Speaker: NA
Text: will recall that exchange controls were abandoned

Speaker: NA
Text: last December, when the Australian dollar was

Speaker: NA
Text: floated. At least on the face of it, most of the 170

Speaker: NA
Text: people working in the former exchange control

Speaker: NA
Text: department of the Reserve Bank have no pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ductive function to perform, but they remain

Speaker: NA
Text: employed, presumably to do tasks which did not

Speaker: NA
Text: previously exist and which were not previously

Speaker: NA
Text: essential.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those are just a couple of stark examples of the

Speaker: NA
Text: profligacy and managerial ineptitude of this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. Other examples will no doubt be-

Speaker: NA
Text: come apparent as more information trickles

Speaker: NA
Text: through. It might be reasonably anticipated that

Speaker: NA
Text: the army of recruits engaged in the offices of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commissioner of Taxation to administer the with-

Speaker: NA
Text: holding tax introduced last year by this Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment may come under close examination in the

Speaker: NA
Text: not too distant future.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Dobie-And the assets test.

Speaker: Mr ROCHER
Text: And the assets test, as my

Speaker: NA
Text: friend reminds me. In some circles it has been

Speaker: NA
Text: suggested that 800 souls were employed to deal

Speaker: NA
Text: with the tonnes of paper generated by this with-

Speaker: NA
Text: holding tax measure. Honourable members will

Speaker: NA
Text: again recall that the imposition of a withholding

Speaker: NA
Text: tax was to be subject to review following serious

Speaker: NA
Text: objections from many Australians. In the absence

Speaker: NA
Text: of an answer to a question on notice asked of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer, it seems more than likely that the cost

Speaker: NA
Text: of collecting a tax in the form of withholding tax,

Speaker: NA
Text: which, incidentally, is tax collected in advance

Speaker: NA
Text: and not additional tax, as may be popularly sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: posed, will not warrant continuation of the

Speaker: NA
Text: measure. It will be interesting to see whether staff

Speaker: NA
Text: recruited in the Australian Taxation Office are

Speaker: NA
Text: shed, as will almost certainly become appropriate

Speaker: NA
Text: after the review.

Speaker: NA
Text: From the examples I have cited there can be

Speaker: NA
Text: little hope that this Government will take the

Speaker: NA
Text: difficult decisions necessary to protect resources

Speaker: NA
Text: provided by Australian taxpayers. As with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's lack of fiscal competence, so also

Speaker: NA
Text: must there be some serious doubt about the

Speaker: NA
Text: efficacy of the prices and incomes accord and

Speaker: NA
Text: associated industrial relations considerations. As

Speaker: NA
Text: with other aspects of this Government's post-

Speaker: NA
Text: election policies-and I emphasise 'post'-its atti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tudes to industrial relations give many great cause

Speaker: NA
Text: for concern. Perhaps the most sobering appraisal

Speaker: NA
Text: of this Government's attitude appeared in a lead-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing article published in the Canberra Times on 14

Speaker: NA
Text: some November last year under the heading 'Anything

Speaker: NA
Text: for a Quiet Life' and the sub-heading 'Morality at

Speaker: NA
Text: a Discount'. The leader writer concluded in his

Speaker: NA
Text: -final paragraph:

Speaker: NA
Text: As far as the Government, the ALP and the union of-

Speaker: NA
Text: ficials are concerned, all this conciliation, capitulation

Speaker: NA
Text: compromise is good industrial .rel-tions: Principle and

Speaker: NA
Text: morality are at a discount. What is disturbing to the rest of

Speaker: NA
Text: the community-or should be-is that the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: and the employers are doing the capitulating, and it is -he

Speaker: NA
Text: rest of the community's interests that are being

Speaker: NA
Text: compromised.

Speaker: NA
Text: The writer, being suspiciously sarcastic, I think,

Speaker: NA
Text: continued:

Speaker: NA
Text: For the sake of the unions' social conscience of course.

Speaker: NA
Text: Recall the settlement of the recent mail strike. Obviously,

Speaker: NA
Text: trade unionists are 'in' under the Hawke Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: That editorial encapsulates, better than anything

Speaker: NA
Text: I have read, the doubts that exist about the direc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of this Government in labour and wage re-

Speaker: NA
Text: lated matters.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Dobie-It has none.

Speaker: Mr ROCHER
Text: It has none, as my friend the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Cook reminds me. Why

Speaker: NA
Text: should a leader writer of such a respected

Speaker: NA
Text: newspaper reach such a conclusion? The editorial

Speaker: NA
Text: drew together a list of then recent events which

Speaker: NA
Text: give a clue to the author's logic. Among. t?em

Speaker: NA
Text: were three decisions announced by the MInIster

Speaker: NA
Text: for Employment and Industrial Relations ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Willis) on 3 November last year. They included

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government's undertaking to pay $\0,000 in

Speaker: NA
Text: costs incurred by the Transport Workers Union in

Speaker: NA
Text: defending an action brought by the Trade Prac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tices Commission, an action brought by an auth-

Speaker: NA
Text: ority set up and commissioned by this Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. I add that similar assistance was not offered

Speaker: NA
Text: to the other parties charged as co-offenders with

Speaker: NA
Text: the TWU. Again, on 3 November last year, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister seemed to think that accumulated tax-

Speaker: NA
Text: payers' funds were adequate for all the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's needs. At least, that is a reasonable infer-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence to be drawn from a decision not to claim

Speaker: NA
Text: costs arising out of a prosecution in the Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: Court of Australia of trade union officials who

Speaker: NA
Text: refused to answer questions before the Royal

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission into the Activities of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Building Construction Employees and Builders

Speaker: NA
Text: Labourers Federation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those same trade unions made it clear that they

Speaker: NA
Text: would not pay the fines imposed on them. I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: know what has happened since, but I suspect that

Speaker: NA
Text: they probably did not pay them. I would be

Speaker: NA
Text: interested to know whether the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: came to the party again.

Speaker: NA
Text: There was a third decision on that momentous

Speaker: NA
Text: day, 3 November, and it was to drop 29 char?es

Speaker: NA
Text: against Australian Capital Territory trade UnIon

Speaker: NA
Text: officials. The price payable on behalf of these al-

Speaker: NA
Text: leged offenders was a Trades and .Labour Cou-cil

Speaker: NA
Text: undertaking to call off bans and pIckets protesting

Speaker: NA
Text: and police action at earlier pickets as well as protests

Speaker: NA
Text: over an alleged under-supply of subsidised accom-

Speaker: NA
Text: modation in the Australian Capital Territory. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government not only is prepared to break into

Speaker: NA
Text: the public purse to free its cohorts of the obli-

Speaker: NA
Text: gations of others, obligations which no ot-ers in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia could possibly escape, but also IS pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared to drop civil charges against. unionists in a

Speaker: NA
Text: way which leaves no doubt tha- I.t can .haPI?en

Speaker: NA
Text: again. I have heard of plea bargaining as It eXIsts

Speaker: NA
Text: in America, but that is plainly ridiculous. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: crazy that charges for civil offences should be

Speaker: NA
Text: dropped at the behest of a friendly government, or

Speaker: NA
Text: any government for that matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: Central as it is to the Government's economic

Speaker: NA
Text: policy, it can only be with some trepidation that

Speaker: NA
Text: we see developments designed to get around the

Speaker: NA
Text: prices and incomes accord. Nowhere is it more a-­

Speaker: NA
Text: parent that the accord is unde- th-eat than. In

Speaker: NA
Text: negotiations affecting remuneratIOn In the butld-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing industry. The latest device used by building in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry unions and some building industry e.m-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployers is the capitulation on a superannuatIOn

Speaker: NA
Text: fund for industry employees. I might add that

Speaker: NA
Text: these developments have happened with the full

Speaker: NA
Text: knowledge of the Minister for Employment and

Speaker: NA
Text: Industrial Relations and his Department.

Speaker: NA
Text: Although it is not the employer of the great ma-

Speaker: NA
Text: jority of building workers, the National Industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: Construction Council, the NICC, has assumed the

Speaker: NA
Text: role of chief negotiator on behalf of building in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry employers. Last month the NICC agreed

Speaker: NA
Text: to implement what it called 'a genuine superannu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation scheme within the building industry'. This

Speaker: NA
Text: intention was qualified as being 'subject to the

Speaker: NA
Text: understanding that a similar package to that of

Speaker: NA
Text: 1983 is reinstated'. I ask honourable members to

Speaker: NA
Text: remember that. Further, the NICC resolved 'that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Federal Government be asked to confirm its

Speaker: NA
Text: support for the NICC's approach': That is, - want

Speaker: NA
Text: to make it clear, the implementatIOn of an indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try superannuation scheme. It is important to

Speaker: NA
Text: note that the NICC sought confirmation only of

Speaker: NA
Text: support, clearly implying that it thought that it

Speaker: NA
Text: already had government support and hence

Speaker: NA
Text: sought only confirmation.

Speaker: NA
Text: In that context one can only begin to guess at

Speaker: NA
Text: differences between the Prime Minister and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer ( Mr Keating) on the one hand and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Employment and Industrial Re-

Speaker: NA
Text: lations on the other. The Minister and his Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, having been actively involved in m-etings

Speaker: NA
Text: which developed the 1983 package to whIch the

Speaker: NA
Text: NICC referred and which I quoted, would be well

Speaker: NA
Text: aware that the package breached the Gover-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's guidelines as set out in the accord. That

Speaker: NA
Text: package was thrown out by the Conciliation and

Speaker: NA
Text: Arbitration Commission last year for the very

Speaker: NA
Text: reason that it breached the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: guidelines.

Speaker: NA
Text: So what do we see in these current finaglings?

Speaker: NA
Text: We see the Minister asked, but seemingly reluc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tant for the moment, to confirm support for the

Speaker: NA
Text: NICC in its promotion of a superannuation

Speaker: NA
Text: . scheme dependent on the restoration of a package

Speaker: NA
Text: thrown out by the Conciliation and Arbitration

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission because it breached the guidelines.

Speaker: NA
Text: From this it can be seen that there is a gap be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween the sanctity the Prime Minister claims for

Speaker: NA
Text: the accord and the involvement of the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Employment and Industrial Relations to de-

Speaker: NA
Text: feat the very provisions of that accord.

Speaker: NA
Text: As you know, Mr Deputy Speaker, our speak-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing time has been restricted. I will abide by my

Speaker: NA
Text: Whip's wishes, not least because he is standing

Speaker: NA
Text: right next to me, but I would like to say that a

Speaker: NA
Text: couple of the matters that I have raised are symp-

Speaker: NA
Text: toms only of the direction in which this Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is heading. I ask all Australians to examine

Speaker: NA
Text: not only those symptoms I have cited but also

Speaker: NA
Text: some that my colleagues have already mentioned

Speaker: NA
Text: and will mention in this debate. I believe that this

Speaker: NA
Text: Hawke socialist Government is on notice. I hope

Speaker: NA
Text: that if it does not have the presence of mind and

Speaker: NA
Text: the intestinal fortitude to tackle the difficult prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lems the electorate will cast it out at the very next

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity.

Speaker: Mr RONALD EDWARDS
Text: Stirling) (6.06)-1

Speaker: NA
Text: join with previous speakers in commenting

Speaker: NA
Text: favourably upon the speeches of the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Hughes ( Mr Tickner), who sits

Speaker: NA
Text: alongside me here, and the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Richmond ( Mr Blunt). It is good to see new

Speaker: NA
Text: members of this House presenting such a favour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able picture to the public at large. I believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: both of them can take some pleasure from their

Speaker: NA
Text: speeches. I certainly know that we on this side of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House are very pleased with the contribution

Speaker: NA
Text: of the honourable member for Hughes. He had

Speaker: NA
Text: some substantial and thoughtful things to say and

Speaker: NA
Text: it is good to welcome him to this chamber in the

Speaker: NA
Text: full sense.

Speaker: NA
Text: There h.as been considerable discussion with re-

Speaker: NA
Text: spect to Appropriation Bills Nos 2, 3 and 4 and

Speaker: NA
Text: some comments by honourable members opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: need to be dealt with. When we are talking about

Speaker: NA
Text: the whole thrust of this Government since it has

Speaker: NA
Text: been in office, for just over a year, we have to take

Speaker: NA
Text: quite realistically some of the propositions put by

Speaker: NA
Text: those opposite.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Bennelong ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Howard) talked about the divisiveness of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke) and the fact that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister sought to oppose matters when he

Speaker: NA
Text: was in opposition and is now seeking a bipartisan

Speaker: NA
Text: and consensus approach to government. The

Speaker: NA
Text: problem that we faced when in opposition was

Speaker: NA
Text: that the whole style of government was

Speaker: NA
Text: dominated by the former right honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Wannon, the then Prime Minister. I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe the Australian community recognises that

Speaker: NA
Text: there has not been a more divisive person in the

Speaker: NA
Text: history of Australian politics. He created a cli-

Speaker: NA
Text: mate in this place. To respond very quickly, I be-

Speaker: NA
Text: lieve that what we ought to say is that the atmos-

Speaker: NA
Text: phere in this place has changed quite considerably

Speaker: NA
Text: and remarkably. We now have a Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: who governs by consensus and to some extent

Speaker: NA
Text: from time to time we have a Leader of the Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: sensus. I think that the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Bennelong, who talks in this place about

Speaker: NA
Text: divisiveness, should look at the record of those op-

Speaker: NA
Text: posite during their seven years in government.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Curtin ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Rocher) touched upon industrial relations. The

Speaker: NA
Text: hallmark of industrial relations policy under the

Speaker: NA
Text: previous Government was divisiveness and

Speaker: NA
Text: conflict. The hallmark of economic policy under

Speaker: NA
Text: the previous Government was divisiveness and

Speaker: NA
Text: conflict. I will not dwell upon that because I

Speaker: NA
Text: would be committing exactly the offence that I

Speaker: NA
Text: am claiming those opposite committed, that is,

Speaker: NA
Text: being partisan about these matters. But if we are

Speaker: NA
Text: to talk about divisiveness, the record has to be put

Speaker: NA
Text: straight. Those opposite established under Mal-

Speaker: NA
Text: colm Fraser a style of government that haunted

Speaker: NA
Text: them to the end of their period in government.

Speaker: NA
Text: They know that and the electorate knows it; and

Speaker: NA
Text: they will continue to know it as people look back

Speaker: NA
Text: in history. There were times when I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: divisiveness was used unfairly in this chamber.

Speaker: NA
Text: This Government has a responsibility to the entire

Speaker: NA
Text: community. We represent not just those who

Speaker: NA
Text: voted for us but also those who did not vote for us.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have a responsibility to represent both of

Speaker: NA
Text: them and I believe that under this Government

Speaker: NA
Text: we are doing that very effectively. The approval

Speaker: NA
Text: ratings certainly demonstrate that.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Curtin also

Speaker: NA
Text: touched on the issue of the assets test. He

Speaker: NA
Text: concluded by saying that we have to start taking

Speaker: NA
Text: some tough decisions. He is quite right. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: trying to take tough decisions, and this is one of

Speaker: NA
Text: them. But it is a decision that should have been

Speaker: NA
Text: taken a long time ago by the previous Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. We are faced with an aging population and

Speaker: NA
Text: a burgeoning welfare bill, and we have to do

Speaker: NA
Text: something about redistributing resources in such a

Speaker: NA
Text: way that we will use them most effectively in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian community. That is the genesis of the

Speaker: NA
Text: assets test. No one particularly likes having to

Speaker: NA
Text: enter an area such as that, but in equity and in

Speaker: NA
Text: fairness we must proceed to do that in the

Speaker: NA
Text: interests of managing this economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Curtin also

Speaker: NA
Text: touched upon the withholding tax. That tax was

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced because, reflecting back, one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: hallmarks of the Government of Malcolm Fraser

Speaker: NA
Text: was to talk about a tax revolt. There was a tax re-

Speaker: NA
Text: volt in this country, and it was encouraged by the

Speaker: NA
Text: then right honourable member for Wannon. One

Speaker: NA
Text: can recall that one prominent newspaper in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia encouraged the tax revolt. It occurred in

Speaker: NA
Text: the building industry and in industry right across

Speaker: NA
Text: the board. What has happened is that we have had

Speaker: NA
Text: to respond sensibly and to try to introduce a tax-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing regimen which will try to recoup some of that

Speaker: NA
Text: tax that was being avoided. The people in the

Speaker: NA
Text: building industry recognise that, we recognise that

Speaker: NA
Text: and I, as the member for Stirling, recognise that.

Speaker: NA
Text: Having introduced a system of withholding tax,

Speaker: NA
Text: one of our important goals must be to ensure-

Speaker: NA
Text: and here I am echoing the thoughts of the building

Speaker: NA
Text: industry-that it is not too cumbersome in terms

Speaker: NA
Text: of paper work. We are looking at that position, in

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of the review, and I am hopeful that we

Speaker: NA
Text: shall emerge with a withholding tax operation

Speaker: NA
Text: that will be fair, equitable and effective in terms

Speaker: NA
Text: of its collection.

Speaker: NA
Text: There has also been some comment about the

Speaker: NA
Text: prices and incomes accord. It is important to talk

Speaker: NA
Text: about that accord in terms of our Government,

Speaker: NA
Text: because what we have tried to do is to set in place

Speaker: NA
Text: a recognition by government, by companies and

Speaker: NA
Text: by unions that we have a responsibility across the

Speaker: NA
Text: board to develop a system of wage fixation and to

Speaker: NA
Text: achieve some social policy goals that will satisfy

Speaker: NA
Text: the large population of this country that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government is about fair and decent government.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is what the prices and incomes accord is

Speaker: NA
Text: about. We are achieving that, and I believe that it

Speaker: NA
Text: worries those opposite that the accord is sticking

Speaker: NA
Text: together. At present there is one renegade union

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia-the Australian Medical Associ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation. I know that it gives comfort and support to

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable members opposite and that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition seeks to raise funds from

Speaker: NA
Text: the AMA, but I am certain that the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: community is not pleased with the behaviour of

Speaker: NA
Text: that renegade union.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the wider issues of economic policy, what

Speaker: NA
Text: we have to put before the public at present is the

Speaker: NA
Text: fact that, after a year, there has been a substantial

Speaker: NA
Text: improvement in the economic performance of this

Speaker: NA
Text: country. Some of that is due to natural factors,

Speaker: NA
Text: some of that is due to world circumstances, and

Speaker: NA
Text: some of that is due to the policy of this Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. Talking of this Government in terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the performance indicators, we now have

Speaker: NA
Text: gross domestic product looking to have increased

Speaker: NA
Text: by the time the year is out by 11 per cent. An 11

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent growth in GDP is a substantial improve-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment particularly when one recognises-and this

Speaker: NA
Text: is the sorry part of the story-that in 1982-83 it

Speaker: NA
Text: fell by 2.5 per cent. So we are turning GDP

Speaker: NA
Text: around from a declining position to a growth pos-

Speaker: NA
Text: ition. That is an important thing. It is important

Speaker: NA
Text: because people in the wider community will have

Speaker: NA
Text: more goods and services to enjoy. That ought to

Speaker: NA
Text: be the goal of any government in this place, be it

Speaker: NA
Text: those opposite who would seek to attain govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment at some stage in the future, or we on this

Speaker: NA
Text: side. Our goal must be to ensure that we improve

Speaker: NA
Text: the economic performance of this economy so

Speaker: NA
Text: that the welfare of the Australian community in

Speaker: NA
Text: general is improved. That is happening. The

Speaker: NA
Text: record at this stage is very good. This Government

Speaker: NA
Text: must take some of the credit for that, because

Speaker: NA
Text: what it has put in place is some positive stimulus

Speaker: NA
Text: in the last Budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: I should like to talk about the last Budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: There was a deficit of about $8.5 billion with that

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget. The important thing that happened with

Speaker: NA
Text: respect to that Budget was that the money market

Speaker: NA
Text: accepted that Budget in terms of its projections

Speaker: NA
Text: and we did not see any adverse impact upon

Speaker: NA
Text: interest rates. We were able to fund that deficit

Speaker: NA
Text: quite effectively through the sale of bonds. What

Speaker: NA
Text: we have had is a Budget that has received the ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceptance of the wider community. It is a Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: that has achieved an important stimulus in'the

Speaker: NA
Text: economy just when we needed it.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the areas of important stimulus has been

Speaker: NA
Text: the housing industry. This is an area that gives

Speaker: NA
Text: great satisfaction to us, in government, and it

Speaker: NA
Text: should give satisfaction to all in the

Speaker: NA
Text: community-to the building companies, to those

Speaker: NA
Text: who are getting into houses, to those who are

Speaker: NA
Text: working in the building industry, and to the wider

Speaker: NA
Text: community that benefits from the multiplier

Speaker: NA
Text: effect of expenditure. The first home owners

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme has been a remarkable success. Great,

Speaker: NA
Text: credit is due to the Minister for Housing and Con-

Speaker: NA
Text: struction ( Mr Hurford) for introducing that

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme and to the Government in general for

Speaker: NA
Text: having the good sense to have consulted the mas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter builders anq financial institutions and for

Speaker: NA
Text: being seen to have introduced a scheme which de-

Speaker: NA
Text: livers in terms of its objectives. The objectives

Speaker: NA
Text: have been to get more housing starts and to get

Speaker: NA
Text: people into homes.

Speaker: NA
Text: The housing start picture is quite remarkable.

Speaker: NA
Text: The announcement at the beginning of this week

Speaker: NA
Text: that we are now looking at 135,000 commence-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments in 1983-84 indicates a remarkable perform-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance. The projection for 1984-85 is 145,000 com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mencements. That is a very good picture for

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, because it means that we are not only

Speaker: NA
Text: building houses but also getting people into

Speaker: NA
Text: homes. We saw the previous performance of

Speaker: NA
Text: 105,000 starts. That is not good enough. The pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: vious Government must have acknowledged that.

Speaker: NA
Text: It really was a great area of deficiency in its policy

Speaker: NA
Text: that it never did enough to introduce some im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portant stimulus in the housing sector. The

Speaker: NA
Text: trouble was that what I refer to as the Fraser-

Speaker: NA
Text: Howard pattern of economic vandalism suc-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceeded in doing just that. It destroyed the building

Speaker: NA
Text: industry. We have restored that industry and we

Speaker: NA
Text: are now getting building activity up again.

Speaker: NA
Text: Taking the figures as at 30 March, in Australia-

Speaker: NA
Text: wide terms, the number of inquiries on the first

Speaker: NA
Text: home owners scheme reached 405,885, and in

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australia the number of inquiries on the

Speaker: NA
Text: first home owners scheme reached 67,606. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: a remarkable performance. In terms of the actual

Speaker: NA
Text: applications received from the public, the

Speaker: NA
Text: national picture as at 30 March showed that

Speaker: NA
Text: 59,668 applications had been received nationally

Speaker: NA
Text: under the first home owners scheme. That is a

Speaker: NA
Text: very important figure, because in Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia 8,494 applications have been received.

Speaker: NA
Text: What it means is that we are getting a remarkable

Speaker: NA
Text: response from the community for the first home

Speaker: NA
Text: owners scheme. That is excellent, because we are

Speaker: NA
Text: getting people at moderate income levels into

Speaker: NA
Text: housing.

Speaker: NA
Text: Two weeks ago I interviewed one constituent

Speaker: NA
Text: who had the good fortune to have moved into a

Speaker: NA
Text: $42,000, three-bedroom brick and tile cottage. He

Speaker: NA
Text: previously had lived in a caravan, and he is now

Speaker: NA
Text: living in a three-bedroom home in Perth. The

Speaker: NA
Text: $7,000 grant for which he qualified has made an

Speaker: NA
Text: enormous difference to the lifestyle of that person

Speaker: NA
Text: and his wife and two children. Suddenly, they are

Speaker: NA
Text: moving into a situation of looking at buying a re-

Speaker: NA
Text: frigerator, a washing machine, a stove and other

Speaker: NA
Text: appliance- for the home which will stimulate the

Speaker: NA
Text: rest of the economy. That is a remarkable thing. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is remarkable for two reasons. First, here we have

Speaker: NA
Text: someone who, in terms of his gross income, is on

Speaker: NA
Text: $16,000. That is his base rate. With allowances

Speaker: NA
Text: and penalties he gets $19,000. He works as a malt-

Speaker: NA
Text: ster in a malting works in Perth. As a maltster, he

Speaker: NA
Text: is someone on a moderate income. But what he

Speaker: NA
Text: has been able to do with the first home owners

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme grant is to turn around from living in a

Speaker: NA
Text: caravan, and most recently in a very tiny unit, to

Speaker: NA
Text: living in his own three-bedroom brick and tile

Speaker: NA
Text: house in suburban Perth. He has two children and

Speaker: NA
Text: a wife who are now able to be housed properly.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are people who should have been housed

Speaker: NA
Text: properly before, and they were not housed prop-

Speaker: NA
Text: erly before. Living in a caravan is a disgrace. It

Speaker: NA
Text: might have been all right for the former right

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Wannon to fly from here

Speaker: NA
Text: on Fridays and go to his property in western Vic-

Speaker: NA
Text: toria, but this person could not do that; he lived in

Speaker: NA
Text: a caravan under that Government. What a dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: grace! What a lamentable situation that honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members opposite let it happen. But they let

Speaker: NA
Text: it happen. They called it economic management.

Speaker: NA
Text: It was not economic management; it was econ-

Speaker: NA
Text: omic vandalism. That is why they are over on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition benches and why they will stay there.

Speaker: NA
Text: The wider community knows that they are incom-

Speaker: NA
Text: petent and incapable of decent management, and

Speaker: NA
Text: it was prepared to say to them in massive numbers

Speaker: NA
Text: that it was going to vote away from them and vote

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Hawke Government. That has happened,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the case that I have just cited is substantial

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence of that. While we have people on moder-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate incomes in Australia living in caravans, with a

Speaker: NA
Text: wife and two children--

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Staples-That Government left them in

Speaker: NA
Text: the streets.

Speaker: Mr RONALD EDWARDS
Text: it did as my

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable friend says. There was a substantial

Speaker: NA
Text: increase in unemployment, with 250,000 people

Speaker: NA
Text: being added to the unemployment list in the last

Speaker: NA
Text: two lamentable years of management by honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members opposite. That is not management.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is economic vandalism. They know it and the

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate knows it. It is no good them coming to

Speaker: NA
Text: this place and bleating and trying to whip up a

Speaker: NA
Text: case, because they do not have one, and there is

Speaker: NA
Text: not a substantial case to make.

Speaker: NA
Text: What we have been able to do is to turn the

Speaker: NA
Text: economy around. We have seen a substantial im-

Speaker: NA
Text: provement in jobs. We are predicting at this stage

Speaker: NA
Text: that by the end of this financial year there will be

Speaker: NA
Text: about 190,000 extra jobs added to the list. At

Speaker: NA
Text: present the figure is about 140,000. That is an im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portant performance, because we are getting jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: coming through and we are getting people back

Speaker: NA
Text: into work. The inflation rate has come down. The

Speaker: NA
Text: implicit price deflator shows that we are looking

Speaker: NA
Text: at a rate of about 6 per cent for the end of 1983.

Speaker: NA
Text: Again, that is a remarkable performance, looking

Speaker: NA
Text: back on the II per cent figure of the previous

Speaker: NA
Text: Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think that, when we are in this place and we

Speaker: NA
Text: are talking about matters such as the Appropri-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation BiIls, we have a responsibility to try to

Speaker: NA
Text: a picture which reflects the reality out there

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian community. The reality out there is

Speaker: NA
Text: that the economy has turned around in a remark-

Speaker: NA
Text: able way, but more importantly the social circum-

Speaker: NA
Text: stances of lots of Austra.\ians have been turned

Speaker: NA
Text: around in a remarkable way. The reality is that

Speaker: NA
Text: the job is not finished. This Government has had

Speaker: NA
Text: one year. It has a large job ahead of it. As the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Hughes indicated earlier,

Speaker: NA
Text: those tasks have a lot to do with creating jobs,

Speaker: NA
Text: with getting people into houses, with having a

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonable and decent educational picture, with

Speaker: NA
Text: having the infrastructure of public sector facili-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties, with having a substantial improvement in

Speaker: NA
Text: health and welfare in the community and with

Speaker: NA
Text: having some prospect on the world scene with re-

Speaker: NA
Text: spect to disarmament and peace. These are all

Speaker: NA
Text: goals that we take seriously in this place.

Speaker: NA
Text: I hope that in the coming weeks honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members opposite can contribute to this debate in

Speaker: NA
Text: a positive way because, to return to where I

Speaker: NA
Text: began, it is not good enough to come into this

Speaker: NA
Text: place and talk about the present Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: and divisiveness. The divisiveness that came to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia began when there was a new Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition back in 1974. That was the hall-

Speaker: NA
Text: mark of the Government that took over in a most

Speaker: NA
Text: unrepresentative way in 1975. What we have seen

Speaker: NA
Text: is, in fact, a turnaround in this country. We now

Speaker: NA
Text: have a Prime Minister who governs by consensus.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have an economy that is performing effec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tively, and the Australian community recognises

Speaker: NA
Text: that. In reflecting on these issues and in talking

Speaker: NA
Text: behalf of my electorate of Stirling I am proud to

Speaker: NA
Text: say that I believe the performance is there. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: conferring with the community. We have policies

Speaker: NA
Text: that are working. I am pleased to commend these

Speaker: NA
Text: BiIls to the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate (on motion by Mr Cadman) adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: COCOS (KEELING) ISLANDS

Speaker: Mr UREN
Text: Reid-Minister for Territories and

Speaker: NA
Text: Local Government)- Mr Deputy Speaker, mayI

Speaker: NA
Text: have the indulgence of the Chair to add to an

Speaker: NA
Text: answer I gave to a question at Question Time?

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Millar)-The

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister may proceed.

Speaker: Mr UREN
Text: During Question Time, the

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: that 48 officials were now on their way to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Cocos (Keeling) Islands with the United Nations

Speaker: NA
Text: Mission which departed Canberra today. That is a

Speaker: NA
Text: complete distortion of the facts. I said in my reply:

Speaker: NA
Text: 'I cannot verify the number but a Boeing 707 air-

Speaker: NA
Text: craft is going there'. The facts are that there are 15

Speaker: NA
Text: paint Australian Government officials accompanying

Speaker: NA
Text: in the the United Nations Mission today. Also accom-

Speaker: NA
Text: panying the Mission are II media representatives,

Speaker: NA
Text: including representation from Film Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The United Nations Mission itself consists of four

Speaker: NA
Text: members plus a secretariat of four. The total size

Speaker: NA
Text: of the party is 34, not 48. As I said during Ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion Time, representatives of the Cocos (Keeling)

Speaker: NA
Text: Islands Council will be returning to Australia with

Speaker: NA
Text: the United Nations Mission. One extra official

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Australian Electoral Office, who is cur-

Speaker: NA
Text: rently on Cocos, will also return with the Mission.

Speaker: NA
Text: I seek leave of the House to table the full list of

Speaker: NA
Text: people travelling on the Boeing 707.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: The Minister may

Speaker: NA
Text: table the document.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Text: Does the list contain the pos-

Speaker: NA
Text: itions that they hold?

Speaker: Mr UREN
Text: Yes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sitting suspended from 6.24 to 8 p.m.

Speaker: NA
Text: JUDICIARY AMENDMENT BILL

Speaker: NA
Text: Consideration resumed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
Text: KingsfordSmith-

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Trade) (8.00)-1 move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Judiciary Amendment Bill (No.2) 1984

Speaker: NA
Text: serves two purposes. III the first place, it aims to

Speaker: NA
Text: on relieve the High Court of Australia of some of its

Speaker: NA
Text: existing work load by removing provisions for

Speaker: NA
Text: appeal as of right to the High Court and by

Speaker: NA
Text: empowering the Court to remit certain matters

Speaker: NA
Text: now within its exclusive jurisdiction to the Fed-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral Court or to State or Territory courts. Sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ondly, the Bill provides for the establishment of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Government Solicitor in place of

Speaker: NA
Text: the present office of Crown Solicitor.

Speaker: NA
Text: Measures to Relieve the Work Load of the High

Speaker: NA
Text: Court

Speaker: NA
Text: The justices of the High Court have expressed

Speaker: NA
Text: concern about the effect of the increasing work

Speaker: NA
Text: load of the High Court on its capacity to function

Speaker: NA
Text: effectively as a final appellate court in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: and as the interpreter of the Constitution. This

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill deals with two of the matters that have given

Speaker: NA
Text: rise to that concern. One is that, where a case in-

Speaker: NA
Text: volves subject matter to the value of $20,000 or

Speaker: NA
Text: more, there is a right of appeal from the Full

Speaker: NA
Text: Court of a State supreme court or the Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: Court of Australia to the High Court, irrespective

Speaker: NA
Text: of the merits of the points in issue. The amount of

Speaker: NA
Text: $20,000 was fixed in 1976 and changing money

Speaker: NA
Text: values have had the result that many more cases

Speaker: NA
Text: fall within the provisions for appeal as of right.

Speaker: NA
Text: the second place, there are certain matters within

Speaker: NA
Text: the exclusive jurisdiction of the High Court which

Speaker: NA
Text: may, on occasion, involve a lengthy trial of the

Speaker: NA
Text: issues of fact involved. It is not appropriate that

Speaker: NA
Text: the time of the High Court should be taken up

Speaker: NA
Text: with the trial of issues of fact which could be more

Speaker: NA
Text: conveniently disposed of by another court.

Speaker: NA
Text: The appellate jurisdiction of the High Court

Speaker: NA
Text: derives from section 73 of the Constitution. Sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion 73 provides for appeals to the High Court

Speaker: NA
Text: from State Supreme courts, or State courts exer-

Speaker: NA
Text: cising Federal jurisdiction and Federal courts.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Parliament may prescribe exception to that

Speaker: NA
Text: appellate jurisdiction and regulate its exercise.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have already indicated that an appeal lies

Speaker: NA
Text: right from a State full court or from the Full

Speaker: NA
Text: Court of the Federal Court to the High Court

Speaker: NA
Text: where the appeal involves subject matter of the

Speaker: NA
Text: value of $20,000 or more regardless of the merits

Speaker: NA
Text: of the matter. The case involving constitutional

Speaker: NA
Text: issues may also be taken on appeal as of right from

Speaker: NA
Text: a State full court to the High Court whether or

Speaker: NA
Text: not the constitutional point is of real substance.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is generally acknowledged that a financial
