Speaker: NA
Text: test is not really an appropriate test for determin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing whether there should be an appeal as of right.

Speaker: NA
Text: The value of the subject matter of an action is no

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary indication of the intrinsic importance of

Speaker: NA
Text: the action. Officers of the Attorney-General's De-

Speaker: NA
Text: partment have had discussions with representa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tives of the Law Council of Australia on the mat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter, and I have also discussed the matter with

Speaker: NA
Text: representatives of the Law Council. They have

Speaker: NA
Text: not been able to suggest a more satisfactory

Speaker: NA
Text: isolate those cases in respect of which there might

Speaker: NA
Text: be an appeal as of right to the High Court. Conse-

Speaker: NA
Text: quently, the Government has agreed to accept the

Speaker: NA
Text: proposition put by the justices of the High Court

Speaker: NA
Text: that all appeals to the High Court from the Fed-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral Court and from State and Territory courts

Speaker: NA
Text: should be by special leave only. The Attorney-

Speaker: NA
Text: General (Senator Gareth Evans) has had dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: cussions with the Chief Justice on measures which

Speaker: NA
Text: might be taken by the Court itself to meet some of

Speaker: NA
Text: the criticisms which the legal profession has made

Speaker: NA
Text: of the existing procedures for seeking special leave

Speaker: NA
Text: to appeal, and those discussions are continuing.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Attorney-General hopes that, in particular,

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements will soon be able to be made for reg-

Speaker: NA
Text: ular sittings of the Court in Sydney and Mel-

Speaker: NA
Text: bourne to hear applications for special leave.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Bill inserts a new section 35A setting out in

Speaker: NA
Text: general terms criteria to which the Court must

Speaker: NA
Text: have regard in deciding whether or not to grant an

Speaker: NA
Text: In application for special leave to appeal. The

Speaker: NA
Text: present exclusive jurisdiction of the High Court is

Speaker: NA
Text: defined by section 38 of the Judiciary Act. The

Speaker: NA
Text: matter specified in that section covers matters

Speaker: NA
Text: arising directly out of any treaty and suits by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth and the States. Except to the

Speaker: NA
Text: extent to which jurisdiction is already conferred

Speaker: NA
Text: on the Federal Court of Australia, the High Court

Speaker: NA
Text: also has exclusive jurisdiction in matters in which

Speaker: NA
Text: a writ of mandamus or prohibition is sought

Speaker: NA
Text: against an officer of the Commonwealth or a Fed-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral court.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Bill would amend section 44 of the Ju-

Speaker: NA
Text: diciary Act. This section already provides for the

Speaker: NA
Text: High Court to remit to a Federal court or to a

Speaker: NA
Text: as of State or Territory court matters commenced in

Speaker: NA
Text: the High Court in which that other court has con-

Speaker: NA
Text: current jurisdiction. Clause 5 of the Bill will

Speaker: NA
Text: empower the High Court similarly to remit mat- .

Speaker: NA
Text: ters arising directly out of any treaty or suits be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween the States or suits between the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth and States. The High Court will be

Speaker: NA
Text: empowered to remit the whole of the matter or it

Speaker: NA
Text: may remit part of the matter as, for example, the

Speaker: NA
Text: hearing of evidence to establish findings of fact.

Speaker: NA
Text: The proceedings in the court to which the matter

Speaker: NA
Text: is remitted will be subject to any direction of the

Speaker: NA
Text: High Court, so that the High Court will retain

Speaker: NA
Text: control over the progress of the matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian Government Solicitor

Speaker: NA
Text: An important function of the Attorney-

Speaker: NA
Text: General's Department is the provision of the ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices of a solicitor to the Commonwealth, to Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: test to isters, departments and, as required, to

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth instrumentalities and other per-

Speaker: NA
Text: sons. The Secretary, as permanent head of the De-

Speaker: NA
Text: partment, is ultimately responsible under the

Speaker: NA
Text: Public Service Act for the proper carrying out of

Speaker: NA
Text: this function, as for all other functions of the De-

Speaker: NA
Text: partment. However, the greater part of the work

Speaker: NA
Text: of the solicitor for the Commonwealth performed

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Department, particularly the conduct of

Speaker: NA
Text: litigation, is carried out in the States and Terri-

Speaker: NA
Text: tories. The supervision of this work must be done

Speaker: NA
Text: on the spot in each State and Territory. An ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: ministrative structure is required to ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: this work is properly integrated with the other

Speaker: NA
Text: legal work of the Department and that there is

Speaker: NA
Text: effective accountability, both under the Public

Speaker: NA
Text: Service Act and to the courts, of those who per-

Speaker: NA
Text: form these solicitor functions.

Speaker: NA
Text: During 1983 a comprehensive review of the

Speaker: NA
Text: structure and organisation of the Attorney-

Speaker: NA
Text: -General's Department was undertaken at the

Speaker: NA
Text: Attorney-General's direction. The review had as

Speaker: NA
Text: its objective improving the Department's ef-

Speaker: NA
Text: ficiency, effectiveness and responsiveness to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, the Attorney-General and clients.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee which conducted the review

Speaker: NA
Text: recommended the change in the solicitor func-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions of the Department embodied in this Bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: Clause 6 of the Bill provides, in place of the per-

Speaker: NA
Text: sonal office of the Crown Solicitor, for the estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: lishment of a statutory corporate entity, to be

Speaker: NA
Text: known as the Australian Government Solicitor.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian Government Solicitor will per-

Speaker: NA
Text: form the function of solicitor for the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth, Ministers, Commonwealth authori-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties and certain other bodies and persons. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Government Solicitor will be, in effect,

Speaker: NA
Text: the 'firm name' under which the legal services

Speaker: NA
Text: functions of the Attorney-General's Department

Speaker: NA
Text: which would ordinarily be performed by a solici-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor for his client will be carried out. The Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Government Solicitor will not be a separ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate authority consituted by a person or body of

Speaker: NA
Text: persons, nor will it have its own staff.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Secretary of the Department and certain

Speaker: NA
Text: legally qualified senior officers of the Department

Speaker: NA
Text: authorised by the Secretary for that purpose will

Speaker: NA
Text: be empowered to act in the name of the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Government Solicitor. Thus, the members

Speaker: NA
Text: of the firm will be, in effect, the Secretary and the

Speaker: NA
Text: authorised officers and they will have the ordinary

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility of a solicitor to the courts in respect

Speaker: NA
Text: of acts done in the name of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Government Solicitor. This will ensure judicial

Speaker: NA
Text: control over those responsible for handling mat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ters befote the courts.

Speaker: NA
Text: Officers authorised to act in the name of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Government Solicitor will be respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sible for their actions in the conduct of their

Speaker: NA
Text: activities to the Secretary of the Department and,

Speaker: NA
Text: through the Secretary, to the Attorney-General.

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition, the authorised officers will be subject

Speaker: NA
Text: to the direction of the Secretary and, where so

Speaker: NA
Text: directed, the responsibility to the courts for acts

Speaker: NA
Text: performed in accordance with those directions

Speaker: NA
Text: will rest with the Secretary.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian Government Solicitor will be

Speaker: NA
Text: empowered to act on behalf of those entities, per-

Speaker: NA
Text: sons and bodies on behalf of which the Crown Sol-

Speaker: NA
Text: icitor is presently empowered to act by virtue of

Speaker: NA
Text: section 55E of the Judiciary Act. For the purposes

Speaker: NA
Text: of acting as solicitor for these persons and entities

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Government Solicitor is entitled

Speaker: NA
Text: under the Bill to the same rights and privileges of

Speaker: NA
Text: a solicitor in each of the States and Territories.

Speaker: NA
Text: These entitlements which are the same as those

Speaker: NA
Text: currently bestowed on the office of Crown Solici-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor will enable the Australian Government Solici-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor to carry out the function of solicitor in the

Speaker: NA
Text: various States and Territories. In addition, for the

Speaker: NA
Text: purposes of acting in the name of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Government Solicitor, the Secretary or an author-

Speaker: NA
Text: ised person will be entitled to do all things necess-

Speaker: NA
Text: ary and convenient to carry out the function and

Speaker: NA
Text: will be entitled to all the rights and privileges of a

Speaker: NA
Text: solicitor in each State or Territory whether or not

Speaker: NA
Text: he is entitled to practise as a solicitor in any State

Speaker: NA
Text: or Territory. I commend the Bill to the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate (on motion by Mr Spender) adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: FEDERAL COURT OF AUSTRALIA

Speaker: NA
Text: AMENDMENT BILL 1984

Speaker: NA
Text: Consideration resumed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
Text: Kingsford-Smith-

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Trade) (8.10)-1 move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: This Bill complements the changes proposed in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Judiciary Amendment Bill (No.2) 1984,

Speaker: NA
Text: which removes existing provisions for appeals as

Speaker: NA
Text: of right to the High Court of Australia from State

Speaker: NA
Text: supreme courts. The effect is to remove the right

Speaker: NA
Text: of appeal from the Full Court of the Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: Court of Australia to the High Court where the

Speaker: NA
Text: appeal involves subject matter of the value of

Speaker: NA
Text: $20,000 or more. I commend the Bill to the

Speaker: NA
Text: House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate (on motion by Mr Spender) adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: AUSTRALIAN GOVERNMENT

Speaker: NA
Text: SOLICITOR (CONSEQUENTIAL

Speaker: NA
Text: AMENDMENTS) BILL 1984

Speaker: NA
Text: Consideration resumed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
Text: Kingsford-Smith-

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Trade) (8.11 )-1 move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: The purpose of this Bill is to make a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments to legislation consequential upon the

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions of the Judiciary Amendment Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: (No.2) 1984 for the establishment of the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Government Solicitor. A number of Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth Acts contain references to the Crown

Speaker: NA
Text: Solicitor or to a Deputy Crown Solicitor. A

Speaker: NA
Text: number of these references are such that they may

Speaker: NA
Text: not be conveniently dealt with by the interpret-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation provision contained in that Bill, by which

Speaker: NA
Text: references to the Crown Solicitor or a Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Crown Solicitor were to be converted into refer-

Speaker: NA
Text: ences to the Australian Government Solicitor. It

Speaker: NA
Text: has therefore been found necessary to make

Speaker: NA
Text: specific amendments to the Acts in question.

Speaker: NA
Text: Generally speaking, the provisions which are

Speaker: NA
Text: amended by the present Bill are such as to require

Speaker: NA
Text: a person to be identified for the purposes of the

Speaker: NA
Text: relevant provision. The approach taken in this

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill is to amend those provisions so that references

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Crown Solicitor or a Deputy Crown Solici-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor are translated into references to the Secretary

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Attorney-General's Department or to an

Speaker: NA
Text: officer of that Department authorised by him to

Speaker: NA
Text: act in the name of the Australian Government

Speaker: NA
Text: Solicitor. It will be recalled that, in setting up the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Government Solicitor as a body cor-

Speaker: NA
Text: porate, it is intended that all acts done in the name

Speaker: NA
Text: of the body corporate shall be done by the Sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: retary to the Attorney-General's Department or

Speaker: NA
Text: by legally qualified officers of that Department

Speaker: NA
Text: authorised by the Secretary for the purpose. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill is purely of a technical and consequential

Speaker: NA
Text: kind, and accordingly 1 commend the Bill to the

Speaker: NA
Text: House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate (on motion by Mr Spender) adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: ACTS INTERPRETATION AMENDMENT

Speaker: NA
Text: Consideration resumed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
Text: Kingsford-Smith-

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Trade) (8.14)-1 move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: The purpose of this Bill is to facilitate the giving

Speaker: NA
Text: effect to the intentions of the Parliament when

Speaker: NA
Text: Acts of the Parliament fall to be interpreted. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill makes a number of amendments to the exist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing Acts Interpretation Act 1901 for this purpose.

Speaker: NA
Text: Eighteen new provisions are proposed to be

Speaker: NA
Text: inserted in the Act, in some cases in substitution

Speaker: NA
Text: for existing provisions. Some of the amendments

Speaker: NA
Text: are of a technical nature and are explained in the

Speaker: NA
Text: explanatory memorandum that has been cir-

Speaker: NA
Text: culated. 1 shall now deal with the more important

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions in this second reading speech.

Speaker: NA
Text: Use ofExtrinisic Material in the Interpretation

Speaker: NA
Text: First and foremost I refer to the proposed new

Speaker: NA
Text: section 15AB, which provides that, if any material

Speaker: NA
Text: not forming part of the Act is capable of assisting

Speaker: NA
Text: in the ascertainment of the meaning of a provision

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Act consideration may be given to that

Speaker: NA
Text: material. This provision has been favourably

Speaker: NA
Text: received by leading jurists and legal bodies since it

Speaker: NA
Text: was introduced in the other place on 8 March

Speaker: NA
Text: 1984. The important point to note about these

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions is that the word used, in proposed sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: section 15AB (I), is 'may', not 'shall'. That is to

Speaker: NA
Text: say, reference to such materials is not to be com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pulsory but is to be left to the discretion and the

Speaker: NA
Text: judgment of the courts. The proposed sub-section

Speaker: NA
Text: also states that, in the contemplation of Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, such material would be used for one of two

Speaker: NA
Text: purposes:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) to confirm that the meaning of the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vision is the ordinary meaning conveyed by

Speaker: NA
Text: the text of the provision taking into

Speaker: NA
Text: account its context in the Act and the pur-

Speaker: NA
Text: pose or object underlying the Act; or

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) to determine the meaning of the provision

Speaker: NA
Text: when either the provision is ambiguous or

Speaker: NA
Text: obscure, or the ordinary meaning is mani-

Speaker: NA
Text: festly absurd or is unreasonable.

Speaker: NA
Text: The provision therefore does not contemplate

Speaker: NA
Text: that extrinsic material would be used to overturn

Speaker: NA
Text: the ordinary meaning of a provision, arrived at by

Speaker: NA
Text: taking into account the purpose or object underly-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the Act, unless there is an ambiguity or ob-

Speaker: NA
Text: scurity or something that is manifestly absurd or

Speaker: NA
Text: unreasonable. On the other hand, the provision

Speaker: NA
Text: does make it clear that extrinsic materials can be

Speaker: NA
Text: BILL 1984 looked at to confirm the ordinary meaning of an

Speaker: NA
Text: Act. The fact is that judges do this already, and

Speaker: NA
Text: have been doing so for some time. The provision

Speaker: NA
Text: goes on in proposed sub-section (2) to specify, in a

Speaker: NA
Text: non-exhaustive way, the main categories of ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: trinsic materials that can assist in the interpret-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation of Acts. As well as such obvious matters as

Speaker: NA
Text: headings and marginal notes to provisions, and

Speaker: NA
Text: of end notes in the next text of the Act as printed by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government Printer, the following categories

Speaker: NA
Text: are covered:

Speaker: NA
Text: Any relevant reports laid before or made to

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament before the time when the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vision was enacted;

Speaker: NA
Text: any treaty or other international agreement

Speaker: NA
Text: that is referred to in the Act;

Speaker: NA
Text: the explanatory memorandum relating to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill circulated to members of parliament be-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore the time when the provision was

Speaker: NA
Text: enacted;

Speaker: NA
Text: the second reading speech of the Minister;

Speaker: NA
Text: of an Act any document that is expressly declared by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Act in question to be a relevant document for

Speaker: NA
Text: the purposes of section 15AB;

Speaker: NA
Text: finally, any relevant material in the journals or

Speaker: NA
Text: votes or proceedings or in Hansard.

Speaker: NA
Text: Attention is also drawn to proposed sub-section

Speaker: NA
Text: (3), which con'(eys the clear wish and intention of

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament that in applying secion 15AB regard

Speaker: NA
Text: shall be had to:

Speaker: NA
Text: the desirability of persons being able to rely

Speaker: NA
Text: the ordinary meaning conveyed by the text of

Speaker: NA
Text: the provision, taking into account the pur-

Speaker: NA
Text: pose or object underlying the Act; and

Speaker: NA
Text: the need to avoid prolonging legal or other pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceedings without compensating advantages.

Speaker: NA
Text: This provision was expressly approved by Lord

Speaker: NA
Text: Wilberforce, a distinguished jurist of the House of

Speaker: NA
Text: Lords, who said: 'I like, particularly, sub-section

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) of the new section 15AB'. In the ministerial

Speaker: NA
Text: statement tabled in the Senate on 30 November

Speaker: NA
Text: 1983 the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth

Speaker: NA
Text: Evans) said that the reaching of a satisfactory

Speaker: NA
Text: outcome in relation to the use of extrinsic

Speaker: NA
Text: materials would depend on the good sense of both

Speaker: NA
Text: judges and Parliament combining to produce a

Speaker: NA
Text: situation in which the range of materials, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: way in which they are used, are reasonably

Speaker: NA
Text: defined and confined. Proposed section 15AB

Speaker: NA
Text: meets these requirements. It does so in a way that

Speaker: NA
Text: respects the independence of the judiciary. Judges

Speaker: NA
Text: are neither required to nor prohibited from look-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing at any materials. On the other hand, the Par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liament in proposed section 15AB would be giving

Speaker: NA
Text: a clear lead as to the way in which extrinsic

Speaker: NA
Text: materials can best be used, without imposing

Speaker: NA
Text: undue burdens on the users of legislation or on the

Speaker: NA
Text: legal system generally.

Speaker: NA
Text: The provision is in accord with the deliber-

Speaker: NA
Text: ations of the top level Symposium on Statutory

Speaker: NA
Text: Interpretation, the proceedings of which were

Speaker: NA
Text: tabled at the time of the ministerial statement of

Speaker: NA
Text: 30 November 1983. The Symposium supported

Speaker: NA
Text: the proposition that Parliament should give a

Speaker: NA
Text: lead-as it had already successfully done in sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion 15AA of the Acts Interpretation Act-by

Speaker: NA
Text: recognising that judges have, or should have, a disrewritten

Speaker: NA
Text: cretion to refer to extrinsic materials where to do

Speaker: NA
Text: so can assist in the interpretation of Acts.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a clear link between the proposed new

Speaker: NA
Text: section 15AB and section 15AA, which was

Speaker: NA
Text: inserted in the Acts Interpretation Act in 1981 on

Speaker: NA
Text: the initiative of the then Attorney-General,

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Durack. We strongly supported that pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vision when in Opposition. It requires the purpose

Speaker: NA
Text: or object underlying an Act be taken into account

Speaker: NA
Text: when interpreting its provisions. The Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment successfully moved the adoption of a similar

Speaker: NA
Text: provision for inclusion in the Companies and Se-

Speaker: NA
Text: curities (Interpretation and Miscellaneous Pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: visions) Act passed in 1983. I am pleased to say

Speaker: NA
Text: that the provision so inserted has already had a

Speaker: NA
Text: significant beneficial effect. In a decision handed

Speaker: NA
Text: down on 28 February 1984, Mr Justice Hampel of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Victorian Supreme Court expressly relied on

Speaker: NA
Text: that provision in deciding that a share offer

Speaker: NA
Text: have been made by way of a prospectus. As one

Speaker: NA
Text: on commentator observed, use of this approach will

Speaker: NA
Text: lead to less legalistic or literal interpretations of

Speaker: NA
Text: the national code of companies and securities

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation, as was the original intention.

Speaker: NA
Text: A provision identical with section 15AA was in-

Speaker: NA
Text: cluded in the Interpretation of Legislation Bill re-

Speaker: NA
Text: cently introduced into the Victorian Parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: That Bill also contains a provision dealing with

Speaker: NA
Text: the use of extrinsic materials. That provision is

Speaker: NA
Text: less elaborate than the proposed section 15AB, but

Speaker: NA
Text: the two provisions are basically consistent one

Speaker: NA
Text: with the other, partly as a result of consultation at

Speaker: NA
Text: officer level. Bills have now been introduced into

Speaker: NA
Text: the Western Australian and South Australian par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liaments which contain provision giving effect to

Speaker: NA
Text: sections 15AA and 15AB. Perhaps in time there

Speaker: NA
Text: will be greater commonality between the laws of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth and the laws of various other

Speaker: NA
Text: States in this area. However, I am sure honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members will agree that it was appropriate

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Commonwealth to take the lead in this

Speaker: NA
Text: area, as indeed it did with section 15AA.

Speaker: NA
Text: Reference to Gender in Acts

Speaker: NA
Text: The existing Acts Interpretation Act provides

Speaker: NA
Text: in section 23, and has so provided since 190 I, that

Speaker: NA
Text: words importing the masculine gender shall in-

Speaker: NA
Text: clude the female, unless the contrary intention

Speaker: NA
Text: appears. I propose by this Bill that this sexist way

Speaker: NA
Text: of dealing with matters of gender should be

Speaker: NA
Text: altered so that the provision simply provides that,

Speaker: NA
Text: unless the contrary intention appears, words

Speaker: NA
Text: importing a gender include the other gender.

Speaker: NA
Text: Modern Methods of Recording Information

Speaker: NA
Text: Section 25 of the existing Act needs to be

Speaker: NA
Text: to define 'documents' and 'writing' so as

Speaker: NA
Text: to include modern modes of storing and reproduc-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing words, figures, symbols et cetera. Also, a pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vision needs to be inserted to provide for the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duction of records kept in a computer or in similar

Speaker: NA
Text: facilities, where an Act requires a person to pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duce the information in question. This is dealt

Speaker: NA
Text: with in the proposed new section 25A.

Speaker: NA
Text: Statement of Reasons

Speaker: NA
Text: A new standard provision needs to be inserted

Speaker: NA
Text: stating that where an Act requires the giving of

Speaker: NA
Text: written reasons for a decision, the instrument giv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the reasons shall also set out the findings on

Speaker: NA
Text: material questions of fact and refer to the evi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dence or other material on which those findings

Speaker: NA
Text: are based. The form of this provision is derived

Speaker: NA
Text: from section 28 of the Administrative Appeals

Speaker: NA
Text: Tribunal Act 1975 and from section 13 of the Ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: should ministrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act

Speaker: NA
Text: Attaining a Particular Age

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a little known legal rule of medieval

Speaker: NA
Text: origin that a person attains a particular age at the

Speaker: NA
Text: first moment of the day immediately before the

Speaker: NA
Text: anniversary of his birth. Thus a person becomes

Speaker: NA
Text: say sixty, not on the first instant of the sixtieth

Speaker: NA
Text: anniversary of his day of birth, but on the first

Speaker: NA
Text: stant of the day immediately before that birthday.

Speaker: NA
Text: I refer anyone interested in this esoterica to the

Speaker: NA
Text: judgment of Sir Owen Dixon in Prowse v. MCIn-

Speaker: NA
Text: tyre (1961) III CLR 264. References to age in

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth legislation clearly need to be

Speaker: NA
Text: brought into line with the common understanding

Speaker: NA
Text: that a person attains a particular age on the first

Speaker: NA
Text: moment of the actual anniversary of his birth.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is proposed to be brought about by the new

Speaker: NA
Text: section 25E to be inserted by the Bill. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed that this particular provision will apply

Speaker: NA
Text: on and after I January 1985.

Speaker: NA
Text: Alterations in Penalties

Speaker: NA
Text: The Bill inserts a new section 45A (I) providing

Speaker: NA
Text: that, where an Act increases a penalty for an of-

Speaker: NA
Text: fence, the penalty is to apply only to offences

Speaker: NA
Text: committed after the commencement of the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vision of the Act increasing the penalty. The Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: also inserts a new section 45A (2) providing that

Speaker: NA
Text: where an Act reduces the penalty the penalty as

Speaker: NA
Text: reduced extends to offences committed before the

Speaker: NA
Text: commencemnet of the provision reducing the

Speaker: NA
Text: penalty-but not so as to affect any penalty

Speaker: NA
Text: imposed before that commencement. Both the

Speaker: NA
Text: above provisions are in accordance with the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quirements of Article 15 of the International

Speaker: NA
Text: Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

Speaker: NA
Text: Other Amendments

Speaker: NA
Text: I have already referred honourable members to

Speaker: NA
Text: the explanatory memorandum in relation to the

Speaker: NA
Text: other amendments. They are all of a technical

Speaker: NA
Text: nature. The only comment I would make is that

Speaker: NA
Text: they deal with deficiencies that have come to light

Speaker: NA
Text: over the years and are long overdue for attention.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Bill has no financial implications. I commend

Speaker: NA
Text: the Bill to the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate (on motion by Mr Spender) adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: COMPANIES AND SECURITIES

Speaker: NA
Text: LEGISLATION (MISCELLANEOUS

Speaker: NA
Text: AMENDMENTS) BILL (No.1) 1984

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first

Speaker: NA
Text: time.

Speaker: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
Text: Kingsford-Smith-

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Trade) (8.23)-1 move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: The primary purpose of the Bill I am introducing

Speaker: NA
Text: today is to make certain amendments to the co-

Speaker: NA
Text: operative companies and securities scheme legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation consequent upon the proposed new articles

Speaker: NA
Text: and business rules of the various stock exchanges

Speaker: NA
Text: permitting corporate membership of the

Speaker: NA
Text: inexchanges and the unfixing of certain brokerage

Speaker: NA
Text: rates. The Bill also contains a number of other

Speaker: NA
Text: relatively urgent amendments, of a technical

Speaker: NA
Text: nature, to the co-operative scheme legislation. I

Speaker: NA
Text: would like to outline, for the benefit of honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members, the administrative and legislative

Speaker: NA
Text: context in which the Bill has been prepared, and

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the principal amendments proposed. A

Speaker: NA
Text: detailed description of the provisions of the Bill is

Speaker: NA
Text: contained in the explanatory memorandum which

Speaker: NA
Text: has been circulated to honourable members for

Speaker: NA
Text: information.

Speaker: NA
Text: Co-operative Companies and Securities Scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: The formal agreement executed by the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth and all the States on 22 December

Speaker: NA
Text: 1978 provides the framework for a co-operative

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth-State scheme for a uniform sys-

Speaker: NA
Text: tem of law and administration regulating

Speaker: NA
Text: companies and the securities industry. The

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme covers the relevant law operating in the

Speaker: NA
Text: six States and the Australian Capital Territory. In

Speaker: NA
Text: accordance with the formal agreement, the Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: before honourable members has been agreed to by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Ministerial Council for Companies and Se-

Speaker: NA
Text: curities. If passed by this Parliament, it will. have

Speaker: NA
Text: the effect of automatically amending the corre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponding State legislation. As indicated in our

Speaker: NA
Text: business regulation policy, the Government con-

Speaker: NA
Text: siders that the co-operative scheme should be

Speaker: NA
Text: retained while it demonstrates progress in the

Speaker: NA
Text: achievement of its aims. However, in the longer

Speaker: NA
Text: term we would prefer to move to a national sys-

Speaker: NA
Text: tem of companies and securities regulation

Speaker: NA
Text: administered by the national Parliament. Neither

Speaker: NA
Text: system can be effective if it does not extend to the

Speaker: NA
Text: whole of Australia, including the Northern Terri-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory. The Attorney-General (Senator Gareth

Speaker: NA
Text: Evans) is currently corresponding with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Northern Territory Government seeking its entry

Speaker: NA
Text: to the scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: Content of Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: A brief outline of the Bill is set out at para-

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading graphs I to 4 of the explanatory memorandum. I

Speaker: NA
Text: will briefly mention the main provisions in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill. More detailed commentary on the individual

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions is contained in the explanatory

Speaker: NA
Text: memorandum.

Speaker: NA
Text: Time-sharing

Speaker: NA
Text: The proposed amendments define time-sharing

Speaker: NA
Text: for the first time. Time-sharing has become a

Speaker: NA
Text: popular method of allowing multiple use by dif-

Speaker: NA
Text: ferent families or groups of one facility, spread

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout a year or other specified period of

Speaker: NA
Text: time. For example, a holiday unit may be booked

Speaker: NA
Text: by different groups for separate blocks of three

Speaker: NA
Text: weeks a year, throughout a year.

Speaker: NA
Text: Time-sharing schemes are different from reg-

Speaker: NA
Text: ular or return bookings of rented holiday homes,

Speaker: NA
Text: in that the time-sharers own, in common with

Speaker: NA
Text: those who share the premises at other times, the

Speaker: NA
Text: facilities they use. The marketing to the public of

Speaker: NA
Text: the bulk of time-sharing schemes is regulated

Speaker: NA
Text: under the Companies Act and the Securities In-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry Act under the prescribed interest pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: visions of those Acts. Division 6 of Part IV of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Companies Act 1981 restricts the offering of

Speaker: NA
Text: prescribed interests to the public except in the

Speaker: NA
Text: manner set out in that Division. Also, the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Companies and Securities Commission

Speaker: NA
Text: in July 1983 issued a policy statement on time-

Speaker: NA
Text: sharing arrangements. This indicates the circum-

Speaker: NA
Text: stances in which the NCSC is prepared to relax

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the provisions of Division 6.

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Prescribed interests' is a wide net which

Speaker: NA
Text: catches most profit-making schemes and invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment schemes marketed to the pUblic. Examples

Speaker: NA
Text: of other types of schemes which are or have been

Speaker: NA
Text: liable to be regulated in the same manner include

Speaker: NA
Text: property trusts, franchises, various plantation

Speaker: NA
Text: schemes, horse-racing syndicates and retirement

Speaker: NA
Text: villages.

Speaker: NA
Text: The purpose of the proposed amendments to

Speaker: NA
Text: the definition of prescribed interest in both the

Speaker: NA
Text: Companies Act and the Securities Industry Act-

Speaker: NA
Text: clauses 4 and 10 (2) of the Bill-is to ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: all time-sharing schemes will continue to be

Speaker: NA
Text: regulated under the prescribed interest provisions,

Speaker: NA
Text: notwithstanding that in some cases the investment

Speaker: NA
Text: in question is structured by reference to rights

Speaker: NA
Text: attaching to shares in a corporation. The Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: terial Council resolved to make this change to

Speaker: NA
Text: close what was perceived as a loophole created by

Speaker: NA
Text: the decision in Brentwood Village v. Corporate

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs Commission (New South Wales). In that

Speaker: NA
Text: case, the New South Wales Supreme Court held

Speaker: NA
Text: that rights attached to a share that may normally,

Speaker: NA
Text: when considered apart from the share, have been

Speaker: NA
Text: characterised as prescribed interests, are indivis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ible from the share and, therefore, not subject to

Speaker: NA
Text: Division 6 of Part IV. Accordingly, time-sharing

Speaker: NA
Text: schemes structured in this way would not require

Speaker: NA
Text: execution by the management company of a trust

Speaker: NA
Text: deed appointing an approved trustee to protect

Speaker: NA
Text: the interests of investors. The Ministerial Council

Speaker: NA
Text: has taken the view that consistency of treatment

Speaker: NA
Text: of time-sharing schemes should be maintained and

Speaker: NA
Text: that the higher degree of disclosure and regulation

Speaker: NA
Text: under the prescribed interest provisions should

Speaker: NA
Text: apply to all such schemes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Registration of Charges

Speaker: NA
Text: Paragraph 200 (1) (h) of the Companies Act

Speaker: NA
Text: requires registration of a lien or charge on a crop,

Speaker: NA
Text: a lien or charge on wool, or a stock mortgage.

Speaker: NA
Text: Clause 5 of the Bill will amend section 200 of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Companies Act so as to clarify what securities

Speaker: NA
Text: come within paragraph 200 (1) (h). The effect of

Speaker: NA
Text: the amendment will be that a lien or charge on a

Speaker: NA
Text: crop, a lien or charge on wool or a stock mortgage

Speaker: NA
Text: over property of a company is registrable under

Speaker: NA
Text: the companies legislation of the place of incorpor-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation of the company if it is registrable under

Speaker: NA
Text: specified legislation in the State or Territory

Speaker: NA
Text: where the property the subject of the security is

Speaker: NA
Text: situated. Some types of charges that fall within

Speaker: NA
Text: the scope of section 200 of the Companies Act

Speaker: NA
Text: and hence are required to be registered under the

Speaker: NA
Text: Companies Act, may also be required to be regis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tered under separate State or Territory legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation. Section 211 of the Companies Act

Speaker: NA
Text: attempts to overcome the need for dual regis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tration in relation to securities over personal chat-

Speaker: NA
Text: tels with the meaning of the Australian Capital

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory Instruments Ordinance 1933. However,

Speaker: NA
Text: doubts have been expressed whether section 211

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Companies Act and State codes satisfac-

Speaker: NA
Text: torily remove the obligation to comply with the

Speaker: NA
Text: relevant provisions of the instruments or bills of

Speaker: NA
Text: sale legislation in the various jurisdictions.

Speaker: NA
Text: .. In respect of bills of sale over personal chattels,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Companies Act interacts with the relevant

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Capital Territory legislation as orig-

Speaker: NA
Text: inally intended. Section 211 has been slightly re-

Speaker: NA
Text: cast simply to ensure that the companies code ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: plying in each State will interact equally well with

Speaker: NA
Text: the local bills of sale legislation in each particular

Speaker: NA
Text: State. However, section 211 as it applies in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Capital Territory does not currently

Speaker: NA
Text: exempt persons registering crop liens, wool liens

Speaker: NA
Text: and stock mortgages under the Companies Act

Speaker: NA
Text: from the operation of the Instruments Ordinance.

Speaker: NA
Text: This does not, however, affect the validity of these

Speaker: NA
Text: securities but failure to effect dual registration

Speaker: NA
Text: under the Instruments Ordinance will result in the

Speaker: NA
Text: chargee not being able to take the benefit of cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain rights conferred under that legislation which

Speaker: NA
Text: he would not have at common law. The amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments to section 211 contained in clause 6 of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill will remove the need for dual registration in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to crop liens, wool liens and stock mort-

Speaker: NA
Text: gages and wiU ensure that registration of the rel-

Speaker: NA
Text: evant security under the Companies Act wiU con-

Speaker: NA
Text: fer on the chargee the benefit of any rights

Speaker: NA
Text: contained in the Instruments Ordinance.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the process of ensuring that the companies

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation interacts as intended with the relevant

Speaker: NA
Text: local legislation relating to biUs of sale, crop liens,

Speaker: NA
Text: wool liens and stock mortgages, translator regu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lations will be required in each State which differ

Speaker: NA
Text: according to the different approaches currently

Speaker: NA
Text: adopted in the particular instruments or bills of

Speaker: NA
Text: sale legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Stock Exchanges

Speaker: NA
Text: Shortly after the Trade Practices Act 1974

Speaker: NA
Text: came into effect, the six capital city stock

Speaker: NA
Text: exchanges applied to the Trade Practices Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission for authorisation of various restrictions

Speaker: NA
Text: imposed on members by stock exchange business

Speaker: NA
Text: rules amongst which are rules relating to broker-

Speaker: NA
Text: age rates to be charged by members and rules

Speaker: NA
Text: governing eligibility for membership of stock

Speaker: NA
Text: exchanges. After a process of public consultation

Speaker: NA
Text: and the issue by the TPC of a draft determination

Speaker: NA
Text: in June 1982, the TPC released its final determi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nation on brokerage and stock exchange member-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship on 27 September 1982. The TPC denied

Speaker: NA
Text: authorisation of the stock exchange business rules

Speaker: NA
Text: for fixed brokerage rates, but aU owed a phasing-in

Speaker: NA
Text: period for unfixed rates. Interim authorisation

Speaker: NA
Text: was granted until I April 1984 for fixed rates on

Speaker: NA
Text: aU transactions and until 1 October 1985 for fixed

Speaker: NA
Text: rates for that part of a transaction up to a

Speaker: NA
Text: threshold value of $100,000. The TPC denied

Speaker: NA
Text: authorisation of stock exchange business rules

Speaker: NA
Text: which restricted entry to membership of stock

Speaker: NA
Text: exchanges, prevented incorporation of stockbrok-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing businesses and restricted certain other activi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties of stockbrokers. The TPC granted interim

Speaker: NA
Text: authorisation until 1 April 1984 for the current

Speaker: NA
Text: membership rules in order to give stock exchanges

Speaker: NA
Text: the opportunity to make amendments to their

Speaker: NA
Text: rules. To date, the TPC has granted interim auth-

Speaker: NA
Text: orisation to the draft business rules relating to the

Speaker: NA
Text: unfixing of certain brokerage rates and to the

Speaker: NA
Text: draft articles of the various exchanges dealing

Speaker: NA
Text: with membership of the stock exchanges by natu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ral persons and corporations.

Speaker: NA
Text: Parts III and IV of the Bill contain amendments

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Companies and Securities (Interpretation

Speaker: NA
Text: and MisceUaneous Provisions) Act 1980 and to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Securities Industry Act 1980 consequent upon

Speaker: NA
Text: the proposed new rules of the stock exchanges

Speaker: NA
Text: permitting corporate membership and the unfix-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing of certain brokerage rates as from 1 April

Speaker: NA
Text: 1984. On 14 July 1983 at a meeting of the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: terial Council, the Attorney-General announced

Speaker: NA
Text: that it was the Commonwealth's firm view that

Speaker: NA
Text: the stockbroking industry should remain subject

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Trade Practices Act. The opening up of

Speaker: NA
Text: membership of the exchanges to corporations and

Speaker: NA
Text: the unfixing of certain brokerage rates from I

Speaker: NA
Text: April 1984 represent a major watershed in the de-

Speaker: NA
Text: velopment of the securities industry in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: It will undoubtedly lead to both innovation and

Speaker: NA
Text: increased competition among brokers. The Camp-

Speaker: NA
Text: beU Committee of Inquiry into the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Financial System clearly favoured deregulation of

Speaker: NA
Text: brokerage rates and removal of the barriers

Speaker: NA
Text: against the entry of corporate members to the

Speaker: NA
Text: exchanges.

Speaker: NA
Text: The amendments contained in the Bill make

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary changes consequent on the TPC's auth-

Speaker: NA
Text: orisation and the alterations to the articles, mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: oranda of association and business rules of the

Speaker: NA
Text: stock exchanges. This represents the first stage in

Speaker: NA
Text: the adaptation of the legislation to the impending

Speaker: NA
Text: changes to the stockbroking industry. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: months ahead, as the new system settles down, it

Speaker: NA
Text: is likely that the Ministerial Council will need to

Speaker: NA
Text: address a number of further issues that may re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quire amendment of the securities industry legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation. These will be best dealt with after the mar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ket and the National Companies and Securities

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission have had some experience with the

Speaker: NA
Text: changed environment. Nevertheless, there are

Speaker: NA
Text: some issues which all parties recognise may need

Speaker: NA
Text: to be examined. I would like to discuss some of

Speaker: NA
Text: these issues.

Speaker: NA
Text: Clause JO( 1) of the Bill contains a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments to the Securities Industry Act which

Speaker: NA
Text: are designed to ensure that a body corporate is

Speaker: NA
Text: covered by certain key definitions such as

Speaker: NA
Text: 'member', 'member firm' and 'sole trader'.

Speaker: NA
Text: Further consideration will need to be given to

Speaker: NA
Text: whether any provisions in the legislation should

Speaker: NA
Text: be extended to a director of a member corpor-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation who is himself a member of an exchange.

Speaker: NA
Text: The proposed new articles of the stock exchanges

Speaker: NA
Text: will enable a broker to be a member of more than

Speaker: NA
Text: one exchange. This raises the question whether

Speaker: NA
Text: the present approach in the legislation in relation

Speaker: NA
Text: to fidelity funds is still the most appropriate. The

Speaker: NA
Text: fidelity fund provisions in the legislation were

Speaker: NA
Text: originally drawn up on the basis that a broker

Speaker: NA
Text: would be a member of only one exchange and

Speaker: NA
Text: each exchange would have its own separate fid-

Speaker: NA
Text: elity fund. The Bill does not disturb the present

Speaker: NA
Text: position of each exchange having a separate fid-

Speaker: NA
Text: elity fund and the effect of clause 17 in respect of

Speaker: NA
Text: a broker who is a member of more than one

Speaker: NA
Text: exchange is to make the fidelity fund of each

Speaker: NA
Text: exchange that has admitted the broker as a

Speaker: NA
Text: member liable for claims against the member's

Speaker: NA
Text: fraud, subject to the existing $500,000 limit in

Speaker: NA
Text: spect of each member. In the longer term it will be

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary for serious consideration to be given to

Speaker: NA
Text: the question whether the time has not come for

Speaker: NA
Text: the introduction of a single, national fidelity fund.

Speaker: NA
Text: While not wishing to pre-empt any decisions on

Speaker: NA
Text: this important issue, the establishment of a single

Speaker: NA
Text: national fund would seem to be logical in the light

Speaker: NA
Text: of the proposed new business rules that will en-

Speaker: NA
Text: able a broker to be a member of more than one

Speaker: NA
Text: exchange. However, the future structure and

Speaker: NA
Text: function of the fidelity funds will have to be con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sidered in conjunction with the proposals for a

Speaker: NA
Text: centralised scrip and accounting system Censas.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Censas proposals are presently being reasses-

Speaker: NA
Text: sed by the stock exchanges and the future role of

Speaker: NA
Text: the fidelity funds as an investor protection mech-

Speaker: NA
Text: anism will be critically examined by governments

Speaker: NA
Text: when considering revised proposals on Censas put

Speaker: NA
Text: forward by the exchanges.

Speaker: NA
Text: The inevitable entry of financial institutions

Speaker: NA
Text: into the stockbroking industry will raise new con-

Speaker: NA
Text: flict of interest issues that will need to be addres-

Speaker: NA
Text: sed. The Ministerial Council has therefore

Speaker: NA
Text: directed the NCSC to monitor the operation of

Speaker: NA
Text: the securities industry legislation and stock

Speaker: NA
Text: exchange rules that relate to conflict of interests

Speaker: NA
Text: in the stockbroking industry and to report to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministerial Council on any amendments to the Se-

Speaker: NA
Text: curities I ndustry Act and stock exchange rules

Speaker: NA
Text: which appear desirable.

Speaker: NA
Text: Financial Impact Statement

Speaker: NA
Text: The Bill is unlikely to have any material effect

Speaker: NA
Text: on costs, revenue or savings to the Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is not expected to be any loss of revenue in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Capital Territory to the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment from the removal of the need for dual regis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tration under the Instruments Ordinance in re-

Speaker: NA
Text: spect of crop liens, wool liens and stock mortgages

Speaker: NA
Text: as none of these securities has been registered in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Capital Territory since 1979. The

Speaker: NA
Text: impact of the Bill on industry and the general

Speaker: NA
Text: public would be varied and, because in most cases

Speaker: NA
Text: it would be indirect, the net costs or benefits are

Speaker: NA
Text: difficult to quantify.

Speaker: NA
Text: For some promoters of time-sharing schemes-

Speaker: NA
Text: that is, those who after the Brentwood decision

Speaker: NA
Text: wished to structure their scheme by reference to

Speaker: NA
Text: rights attaching to shares in a corporation-the

Speaker: NA
Text: expenses connected with the preparation and

Speaker: NA
Text: lodgment of an approved deed and with the costs

Speaker: NA
Text: associated with the appointment and remuner-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation of a trustee would no longer be avoided. On

Speaker: NA
Text: the other hand, these direct costs would need to be

Speaker: NA
Text: set off against the intangible public interest

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits accruing to investors in the scheme who

Speaker: NA
Text: re- would be afforded greater protection by reason

Speaker: NA
Text: that the scheme was being regulated under the

Speaker: NA
Text: prescribed interest provisions.

Speaker: NA
Text: While the direct pecuniary savings to the public

Speaker: NA
Text: from the removal of the need for dual registration

Speaker: NA
Text: under the Instruments Ordinance and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Companies Act would be small, the intangible

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit of simply not having to complete the regis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tration process must also be taken into account.

Speaker: NA
Text: This observation must, of course, be qualified by

Speaker: NA
Text: the fact that no crop lien, wool lien or stock mort-

Speaker: NA
Text: gage has been registered in the Australian Capital

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory since 1979. There would not appear to

Speaker: NA
Text: be any direct costs associated with the stock

Speaker: NA
Text: exchange amendments in the Bill as these are only

Speaker: NA
Text: consequent upon the proposed new stock

Speaker: NA
Text: exchange rules on corporate membership and

Speaker: NA
Text: brokerage rates. I commend the Companies and

Speaker: NA
Text: Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments) Bill to the House. .

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate (on motion by Mr Spender) adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: APPROPRIATION BILL (No.3) 1983-84

Speaker: NA
Text: [COGNA TE BILLS:

Speaker: NA
Text: APPROPRIATION BILL (No.4) 1983-84

Speaker: NA
Text: APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY

Speaker: NA
Text: DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No.2) 1983-84]

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER ( Mrs Child)-

Speaker: NA
Text: Before the debate on this Bill is resumed, I remind

Speaker: NA
Text: the House that it has been agreed that a general

Speaker: NA
Text: debate be allowed covering this Bill, Appropri-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation Bill (No.4) 1983-84 and Appropriation

Speaker: NA
Text: (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No.2)

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Text: Mitchell) (8.38)-1 think that

Speaker: NA
Text: the time has come for us to examine how

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia is getting on, how we are going as an

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian family, where we are going and from

Speaker: NA
Text: where we have come. About six months ago I

Speaker: NA
Text: made just such an examination to ascertain for

Speaker: NA
Text: myself and on behalf of the electors of the elector-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate of Mitchell where we stood and where we

Speaker: NA
Text: were going. On that occasion I took the oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunity to make a few comparisons between com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mitments and the delivery of promises. However,

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances today are somewhat different.

Speaker: NA
Text: How does one design a Budget in April 1984 to

Speaker: NA
Text: meet an election at the end of 1984?

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us look at all the circumstances that may be

Speaker: NA
Text: involved in that process, because that is the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's intention. The Prime Minister ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Hawke) has made a commitment that there will

Speaker: NA
Text: be an election later this year or early next year.

Speaker: Mr GOODLUCK
Text: This year?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr CADMANYes, indeed. The problem for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government is how to design a Budget that

Speaker: NA
Text: will get past the election successfully?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Groom-And win votes.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Text: And win votes, gain seats or

Speaker: NA
Text: encourage the Australian people to support the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister. We know, for instance, that dur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the past year the average Australian family

Speaker: NA
Text: has paid out about an additional $15 a week.

Speaker: Mr HODGMAN
Text: Seventeen.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Text: The honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Denison says it is $17. I am being conservative to-

Speaker: NA
Text: night but I think that Medicare, the indexation of

Speaker: NA
Text: petrol costs, the lump sum superannuation tax,

Speaker: NA
Text: the failure to index spouses' allowances and all of

Speaker: NA
Text: the other measures that were promised but were

Speaker: NA
Text: not fulfilled, are costing the average Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: family about $15 more than was the case about 12

Speaker: NA
Text: months ago.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government now has to design a Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: which will meet the needs of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: people, who will say: 'What good management;

Speaker: NA
Text: what splendid activity on behalf of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Government!'. We have had a year in which

Speaker: NA
Text: wages did not go up, but more people are in work

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Australian community, as was predicted

Speaker: NA
Text: when the wage freeze was introduced. People

Speaker: NA
Text: have had to pull in their belts a little because

Speaker: NA
Text: were no wage increases, but there are more people

Speaker: NA
Text: in jobs. That is fine. We accepted that at the time;

Speaker: NA
Text: we still accept it; and we still think it is a good

Speaker: NA
Text: idea. During the last year the drought has broken.

Speaker: NA
Text: The drought will break only once, but it has

Speaker: NA
Text: broken and it will mean a tremendous amount to

Speaker: NA
Text: every individual in Australia. City people tend to

Speaker: NA
Text: underestimate the importance of rural industries,

Speaker: NA
Text: the value of rural industries and their export earn-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings. The jobs they create in cities are very sig-

Speaker: NA
Text: nificant to the Australian economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last year the Government said: 'We will go out

Speaker: NA
Text: and borrow a lot of dollars, stoke up the fires a bit

Speaker: NA
Text: and get this country moving'. That is what the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister said he would do. So he borrowed

Speaker: NA
Text: a lot of money. He has borrowed it from every-

Speaker: NA
Text: where around the world and from Australians as

Speaker: NA
Text: well during this year. Therefore, Australian famil-

Speaker: NA
Text: ies have seen the Government borrow money to

Speaker: NA
Text: help us through this difficult period. We did not

Speaker: NA
Text: have our wage rises but we know that our children

Speaker: NA
Text: are starting to get more jobs than before. The jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: are not as good as we would like, but they are

Speaker: NA
Text: starting to get more jobs.

Speaker: NA
Text: What can be done next year? No drought will

Speaker: NA
Text: break. What sort of bank account do we want at

Speaker: NA
Text: the end of next year? Do we want to be well in the

Speaker: NA
Text: red or a little into the red? How will we balance

Speaker: NA
Text: our books for this coming year? Will we borrow a

Speaker: NA
Text: lot or can we cut down a little on our spending as a

Speaker: NA
Text: family?

Speaker: NA
Text: Government members interjecting-

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER ( Mrs Child)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: suggest to honourable members that the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Mitchell has the floor. I call the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Text: They are extremely encourag-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing. I can understand the support I am getting

Speaker: NA
Text: from members of the Australian Labor Party for

Speaker: NA
Text: the contentions that I am putting now. They are

Speaker: NA
Text: supporting every word I say. They cannot contain

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves. Do we cut down a little on our ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: penses? Do we as a family draw in the belt a little

Speaker: NA
Text: more and say: 'We will not spend as much. We

Speaker: NA
Text: will not be as extravagant this year'? We could do

Speaker: NA
Text: that. We could raise a little more income by rais-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing taxes. We could get some more money into the

Speaker: NA
Text: tin by raising taxes or we could borrow more. Just

Speaker: NA
Text: what size do we want the overdraft to be? How

Speaker: NA
Text: big will our overdraft be at the end of next year

Speaker: NA
Text: and how big should i't be when we want a Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: designed to win an election?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Hand-Have we got an overdraft?

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Text: Australia has a massive over-

Speaker: NA
Text: draft, and the Labor Party has led us into it. It was

Speaker: NA
Text: there $8.5 billion this financial year. What does the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government want to do next year? What should

Speaker: NA
Text: we do? If the Government wants to be popular

Speaker: NA
Text: and give a lot of things away, it will say: 'We will

Speaker: NA
Text: have a fairly big overdraft again'. I guess that the

Speaker: NA
Text: overdraft will be about $7.5 billion. Responsible

Speaker: NA
Text: people say it will be $5 billion, but let us say it will

Speaker: NA
Text: be $7.5 billion.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Groom-Ten.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Text: The forward Estimates show

Speaker: NA
Text: a deficit of almost $10 billion, but I do not think it

Speaker: NA
Text: will be $10 billion because an atmosphere of re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsibility is required. We must be careful as the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Council of Trade Unions and many

Speaker: NA
Text: other people believe that a promise was made iIi

Speaker: NA
Text: regard to tax cuts. So I tend to think that there

Speaker: NA
Text: will be a fairly big deficit because to offer sig-

Speaker: NA
Text: nificant tax cuts there has to be an expenditure of

Speaker: NA
Text: public funds of about $1 billion. That would give

Speaker: NA
Text: the average family about $3 or $4 in the pocket

Speaker: NA
Text: next year as compared with last year.

Speaker: NA
Text: I predict that the Budget will raise a few taxes

Speaker: NA
Text: from the tall poppies, people who do not really

Speaker: NA
Text: matter in the Government's eyes. Such people

Speaker: NA
Text: only employ others; so they do not really matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government will say: 'We will raise a few

Speaker: NA
Text: more taxes from them. We will give some tax cuts

Speaker: NA
Text: and we will not withdraw much from government

Speaker: NA
Text: services'. I predict that is what the Budget will do,

Speaker: NA
Text: and that will make the Government fairly popu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lar. It will allow us to retain a fairly big overdraft

Speaker: NA
Text: but it will be presented as a responsible decision. I

Speaker: NA
Text: wonder why I suspect that the Government will

Speaker: NA
Text: adopt this type of economic approach. I think it

Speaker: NA
Text: will take this approach because it has been the

Speaker: NA
Text: practice of this Government to make itself popu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lar and at the first opportunity to say that it can

Speaker: NA
Text: no longer keep its promises. It then reins back on

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure and changes the whole scene very

Speaker: NA
Text: quickly.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government has made commitments in

Speaker: NA
Text: the past, and I suspect that that is what will hap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pen in this Budget. There will be tax cuts for

Speaker: NA
Text: middle and lower income families, there will be

Speaker: NA
Text: some tax levied on the tall poppies and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government supporters will think that is good;

Speaker: NA
Text: there will be no cut in government services. So the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government will basically remain popular. It

Speaker: NA
Text: really cannot sustain that situation if it is to be

Speaker: NA
Text: economically responsible, to create jobs and to be

Speaker: NA
Text: able to encourage the investment that we need in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia to create more jobs and to allow the

Speaker: NA
Text: economy to expand. The Government will create

Speaker: NA
Text: a popular Budget. It will stick around for a couple

Speaker: NA
Text: of months and say what good fellows its members

Speaker: NA
Text: are, then it will have an election and very quickly

Speaker: NA
Text: bring on a nasty mini-Budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: I wonder why I suspect that. I suspect it be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause I have looked at the record, and the record

Speaker: NA
Text: tells me, as my colleagues have been telling me,

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Government is rather keen on taxes. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: rather keen on wealth taxes, capital gains taxes,

Speaker: NA
Text: assets tests, death duties and things like that. They

Speaker: NA
Text: are being examined at the moment. I do not think

Speaker: NA
Text: that these matters are being examined so that they

Speaker: NA
Text: will never be used; they are being examined so

Speaker: NA
Text: that they can be put into action. I am sure that

Speaker: NA
Text: this will be the Government's approach. I will

Speaker: NA
Text: read some of the promises made before 5 March

Speaker: NA
Text: 1983, which stated in part:

Speaker: NA
Text: Our Government's total income tax package is being

Speaker: NA
Text: leased concurrently with this speech.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Groom-Who said that?

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Text: I have a copy of the speech

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Prime Minister made at the opening of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Labor Party campaign on 16

Speaker: NA
Text: February at the Sydney Opera House. He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Its key elements include immediate reductions in in-

Speaker: NA
Text: come tax for almost six million Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: taxpayers . . .

Speaker: NA
Text: The Prime Minister mentioned 'six million Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian taxpayers', yet Australian families are pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing an extra $15 each. I cannot understand that. I

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot believe it. The Prime Minister continued:

Speaker: NA
Text: . . . with the greatest tax cuts going to those on the

Speaker: NA
Text: lowest incomes . . . a taxpayer without dependants

Speaker: NA
Text: earning $225 a week, for example, will get a tax cut of

Speaker: NA
Text: $4.76 a week;

Speaker: NA
Text: Nobody has seen that act, but that was the

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Groom-People are suckers.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Text: People are suckers. They

Speaker: NA
Text: were taken for suckers. The Australian com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity is very shrewd in assessing these things.

Speaker: NA
Text: The people know that when we have a generous

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget followed by an election we will have many

Speaker: NA
Text: promises in the Budget and in the election cam-

Speaker: NA
Text: paign. They know that, as last time, these prom-

Speaker: NA
Text: ises will not be fulfilled.

Speaker: NA
Text: There were many promises. On page 14 of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister's speech he promised to reduce

Speaker: NA
Text: the price of petrol by 3c a litre. Actually, he has

Speaker: NA
Text: put up petrol prices by a fancy indexation process.

Speaker: NA
Text: There was a promise made by the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: that he would not break promises. That is an un-

Speaker: NA
Text: believable promise and we are sure to hear it

Speaker: NA
Text: again. Promises were made to increase funding for

Speaker: NA
Text: government schools by $37m. That has not oc-

Speaker: NA
Text: curred. Promises were made to all sorts of com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munities, to pensioners and fringe dwellers. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has introduced legislation to change

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian oath of allegiance by removing ref-

Speaker: NA
Text: erence to the Queen, with all that that concept

Speaker: NA
Text: stands for in our society. The Government is seek-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to remove reference to the Crown Solicitor in

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation introduced tonight and it wants to

Speaker: NA
Text: change the Australian flag. It has enacted sex dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: crimination legislation. It has spoilt a brilliant mi-

Speaker: NA
Text: gration program so that now, where migration

Speaker: NA
Text: does exist, it is based on all sorts of unusual atti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tudes and ideas of the Minister for Immigration

Speaker: NA
Text: and Ethnic Affairs ( Mr West). It has introduced a

Speaker: NA
Text: lump sum tax on superannuation. It has fooled

Speaker: NA
Text: around with and mucked up the totality of our de-

Speaker: NA
Text: fence system. It has gone to extremes to try to

Speaker: NA
Text: rechange by subterfuge the very attitudes that it

Speaker: NA
Text: tries to present.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Prime Minister appears glib and confident

Speaker: NA
Text: on television. Actually, what is happening in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Cabinet room and in other areas is the exact op-

Speaker: NA
Text: posite of the presentation put forward by the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Labor Party in the public place. I will read

Speaker: NA
Text: to the House what the Labor Party promised

Speaker: NA
Text: about defence, a most serious matter affecting the

Speaker: NA
Text: security of all Australian families:

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor is committed to the re-establishment and main-

Speaker: NA
Text: tenance of a well equipped, highly trained and mobile De-

Speaker: NA
Text: fence Force to ensure the security of Australia's sovereign

Speaker: NA
Text: territory, particularly in the

Speaker: NA
Text: economic zones and its areas of vita! interest.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have withdrawn from Butterworth.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Groom-We are disarming.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Text: We are disarming. We were

Speaker: NA
Text: told this week that our soldiers do not have

Speaker: NA
Text: sufficient supplies. They do not have decent boots

Speaker: NA
Text: and they have to buy their own ammunition. Time

Speaker: NA
Text: after time, as we read the policy speech the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister made at the Opera House a little over 12

Speaker: NA
Text: months ago, we find that promise after promise

Speaker: NA
Text: has been broken. I predict that we will have a

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget which appears generous, a promising

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget, an encouraging Budget, a Budget that will

Speaker: NA
Text: lead into an election campaign in which more

Speaker: NA
Text: promises will be built on the promises of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget. I ask honourable members of this House:

Speaker: NA
Text: How much real work has been done in this place

Speaker: NA
Text: over the last two weeks? Insignificant legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: has been introduced. One or two Bills a day are

Speaker: NA
Text: being introduced and debated cognately. Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment members cannot find sufficient matters to

Speaker: NA
Text: interest them even to attend in this place.

Speaker: Mr HODGMAN
Text: Where are they?

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Text: Where are they? They sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port these important economic measures of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government so strongly that there are only three

Speaker: NA
Text: members in the House and the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no enthusiasm for the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: policies. Government members have been con-

Speaker: NA
Text: founded by the sheer cynicism of the approach

Speaker: NA
Text: adopted by the Australian Labor Party. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: about to begin that cycle again, a cycle that I find

Speaker: NA
Text: concerning and damaging. The Government, in-

Speaker: NA
Text: stead of giving the tax cuts promised, takes taxes

Speaker: NA
Text: out of people's pockets indirectly. The taxes come

Speaker: NA
Text: from individuals and the Government's coffers

Speaker: NA
Text: are built up to the extent of a $15 contribution by

Speaker: NA
Text: the average Australian family.

Speaker: NA
Text: One after another, the Government has done

Speaker: NA
Text: its best to remove, step by step, the promises of

Speaker: NA
Text: tax cuts, cuts in the price of petrol, better defence

Speaker: NA
Text: and better foreign relations. It is a really cynical

Speaker: NA
Text: process that I see going on in this House. Commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments are made publicly by the Prime Minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: but the announcements made by other Ministers

Speaker: NA
Text: go in the opposite direction and the socialist com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mitment to change the face of Australia is gradu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ally being fulfilled. I warn the Australian people

Speaker: NA
Text: that they should not be taken in by a generous

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget. That can only spell disaster eventually for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian nation, and that disaster will occur

Speaker: NA
Text: in 1985. In 1985 the reins of government need to

Speaker: NA
Text: be in the hands of responsible, good managers.

Speaker: NA
Text: vulnerable north and west, its

Speaker: NA
Text: There will be a change of government at the end

Speaker: NA
Text: of the year because the Australian people have

Speaker: NA
Text: seen through this process.

Speaker: Mr STAPLES
Text: Diamond Valley)(8.55)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: am glad to hear that the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Mitchell ( Mr Cadman) is resigned to losing the

Speaker: NA
Text: next election, and well he should be. The people

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia will not forget quickly the mess in

Speaker: NA
Text: which the previous Government left Australia in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1983. He talked about economic responsibility.

Speaker: NA
Text: The economic irresponsibility of his Government

Speaker: NA
Text: left Australia with a massive deficit, in massive de-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceit, and he knows it. The weight of the borrow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings the Fraser Government made over the years

Speaker: NA
Text: is now being reflected in the interest bills this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government and the people of Australia have to

Speaker: NA
Text: pick up. I will refer later to the problems with

Speaker: NA
Text: which we were left.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to talk tonight about the great Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian dream. The great Australian dream for

Speaker: NA
Text: thousands of homeless people in this country is

Speaker: NA
Text: not to own their own homes; that is the dream of a

Speaker: NA
Text: dream. The real life Australian dream for thou-

Speaker: NA
Text: sands of homeless families and young people is

Speaker: NA
Text: just to live and sleep in warm, secure accommo-

Speaker: NA
Text: dation at reasonable expense. Throughout

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, in all our States and Territories, the

Speaker: NA
Text: story is the same and the dream is the same.

Speaker: NA
Text: People who are poor, unemployed, black, single

Speaker: NA
Text: male or female parents, the single man or woman,

Speaker: NA
Text: the young, invalids, migrants or the aged, if they

Speaker: NA
Text: are not entirely homeless will most likely be pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing half their income as rent. Warm, secure ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: commodation is a basic need for us all. It is a right

Speaker: NA
Text: that all of us in this country should expect to be

Speaker: NA
Text: delivered. Today, and for decades before, that

Speaker: NA
Text: right has been denied to an increasing number of

Speaker: NA
Text: people in Australia. Many are homeless or strug-

Speaker: NA
Text: gling in the private rental market. Families face

Speaker: NA
Text: long waiting lists for what in Victoria are mainly

Speaker: NA
Text: high rise flats in the public sector. Low and mod-

Speaker: NA
Text: erate income earners in Australia continue to face

Speaker: NA
Text: a housing crisis. Approximately 70 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian householders own or are buying their

Speaker: NA
Text: own homes. For the remaining 30 per cent, home

Speaker: NA
Text: ownership is, and has been, to dream the imposs-

Speaker: NA
Text: ibledream.

Speaker: NA
Text: Approximately 20 per cent of Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: households are occupied by private tenants. A

Speaker: NA
Text: number of studies have proved that a large per-

Speaker: NA
Text: centage of private tenants are more financially

Speaker: NA
Text: disadvantaged than those in public housing. Of

Speaker: NA
Text: the 670,000 social security pensioners renting pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: vately, nearly all would be eligible for public

Speaker: NA
Text: housing if it were available. Among private ten-

Speaker: NA
Text: ants, it is the 670,000 people dependent on pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions and benefits who are in the worst position. A

Speaker: NA
Text: 1976 survey showed that 86 per cent of those

Speaker: NA
Text: people were paying out more than 20 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: their income on rent, and 62 per cent of those

Speaker: NA
Text: people were paying over 50 per cent of their in-

Speaker: NA
Text: come on rent.

Speaker: NA
Text: To give honourable members an indication of

Speaker: NA
Text: the struggle that hundreds of thousands of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralians face in their day to day existence, let me

Speaker: NA
Text: quote some figures from the South Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Housing Trust of September 1983. The weekly in-

Speaker: NA
Text: come of a person who is unemployed and under

Speaker: NA
Text: 18 is $45. The average weekly vacant rent for a

Speaker: NA
Text: flat at the time of the figures quoted was $72.51.

Speaker: NA
Text: RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN INCOME AND

Speaker: NA
Text: Pension/benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: Unemployed under 18

Speaker: NA
Text: Unemployed over 18

Speaker: NA
Text: Unemployed married + 2

Speaker: NA
Text: children

Speaker: NA
Text: Supporting parent + 2 children

Speaker: NA
Text: (Source: S.A. Housing Trust figures For September, 1983)

Speaker: Mr STAPLES
Text: Why do so many Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: citizens live in such poverty? Clearly from the

Speaker: NA
Text: figures I have provided, figures that have been

Speaker: NA
Text: around for decades in one form or another, it can

Speaker: NA
Text: be seen that the problem is that people have just

Speaker: NA
Text: so much to spend on rent. Why are the rents so

Speaker: NA
Text: high? Why has this problem not been addressed

Speaker: NA
Text: before? In Victoria thousands of people live in in-

Speaker: NA
Text: humane high rise buildings. Honourable members

Speaker: NA
Text: on their next visit to Melbourne should look out

Speaker: NA
Text: of the window of their aircraft at those high rise

Speaker: NA
Text: buildings, and see how they rise interminably out

Speaker: NA
Text: of the ground, out of the city below, and try to im-

Speaker: NA
Text: agine how they would live, as a single parent per-

Speaker: NA
Text: haps with a couple of kids, in those sorts of con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ditions. They should try to imagine the lack of

Speaker: NA
Text: privacy, the lack of open space, the incon-

Speaker: NA
Text: venience, the danger and the lack of amenities. If

Speaker: NA
Text: members of this Parliament or the community in

Speaker: NA
Text: general had some time, my colleague the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Melbourne ( Mr Hand) would be

Speaker: NA
Text: very happy to show them some of the housing

Speaker: NA
Text: problems in his electorate. His problems are the

Speaker: NA
Text: problems of so many.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is one and a half times the person's weekly

Speaker: NA
Text: income. If a person is unemployed, married and

Speaker: NA
Text: with two children, 59 per cent of the family's

Speaker: NA
Text: weekly income of $177 .20 would be spent on rent-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing a house. In other words, that family has only

Speaker: NA
Text: about $70 a week to clothe, feed, educate, enter-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain, travel, pay the gas and light bills and keep

Speaker: NA
Text: healthy. I should be more accurate in my figures,

Speaker: NA
Text: for $1 or $2 in those circumstances can mean so

Speaker: NA
Text: much to a family; so much, in fact, that the

Speaker: NA
Text: weekly disposable income would be $72.49, or

Speaker: NA
