Text: $18.12 per person per week for week after week. I

Speaker: NA
Text: seek leave to have the table from which I quoted

Speaker: NA
Text: incorporated in Hansard. .

Speaker: NA
Text: Leave granted.

Speaker: NA
Text: The table read asfollows-

Speaker: NA
Text: RENT FOR SOCIAL SECURITY BENEFICIARIES

Speaker: NA
Text: Weekly Average weekly vacant rents

Speaker: NA
Text: average

Speaker: NA
Text: rents Flats Houses

Speaker: NA
Text: Weekly as%oF as%oF as%oF

Speaker: NA
Text: income income income income

Speaker: NA
Text: In the estates closer to ground level, houses that

Speaker: NA
Text: were built during the 1950s and 1960s under suc-

Speaker: NA
Text: cessive Liberal-National Party governments in

Speaker: NA
Text: that State, under Bolte, Hamer and Thompson,

Speaker: NA
Text: are cracking and falling apart. Plaster falls from

Speaker: NA
Text: the ceilings and from the walls. Windows are

Speaker: NA
Text: smashing in their frames because of the sinking

Speaker: NA
Text: and twisting of the buildings. Cracks centimetres

Speaker: NA
Text: wide appear in the walls overnight. The Victorian

Speaker: NA
Text: Government is doing something. It is doing some

Speaker: NA
Text: magnificent work in estate improvement, tenant

Speaker: NA
Text: participation and structural repair, but it is ham-

Speaker: NA
Text: pered by lack of funds. For those millions of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralians who live in spacious suburban homes-

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Text: Give them some money.

Speaker: Mr STAPLES
Text: Where has the money come

Speaker: NA
Text: from in the past? I will get back to that and the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member will see where the money has

Speaker: NA
Text: not come from and why this has happened. Most

Speaker: NA
Text: people like me and most of us who live in spacious

Speaker: NA
Text: suburban homes would spend as much in one

Speaker: NA
Text: night in a restaurant as millions of Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: who live in poverty now would be able to spend

Speaker: NA
Text: on food for weeks. It is another world but it is a

Speaker: NA
Text: world we should be more concerned about. What

Speaker: NA
Text: is the real use of our National Gallery, our sump-

Speaker: NA
Text: tuous High Court of Australia and winning the

Speaker: NA
Text: America's Cup if so many millions of our neigh-

Speaker: NA
Text: bours live in poverty, so often without decent

Speaker: NA
Text: shelter? Thousands of our fellow Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: right now will be trying to get warm and trying to

Speaker: NA
Text: get to sleep in a car or a tent in the cities around

Speaker: NA
Text: our country. Many will break into a vacant office

Speaker: NA
Text: or church to escape the cold and many will sleep

Speaker: NA
Text: in some old clothing bin at a suburban service

Speaker: NA
Text: station or elsewhere. The Whitlam Government

Speaker: NA
Text: set about doing something very concrete about

Speaker: NA
Text: public housing and housing-related poverty.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr STAPLES
Text: Let those honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members opposite who interject, to ask why we

Speaker: NA
Text: are not doing something, listen now. Let them in-

Speaker: NA
Text: terject now. In 1974-75 dollar terms the last

Speaker: NA
Text: Hayden Budget gave $290.5m to the States

Speaker: NA
Text: through the Commonwealth-State Housing

Speaker: NA
Text: Agreement. There was a tremendous boost to

Speaker: NA
Text: public housing through the Whitlam years, as

Speaker: NA
Text: there was in urban and regional development in

Speaker: NA
Text: general. But the Fraser years eroded that Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution to public housing and housing in gen-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral. In constant dollar terms, the housing budget

Speaker: NA
Text: fell from $290.5m in 1974-75 to $139.6m in the

Speaker: NA
Text: last Fraser Budget. In that period the policy of

Speaker: NA
Text: market rents was also imposed on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement and

Speaker: NA
Text: on the public tenants. That was done explicitly to

Speaker: NA
Text: ration the available public housing stocks because

Speaker: NA
Text: that Government was not going to build them; it

Speaker: NA
Text: was going to force these people out on to the

Speaker: NA
Text: streets and into expensive rents; it did not care.

Speaker: NA
Text: This had the effect of turning public housing into

Speaker: NA
Text: welfare housing. Public housing is not welfare

Speaker: NA
Text: housing; it is public housing. There are hundreds

Speaker: NA
Text: of thousands of Australian families who need pub-

Speaker: NA
Text: lic housing right now at cost rents.

Speaker: NA
Text: In its first Budget the Hawke Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: increased the appropriation for public housing by

Speaker: NA
Text: 50 per cent from $330m in 1982-83 to $500m in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1983-84. With the phenomenal success of the first

Speaker: NA
Text: home owners scheme and other associated hous-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing programs, as was indicated earlier by the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Stirling ( Mr Ronald

Speaker: NA
Text: Edwards), there has been a 24 per cent increase in

Speaker: NA
Text: the appropriation for public housing to $1.3

Speaker: NA
Text: billion. That contrasts vividly with the real terms

Speaker: NA
Text: reduction of 40 per cent during those Fraser years.

Speaker: NA
Text: Had the spending in the Hayden Budget been

Speaker: NA
Text: maintained by the Fraser Government through-

Speaker: NA
Text: out its term of office, $3,750m-

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members interjecting-

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER ( Mrs Child)-

Speaker: NA
Text: Order! The honourable member will resume his

Speaker: NA
Text: seat. The Chair has had occasion to speak to both

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Mitchell and the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Braddon on three

Speaker: NA
Text: occasions. The honourable member for Mitchell

Speaker: NA
Text: was protected by the Chair while he was speaking.

Speaker: NA
Text: I ask him to give the same courtesy to the speaker,

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Diamond Valley.

Speaker: Mr STAPLES
Text: I shall reiterate what I said be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause I am sure that honourable members

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite did not hear. Had the spending of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Hayden Budget been maintained by the Fraser

Speaker: NA
Text: Government over those years, $3,750m would

Speaker: NA
Text: have been spent on public housing. Had that

Speaker: NA
Text: $3,750m been spent on public housing, thousands

Speaker: NA
Text: would not be homeless or living in squalor or pov-

Speaker: NA
Text: erty now. That is where the blame lies. As was

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstrated last week during Question Time,

Speaker: NA
Text: hundreds of thousands of people are frustrated,

Speaker: NA
Text: distraught and angry. Who can blame them? They

Speaker: NA
Text: are the impoverished, the unemployed and the

Speaker: NA
Text: homeless. If they are a little luckier in this lucky

Speaker: NA
Text: country of ours, they are the impoverished, the

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployed and those who are paying more than

Speaker: NA
Text: half their meagre incomes on rent, often for

Speaker: NA
Text: substandard accommodation.

Speaker: NA
Text: We need more money for public housing. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have to erase the misery and poverty for our fel-

Speaker: NA
Text: low Australians. The honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Maranoa ( Mr Ian Cameron), who is trying to in-

Speaker: NA
Text: terject, wonders what he can do. I will tell him.

Speaker: NA
Text: This House has passed legislation to recoup tax

Speaker: NA
Text: from the bottom of the harbour tax avoiders, but

Speaker: NA
Text: its implementation is continually frustrated by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Liberal-National Party Opposition and some

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the Australian Democrats, including

Speaker: NA
Text: its leader, and Senator Harradine of Tasmania.

Speaker: NA
Text: Three bottom of the harbour Bills have been

Speaker: NA
Text: rejected by the Senate. Only last week it rejected

Speaker: NA
Text: the cherry-picker superannuation tax rort. What

Speaker: NA
Text: a sham! Those opposite have no reason to yell

Speaker: NA
Text: abuse at me with a record like that. If this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government were allowed to recoup that money,

Speaker: NA
Text: if the Senate would pass that legislation and if

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the Liberal-National Party Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition would support it by putting their money

Speaker: NA
Text: where their mouths are, fewer people would be

Speaker: NA
Text: living in misery and fear.

Speaker: NA
Text: H we all thought about it and put ourselves in

Speaker: NA
Text: the position of these people, many of us would be

Speaker: NA
Text: able to understand the anger of the unemployed,

Speaker: NA
Text: the homeless and those on the public housing

Speaker: NA
Text: waiting lists. Public housing is a public issue. Pub-

Speaker: NA
Text: lic spending on public housing must grow and we

Speaker: NA
Text: as a nation must together give a fair go to our fel-

Speaker: NA
Text: low Australians who tonight will sleep in the

Speaker: NA
Text: streets, in their cars, in tents, in caravans and in

Speaker: NA
Text: clothing bins. We have to give a fair go to those

Speaker: NA
Text: who now have to spend more than half their

Speaker: NA
Text: meagre incomes on very basic and insecure ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: commodation. We have to inject a massive in-

Speaker: NA
Text: crease of funds with a base level of at least $1.7

Speaker: NA
Text: billion to enable the Federal Government to begin

Speaker: NA
Text: to double the proportion of public housing within

Speaker: NA
Text: ten years. We have to bring back cost rents or

Speaker: NA
Text: non-profit rents instead of the regressive market

Speaker: NA
Text: rents introduced under the Fraser Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have to allow tenant control and participation

Speaker: NA
Text: in the management of public housing. We have to

Speaker: NA
Text: introduce new flexible housing programs under

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement

Speaker: NA
Text: which includes equal access to public housing for

Speaker: NA
Text: single people.

Speaker: NA
Text: We should be looking at the community hous-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing expansion program which would fund

Speaker: NA
Text: programs such as the rental housing co-

Speaker: NA
Text: operatives, which are so successful in many Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: States now, and local government housing

Speaker: NA
Text: programs. We have to accept rent rebates as an in-

Speaker: NA
Text: come security responsibility and provide carefully

Speaker: NA
Text: targetted home ownership assistance, ending the

Speaker: NA
Text: unfair subsidies to home owners and purchasers

Speaker: NA
Text: and ensuring equity for public and private

Speaker: NA
Text: tenants-the concept of tenure equality. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: to introduce an annual housing budget based on

Speaker: NA
Text: social needs and not just on economic conditions.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have to develop national housing policies in

Speaker: NA
Text: consultation with tenant and community housing

Speaker: NA
Text: groups. We have to bring in a Commonwealth-

Speaker: NA
Text: State Housing Agreement that will mean some-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing. I am sure that the Minister for Housing and

Speaker: NA
Text: Construction ( Mr Hurford) is doing this. Our

Speaker: NA
Text: work with him is showing that this will happen

Speaker: NA
Text: and that people are going to be protected.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are a wealthy country, and we are a lucky

Speaker: NA
Text: country. We must now invest much more money

Speaker: NA
Text: in public housing in this new Commonwealth-

Speaker: NA
Text: State Housing Agreement. The burden must be

Speaker: NA
Text: lifted from the poor. They have waited too long.

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Text: Gwydir) (9.10)-Before I deal

Speaker: NA
Text: with one of the issues of great concern to me, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's community employment program,

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to comment on the problem of unemploy-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment and the problems about which the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Diamond Valley ( Mr Staples)

Speaker: NA
Text: expressed concern. I think that every member of

Speaker: NA
Text: this House has a concern for those people who

Speaker: NA
Text: have had a great difficulty in obtaining proper ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: commodation. The former Government went a

Speaker: NA
Text: long way down the track with the resources at its

Speaker: NA
Text: disposal to try to overcome a very serious situ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation. I share the view of most members of this

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament that it is absolutely essential to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that people in this country have adequate hous-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing, and that includes the Aboriginal people who

Speaker: NA
Text: live out in the back blocks of my electorate. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginal people have a greater demand for

Speaker: NA
Text: proper housing, proper education and job oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunities than they do for anything else, including

Speaker: NA
Text: land rights, in my part of New South Wales. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: sure that most people would support a policy that

Speaker: NA
Text: was within the bounds of realism to ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: people receive adequate housing and facility.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the issues upon which I wish to concen-

Speaker: NA
Text: trate is a serious anomaly that has arisen in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's community employment program.

Speaker: NA
Text: That program is currently providing jobs for

Speaker: NA
Text: about 40,000 people. To that extent, it is a very

Speaker: NA
Text: beneficial program. On 1 August last year the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Employment and Industrial Re-

Speaker: NA
Text: lations, the Hon. Ralph Willis, announced details

Speaker: NA
Text: of this program, and the Prime Minister ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Hawke) was also party to its launching. Honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members may recall him doing so at a func-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion near Sydney not so long ago. I have a copy of

Speaker: NA
Text: the statement, taken from the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Record of I August to 7 August 1983, which,

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam Deputy Speaker, I now table. The Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter for Employment and Industrial relations said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Federal allocations under CEP will begin gradually

Speaker: NA
Text: during 1983-84 until the program becomes fully oper-

Speaker: NA
Text: ational in the latter half of the financial year. When it is

Speaker: NA
Text: fully operational, CEP is expected to create up to 70,000

Speaker: NA
Text: new job- nationally in a year on worthwhile community

Speaker: NA
Text: projects.

Speaker: NA
Text: That statement clearly shows that the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment expects the CEP to be fully operational in

Speaker: NA
Text: the latter half of the present financial year-in

Speaker: NA
Text: other words, around now-and that it should be

Speaker: NA
Text: creating 70,000 jobs at a cost of $300m in this

Speaker: NA
Text: financial year. But there seems to have been extra-

Speaker: NA
Text: ordinary change in estimations on the part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, almost overnight, on the CEP

Speaker: NA
Text: potential. On 29 September last year, the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: issued a progress statement on the CEP. Again, I

Speaker: NA
Text: have a copy, taken from the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Record of 3 October to 9 October 1983. I quote

Speaker: NA
Text: from it:

Speaker: NA
Text: The Federal Government is spending $300m on CEP

Speaker: NA
Text: during 1983-84 to create up to 40,000 jobs.

Speaker: NA
Text: What has happened to the remaining 30,000 jobs?

Speaker: NA
Text: That is the first question. The Minister also re-

Speaker: NA
Text: peated his 40,000 jobs estimate in the House only

Speaker: NA
Text: last week. During Question Time on 29 March,

Speaker: NA
Text: speaking about the CEP, he said that it was:

Speaker: NA
Text: . . . being successfully implemented and will, in

Speaker: NA
Text: the course of this year, assist 40,000 people to obtain

Speaker: NA
Text: employment.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have subsequently been advised that of the

Speaker: NA
Text: $300m allocated for 1983-84, a total of $260m has

Speaker: NA
Text: been approved so far for job creation projects,

Speaker: NA
Text: although not all of this has yet been taken up. In

Speaker: NA
Text: his answer in the Parliament on 29 March, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister told us that up until now there was a

Speaker: NA
Text: total of 33,661 jobs that had either been approved

Speaker: NA
Text: or were awaiting approval under the CEP. Is the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister therefore saying that it has cost $260m to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide fewer than half the original estimated

Speaker: NA
Text: 70,000 jobs that would have been created under

Speaker: NA
Text: the scheme? It seems an amazing change of cir-

Speaker: NA
Text: cumstance when we are initially told that the

Speaker: NA
Text: $300m will provide 70,000 jobs and then find out

Speaker: NA
Text: that in fact $260m provides only 33,600 jobs.

Speaker: NA
Text: Why has the Minister not explained any of this

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Parliament or to the Australian people? No

Speaker: NA
Text: doubt this is an issue to which an Estimates com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee could well devote itself. A very large slab

Speaker: NA
Text: of the taxpayer's money is involved here and we

Speaker: NA
Text: have a right to know why such huge anomalies

Speaker: NA
Text: have come to light. There is more than just a hint

Speaker: NA
Text: of maladminstration by the Government and of

Speaker: NA
Text: bureaucratic bungling. Has the Government had

Speaker: NA
Text: the wool pulled over its eyes as to just how many

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs could be created under the scheme for

Speaker: NA
Text: $300m? Is the truth of the matter the fact that to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide 70,000 jobs would cost a massive $600m

Speaker: NA
Text: under this scheme, which is double the original

Speaker: NA
Text: timate? Does the Government intend to pursue

Speaker: NA
Text: the original 70,000 jobs target which was

Speaker: NA
Text: promised by the Prime Minister, or has it realised

Speaker: NA
Text: that job creation schemes are too costly to be of

Speaker: NA
Text: lasting benefit? There are many serious questions

Speaker: NA
Text: about the whole administration and intent of the

Speaker: NA
Text: community employment program that this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government must answer, and it must answer

Speaker: NA
Text: them in detail to this Parliament and to the

Speaker: NA
Text: people.

Speaker: NA
Text: I turn to two issues of vital concern to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's international trade and our rural

Speaker: NA
Text: sector-our share of the Japanese beef trade, and

Speaker: NA
Text: recent problems with the importation of sheep-

Speaker: NA
Text: meat from New Zealand. The first of these issues

Speaker: NA
Text: has arisen due to what can only be described as

Speaker: NA
Text: negligence on the part of the Government. Just

Speaker: NA
Text: two months ago the Prime Minister, from Tokyo,

Speaker: NA
Text: reassured Australia's beef producers that their

Speaker: NA
Text: share of the Japanese market would not be disad-

Speaker: NA
Text: Vantaged by the bilateral talks between Japan and

Speaker: NA
Text: the United States. It is now becoming increasingly

Speaker: NA
Text: evident that the reassurance given by the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister will not be fulfilled. This was no more

Speaker: NA
Text: evident that in the media reports emanating this

Speaker: NA
Text: week from Tokyo which give credence to the

Speaker: NA
Text: growing suspicion that the Australian share of the

Speaker: NA
Text: increase in the Japanese market will, at best, be

Speaker: NA
Text: nominal. This week media reports indicate that

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian exporters will receive an allocation,

Speaker: NA
Text: most, of only an extra 1,800 tonnes in the 1984

Speaker: NA
Text: fiscal year, whilst the United States will be offered

Speaker: NA
Text: an additional allocation of 6,200 tonnes. This rep-

Speaker: NA
Text: resents an increase in the new allocation of 22.5

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent for Australian exporters, as against a 77.5

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent increase for the American exporters.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last week I sought an assurance from the Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister for Trade ( Mr Lionel Bowen) that every

Speaker: NA
Text: effort was being made to maintain our vital share

Speaker: NA
Text: of the beef market in Japan, but the House was

Speaker: NA
Text: treated to what can only be described as a non-

Speaker: NA
Text: answer. The Minister for Trade said that he

Speaker: NA
Text: thought that Australia might have difficulty in

Speaker: NA
Text: maintaining its market. His limp defeatist re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponse was a disgrace. The Prime Minister, today,

Speaker: NA
Text: did not do his Government any justice in trying to

Speaker: NA
Text: admonish me for having asked the question and

Speaker: NA
Text: trying to cast upon the Japanese Prime Minister a

Speaker: NA
Text: suggestion that I was doubting the honour of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Japanese Prime Minister. Nothing was further

Speaker: NA
Text: from the truth. I asked the Prime Minister to ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: plain why Mr Nakasone appeared to be breaking

Speaker: NA
Text: undertakings given to him. I can only go on the

Speaker: NA
Text: word that the Prime Minister had given to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Press conferences. That is why I thought that he

Speaker: NA
Text: should make a statement to this Parliament on the

Speaker: NA
Text: esextent to which undertakings were supposedly

Speaker: NA
Text: given to him in respect of the Australian share of

Speaker: NA
Text: the beef market. I assure honourable members

Speaker: NA
Text: that the industry is now deeply concerned, and, it

Speaker: NA
Text: would seem, with every justification. It is con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned that its share of the new Japanese allo-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation will be dwarfed by the share given to the

Speaker: NA
Text: United States of America.

Speaker: NA
Text: What makes the situation even more serious

Speaker: NA
Text: and disturbing is that we can only speculate about

Speaker: NA
Text: what happened in Tokyo. Why is it that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has failed to come clean on the

Speaker: NA
Text: issue? Why is it that a growing stream of reports

Speaker: NA
Text: emanating from Japan predict that Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: beef producers have been overlooked in the new

Speaker: NA
Text: year's allocations, yet we have heard nothing from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government to confirm or deny those rum-

Speaker: NA
Text: ours? I believe that the answer is simple: The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has bungled the beef negotiations. It

Speaker: NA
Text: has made a mess of our export trade to Japan, and

Speaker: NA
Text: it knows it. If this week's reports are borne out the

Speaker: NA
Text: beef industry will be dealt a serious blow on top of

Speaker: NA
Text: the reduction of the intake to Korea.

Speaker: NA
Text: The only indication we have had from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government that all is not well with our Japanese

Speaker: NA
Text: beef trade has been the belated decision to send

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Primary Industry ( Mr Kerin) to

Speaker: NA
Text: Japan on 10 April. That is nothing short of a joke.

Speaker: NA
Text: That will be two and a half months after the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister told us that he had an assurance

Speaker: NA
Text: at from Mr Nakasone that nothing would be done to

Speaker: NA
Text: disadvantage Australian beef producers and ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: porters. An announcement was made by officials

Speaker: NA
Text: in Japan that that was not a fact. I called upon

Speaker: NA
Text: either the Minister for Trade or the Prime Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter himself to go to Tokyo as a matter of urgency

Speaker: NA
Text: to clear up the apparent misunderstanding be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween the Prime Minister and Mr Nakasone.

Speaker: NA
Text: Today there seems little chance that we will main-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain our proportional share of our hard-won mar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ket in Japan. Clearly the Government has been

Speaker: NA
Text: out-manoeuvred, allowing events to drift along to

Speaker: NA
Text: the point where, virtually overnight, this bomb-

Speaker: NA
Text: shell has been dropped on the beef industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: What conclusion can the beef producers of this

Speaker: NA
Text: nation draw other than that the Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: bungled the beef trade with Japan? It has made an

Speaker: NA
Text: ass of itself at the expense of the cattle producers

Speaker: NA
Text: in a,great number of constituencies throughout

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia.

Speaker: Mr HODGMAN
Text: They have been sold out.

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Text: They have been sold out. If the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister were genuine in his concern for

Speaker: NA
Text: the industry he would have been on the first plane

Speaker: NA
Text: back to Tokyo as soon as he heard of the threats to

Speaker: NA
Text: our market share. The rural sector is now begin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ning to see this Government in its true light. It has

Speaker: NA
Text: no regard for the rural areas of Australia. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: busy trying to satisfy and trying to quieten some of

Speaker: NA
Text: the internal Left-Right fights within its own ranks

Speaker: NA
Text: to worry' about the cattle producers of this

Speaker: NA
Text: country.

Speaker: NA
Text: I turn to an issue in which the Government can

Speaker: NA
Text: still intervene before the worst of the damage is

Speaker: NA
Text: done. I refer to the concern of sheepmeat industry

Speaker: NA
Text: leaders that heavily subsidised imports of New

Speaker: NA
Text: Zealand mutton and lamb are contravening the

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of the closer economic relations agreement

Speaker: NA
Text: with New Zealand. The Government must be

Speaker: NA
Text: ready quickly to respond to any calls by the indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try for countervailing duties to be imposed in

Speaker: NA
Text: order to restore a market balance. In a statement

Speaker: NA
Text: last week the President of the Sheepmeat Council

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia, Mr Ralph James, noted that imports

Speaker: NA
Text: of subsidised New Zealand sheepmeat into

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia had grown by 1,500 per cent over the

Speaker: NA
Text: past three years. He said imports were set to quad-

Speaker: NA
Text: ruple since last year.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of particular concern has been the declining

Speaker: NA
Text: unit value of those imports, heightening fears that

Speaker: NA
Text: extensive New Zealand subsidies were supporting

Speaker: NA
Text: the country's sheepmeat exporters. In the year to

Speaker: NA
Text: September 1983 the New Zealand sheepmeat in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry in fact received $219m in support for lamb

Speaker: NA
Text: prices and a further $69m was provided for the

Speaker: NA
Text: mutton industry. Added to this would be related

Speaker: NA
Text: government aid to the New Zealand wool indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try. The concern of the industry in Australia has

Speaker: NA
Text: been growing for some months but it has now

Speaker: NA
Text: come to a head with the sale of imported lamb at

Speaker: NA
Text: prices as low as 43c a kilogram. There is simply no

Speaker: NA
Text: way that Australian lamb producers can compete

Speaker: NA
Text: against such heavily subsidised imported meat.

Speaker: NA
Text: There will be no winners in Australia if this situ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation is allowed to continue unchecked; there will

Speaker: NA
Text: only be losers.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the short term the New Zealand exporters

Speaker: NA
Text: will offload a large proportion of their current

Speaker: NA
Text: oversupply, which was estimated in one Auckland

Speaker: NA
Text: newspaper last week to stand currently at around

Speaker: NA
Text: 100,000 tonnes, or about three times the normal

Speaker: NA
Text: level. If our market prices were to be heavily

Speaker: NA
Text: undercut many hundreds of Australian sheep-

Speaker: NA
Text: meat producers would be forced to the wall. That,

Speaker: NA
Text: in turn, would force a contraction along the meat

Speaker: NA
Text: industry production chain, throwing many hun-

Speaker: NA
Text: dreds of people out of work and reducing the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duction capacity of our industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: I might say that already the abattoirs of this

Speaker: NA
Text: country are in serious difficulty. We have already

Speaker: NA
Text: had enormous unemployment problems in many

Speaker: NA
Text: of our regional centres as a result of the difficulty

Speaker: NA
Text: they have been experiencing. If that situation is al-

Speaker: NA
Text: too lowed to continue we will see mOJ:e abattoirs clos-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing down and further unemployment in an indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try that is very important to this country. If the

Speaker: NA
Text: cheap, subsidised meat supply were then to dry

Speaker: NA
Text: up-this is the other consideration that con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumers ought to bear in mind-the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: market would be left with a severe undercapacity

Speaker: NA
Text: to meet demand, with the inevitable result of in-

Speaker: NA
Text: flated prices to the consumer.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe that the industry has every reason now

Speaker: NA
Text: to approach the Federal Government seeking the

Speaker: NA
Text: imposition of countervailing duties in order to bal-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance the effect of the heavy New Zealand sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: sidies. If the industry were to do so, and I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: such an approach may be forthcoming in the next

Speaker: NA
Text: few days, it will be up to the Government-I hope

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Minister for Trade and the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Primary Industry will co-operate-to respond as a

Speaker: NA
Text: matter of urgency to protect the Australian indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try and, in the longer term, the Australian con-

Speaker: NA
Text: suming public.

Speaker: Mr LINDSAY
Text: Herbert) (9.26)-

Speaker: NA
Text: Appropriation Bill (No.3) 1983-84, Appropri-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation Bill (No.4) 1983-84 and the Appropriation

Speaker: NA
Text: (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No.2)

Speaker: NA
Text: 1983-84 seek additional appropriation to meet

Speaker: NA
Text: commitments that have been approved by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government since last year's Federal Budget and

Speaker: NA
Text: to meet requirements which the Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: considered appropriate to achieve this financial

Speaker: NA
Text: year. Division 592 of Appropriation Bill (No.3)

Speaker: NA
Text: 1983-84 provides for an additional appropriation

Speaker: NA
Text: of $2m for the year 1983-84 for the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Tourist Commission. The Australian Tourist

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission is Australia's national tourist office

Speaker: NA
Text: and is responsible for tourist promotion. It was es-

Speaker: NA
Text: tablished in 1967 with the aim of encouraging

Speaker: NA
Text: travel to and within Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian Tourist Commission seeks to

Speaker: NA
Text: maximise for Australia the financial benefits of in-

Speaker: NA
Text: ternational tourism. It seeks to develop and main-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain working relationships with appropriate Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian companies and bodies so as to maximise

Speaker: NA
Text: the return for Australia of both public and private

Speaker: NA
Text: sector spending on developing international tour-

Speaker: NA
Text: ism. The 1983-84 Federal Budget provided an in-

Speaker: NA
Text: crease of 75 per cent; that is, an increase of $7

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Australian Tourist Commission.

Speaker: NA
Text: New procedures have been initiated not only to

Speaker: NA
Text: promote domestic tourism but also to increase

Speaker: NA
Text: dramatically overseas promotion of tourism to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. Accordingly, the Australian Tourist

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission has launched a major campaign to

Speaker: NA
Text: attract American tourists to Australia. The cam-

Speaker: NA
Text: paign is taking the form of short television ader-

Speaker: NA
Text: vertisements and other campaign material. It fea-

Speaker: NA
Text: tures the famous Australian comedian, Paul

Speaker: NA
Text: Hogan. The advertisements in the United States

Speaker: NA
Text: of America have so far been aimed at audiences in

Speaker: NA
Text: Los Angeles, San Francisco, and San Diego. How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, market penetration of the advertisements

Speaker: NA
Text: has also been extensive in the east coast of the

Speaker: NA
Text: United States. The flood of inquiries in the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States seeking further information on Australia as

Speaker: NA
Text: a tourist destination are a direct response to this

Speaker: NA
Text: excellent media campaign. The campaign will be

Speaker: NA
Text: further promoted in the United States next finan-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial year and it will be a most effective boost to

Speaker: NA
Text: ongoing and extensive promotional and market-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing activity being undertaken by the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Tourist Commission and the Australian travel

Speaker: NA
Text: industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last week the Australian Government, through

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Tourist Commission, embarked on

Speaker: NA
Text: a major advertising campaign, again featuring

Speaker: NA
Text: Paul Hogan, to promote this initiative. This

Speaker: NA
Text: program is aimed at encouraging Australians to

Speaker: NA
Text: take their vacations in Australia. In addition, a

Speaker: NA
Text: motivational booklet will appear in the April issue

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Australian Women's Weekly magazine.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some two million copies of this booklet have been

Speaker: NA
Text: printed and these will be available in airline

Speaker: NA
Text: offices and from travel agencies throughout

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: If the domestic tourist market could be

Speaker: NA
Text: expanded by a mere 5 per cent as a result of the

Speaker: NA
Text: launching of this program, some $600m more

Speaker: NA
Text: would be injected into the Australian economy

Speaker: NA
Text: and some 20,000 extra jobs could be created. The

Speaker: NA
Text: domestic campaign has been applauded by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian tourist industry. The Australian Tour-

Speaker: NA
Text: ist Commission has received $1.6m from private

Speaker: NA
Text: contributions to promote the domestic campaign.

Speaker: NA
Text: Major contributors include General Motors-

Speaker: NA
Text: Holden Ltd, Trans Australia Airlines and Ansett

Speaker: NA
Text: Airlines of Australia, to name just a few. Contri-

Speaker: NA
Text: butions are still being received.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tourism can provide thousands of jobs for the

Speaker: NA
Text: semi-skilled or unskilled men and women and

Speaker: NA
Text: young people throughout Australia. The industry

Speaker: NA
Text: can be easily decentralised and is suitable for the

Speaker: NA
Text: .5m, economic rejuvination of naturally attractive

Speaker: NA
Text: areas which have suffered economic decline. The

Speaker: NA
Text: number of jobs currently attributable to tourism

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia is about 375,000. Recent surveys by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Bureau of Industry Economics estimate that

Speaker: NA
Text: tourism contributes around $12 billion annually

Speaker: NA
Text: or between 5 per cent and 6 per cent of gross dom-

Speaker: NA
Text: estic product. As an industry, it is of the same

Speaker: NA
Text: rank as the mining and motor car manufacturing

Speaker: NA
Text: industries. The results from the Bureau of Indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try Economics study suggest that Australians aged

Speaker: NA
Text: 14 years or more took more than 52.6 million trips

Speaker: NA
Text: of one night or more away from home in the 12

Speaker: NA
Text: months to September 1982 spending an average of

Speaker: NA
Text: between $150 and $160 per trip. Since the average

Speaker: NA
Text: trip length was just over four days, this amounted

Speaker: NA
Text: to an average of $35 to $40 per person per day.

Speaker: NA
Text: Preliminary estimates of foreign exchange earn-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings from tourism are $1,21Im in 1983, an in-

Speaker: NA
Text: crease of 12.4 per cent over 1982.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tour-

Speaker: NA
Text: ism ( Mr John Brown) has led the recovery of the

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian international and domestic tourism in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry. He correctly identified high fares and lack

Speaker: NA
Text: of promotion as curbing travel by international

Speaker: NA
Text: visitors and Australians within Australia. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister has developed a program which will cre-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate 100,000 new jobs in the tourist industry by

Speaker: NA
Text: 1988. This program is designed to refurbish, res-

Speaker: NA
Text: tructure and establish the tourist industry as a

Speaker: NA
Text: major, robust and expanding growth area of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Hawke Government, an authentic Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian government, has set about creating new

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs. The Government has decided that tourism is

Speaker: NA
Text: one of the best prospects for creating new jobs. To

Speaker: NA
Text: that end a special grant of approximately $Im

Speaker: NA
Text: was made in the \983-84 Federal Budget to subsi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dise diesel fuel costs to Great Barrier Reef tourist

Speaker: NA
Text: resorts. The Hawke Government has also rein-

Speaker: NA
Text: stated the exemption from sales tax for certain

Speaker: NA
Text: tourist boats. This exemption was backdated to 19

Speaker: NA
Text: August 1981, the date that the Fraser Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment put a tax on the building of tourist boats

Speaker: NA
Text: within Australia. This was also the date that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Fraser Government imposed a 6c a litre tax on the

Speaker: NA
Text: use of diesel fuel in the tourist industry. This was a

Speaker: NA
Text: major blow to the operational costs of the Great

Speaker: NA
Text: Barrier Reef island tourist resorts. A special grant

Speaker: NA
Text: of approximately $1 m to subsidise the diesel fuel

Speaker: NA
Text: costs to Great Barrier Reef island tourist resorts

Speaker: NA
Text: will allow the development of major new facilities

Speaker: NA
Text: on Barrier Reef islands.

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition, the Hawke Government provided

Speaker: NA
Text: over $490,000 in last year's Budget to assist the

Speaker: NA
Text: operation of the tourist industry training

Speaker: NA
Text: commitees-an increase of around $120,000 over

Speaker: NA
Text: the last year of the Fraser Government. Work is

Speaker: NA
Text: well under way on a Hawke Government

Speaker: NA
Text: program-the Townsville School of Catering and

Speaker: NA
Text: Hospitality-for which $1.138m has been appro-

Speaker: NA
Text: priated under the States grants legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: More than 80 per cent of visitors to northern

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland travel on the Bruce Highway. In rec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ognition of the importance of providing a highway

Speaker: NA
Text: to enable tourists to travel in relative safety and

Speaker: NA
Text: comfort, the Hawke Government has allocated

Speaker: NA
Text: more than $15m for the development of road

Speaker: NA
Text: works in the Herbert electorate during the last

Speaker: NA
Text: year. Tourist attractions within the Herbert elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: torate are a major tourist destination for domestic

Speaker: NA
Text: and international visitors. Direct weekly flights by

Speaker: NA
Text: Qantas Airways Ltd from New Zealand, South

Speaker: NA
Text: East Asia and Europe to Townsville have estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: lished Townsville as a major tourist growth area

Speaker: NA
Text: of northern Australia. South East Asia is one of

Speaker: NA
Text: our fastest growing markets. Last week Sir Leslie

Speaker: NA
Text: Thiess announced the $45m casino project to be

Speaker: NA
Text: built at Townsville. The Sheraton Hotel group

Speaker: NA
Text: will be a partner in this spectacular development.

Speaker: NA
Text: Work is expected to commence within the next

Speaker: NA
Text: few months.

Speaker: NA
Text: Plans by Air Pacific to commence a weekly ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vice from Fiji to Townsville in November this

Speaker: NA
Text: year will provide Japanese visitors with easy

Speaker: NA
Text: access to Townsville to enjoy not only the Great

Speaker: NA
Text: Barrier Reef and the many tourist facilities in my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate but also to gain first hand acquaint-

Speaker: NA
Text: anceship with koala bears which live in great

Speaker: NA
Text: numbers on Magnetic Island. I have had lengthy

Speaker: NA
Text: discussions with Japanese officials both in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia and Japan to encourage Japanese tour-

Speaker: NA
Text: ists to enter Australia through Townsville as part

Speaker: NA
Text: of a packaged tourism circuit of Australia. Fur-

Speaker: NA
Text: thermore, the State Government has nominated

Speaker: NA
Text: the Townsville Barrier Reef world project as a bi-

Speaker: NA
Text: centennial commemorative project. Reef World is

Speaker: NA
Text: a unique maritime museum which will enable visi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tors to walk along transparent tunnels and view

Speaker: NA
Text: living coral and other reef life. This breathtaking

Speaker: NA
Text: project will be administered by the Great Barrier

Speaker: NA
Text: Reef Marine Park Authority.

Speaker: NA
Text: The establishment of a tourism development

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance program will provide substantial

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits to the tourist industry. Last year the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government concluded an agreement with the

Speaker: NA
Text: MCDonnell Douglas Corporation of the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States of America for offsets related to Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: purchase of the FA18A tactical fighter. Under

Speaker: NA
Text: this agreement the MCDonnell Douglas Corpor-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation will promote tourism to and within

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. It will provide appropriate promo-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional support and marketing assistance to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government and it will undertake mutually

Speaker: NA
Text: agreed research surveys both in Australia and

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Hawke Government accepts the challenge

Speaker: NA
Text: of organising the tourist industry, fragmented by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Fraser Government, into a cohesive and more

Speaker: NA
Text: professional entity. The challenge is to bring all

Speaker: NA
Text: the competing forces within the industry to a

Speaker: NA
Text: single point of view, that is, the creation of jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: for Australians. For these many initiatives the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism de-

Speaker: NA
Text: serves the highest commendation and the thanks

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Australian people. For the Australian in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry it represents the beginning of a vibrant and

Speaker: NA
Text: permanent future.

Speaker: NA
Text: I now turn to Division 334 of Appropriation

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill (No.3) 1983-84. The Australian War Mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: orial's current approved average staffing level is

Speaker: NA
Text: 159 full time and 25 part time personnel. In esti-

Speaker: NA
Text: mating the expenditure required to meet the

Speaker: NA
Text: salaries of these staff, the following unforeseeable

Speaker: NA
Text: factors were not provided for: First, an unusually

Speaker: NA
Text: high expenditure related to cessation payments,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly one Second Division officer who was

Speaker: NA
Text: voluntarily retrenched requiring the expenditure

Speaker: NA
Text: of an additional $160,000; secondly, the 4.3 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent national wage increase at a cost of $110,000;

Speaker: NA
Text: and thirdly, the need to employ short term staff to

Speaker: NA
Text: assist with the movement of large numbers of col-

Speaker: NA
Text: lection items and equipment at short notice in as-

Speaker: NA
Text: sociation with the building renovation program at

Speaker: NA
Text: an additional cost of $30,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: Given the Memorial's very poor staffing pos-

Speaker: NA
Text: ition in comparison to other similar institutions-

Speaker: NA
Text: for example, the Australian National Gallery has

Speaker: NA
Text: approximately 100 more staff and fewer

Speaker: NA
Text: functions-and the increased visitor numbers

Speaker: NA
Text: which were three-q uarters of a million in 1980

Speaker: NA
Text: and 1.3 million in 1983, to a major tourist desti-

Speaker: NA
Text: nation in Australia, it is impossible for the Mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: orial to absorb any of the unforeseen expenditure.

Speaker: NA
Text: All staff are already heavily burdened and

Speaker: NA
Text: programs are operating at levels which could not

Speaker: NA
Text: be cut further. Programs concerned with the

Speaker: NA
Text: documentation, conservation and curatorship of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Memorial's collection need to be significantly

Speaker: NA
Text: upgraded in accordance with criticisms levelled

Speaker: NA
Text: by a Joint Committee of Public Accounts inquiry

Speaker: NA
Text: and an addition of 42 to the Memorial's average

Speaker: NA
Text: staffing level for 1984-85 has been sought. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Memorial is an institution of importance to all

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians, and the interest in it and respect for

Speaker: NA
Text: what it commemorates grows every year. Its exist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence must be supported by the provision of ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: equate funds to maintain existing staffing and

Speaker: NA
Text: allow necessary growth.

Speaker: NA
Text: Finally, I turn to Division 865 of Appropriation

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill (No.4) 1983-84. The Minister for Finance

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Dawkins) stated in his second reading

Speaker: NA
Text: speech:

Speaker: NA
Text: Almost half of the additional appropriations sought

Speaker: NA
Text: for natural disaster relief and restoration.

Speaker: NA
Text: During January and February this year floods

Speaker: NA
Text: extensively damaged the Flinders Highway and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Great Northern Railway between Hughenden

Speaker: NA
Text: and Cloncurry. Damage is estimated at in excess

Speaker: NA
Text: of $8m. Both the highway and the railroad are the

Speaker: NA
Text: lifelines of the remote communities in far western

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland. The great city of Mount Isa depends

Speaker: NA
Text: almost entirely on the highway and railroad for its

Speaker: NA
Text: sustenance and for the shipment of its vast min-

Speaker: NA
Text: eraI production to Townsville. I am confident that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Federal Government will provide whatever

Speaker: NA
Text: money is required to ensure that the costs of rec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tification are met. These Bills are further written

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence of the accomplishments of the Hawke

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Government in carrying out its pledge

Speaker: NA
Text: to pursue national reconciliation, national recov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ery and national reconstruction.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: O'Connor) (9.42)-ln this

Speaker: NA
Text: wide-ranging debate I, like the Deputy Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition, the honourable member for Ben-

Speaker: NA
Text: nelong ( Mr Howard), look at the performance

Speaker: NA
Text: and activity and credibility of the Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Today I asked a question of the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Hawke) relating to his care of sensitive

Speaker: NA
Text: documents.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Robert Brown-A terrible question.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: I am pleased that the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member says it is a terrible question. He

Speaker: NA
Text: might be the person who will explain to me why it

Speaker: NA
Text: is a terrible question. The basis of the question

Speaker: NA
Text: was whether or not the Prime Minister had been

Speaker: NA
Text: careful with certain sensitive documents he left in

Speaker: NA
Text: a hotel room and whether he had suffered a simi-

Speaker: NA
Text: lar degree of carelessness-this has now been

Speaker: NA
Text: confirmed-in the loss of some $5,000 or more. In

Speaker: NA
Text: fact, it could have been as high as $5,600. My

Speaker: NA
Text: advice is that the money was in Australian cur-

Speaker: NA
Text: rency, and some $1,000 in American currency,

Speaker: NA
Text: and an undetermined amount in travellers

Speaker: NA
Text: cheques. It was not only an undetermined

Speaker: NA
Text: amount, but it was also not known from which

Speaker: NA
Text: bank they came.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nevertheless, the Prime Minister got extremely

Speaker: NA
Text: angry at this question. I note that he attacked the

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: ably for being party to this question. My question

Speaker: NA
Text: to the House and to the honourable member who

Speaker: NA
Text: interjected a moment ago is this: Why did the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister get so angry? I think he is man

Speaker: NA
Text: enough to take the criticism that he might have

Speaker: NA
Text: been careless. He said he was not, we have to pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sume it was not that. I think he has added up the

Speaker: NA
Text: pluses of his trip to that champagne function at

Speaker: NA
Text: the Royal Perth Yacht Club. That did not make

Speaker: NA
Text: is him angry. What did make him angry? Was it my

Speaker: NA
Text: example of another time when he had a loss? I am

Speaker: NA
Text: sure most honourable members on some occasions

Speaker: NA
Text: have lost money in one circumstance or another.

Speaker: NA
Text: Why then did the Prime Minister, on his own ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission, say that this was a very low trick? Quite

Speaker: NA
Text: clearly, there was something wrong with that

Speaker: NA
Text: money.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Robert Brown-No.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: Well, if there was not, why did

Speaker: NA
Text: he get so unhappy? I do not know that.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Robert Brown-We have all carried travel-

Speaker: NA
Text: lers cheques.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: Oh yes, and $1,000 worth of

Speaker: NA
Text: American currency. I am not saying there was

Speaker: NA
Text: anything wrong with the Prime Minister having

Speaker: NA
Text: $5,000 or $6,000 cash in his room. I am asking

Speaker: NA
Text: why he. got so upset about it. Why did he believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that there was something wrong in my giving that

Speaker: NA
Text: example, unless guilt rests very squarely on his

Speaker: NA
Text: shoulders? Let us get that out of the way first. I

Speaker: NA
Text: was interested in national security when I asked

Speaker: NA
Text: the question and I must now be concerned with

Speaker: NA
Text: the propriety of the Prime Minister and what he

Speaker: NA
Text: has done. I saw no reason whatsoever for him to

Speaker: NA
Text: get so angry. Let us get away from that point-I

Speaker: NA
Text: simply used the opportunity to make that point-

Speaker: NA
Text: and look at what is happening in other parts of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. The Government has gone out to

Speaker: NA
Text: woo big business, and in the forefront it has the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Finance ( Mr Dawkins). I thought we

Speaker: NA
Text: might have a look at the rhetoric and the reality of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Finance. I have had a look at his

Speaker: NA
Text: maiden speech which he made in 1974, and I am

Speaker: NA
Text: sure big business would be thrilled to read some of

Speaker: NA
Text: the things he said. He stated:

Speaker: NA
Text: . . . Australia's capitalist system has faltered because

Speaker: NA
Text: capitalism by its nature is ill-fitted to respond to the

Speaker: NA
Text: mands of a just and equitable society. This is because the

Speaker: NA
Text: . modern capitalist system is not only hopelessly

Speaker: NA
Text: ramshackled . . .

Speaker: NA
Text: The capitalist theory is founded on an unquestioning

Speaker: NA
Text: faith in the market . . .

Speaker: NA
Text: That is a good message for the people he tells that

Speaker: NA
Text: this Government is in favour of big business. I

Speaker: NA
Text: thought we might give the housing sector a bit of

Speaker: NA
Text: encouragement by reading what the Minister said

Speaker: NA
Text: . in that speech. He stated:

Speaker: NA
Text: This has meant that most of the rental

Speaker: NA
Text: is privately owned by people intent on making a profit.

Speaker: NA
Text: Shame! He continued:

Speaker: NA
Text: The high rents that inevitably resulted only served to

Speaker: NA
Text: make the purchase of a house on a mortgage basis rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tively more attractive.

Speaker: NA
Text: This process was spurred

Speaker: NA
Text: advertising agencies which brainwashed the community

Speaker: NA
Text: into believing that owning one's own home was not only

Speaker: NA
Text: cheaper but indeed was the only Australian thing to do.

Speaker: NA
Text: Further on he stated:

Speaker: NA
Text: The once proud homebuyer realises he has been

Speaker: NA
Text: hooked. He realises that behind the rosy propaganda is the

Speaker: NA
Text: lie.

Speaker: NA
Text: I guess that might have something to do with what

Speaker: NA
Text: we hear from the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Adelaide ( Mr Hurford) and the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Stirling ( Mr Ronald Edwards) about

Speaker: NA
Text: the great success of the $7,000 scheme. Clearly,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Finance thinks that people are

Speaker: NA
Text: being hooked. Going back to his maiden speech,

Speaker: NA
Text: he said:

Speaker: NA
Text: He realises that behind the rosy propaganda is the lie.

Speaker: NA
Text: He finds he is committed probably for the greater portion

Speaker: NA
Text: of his working life to something he does not really need to

Speaker: NA
Text: own and probably cannot afford. The promise that capi-

Speaker: NA
Text: talism in this country makes in regard to private owner-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship is indeed an illusion.

Speaker: NA
Text: How do we tie that in with some of the rhetoric?

Speaker: NA
Text: That is the reality. That is getting inside the rather

Speaker: NA
Text: competent brain of the Minister, who has been

Speaker: NA
Text: able to dream up more tax avoidance schemes

Speaker: NA
Text: than most other people in this Parliament. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: what he says inside. Recently he made an

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia Day speech, and it is funny that once he

Speaker: NA
Text: got outside the Parliament he had a few things to

Speaker: NA
Text: say of a similar nature. In that speech he said on

Speaker: NA
Text: 26 January, 1984:

Speaker: NA
Text: We have lived through a period when the political de-

Speaker: NA
Text: bate has been dominated by economists who have

Speaker: NA
Text: debauched their profession by claiming too much.

Speaker: NA
Text: Monetarism has failed and increasingly we are seeing both

Speaker: NA
Text: in Austalia and elsewhere a return to interventionist poli-

Speaker: NA
Text: decies of reflation which have their origins in Keynesian

Speaker: NA
Text: theory.

Speaker: NA
Text: More importantly, he stated:

Speaker: NA
Text: Great public commercial organisations have in the last

Speaker: NA
Text: few years been vandalised as a side effect of the monetarist

Speaker: NA
Text: experiment.

Speaker: NA
Text: He is talking about the bureaucracy here. He

Speaker: NA
Text: continued:

Speaker: NA
Text: We intend to reverse that trend. Shortly we will an-

Speaker: NA
Text: nounce a renewed commitment to the role of public sector

Speaker: NA
Text: activities and a new approach to ensure their efficient op-

Speaker: NA
Text: housing available eration within guidelines . . .

Speaker: NA
Text: Those are a few questions to confront. Since then

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister has made an address to the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Press Club and answered a few questions. Peter

Speaker: NA
Text: Harvey from the Nine Network said: 'Minister, to

Speaker: NA
Text: paraphrase somebody some time ago, where is the

Speaker: NA
Text: on by speculative builders and

Speaker: NA
Text: money? In particular, where is the $3 billion the

Speaker: NA
Text: Auditor-General referred to in the second part of

Speaker: NA
Text: the question?' The Minister has a lot to say about

Speaker: NA
Text: what that is all about. He said: 'Only yesterday we

Speaker: NA
Text: saw a repeat of the gutlessness by the Senate when

Speaker: NA
Text: they rejected another piece of legislation designed

Speaker: NA
Text: to retrospectively crack down on a scheme'. He

Speaker: NA
Text: went on: 'We increased substantially the resources

Speaker: NA
Text: available to the Tax Commissioner. He did a re-

Speaker: NA
Text: view of his top structure to better fortify himself

Speaker: NA
Text: in his war with the tax avoidance industry'.

Speaker: NA
Text: He went on to talk about the continuing im-

Speaker: NA
Text: morality of tax avoiders. Finally he said that

Speaker: NA
Text: people should pay what they ought to pay. If

Speaker: NA
Text: everybody was paying what they ought to be pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing, presumably tax levels would be lower than

Speaker: NA
Text: they are today. Of course, we heard Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: Walsh talk about greedy tax cheats. The honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Diamond Valley ( Mr Staples)

Speaker: NA
Text: just gave us a tearful effort on the lack of public

Speaker: NA
Text: housing because people cheat on their tax. It was

Speaker: NA
Text: 5 October 1983 when I came into this Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: and drew the Government's attention to a tax

Speaker: NA
Text: evasion scheme and massive evidence of tax

Speaker: NA
Text: avoidance contributed to by the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Finance. What has the Government done about it

Speaker: NA
Text: at this stage? It has done absolutely nothing. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister is still embraced by the Government. For

Speaker: NA
Text: any honourable member who interjects I mention

Speaker: NA
Text: that I am happy to look at the vote. I brought in

Speaker: NA
Text: the record showing all of those honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members who supported the Minister and denied

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition's condemnation of him. There are

Speaker: NA
Text: some interesting names on that record. Of course,

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Diamond Valley who

Speaker: NA
Text: complained about what tax avoidance and tax

Speaker: NA
Text: evasion was doing to the industry voted too. He is

Speaker: NA
Text: guilty by association.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr HollisDo not try to threaten us.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: I am not threatening those op-

Speaker: NA
Text: posite. I am just making it quite clear that not

Speaker: NA
Text: Government member can be classified as anything

Speaker: NA
Text: but a tax cheat because they came in here and

Speaker: NA
Text: backed up a tax cheat. That is the difference be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween the rhetoric of the Labor Government and

Speaker: NA
Text: the reality of the Labor Government. Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment members embraced the Minister and stuck

Speaker: NA
Text: by him. All honourable members on the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment side who are on that list are guilty. But do

Speaker: NA
Text: not take too much notice of that. Let us look at

Speaker: NA
Text: what I am talking about. Recently I got hold of

Speaker: NA
Text: the probate figures relative to this matter. What

Speaker: NA
Text: did I find? I found that the estate could have been

Speaker: NA
Text: valued as high as $2,153,130. I found-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Maher- Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a

Speaker: NA
Text: point of order.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr MilIar)-

Speaker: NA
Text: Order! Before the honourable member for O'Con-

Speaker: NA
Text: nor proceeds I alert him to the fact that in the

Speaker: NA
Text: judgment of the Chair he is sailing rather close to

Speaker: NA
Text: the wind in respect of the standing order which

Speaker: NA
Text: precludes reflection on any honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: of the House. I will hear the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: further but I ask him to be very mindful of what I

Speaker: NA
Text: have said.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: Mr Deputy Speaker, I will. I

Speaker: NA
Text: was referring to matters already raised in the

Speaker: NA
Text: House by myself.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Maher- Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a

Speaker: NA
Text: point of order.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Order! I ask the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for O'Connor to resume his

Speaker: NA
Text: seat. I call the honourable member for Lowe on a

Speaker: NA
Text: point of order.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Maher- Mr Deputy Speaker, my point of

Speaker: NA
Text: order actually refers to another standing order. I

Speaker: NA
Text: refer to standing order 71 under which no member

Speaker: NA
Text: may allude to any debate or proceedings of the

Speaker: NA
Text: same session unless such an allusion be relevant to

Speaker: NA
Text: the matter under discussion. I submit to you that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Appropriation Bill is not an appropriate

Speaker: NA
Text: occasion on which to run all these matters which

Speaker: NA
Text: have been debated at great length for days during

Speaker: NA
Text: this session.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Order! The

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member will resume his seat. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Chair is not of a mind to rule that at this juncture

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a point of order. I call the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for O'Connor.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: Thank you, Mr Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker. All I was able to do was calculate in re-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation to this matter that on an estate of that size

Speaker: NA
Text: the probate would have been $988,831. I leave the

Speaker: NA
Text: matter at that. As far as the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: one for Diamond Valley is concerned, that would be a

Speaker: NA
Text: lot of houses.

Speaker: NA
Text: While we are on the subject of tax avoidance

Speaker: NA
Text: and tax evasion I thought I would bring up a new

Speaker: NA
Text: matter related to the tax avoidance industry

Speaker: NA
Text: which I have labelled the bottom of the sandpit

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme. This is a scheme whereby certain contrac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tors go along to the owners of sandy properties in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Perth metropolitan area and maybe in other

Speaker: NA
Text: States as well. Instead of saying to those people:

Speaker: NA
Text: 'You have a nice looking sandhill there which has

Speaker: NA
Text: value to me because I will cart it away and sell it

Speaker: NA
Text: to somebody else and I will pay you a royalty'-

Speaker: NA
Text: which of course would be taxable in the hands of

Speaker: NA
Text: the recipient-they say instead: 'No, we will offer

Speaker: NA
Text: to buy that sandhill off you for a capital purchase.

Speaker: NA
Text: But as we are not going to carry the sand away on

Speaker: NA
Text: the day of purchase we want a terms deal on it.

Speaker: NA
Text: What about we buy it over the period during

Speaker: NA
Text: which we will take it away, maybe two years or

Speaker: NA
Text: maybe three years?' The purchaser says: 'Fine, I

Speaker: NA
Text: will do that'. That scheme is all very attractive be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause in fact no tax is then charged.

Speaker: NA
Text: The most interesting thing about the bottom of

Speaker: NA
Text: the sandpit scheme is that some people might end

Speaker: NA
Text: up with a hole on their property. Those people

Speaker: NA
Text: write to the Commissioner of Taxation and say:

Speaker: NA
Text: 'After all, I have had diminution of my capital

Speaker: NA
Text: asset. My land is no longer as valuable. They have

Speaker: NA
Text: taken something away'. If there is a hole left on

Speaker: NA
Text: the property the facts of life are that the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: missioner would probably be quite right in agree-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing. Of course, it was originally a sandhill it just

Speaker: NA
Text: might be that the owner of the property ends up

Speaker: NA
Text: with a nice level block which he is planning to

Speaker: NA
Text: subdivide anyway. Of course, that nice level block

Speaker: NA
Text: has improved in value. The owner does not pay

Speaker: NA
Text: tax on what he gets for the sand taken away. Of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, when the owner subdivides and sells that

Speaker: NA
Text: land-if he has held it for any period and runs a

Speaker: NA
Text: few sheep and cattle on it-he will not pay any

Speaker: NA
Text: tax on that either.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr MACKellar-Who did that?

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: Is it not remarkable who has

Speaker: NA
Text: been involved in the bottom of the sandpit scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: in Perth? I wonder whether any honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member would like to take three guesses? I would

Speaker: NA
Text: start with the Minister for Finance if I were the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member. This gentleman has not even

Speaker: NA
Text: learnt his lesson. He is still not prepared to act on

Speaker: NA
Text: some of his own rhetoric. He is not prepared to

Speaker: NA
Text: come out and do what he expects other people to

Speaker: NA
Text: do. It is a disgrace. It reflects on the Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is what I am here to speak about. I am here

Speaker: NA
Text: to speak about the rhetoric and the reality. We

Speaker: NA
Text: could go on time after time. Mr Deputy Speaker, I

Speaker: NA
Text: ask your guidance. Are we limited in this debate

Speaker: NA
Text: to IS minutes or has it just been by accident that

Speaker: NA
Text: some honourable members have stopped at 15

Speaker: NA
Text: minutes?

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: The provisions of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Standing Orders enable the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member to speak in accordance with the time

Speaker: NA
Text: indicated on the clock.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: I thank the Chair but I under-

Speaker: NA
Text: stand that there is some special arrangement. I do

Speaker: NA
Text: not wish to break the arrangement and interfere

Speaker: NA
Text: with other members. However, as I was inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: rupted for a moment or two by a point of order, I

Speaker: NA
Text: repeat that it has happened time and again. Other

Speaker: NA
Text: members have stood up here today and said that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government is not dinkum. Honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members have said that the Government does not

Speaker: NA
Text: do what it says. More importantly, members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the backbench are prepared to embrace people

Speaker: NA
Text: who break the basic concepts that this Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment professes to stand for and they ought to be

Speaker: NA
Text: considered as bad as anyone else.

Speaker: Mr BALDWIN
Text: Sydney) (9.58)-As I under-

Speaker: NA
Text: stand it, the debates on the Appropriation Bills,

Speaker: NA
Text: even minor ones, provide an opportunity to can-

Speaker: NA
Text: vass a very broad range of subjects. Consequently,

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to make a number of remarks about what is

Speaker: NA
Text: set out in the so-called 'Strategic Basis of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Defence Policy 1983' which, I am sure all

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable members would be aware, has been

Speaker: NA
Text: well and truly eschewed by the Government,

Speaker: NA
Text: insofar as policy prescriptions are concerned, par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticularly in regard to the suggestion that Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: needs to be in a position to match the potential

Speaker: NA
Text: nuclear capability of other powers within the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: gion. Honourable members presumably would re-

Speaker: NA
Text: call my question to the Minister for Foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs ( Mr Hayden) yesterday when I referred to

Speaker: NA
Text: the specific matter of the claim made in the docu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment that the Soviet Union had in fact achieved

Speaker: NA
Text: strategic nuclear superiority over the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States. I will quote from the relevant section of

Speaker: NA
Text: the strategic basis paper as it appears in the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Times. It asserts:

Speaker: NA
Text: Initially greatly inferior in nuclear armament, the

Speaker: NA
Text: USSR, by its own sustained efforts and aided by the rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive US neglect of US nuclear forces, has achieved

Speaker: NA
Text: ority in the critical area of ICBMs and intermediate nu-

Speaker: NA
Text: clear forces which is not fully compensated by US

Speaker: NA
Text: maritime and air forces.

Speaker: NA
Text: I argue that that sort of proposition is the basis of

Speaker: NA
Text: a regeneration of the Cold War mentality. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: something that all honourable members of this

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament ought to resist strongly. I also reiterate

Speaker: NA
Text: that it is not the Government's view that that is

Speaker: NA
Text: the case-at least as reflected in the answer of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Foreign Affairs yesterday. I really

Speaker: NA
Text: think that what we are looking at here is a docu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment which is the product of a group of bureau-

Speaker: NA
Text: crats in the Defence establishment and senior

Speaker: NA
Text: military officers. Frankly, I am frightened to think

Speaker: NA
Text: that that sort of thinking predominates even in

Speaker: NA
Text: those quarters. I am pleased to see that it does not

Speaker: NA
Text: predominate in Government quarters. Obviously

Speaker: NA
Text: that sort of proposition has great relevance so far

Speaker: NA
Text: as the Australian Government is concerned in

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of its action. If we accept that that sort of

Speaker: NA
Text: statement is true, that has important implications.

Speaker: NA
Text: The fact is that whether we like it or not the

Speaker: NA
Text: presence of United States bases on our soil means

Speaker: NA
Text: that we are a significant element of the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States global strategic war fighting capability. Ob-

Speaker: NA
Text: viously we have to give great consideration to

Speaker: NA
Text: whether those bases make a greater contribution

Speaker: NA
Text: to peace by contributing to the verification of

Speaker: NA
Text: compliance with strategic arms treaties or

Speaker: NA
Text: whether they increase the probability of war by

Speaker: NA
Text: facilitating the development of a first strike

Speaker: NA
Text: capability.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are the sorts of questions we need to con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sider. That sort of proposition, if accepted in sig-

Speaker: NA
Text: nificant circles within the defence establishment,

Speaker: NA
Text: obviously is a matter of grave concern. The fact is

Speaker: NA
Text: that a number of Press commentaries have

Speaker: NA
Text: appeared on the strategic basis paper. Some have

Speaker: NA
Text: chosen to focus on the fact of the leak having oc-

Speaker: NA
Text: curred. Others have chosen to focus on the actual

Speaker: NA
Text: content of the paper. The Australian Financial

Speaker: NA
Text: Review for one, while certainly not a journal

Speaker: NA
Text: noted for its left wing opinions, was moved to

Speaker: NA
Text: comment that the analysis appearing in the stra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tegic basis paper was highly incompetent and ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pressed grave concern on that score.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think it would be true to say that in the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments on the content of the so-called strategic

Speaker: NA
Text: basis paper most of the emphasis has been on the

Speaker: NA
Text: suggestion that Australia ought to be in a position

Speaker: NA
Text: to match any regional power in developing a nu-

Speaker: NA
Text: clear weapons capability, should such an eventu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ality or possibility arise. I would like to focus on

Speaker: NA
Text: the quotation which I read out earlier, which re-

Speaker: NA
Text: lates to the claim of Soviet strategic nuclear su-

Speaker: NA
Text: periority. I think it needs to be borne in mind that

Speaker: NA
Text: superia claim of that type is not currently pursued even

Speaker: NA
Text: by the military leadership in the United States,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Pentagon. I think that the general speculation

Speaker: NA
Text: on the strategic basis paper seems to be that it was

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared in about 1982, at which time Reagan

Speaker: NA
Text: made a well publicised statement to the effect that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Soviet Union had acquired a significant edge

Speaker: NA
Text: in the area of strategic nuclear capabilities.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am certainly not an apologist for the actions

Speaker: NA
Text: the Soviet Union. I think that it has committed

Speaker: NA
Text: many reprehensible acts. I think that its own

Speaker: NA
Text: actions in the area of a strategic nuclear build-up

Speaker: NA
Text: are-to put it mildly-extremely questionable

Speaker: NA
Text: and not consistent with the best interests of world

Speaker: NA
Text: peace. In asserting that, I also absolutely reject

Speaker: NA
Text: the thrust of the Reagan Administration; that is,

Speaker: NA
Text: that world peace and international security re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quire a massive arms build-up on the western side

Speaker: NA
Text: of the East-West division.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think that in analysing these sorts of claims

Speaker: NA
Text: about the relative strengths of the Soviet and

Speaker: NA
Text: Western blocks, it needs to be borne in mind that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Soviet and Western armed forces are structur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ally different in various ways. The Soviet Union is

Speaker: NA
Text: peculiarly dependent on intercontinental ballistic

Speaker: NA
Text: missiles for its strategic nuclear capability. The

Speaker: NA
Text: overwhelming bulk of its capacity in that area is

Speaker: NA
Text: land-based heavy ICBMs. The United States by

Speaker: NA
Text: contrast places a considerably higher reliance on

Speaker: NA
Text: submarine-based missile systems, air-launched

Speaker: NA
Text: cruise missiles and strategic bombers. There is a

Speaker: NA
Text: great difference in the composition of the forces

Speaker: NA
Text: which exist. So to restrict an analysis to a com-

Speaker: NA
Text: parision of the number of warheads, the number

Speaker: NA
Text: of missile launchers and the throw weights avail-

Speaker: NA
Text: able in terms of the land-based ICBMs possessed

Speaker: NA
Text: by both sides leads to a grossly distorted image of

Speaker: NA
Text: the real position.

Speaker: NA
Text: In making assessments of superiority, if one is

Speaker: NA
Text: talking about the capacity to destroy or to knock

Speaker: NA
Text: out the other side's strategic nuclear launchers as

Speaker: NA
Text: well as the throw weight, the total explosive

Speaker: NA
Text: power that can be brought to bear, one obviously

Speaker: NA
Text: needs to take account of the accuracy of the miss-

Speaker: NA
Text: ile systems possessed by both sides. I think it is

Speaker: NA
Text: generally conceded that the United States still has

Speaker: NA
Text: a pretty substantial edge in this area. In that con-

Speaker: NA
Text: text I shall quote briefly from a paper written by

Speaker: NA
Text: Desmond Ball of the Australian National Univer-

Speaker: NA
Text: sity Research School of Pacific Studies Strategic

Speaker: NA
Text: and Defence Studies Centre. He delivered the

Speaker: NA
Text: paper on 12-15 July 1982 a t a con ference on inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: national security in the South East Asian and

Speaker: NA
Text: South West Pacific regions. In that paper he dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: cusses this sort of question and talks about the

Speaker: NA
Text: various indices and measures of the capacity pos-

Speaker: NA
Text: sessed by nuclear powers to deliver a warhead

Speaker: NA
Text: within a certain accurate radius. So far as the ca-

Speaker: NA
Text: pacity to destroy an opponent's nuclear silo is

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned, he argues that a particular index

Speaker: NA
Text: called the 'counter military potential'-CMP-is

Speaker: NA
Text: a significant factor. He argues:

Speaker: NA
Text: CMP is the most meaningful general index of destruc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive capability of nuclear weapons against 'hard' or 'point'

Speaker: NA
Text: targets such as·ICBM silos . . .

Speaker: NA
Text: of As far as that capability is concerned-in other

Speaker: NA
Text: words, the ability to knock out a hardened

Speaker: NA
Text: installation-he goes on to say:

Speaker: NA
Text: As of luly 1982, the total CMP of the US strategic nu-

Speaker: NA
Text: clear forces was approximately double that of the Soviet

Speaker: NA
Text: arsenal . . . so that by the end of the decade the

Speaker: NA
Text: total CMP of the Soviet forces should be almost as great as

Speaker: NA
Text: that of the US forces.

Speaker: NA
Text: So, far from the Soviet Union having a strategic

Speaker: NA
Text: edge at the moment, in fact, if one extrapolates

Speaker: NA
Text: the Soviet Union's current weapons development

Speaker: NA
Text: programs on an assumption of roughly static

Speaker: NA
Text: United States capability, we will be waiting until

Speaker: NA
Text: the end of this decade before we even get parity.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course that does not take into account the

Speaker: NA
Text: massive United States arms building program
