Speaker: NA
Text: which is currently going on-the development of

Speaker: NA
Text: the MX missile system, which has a greatly enhan-

Speaker: NA
Text: ced capability to hit a target with a great deal of

Speaker: NA
Text: precision. So I submit that the sorts of claims

Speaker: NA
Text: which are made of Soviet strategic superiority by

Speaker: NA
Text: way of justification of a massive arms build-up on

Speaker: NA
Text: the American side are unjustified, unwarranted,

Speaker: NA
Text: dangerous to world peace and conducive to a

Speaker: NA
Text: further massive misallocation of resources to the

Speaker: NA
Text: arms business.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Deputy Speaker, I understand that arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments have been made by way of curtailing the

Speaker: NA
Text: length of speeches. I have a great deal more I

Speaker: NA
Text: would like to say on this matter, but I shall simply

Speaker: NA
Text: continue a little on the general theme of the

Speaker: NA
Text: incomparability of the strategic forces deployed

Speaker: NA
Text: by the United States and the Union of Soviet

Speaker: NA
Text: Socialist Republics. One claim which is sometimes

Speaker: NA
Text: made is that the United States possesses a superi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ority in submarine-launched missile capability but

Speaker: NA
Text: that fails to compensate for its deficiency in the

Speaker: NA
Text: ICBM area. Various facets of that argument exist.

Speaker: NA
Text: One major point made which is, I think, of rel-

Speaker: NA
Text: evance here is that it is generally conceded that

Speaker: NA
Text: the United States has a very major edge over the

Speaker: NA
Text: Soviet Union in terms of allowing its submarines

Speaker: NA
Text: to run silently and undetected, and a far greater

Speaker: NA
Text: capability than the Soviet Union so far as the

Speaker: NA
Text: technology of detection of an opponent's nuclear

Speaker: NA
Text: submarines is concerned. So I think that if we take

Speaker: NA
Text: into account those sorts of technological

Speaker: NA
Text: differences it serves to reinforce the general point

Speaker: NA
Text: that I am making; that is, that the claim of Soviet

Speaker: NA
Text: strategic nuclear superiority, as asserted in the

Speaker: NA
Text: strategic basis document, is not warranted. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: not conducive to world peace and is something

Speaker: NA
Text: which the Government and elements within its

Speaker: NA
Text: bureaucracy and defence establishment ought to

Speaker: NA
Text: eschew.

Speaker: Mr CARLTON
Text: Mackellar) (10.08)-

Speaker: NA
Text: Tonight we are discussing the Appropriation Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: (No.3) 1983-84, the Appropriation Bill (No.4)

Speaker: NA
Text: 1983-84 and the Appropriation Bill (Parliamen-·

Speaker: NA
Text: tary Departments) Bill (No.2) 1983-84. I would

Speaker: NA
Text: like to concentrate on the appropriations for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of Health. This morning the Sydney

Speaker: NA
Text: Morning Herald ran an editorial headed 'Doc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tors: now is the time to quit'. There followed an

Speaker: NA
Text: analysis of the present industrial situation, which

Speaker: NA
Text: is very unfortunate and in which doctors for the

Speaker: NA
Text: first time in the history of Australia have felt

Speaker: NA
Text: they should go on strike. I think that is a very

Speaker: NA
Text: fortunate outcome of the present Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: policies. I understand the concerns which the doc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tors have. The editorial analysis is extraordinary

Speaker: NA
Text: because it merely analyses the industrial muscle

Speaker: NA
Text: which the doctors are able to put up and comes to

Speaker: NA
Text: the conclusion that they do not have sufficient

Speaker: NA
Text: muscle to beat the Minister for Health (Dr

Speaker: NA
Text: Blewett). But nowhere in the whole editorial is

Speaker: NA
Text: there any examination of the underlying issues, no

Speaker: NA
Text: examination of whether it would be in the

Speaker: NA
Text: interests of the Australian people and of good

Speaker: NA
Text: health care if the arguments being advanced by

Speaker: NA
Text: the doctors were to prevail. It is within that

Speaker: NA
Text: framework that I would like to address some re-

Speaker: NA
Text: marks to the House tonight.

Speaker: NA
Text: Within the Government's general program,

Speaker: NA
Text: within its Budget and within the scope of these

Speaker: NA
Text: Appropriation Bills there are two main thrusts of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government's health policy. The first is a

Speaker: NA
Text: major move in the direction of increased govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment control over health care insurance and de-

Speaker: NA
Text: livery. That is the first thrust of the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: policy. Certainly, honourable members opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: would acknowledge that that is a clear objective

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Labor Government-a major move in the

Speaker: NA
Text: direction of increased government control.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second thrust of the Government's policy

Speaker: NA
Text: is the implementation of one aspect of the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Labor Party-Australian Council of Trade

Speaker: NA
Text: Unions accord which aimed to produce a

Speaker: NA
Text: nationalised or almost nationalised health scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: and within that to gain control over non-wage in-

Speaker: NA
Text: comes. That is the second main thrust of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's health policy. The component of

Speaker: NA
Text: increases in Government control within health

Speaker: NA
Text: policy covers three main areas. The first one I

Speaker: NA
Text: draw particularly to the attention of the business

Speaker: NA
Text: community which has in some respects been laud-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the conservatism of the Prime Minister ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Hawke) and the Treasurer ( Mr Keating) in econ-

Speaker: NA
Text: omic policy. In regard to health insurance, this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has actually nationalised $1. 7 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: worth of private health insurance premiums. It

Speaker: NA
Text: has taken those over into the public sector. It has

Speaker: NA
Text: dislodged 5,000 private sector employees and has

Speaker: NA
Text: taken on employees in the public sector to take

Speaker: NA
Text: over the duties that private sector employees have

Speaker: NA
Text: been carrying out. So there has been a major act of

Speaker: NA
Text: nationalisation in the health industry, as I said,

Speaker: NA
Text: amounting to $1.7 billion. We have not heard a

Speaker: NA
Text: peep out of the business community about this

Speaker: NA
Text: major act of nationalisation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second major area of nationalisation con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerns the doctors. This relates very much to the

Speaker: NA
Text: matter discussed in the Sydney Morning Herald.

Speaker: NA
Text: that There were two aspects of the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: un- extra control over doctors. The first is to move

Speaker: NA
Text: government or taxpayer support for doctors in

Speaker: NA
Text: their surgeries in respect of the schedule fee from

Speaker: NA
Text: the 30 per cent government subsidy under the old

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme to an 85 per cent government subsidy. So

Speaker: NA
Text: a scheme which had a measure of government in-

Speaker: NA
Text: tervention up to the level of 30 per cent under the

Speaker: NA
Text: previous Government, with some tax concessions,

Speaker: NA
Text: has now moved to an 85 per cent taxpayer sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: vention. The aim there is to try to get all doctors

Speaker: NA
Text: to bulk bill the government for surgery consul-

Speaker: NA
Text: tations and to accept 85 per cent of the prescribed

Speaker: NA
Text: fee in full payment of the bill. As a result, those

Speaker: NA
Text: doctors will be directly dependent on the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment payroll.

Speaker: NA
Text: A direct billing system inevitably leads to high

Speaker: NA
Text: utilisation because the patients have no financial

Speaker: NA
Text: constraints on visiting their doctors. They make

Speaker: NA
Text: no payment at the point of service. The doctors

Speaker: NA
Text: merely have to send a bill, virtually anonymously,

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Department of the Treasury, and the bill is

Speaker: NA
Text: paid. Also, because of the 15 per cent discount

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a temptation to increase the number of

Speaker: NA
Text: services rendered both on the part of the patient,

Speaker: NA
Text: who does not have to put in anything at the point

Speaker: NA
Text: of service, and on the part of the doctor who sends

Speaker: NA
Text: a bill anonymously to the government. If doctors

Speaker: NA
Text: are foolish enough in very large numbers to go

Speaker: NA
Text: into the bulk billing system and if their rates of

Speaker: NA
Text: utilisation start to increase, the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Health will say that they are guilty of overservic-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing and will exercise his control over their incomes

Speaker: NA
Text: either by reducing the schedule fee or possibly by

Speaker: NA
Text: moving to capitation or salary systems. So this is

Speaker: NA
Text: the first element in controlling the doctors to a

Speaker: NA
Text: much greater extent than before.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second element is to control the hospital

Speaker: NA
Text: specialists. This has been done in a very crude

Speaker: NA
Text: fashion by introducing a new section to the Health

Speaker: NA
Text: Insurance Act which gives the Federal Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: direct control without arbitration or appeal over

Speaker: NA
Text: the contracts that visiting medical officers to pub-

Speaker: NA
Text: lic hospitals have with those hospitals. The pur-

Speaker: NA
Text: pose of this move is the same as that involved in

Speaker: NA
Text: the bulk billing objective; to make these doctors

Speaker: NA
Text: wholly dependent on the Government for their in-

Speaker: NA
Text: come; so doctors in surgeries and doctors visiting

Speaker: NA
Text: hospitals will both be entirely under the control of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Federal Government, and therefore will be

Speaker: NA
Text: getting around the provisions of section 51 of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Constitution, which prohibits the civil conscrip-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of doctors for the purpose of providing

Speaker: NA
Text: government medical services. I think that the doc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tors would be wise to challenge that legislation in

Speaker: NA
Text: the High Court of Australia as I believe there are

Speaker: NA
Text: sound grounds for believing that it contravenes

Speaker: NA
Text: that provision of section 51 of the Constitution

Speaker: NA
Text: which prevents civil conscription of doctors and

Speaker: NA
Text: dentists.

Speaker: NA
Text: The third area of increased Government con-

Speaker: NA
Text: trol is that of private hospitals. The Federal Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister for Health has introduced a system of

Speaker: NA
Text: categorisation on the Federal level of all private

Speaker: NA
Text: hospitals in Australia into categories 1, 2 and 3.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a very arbitrary categorisation and deter-

Speaker: NA
Text: mines the level of public taxpayer subsidy as well

Speaker: NA
Text: as the level of private health insurance rebate for

Speaker: NA
Text: patients attending those private hospitals. Be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause of the arbitrary and bureaucratic nature of

Speaker: NA
Text: those controls, some hospitals no doubt will get a

Speaker: NA
Text: bit of a windfall in terms of reimbursement, but

Speaker: NA
Text: other hospitals most definitely have been put in a

Speaker: NA
Text: very disadvantageous position. I refer particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: to private psychiatric hospitals with chronic psy-

Speaker: NA
Text: chiatric patients who have been obliged under this

Speaker: NA
Text: categorisation, in most cases, to pay an extra $38 a

Speaker: NA
Text: day out of their private resources. Given the

Speaker: NA
Text: nature of these patients and the problems their

Speaker: NA
Text: families are having with them, over many years in

Speaker: NA
Text: many cases, this is a very cruel imposition by this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: I might add in passing that these categorisation

Speaker: NA
Text: proposals were invalid in law. When the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: set these categorisations in December he had not

Speaker: NA
Text: consulted fully with his State ministerial col-

Speaker: NA
Text: leagues as is required under his legislation. Also,

Speaker: NA
Text: he had not fulfilled the provisions of his own Act

Speaker: NA
Text: which called for gazettal of these guidelines.

Speaker: NA
Text: Therefore, the guidelines have been found to be

Speaker: NA
Text: invalid and every single private hospital in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia has been asked last week and this week

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Federal Government to re-apply for

Speaker: NA
Text: categorisation. But that is a minor matter when

Speaker: NA
Text: compared with the attack on the private hospitals

Speaker: NA
Text: and on their independence. The purpose of this

Speaker: NA
Text: whole exercise has been made clear by Dr John

Speaker: NA
Text: Deeble in an interview recorded in the Sun-

Speaker: NA
Text: Herald newspaper on 29 January 1984. In this in-

Speaker: NA
Text: terview Dr Deeble said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Putting private hospitals into three classes is the very

Speaker: NA
Text: first step towards putting private hospitals into the public

Speaker: NA
Text: system. This is a very big step, but it is a long term aim.

Speaker: NA
Text: Clearly these areas of health insurance, the $1.7

Speaker: NA
Text: billion worth of premiums being nationalised, the

Speaker: NA
Text: attempt to get doctors to bulk bill for all patients

Speaker: NA
Text: and to make them totally dependent on tax-

Speaker: NA
Text: payers' money for all surgical consultations, the

Speaker: NA
Text: attempt to have specialists' contracts come di-

Speaker: NA
Text: rectly under the control of the Federal Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: without arbitration or appeal, and the total

Speaker: NA
Text: categorisation and control of the private hospitals

Speaker: NA
Text: in line with Dr Deeble's and Dr Blewett's objec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tives of bringing them eventually into the public

Speaker: NA
Text: system, are part of the Labor Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: attempt to bring about an almost total control of

Speaker: NA
Text: health care financing and delivery and an almost

Speaker: NA
Text: total control of the whole shooting match.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Reeves-And to control costs.

Speaker: Mr CARLTON
Text: One honourable member has

Speaker: NA
Text: interjected and said that it will control costs.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Reeves-And could stop rip-off's.

Speaker: Mr CARLTON
Text: The honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: says it would stop rip-off's. There are two ways of

Speaker: NA
Text: going about this problem. It is a genuine problem

Speaker: NA
Text: in health schemes around the world and I think it

Speaker: NA
Text: has been described very well by Jack A. Meyer in

Speaker: NA
Text: the introduction to a recent publication of the

Speaker: NA
Text: American Enterprise Institute in which he says:

Speaker: NA
Text: The principal problem in health care today is the need

Speaker: NA
Text: For a workable mechanism to achieve a proper balance be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween acceptable cost and an ensured level of

Speaker: NA
Text: quality . . .

Speaker: NA
Text: Too oFten, the Government defines the problem

Speaker: NA
Text: through the narrow prism of its own Frantic search for

Speaker: NA
Text: ways to bring rising Government outlays in line with a

Speaker: NA
Text: shrinking fiscal resource base.

Speaker: NA
Text: The only way out of that box is to ensure that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government is not the only source of funds for

Speaker: NA
Text: health care and that greater reliance is placed on

Speaker: NA
Text: market oriented incentives to encourage health

Speaker: NA
Text: care providers to delivery services of acceptable

Speaker: NA
Text: quality at lower cost. What the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Health does not realise is that these market mech-

Speaker: NA
Text: anisms have not been satisfactorily tried. In my

Speaker: NA
Text: view they were not satisfactorily tried under the

Speaker: NA
Text: old system and they have not been satisfactorily

Speaker: NA
Text: tried now. Around the world, in every health.sys-

Speaker: NA
Text: tem that is concerned about costs and quality,

Speaker: NA
Text: people are realising that the way to solve those

Speaker: NA
Text: concerns is not to put all the health care dollars

Speaker: NA
Text: into the taxpayer dollar pot. If that happens, all

Speaker: NA
Text: the responsibility for quality and cost control

Speaker: NA
Text: comes back onto the administrators and Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ters. They have to exercise a big valve control at

Speaker: NA
Text: the very top. The real controls, if they are to be

Speaker: NA
Text: sensitive and related to patient needs, must be

Speaker: NA
Text: exercised at the bottom end of the scale, at the

Speaker: NA
Text: work face, where the provider meets the actual

Speaker: NA
Text: customer, the patient.

Speaker: NA
Text: Around the world, where people are looking

Speaker: NA
Text: sensibly at those problems and at the solutions to

Speaker: NA
Text: them, they are looking for mechanisms that will

Speaker: NA
Text: introduce incentive down the line as far as poss-

Speaker: NA
Text: ible and keep a number of private dollars in the

Speaker: NA
Text: pot. In that way we do not have a continual

Speaker: NA
Text: clamping-down, a restriction on hospital systems,

Speaker: NA
Text: doctors, providers and patients. We do not have

Speaker: NA
Text: the queuing, the shortages and the difficulties we

Speaker: NA
Text: have seen under Roper in Victoria and Brereton

Speaker: NA
Text: in New South Wales, and now under Blewett in

Speaker: NA
Text: Canberra.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second aspect of the Government's policy

Speaker: NA
Text: on which I want to touch briefly is the issue of the

Speaker: NA
Text: prices and incomes accord. Under the accord be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween the Australian Council of Trade Unions

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Australian Labor Party, signed before the

Speaker: NA
Text: last election-a deal between the trade union

Speaker: NA
Text: movement and the Labor Party which was foisted

Speaker: NA
Text: onto the other participants at the National Econ-

Speaker: NA
Text: omic Summit Conference-there appeared this

Speaker: NA
Text: item under the heading 'Non-wage incomes':

Speaker: NA
Text: Non-wage incomes include dividends, capital gains,

Speaker: NA
Text: rent, interest, director's fees and incomes of unincorporation

Speaker: NA
Text: ated enterprises (doctors, lawyers, shopkeepers, self-

Speaker: NA
Text: employed builders and tradesmen, etc.)

Speaker: NA
Text: Part of the accord, in the same paragraph, states:

Speaker: NA
Text: The establishment of a health insurance scheme incor-

Speaker: NA
Text: porating measures to remove the ability of doctors to ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: ploit patients through overservicing, use of unduly costly

Speaker: NA
Text: procedures and non-adherence to scheduled fees.

Speaker: NA
Text: It also includes this clause about seeking the co-

Speaker: NA
Text: operation of State governments:

Speaker: NA
Text: The States have unlimited constitutional power to

Speaker: NA
Text: trol prices (except where they are controlled by

Speaker: NA
Text: eral Government), and their assistance will be sought in

Speaker: NA
Text: regulating prices charged by important sections of the

Speaker: NA
Text: non-corporate area.

Speaker: NA
Text: We see in this health policy an application of the

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions of the accord by the bringing in of price

Speaker: NA
Text: control by the Federal Minister, in effect, over

Speaker: NA
Text: schedule fees and over contracts, by agreements

Speaker: NA
Text: with his State counterparts to bring in price con-

Speaker: NA
Text: trol regulations in the States, and thereby to bring

Speaker: NA
Text: about price control of what are essentially small

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses. We are not talking about income con-

Speaker: NA
Text: trol in this case; we are talking about a control of

Speaker: NA
Text: price at the turnover level, a gross income from

Speaker: NA
Text: which expenses have to be deducted. It is the same

Speaker: NA
Text: as controlling the prices in a shop without having

Speaker: NA
Text: any real understanding of the component costs.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is the direction in which this Government

Speaker: NA
Text: is heading. It is the new corporate state in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. It has begun in other areas and it is now

Speaker: NA
Text: being extended to health. In two principal re-

Speaker: NA
Text: spects, in the quality of health care--

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Blanchard- Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a

Speaker: NA
Text: point of order. It was my understanding that only

Speaker: NA
Text: 15 minutes was being given to speakers in the

Speaker: NA
Text: debate.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Millar)-The

Speaker: NA
Text: matter is not within the province of the Chair.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no point of order.

Speaker: Mr CARLTON
Text: If the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: had not raised the point of order I would have

Speaker: NA
Text: been able to conclude the sentence and keep

Speaker: NA
Text: within my time limit. The Government in two

Speaker: NA
Text: principal respects-in attacking the long term

Speaker: NA
Text: quality of Australian health care by, in effect,

Speaker: NA
Text: nationalising health care delivery and in making a

Speaker: NA
Text: major attack on what are essentially small

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses-is taking Australia in a totally unsat-

Speaker: NA
Text: isfactory direction as a result of its general health

Speaker: NA
Text: care policy.

Speaker: Mr ROBERT BROWN
Text: Hunter)

Speaker: NA
Text: (10.24)-The purpose of these three Bills-the

Speaker: NA
Text: Appropriation Bill (No.3) 1983-84, the Appro-

Speaker: NA
Text: priation Bill (No.4) 1983-84, and the Appropri-

Speaker: NA
Text: (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No.2)

Speaker: NA
Text: 1983-84-is to appropriate supplementary funds

Speaker: NA
Text: for the purposes of government expenditure be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween now and the end of the current financial

Speaker: NA
Text: year. It is usual at this time of the year for these

Speaker: NA
Text: Bills to be introduced in order to make those ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: propriations possible. Before I deal with some

Speaker: NA
Text: specific matters, I draw the attention of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: to the fact that on this occasion the additional ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: propriation represents only 0.59 per cent of the

Speaker: NA
Text: total net appropriations at this time of the year.

Speaker: NA
Text: con- This reflects very well on the budgetary and finan-

Speaker: NA
Text: the Fed- cial management capacity of the Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: That percentage is the lowest for a considerable

Speaker: NA
Text: number of years. In fact, I think it is the lowest

Speaker: NA
Text: figure for at least 10 years. It has been reduced, for

Speaker: NA
Text: example, from 1.1 per cent in 1981-82 and from

Speaker: NA
Text: 2.3 per cent in 1982-83. In terms of gross expendi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture, the percentage this year of 1.11 per cent is

Speaker: NA
Text: the lowest for the last 10 years, with the exception

Speaker: NA
Text: I know that the Minister for Finance ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Dawkins) in his second reading speech drew

Speaker: NA
Text: attention to the fact that this is testimony to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's more thorough and rational man-

Speaker: NA
Text: agement of the budgetary process as a result of its

Speaker: NA
Text: more careful management this year. That the

Speaker: NA
Text: budgetary position is as sound as it is at present is

Speaker: NA
Text: also testimony to the very effective continuing

Speaker: NA
Text: economic management this Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: undertaken since 5 March last year. I do not have

Speaker: NA
Text: time to deal in very much detail with the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's initiatives, but I think it is important that

Speaker: NA
Text: they be at least referred to. If I have time, I will

Speaker: NA
Text: draw attention to the impact this series of econ-

Speaker: NA
Text: omic measures has had on Australia's economic

Speaker: NA
Text: position.

Speaker: NA
Text: The first point to which I make brief reference

Speaker: NA
Text: is the fundamental approach of this Government

Speaker: NA
Text: in connection with the prices and incomes accord.

Speaker: NA
Text: This was completed, of course, before 5 March

Speaker: NA
Text: last year between the Australian Labor Party and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Council of Trade Unions. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary to have that agreement because of the

Speaker: NA
Text: attempt by the Labor Party in government to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that it could make a simultaneous attack

Speaker: NA
Text: on the twin problems of unemployment and infla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. In terms of our fiscal policy, we determined

Speaker: NA
Text: that we would provide maximum fiscal stimulus

Speaker: NA
Text: to the economy which at the same time was con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sistent with our anti-inflationary objectives. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: very difficult to do that starting from a very high

Speaker: NA
Text: inflation floor. If expansionary, stimulatory poli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cies are to be adopted, it is quite clearly necessary

Speaker: NA
Text: to put into place at the same time policies that will

Speaker: NA
Text: have an anti-inflationary component.

Speaker: NA
Text: It was also necessary to balance our monetary

Speaker: NA
Text: policy because, unlike the previous Government,

Speaker: NA
Text: we determined that we would allow sufficient

Speaker: NA
Text: monetary growth to accommodate the growth in

Speaker: NA
Text: nominal output. The previous Government had

Speaker: NA
Text: allowed money to grow by an amount which was

Speaker: NA
Text: sufficient to accommodate inflation, but not

Speaker: NA
Text: sufficient to accommodate any real growth. The

Speaker: NA
Text: result of that type of approach, that policy, was

Speaker: NA
Text: that the previous Government squeezed out of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian economy any potential for real

Speaker: NA
Text: growth. The approach the Hawke Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has adopted has been more realistic. It has been

Speaker: NA
Text: more understanding of the type of economic cir-

Speaker: NA
Text: cumstances that exist, and it has undoubtedly

Speaker: NA
Text: been vastly more successful.

Speaker: NA
Text: The first major step this Government took after

Speaker: NA
Text: its election to office on 5 March last year occurred

Speaker: NA
Text: three days after that election. On 8 March it be-

Speaker: NA
Text: came necessary for the Government to devalue

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian currency and at the same time to

Speaker: NA
Text: serve notice on speculators that their speculative

Speaker: NA
Text: activities in relation to capital movements, capital

Speaker: NA
Text: inflow and outflow, would not be tolerated by a

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor government. I think notice was very effec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tively served on that occasion. About $3,000m

Speaker: NA
Text: had flowed out of Australia in the three weeks

Speaker: NA
Text: prior to the election. Of course, that was fuelled

Speaker: NA
Text: by the extremely irresponsible statements made

Speaker: NA
Text: by spokesmen for the now Oppostion, including

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: said:

Speaker: NA
Text: . . . election of a Labor Government would inevi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tably mean a major devaluation of the dollar.

Speaker: NA
Text: He continued:

Speaker: NA
Text: Many experts believe that an ALP Government would

Speaker: NA
Text: probably devalue the dollar by at least 15 per cent in its

Speaker: NA
Text: first days in office.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate interrupted.

Speaker: NA
Text: ADJOURNMENT

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I

Speaker: NA
Text: propose the question:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the House do now adjourn.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Barry Jones-I require the question to be

Speaker: NA
Text: put forthwith without debate.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question resolved in the negative.

Speaker: NA
Text: APPROPRIATION BILL (No.3) 1983-84

Speaker: NA
Text: [COGNATE BILLS:

Speaker: NA
Text: APPROPRIATION BILL (No.4) 1983-84

Speaker: NA
Text: APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY

Speaker: NA
Text: DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No.2) 1983-84]

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed.

Speaker: Mr ROBERT BROWN
Text: Hunter)

Speaker: NA
Text: (10.30)-The next major initiative of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, of course, was the realisation of the

Speaker: NA
Text: ambition of the present Prime Minister ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Hawke) over a long period to bring together all

Speaker: NA
Text: the interests in the Australian economy by way of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Economic Summit Conference. We did that

Speaker: NA
Text: within almost one month of the election of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. It occurred in April 1983 and, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, it occurred in this chamber. The next

Speaker: NA
Text: major initiative was the May economic statement.

Speaker: NA
Text: Because of a number of different undertakings

Speaker: NA
Text: which the Government had given prior to the

Speaker: NA
Text: election, it was necessary for us to shave off from

Speaker: NA
Text: the previous Government's expenditure under-

Speaker: NA
Text: takings and programs something like $1,OOOm.

Speaker: NA
Text: We took advantage of the opportunity then to re-

Speaker: NA
Text: place them with about $500m worth of initiatives

Speaker: NA
Text: of this Government. They included initiatives in

Speaker: NA
Text: public housing, the home ownership assistance

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme, the community employment program

Speaker: NA
Text: and manpower and training programs.

Speaker: NA
Text: The next initiative was the Premiers Confer-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence which took place on 30 June 1983. This

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, realising the very serious financial

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances that the States were facing in con-

Speaker: NA
Text: nection with their budgeting, made available to

Speaker: NA
Text: them an extra $270m in cash grants and loan ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: provals. That included a total of $155m in a

Speaker: NA
Text: one-off grant to relieve the States of those budget-

Speaker: NA
Text: ary problems. That was provided by way of a

Speaker: NA
Text: special revenue assistance grant.The next initiat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ive was the establishment of the Economic Plan-

Speaker: NA
Text: ning Advisory Council. It first met in July 1983.

Speaker: NA
Text: The purpose of establishing EPAC was to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that the process of consultation, negotiation and

Speaker: NA
Text: discussion which had been initiated with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Economic Summit Conference would be con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinued. Everyone in the Australian community

Speaker: NA
Text: now applauds the fact that EPAC was put into

Speaker: NA
Text: place. It is operating. It is a means of continuing

Speaker: NA
Text: consultation and discussions between the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment and important sectors of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: The next initiative, of course, was the Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: which was introduced on 23 August 1983. It is the

Speaker: NA
Text: single most important financial document which

Speaker: NA
Text: any government introduces during any year.

Speaker: NA
Text: Faced with the daunting Budget deficit of some-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing like $9.6 billion which it became apparent

Speaker: NA
Text: would be the inheritance of the Hawke Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment from the previous Government, it was

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary for us not only to maintain some type of

Speaker: NA
Text: significant stimulation of the Australian economy

Speaker: NA
Text: but also to take advantage of that opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: rein back on the type of deficit we were inheriting.

Speaker: NA
Text: So we budgeted for a deficit of about $8.5 billion,

Speaker: NA
Text: and those general Budget objectives were

Speaker: NA
Text: applauded again by all responsible elements of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian community.

Speaker: NA
Text: The next major initiative was the floating of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian dollar on 12 December last year. It was

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary to take that step because it was the only

Speaker: NA
Text: realistic step in the light of the continuation of

Speaker: NA
Text: very speculative activity with respect to capital

Speaker: NA
Text: movements. There had been a major inflow of

Speaker: NA
Text: capital funds that was threatening the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's objective in relation to the control of the

Speaker: NA
Text: money supply and at the same time was providing

Speaker: NA
Text: speculators, who were almost assured of a sig-

Speaker: NA
Text: nificant revaluation of the Australian dollar, with

Speaker: NA
Text: the opportunity to make very large speculative

Speaker: NA
Text: gains. I think that that initiative by the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has been a resounding success. Some prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lems persist, but in general terms I think that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government can take a great deal of credit for

Speaker: NA
Text: showing much greater courage in that connection

Speaker: NA
Text: than was shown by our conservative opponents

Speaker: NA
Text: when they were in government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Then the Martin report on the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: financial system was brought down in December

Speaker: NA
Text: 1983. The chief issues of the Martin report will

Speaker: NA
Text: continue to be matters of concern, interest and

Speaker: NA
Text: discussion as this Government undoubtedly

Speaker: NA
Text: moves, at least to some extent, further down the

Speaker: NA
Text: track towards freeing up financial markets while

Speaker: NA
Text: at the same time ensuring that it retains for itself

Speaker: NA
Text: sufficient capacity to control the financial system

Speaker: NA
Text: and to exercise legitimate, necessary and sensible

Speaker: NA
Text: forms of control over the money system generally.

Speaker: NA
Text: rise to speak on the Appropriation Bills as they

Speaker: NA
Text: give us an opportunity to canvass quite a few mat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ters which might concern not only the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: but also the people of Australia. 1 start by saying

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Budget, when it was introduced, provided

Speaker: NA
Text: for an $8.6 billion deficit which was at that time

Speaker: NA
Text: and still is a record deficit for Australia. But it was

Speaker: NA
Text: sold to the Australian people. Since then the esti-

Speaker: NA
Text: mates on which it was based, 1 believe, have

Speaker: NA
Text: improved due to the breaking of the drought. As

Speaker: NA
Text: one honourable member said, it seems to be a

Speaker: NA
Text: weather-led recovery, but the figures in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget have improved because of a real increase

Speaker: NA
Text: in productivity.

Speaker: NA
Text: .1 have looked at the figures released by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Finance ( Mr Dawkins) to indicate

Speaker: NA
Text: that there has been no blow-out in the Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: figures themselves. But when one takes into

Speaker: NA
Text: account the improvement in the economy, one

Speaker: NA
Text: would expect that the deficit would naturally re-

Speaker: NA
Text: duce. 1 have heard that for everyone per cent im-

Speaker: NA
Text: provement in the gross domestic product, there is

Speaker: NA
Text: a potential reduction in the deficit of $500m. This

Speaker: NA
Text: is probably brought about by the fact that people

Speaker: NA
Text: are being taken off the unemployment list, are be-

Speaker: NA
Text: coming productive and contributing to the rev-

Speaker: NA
Text: the enue. So, that one per cent increase should mean a

Speaker: NA
Text: saving of $500m. On those figures, as the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer ( Mr Keating) has indicated, if pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ductivity has increased by 3 per cent over Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: Estimates, we should be looking at a deficit at the

Speaker: NA
Text: moment not of the order of $8.6 billion but of $7

Speaker: NA
Text: billion-$1.5 billion less. So if we look at it re-

Speaker: NA
Text: alistically we see that there has been a blow-out in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Budget of the proportion of $1.5 billion. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer might explain that to us in more detail.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Budget figures indicating the potential to

Speaker: NA
Text: employ 70,000 people throughout Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: under the community employment program have

Speaker: NA
Text: been revised to the extent that it is now said by the

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible Minister that only 40,000 people can

Speaker: NA
Text: be employed under that program. This is a mass-

Speaker: NA
Text: ive reduction from the original estimate; it is

Speaker: NA
Text: almost half. Again I believe that the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: people should be advised as to how this discrep-

Speaker: NA
Text: ancy has come about, how the 70,000 has slipped

Speaker: NA
Text: to 40,000. There has been no proper explanation

Speaker: NA
Text: in this regard. It worries me when 1 hear about a

Speaker: NA
Text: deficit displayed with such gay abandon in this

Speaker: NA
Text: House without realising its implications. 1 know

Speaker: NA
Text: that people will say that I am a square and per-

Speaker: NA
Text: haps a conservative, but 1 always like to believe or

Speaker: NA
Text: compare the ways-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Barry Jones-And you are an accountant

Speaker: NA
Text: too.

Speaker: Mr BRAITHWAITEAITE
Text: I am an accountant.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is probably the basis of my conservatism. I

Speaker: NA
Text: am not apologising for that, but accountants are

Speaker: NA
Text: conservative. I always believe that a person in a

Speaker: NA
Text: household, if he cannot earn sufficient within a

Speaker: NA
Text: particular time to give him the capacity to borrow

Speaker: NA
Text: and to repay a loan, should live within his income

Speaker: NA
Text: and the funds he has. This situation is not peculiar

Speaker: NA
Text: to this Labor Government. It is common to other

Speaker: NA
Text: governments. A deficit occurs when a nation

Speaker: NA
Text: spends beyond its means without the equivalent of

Speaker: NA
Text: the deficit being put into hard assets for the

Speaker: NA
Text: future generations. I noticed in the last Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: that the cost of funding accumulated deficits over

Speaker: NA
Text: the period was 7c for every dollar spent by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth. That means an amount must be

Speaker: NA
Text: built into the expenditure factor and cannot be

Speaker: NA
Text: used on other things. The taxpayers and the youth

Speaker: NA
Text: of the future will have to bear that continuing ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pense because of today's extravagances. I hope

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Government will heed the advice of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Business Council of Australia, which has called

Speaker: NA
Text: for a concerted effort to bring that deficit back by

Speaker: NA
Text: an appreciable amount. By saying that, I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: mean that it expects tax increases to occur so that

Speaker: NA
Text: that can be accomplished.

Speaker: NA
Text: The effect on the inflation rate must also be

Speaker: NA
Text: taken into account. The honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Hunter ( Mr Robert Brown) mentioned that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has been successful in reducing the

Speaker: NA
Text: inflation rate. I remind the House and the people

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia that that inflation rate has been

Speaker: NA
Text: artificially reduced, because of the effects of the

Speaker: NA
Text: health insurance proposals, by some 2.3 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: for the current year. So, in looking at the attack

Speaker: NA
Text: on inflation, perhaps the result is not quite as

Speaker: NA
Text: as might have been expected -but then

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Robert Brown-I said that the claim that

Speaker: NA
Text: you people are making cannot be substantiated.

Speaker: Mr BRAITHWAITEAITE
Text: The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member might not have said that. What I am say-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing is that the attack on inflation has not taken

Speaker: NA
Text: into account the artificial reduction because of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare insurance factor. We should be aware

Speaker: NA
Text: that, because of this artificial reduction, the areas

Speaker: NA
Text: that are normally indexed, such as local govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, a sphere of government within our society,

Speaker: NA
Text: will not be getting exactly what they wanted. In

Speaker: NA
Text: local government finances there is an automatic

Speaker: NA
Text: expectation of indexation.

Speaker: NA
Text: When the establishment of the Economic Plan-

Speaker: NA
Text: ning Advisory Council was initially mentioned at

Speaker: NA
Text: the conference last April, I for one applauded it,

Speaker: NA
Text: because if the people of Australia-the business

Speaker: NA
Text: people, the unions, and all interested people-can

Speaker: NA
Text: get together and make a decision in regard to the

Speaker: NA
Text: future and the Government is prepared to listen

Speaker: NA
Text: to them, well and good. But I do not believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: consensus has ever spread over 100 people trying

Speaker: NA
Text: to give their advice on what Australia wanted.

Speaker: NA
Text: The conference ended with an agreement on

Speaker: NA
Text: everything but, basically, what the wage structure

Speaker: NA
Text: was to be, and that was to fall into the prices and

Speaker: NA
Text: incomes accord. I understand that already there

Speaker: NA
Text: has been an increase of some 5 per cent because of

Speaker: NA
Text: the indexation of the last 6 months. I understand

Speaker: NA
Text: that there is to be a 4.1 per cent increase at this

Speaker: NA
Text: use of stage. This makes me believe that perhaps the

Speaker: NA
Text: basic structure of wages will go beyond the Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: expectations. That highlights the difficulties of

Speaker: NA
Text: holding a conference of that nature without tying

Speaker: NA
Text: up all the ends. The income end was stitched up,

Speaker: NA
Text: but the wage end was not. So consensus depends

Speaker: NA
Text: very much on the outcome of the wage increases

Speaker: NA
Text: up to the end of June. As I said, it is all very well

Speaker: NA
Text: to get a lot of people together to say that EPAC

Speaker: NA
Text: has recommended this or that, but it must also be

Speaker: NA
Text: appreciated that much of the advice that is being

Speaker: NA
Text: given through EPAC is not necessarily the advice

Speaker: NA
Text: that might be offered by people outside.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Herbert ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Lindsay) made particular reference to national

Speaker: NA
Text: disasters. I support his call for the Government to

Speaker: NA
Text: look very carefully at the disaster that has oc-

Speaker: NA
Text: curred because of the abnormally wet season in

Speaker: NA
Text: north Queensland and the fact that the major

Speaker: NA
Text: trade and export route of the rail link between

Speaker: NA
Text: Mount Isa and Townsville has been severely

Speaker: NA
Text: disrupted. It does not require just maintenance; it

Speaker: NA
Text: requires work of a more immediate nature. When

Speaker: NA
Text: I saw that item on national disasters in the papers,

Speaker: NA
Text: good I immediately thought of the Labor Government

Speaker: NA
Text: I realised that other things were being

Speaker: NA
Text: talked about. I just thought I would add that too.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the aspect of Medicare, I have already men-

Speaker: NA
Text: tioned the artificial reduction in the CPI, but the

Speaker: NA
Text: current dispute between the Government and

Speaker: NA
Text: doctors, in which the Government wants to try to

Speaker: NA
Text: reduce the medical fees to its own artificial sched-

Speaker: NA
Text: ule fees, is nothing short of ridiculous and nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: short of an attempt to nationalise and to regulate

Speaker: NA
Text: the medical profession. Perhaps that is just the

Speaker: NA
Text: thin end of the wedge which has been revealed by

Speaker: NA
Text: many of this Government's actions over the last

Speaker: NA
Text: 12 months.

Speaker: NA
Text: In that respect, I just mention the resource rent

Speaker: NA
Text: tax. I am. not sure where it stands with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government at present, but it is just another

Speaker: NA
Text: attempt to take over the resources of Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: just as Mr Connor, a Minister in the Whitlam

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, tried to do many years ago. I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that the resource rent tax will have a greatly dam-

Speaker: NA
Text: aging effect on the potential for development of

Speaker: NA
Text: our resources. It has already shown that in con-

Speaker: NA
Text: nection with oil, and I am very sure that it will

Speaker: NA
Text: show it in respect of man/of our other resources.

Speaker: NA
Text: EPAC apparently, in its own way, is now said

Speaker: NA
Text: to have endorsed a capital gains tax, a wealth tax,

Speaker: NA
Text: a purchase tax and quite a few other taxes. But I

Speaker: NA
Text: suggest that the Government look very carefully

Speaker: NA
Text: at all these aspects just to see where the net

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit will be and whether more will be gained

Speaker: NA
Text: from the collection of those taxes than will be

Speaker: NA
Text: expended in the cost of their collection. That is a

Speaker: NA
Text: vital point. When talking about political philos-

Speaker: NA
Text: ophy, one should get down to the realism of ascer-

Speaker: NA
Text: taining where the net gain is.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have been asked to cut the length of my

Speaker: NA
Text: speech to 10 minutes. I would have been more

Speaker: NA
Text: than happy to make other comments, but those

Speaker: NA
Text: will suffice for the time being.

Speaker: Mr HOLLIS
Text: Macarthur) (I0.46)-At the

Speaker: NA
Text: outset, I congratulate those honourable members

Speaker: NA
Text: who have made their maiden speeches this

Speaker: NA
Text: evening-my colleague and friend the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Hughes ( Mr Tickner) and the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Richmond ( Mr Blunt)-

Speaker: NA
Text: and I wish them well in the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: In speaking to these Appropriation Bills I

Speaker: NA
Text: should like to devote my brief comments to a sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: ject dear to the hearts of all honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members-education. Perhaps nothing distin-

Speaker: NA
Text: guishes the parties of this chamber more than edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation. There are no blurrings of the edges and

Speaker: NA
Text: there is no consensus. There is a clear cut distincagree

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. Honourable members on the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: side of the House are committed to a fairer, more

Speaker: NA
Text: balanced, more equitable education system, a sys-

Speaker: NA
Text: tem whereby all, regardless of wealth, position or

Speaker: NA
Text: sex, have the opportunity to realise their full

Speaker: NA
Text: potential, an education system that is both

Speaker: NA
Text: rewarding and enriching. Contrast this with the

Speaker: NA
Text: views of our conservative opponents who,

Speaker: NA
Text: through education, want division in society, who

Speaker: NA
Text: want to support elitism with all its inherent conseparents

Speaker: NA
Text: quences. It is interesting that all leading educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tionists, not only in Australia but also throughout

Speaker: NA
Text: the world, reject elitism. But honourable members

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite, who, between them, I doubt hold one

Speaker: NA
Text: educational qualification, these great educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tionists, want elitism. Their education policy, like

Speaker: NA
Text: their other policies, is bankrupt.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have heard a lot from our conservative

Speaker: NA
Text: opponents about the 41 schools on the so-called

Speaker: NA
Text: hit list. Two of these schools are in my electorate

Speaker: NA
Text: of Macarthur-Frensham and Tudor House. I

Speaker: NA
Text: have received letters from many parents whose

Speaker: NA
Text: children attend these schools. Most make the

Speaker: NA
Text: same argument. The schools are not elitist, they

Speaker: NA
Text: tell me, and they, the parents, are not wealthy.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are just ordinary working folk who have

Speaker: NA
Text: saved and made sacrifices to send their children to

Speaker: NA
Text: these schools. On the surface this appears to be a

Speaker: NA
Text: very good argument, but it falls down when I look

Speaker: NA
Text: at the notepaper on which these letters are writ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ten. It is always personalised notepaper, with an

Speaker: NA
Text: embossed name at the top of it. I doubt whether

Speaker: NA
Text: any parents of children at Koonawarra School,

Speaker: NA
Text: Dapto High School, Kiama High School, Nowra

Speaker: NA
Text: High School or Bomaderry High School-also in

Speaker: NA
Text: my electorate-have their own personalised note-

Speaker: NA
Text: paper. This Government's policy in no way inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: feres with the right of any parent to choose a

Speaker: NA
Text: private school. It is the democratic right of all

Speaker: NA
Text: parents to choose the education for their children,

Speaker: NA
Text: and that has never been questioned by the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, freedom of choice is not the same as

Speaker: NA
Text: being allowed an automatic subsidy from public

Speaker: NA
Text: funds. Too many confuse this freedom of choice

Speaker: NA
Text: with a so-called right to a guaranteed portion of

Speaker: NA
Text: public funds. Taxation provides resources which a

Speaker: NA
Text: government uses to implement its decisions. A

Speaker: NA
Text: taxpayer who chooses to employ private security

Speaker: NA
Text: guards does not have the right to have such a

Speaker: NA
Text: choice subsidised, even though part of the tax dol-

Speaker: NA
Text: lar goes towards providing public security forces.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government provides a postal service so that

Speaker: NA
Text: all Australians, regardless of where they live, will

Speaker: NA
Text: have the same standard of service for the same

Speaker: NA
Text: cost. I am sure that honourable members will

Speaker: NA
Text: that any person who chooses to use a private

Speaker: NA
Text: courier service should not expect the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: to pay for it, or would any honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: suggest that a taxpayer who chooses not to use

Speaker: NA
Text: public transport may legitimately claim subsidis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation for his or her private transport from that

Speaker: NA
Text: portion of his or her tax dollar which now subsi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dises public transport?

Speaker: NA
Text: By choosing a private school for their children

Speaker: NA
Text: sending their children to elite private

Speaker: NA
Text: schools are choosing to exclude themselves from a

Speaker: NA
Text: government service. It is their right to do that, but

Speaker: NA
Text: they should not expect a private choice to be paid

Speaker: NA
Text: for from public funds. We hear a lot about par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ental choice in education. I sometimes wonder

Speaker: NA
Text: when we will hear about the children's freedom to

Speaker: NA
Text: choose. Because this Government believes that no

Speaker: NA
Text: child should be educationally disadvantaged by a

Speaker: NA
Text: parental choice, it provides funds to private

Speaker: NA
Text: schools when it is necessary to maintain standards

Speaker: NA
Text: roughly on a par with government system stan-

Speaker: NA
Text: dards. However, some private schools are already

Speaker: NA
Text: operating at a resource level many times above

Speaker: NA
Text: the level of the average government school. There

Speaker: NA
Text: is no reason for public funds to be allocated to

Speaker: NA
Text: those schools.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question resolved in the affirmative.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Leave granted for third reading to be moved

Speaker: NA
Text: forthwith.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill (on motion by Mr Barry Jones) read a

Speaker: NA
Text: third time.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Text: Mallee) (10.55)-1 wish to raise

Speaker: NA
Text: tonight an apparent anomaly in our existing tax-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation regulations. It has come to my attention

Speaker: NA
Text: contact with a number of unemployed young

Speaker: NA
Text: people in my electorate that de facto couples are

Speaker: NA
Text: taxed at a different rate from the rate at which

Speaker: NA
Text: married couples are taxed. I give the House an

Speaker: NA
Text: example of this. At present a married man receiv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the unemployment benefit receives $143.20 a

Speaker: NA
Text: week. He is able to claim his wife as a dependant

Speaker: NA
Text: spouse, with the result that his weekly tax, ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: cording to the latest weekly rates of income tax in-

Speaker: NA
Text: stalments which incorporate the Medicare levy, is

Speaker: NA
Text: $3.70. Presumably that weekly deduction is less if

Speaker: NA
Text: a Medicare levy variation declaration form has

Speaker: NA
Text: Third Reading been completed. If, however, that same man is not

Speaker: NA
Text: married but is living in a de facto relationship, he

Speaker: NA
Text: has to pay a weekly tax of $19.45, the amount he

Speaker: NA
Text: would pay if he were single and earning the same

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of$143.20 a week.

Speaker: NA
Text: A de facto wife, in fact, is not recognised as a

Speaker: NA
Text: dependant as the married wife is. A de facto wife

Speaker: NA
Text: becomes an allowable dependant only if she is

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: caring for a child. Income from the unemploy-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment benefit for a person with one child is $155.20

Speaker: NA
Text: a week and the corresponding weekly tax is $8.45.

Speaker: NA
Text: The weekly tax for a married man with one child

Speaker: NA
Text: is only $3.70. Although the de facto wife is not

Speaker: NA
Text: recognised as a dependant for taxation purposes

Speaker: NA
Text: in that instance, she is recognised as the basis for

Speaker: NA
Text: Third Reading varying the amount of taxation paid when

Speaker: NA
Text: completing the new Medicare levy variation dec-

Speaker: NA
Text: laration form. For example, the form reads: 'Do

Speaker: NA
Text: complete the attached declaration if the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: bined income of you and your spouse, including a

Speaker: NA
Text: de facto spouse, is less than .'. Obviously

Speaker: NA
Text: the Department of Social Security affords a de

Speaker: NA
Text: facto relationship the same status as it affords a

Speaker: NA
Text: marriage. I understand also that a spouse, married

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading or de facto, loses her entitlement to a travel

Speaker: NA
Text: voucher. In all senses then, the de facto wife is

Speaker: NA
Text: treated as a legal wife in those circumstances.

Speaker: NA
Text: I raise this issue tonight not to make any com-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment on the legal position of a de facto relation-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship and its treatement in the assessment of

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit within the social security system or within

Speaker: NA
Text: Third Reading the taxation system. From time to time a number

Speaker: NA
Text: of people in this place, including me, have

Speaker: NA
Text: espoused principles based on their own assess-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments of life styles or the structure that is necess-

Speaker: NA
Text: ary for a satisfactory society, but tonight I only

Speaker: NA
Text: argue that the policies within the social security

Speaker: NA
Text: system and the taxation system should be consist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ent and should ensure that the treatment of

Speaker: NA
Text: Taxation people is uniform.

Speaker: NA
Text: I could well raise other issues in relation to the

Speaker: NA
Text: payment of benefit to de factos or other people

Speaker: NA
Text: within the social welfare system. For example, I

Speaker: NA
Text: could raise another situation that was brought to

Speaker: NA
Text: via my attention today, that of a constituent of mine

Speaker: NA
Text: who advertised for a position. From a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: applicants he selected and appointed a young

Speaker: NA
Text: woman as an accounts clerk-computer operator

Speaker: NA
Text: for his business. After due consideration of the

Speaker: NA
Text: salary that he offered, which was some $280 gross

Speaker: NA
Text: a week, she determined not to accept the position

Speaker: NA
Text: because she considered that as an unmarried

Speaker: NA
Text: mother she was better off on the supporting

Speaker: NA
Text: parent benefit. I point out only that that issue

Speaker: NA
Text: raises a number of questions that relate to moral

Speaker: NA
Text: principles, ones which I do not wish to raise here

Speaker: NA
Text: tonight. However, I have written to the Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Keating) on the issue. I have detailed a par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticular case. I have not called on the Treasurer to-

Speaker: NA
Text: night because I was not aware that I would have

Speaker: NA
Text: the opportunity to speak, but I do ask him to cor-

Speaker: NA
Text: rect what is an obvious anomaly within our tax-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation system. I believe it should be corrected.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question resolved in the affirmative.

Speaker: NA
Text: House adjourned at 10.59 p.m.

Speaker: Mr HOWE
Text: The answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: In December 1983, there were no persons engaged in

Speaker: NA
Text: my Department under the community employment

Speaker: NA
Text: program.

Speaker: NA
